# 上清灵宝大法（宋金尤中）

**The Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Method**

**Scripture Title:** *The Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Method*. Compiled by Jin Youzhong of the Southern Song. One of the comprehensive collections of talismanic and incantatory methods of the Numinous Treasure tradition. Comprising fifty-five sections in forty-four scrolls, with an additional scroll for the preface and table of contents.

**Origin of the Text:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, Orthodox Section, Part One.

---

**General Preface to the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Method**

It is said that before the Ultimate Non-Polarity, all was undifferentiated and unfathomable. At the dawn of primordial chaos, clarity and turbidity first took form. The vault of heaven floated above, vast and boundless through eons; the qi of spontaneity governed the fundamental principles. As Qian revolved and Kun stood firm, the myriad beings were born; as the mechanisms of transformation unfolded, the Five Scripts shone forth. That which germinated in the heavens condensed into clouds and formed talismanic seals. That which descended to the human world was translated into written chapters. It revealed the triggers of virtue and power, and established the ladder to transcendence.

From the Dragon Han era onward, the Great Vehicle was taught. By the Yan Kang era, the Middle Grade was transmitted. Thus, the legacy of the *Dongxuan* (Cavern Mystery) flourished in divine transformations. Later generations applied its methods through purification rites and memorial petitions, yet its regulations, oral instructions, methods, talismans, and sacred texts were scattered across various works. The *Dongxuan* corpus, with its vast array of sections and boundless literary expanse, found its deepest essence distilled in the single scroll of the *Scripture of Salvation*. Within it lay the profound mechanisms of deliverance: inwardly, through refinement and transcendence, one could ascend to the Real and cross over the world; outwardly, through meritorious deeds and completion of tasks, one could bring blessings to the manifest and aid the hidden. Its arcane instructions and numinous sounds were all contained within, though its principles remained obscure, and the world could not fully comprehend them.

From the middle ages onward, the traditions branched into many schools. Master Lu Xiujing of the Song, known as the Simplicity and Tranquility Master, distinguished the sources of the Three Caverns and categorized the Four Supplements, gradually establishing order in the regulations. By the Tang, Master Du Guangting of the Broad Completion lineage compiled the *Yellow Register Purification Rites* in forty scrolls, based on the scriptural injunctions. Thus, the regulations were perfected, the canonical forms fully manifested, spanning antiquity and surpassing the present to become a model for all ages. When the work was completed and revealed, it aligned with the auspicious signs of the numinous heavens, and neither the world nor later generations dared to transgress it.

However, talismans and official documents were not included in the purification rites. Those who propagated the teachings transmitted them to one another. Thus, the talismans, incantations, and instructions from the various scriptures of the Central Cavern were gathered and compiled into a single work, fundamentally rooted in the *Scripture of Salvation*. The scriptures are the foundation of the methods, while the methods are the application of the scriptures. The methods derive from the Numinous Treasure and belong to the *Dongxuan* tradition, hence they are called the *Numinous Treasure Great Method*. Within these scriptures, all that could open the way for the lost souls, benefit and protect the living, talismanic writings, and ritual techniques were comprehensively collected and recorded, forming a radiant and interconnected whole. This allowed those who inherited the methods to practice without undue effort.

In ancient purification rites of the highest grade, their efficacy could silently move heaven, and through visualization and alignment with things, they were not readily practiced by ordinary people. In other purification rites, sincerity and devotion were paramount, with memorial petitions as the primary means. Later generations added official documents and memorials, adapting secular practices to supplement what the written petitions could not fully express. Once the ritual office was established, the registers of the *Dongxuan* corpus were placed at its head. The alignment of method and register served as ranks, enabling communication with the Supreme Mystery and traversing the Three Realms, necessitating the observance of proper forms.

Having established ranks and arranged documents, seals and talismans could not be absent. As for those who attained the Dao and ascended, they received true offices in the celestial realms—such as Xu Jingyang as the Grand Immortal Historian, Liu Kuan as the Supreme Marshal of Youthful Beginnings, the Orthodox Celestial Master receiving the Jade Seal of Lord Lao, and Fei Changfang receiving the talismanic register from Master Hu. These were divine transmissions from the heavenly realms, the so-called true seals and offices of transcendents. In the present age, those who inherit the registers and practice the rites do so through transmission from their masters. They open the gradual path to refinement and the essential road to establishing merit, which does not depend on the complexity of seals or the loftiness of ranks.

In recent times, compilations of the *Numinous Treasure Great Method* have proliferated. Some extend to one hundred and twenty scrolls, seemingly overly detailed, incorporating nearly all the scriptures of the Three Caverns. Wang Shengqing of Futang compiled a version in twenty scrolls, which is more moderate, though it focuses heavily on worldly rites, dividing them into bureaus and offices, and includes preemptive purification rituals without scriptural basis. Such works, while largely sound, contain minor flaws. Others have condensed it into twenty scrolls, which is concise and appropriate, yet those newly initiated into the methods often struggle to grasp their origins. There are also compilations that arrange methods according to the scriptures, adapting the rituals within to practical use—these are truly rooted in the source. However, the world sometimes refers to them as the *Great Method of Salvation* or claims they derive from a separate tradition within the *Numinous Treasure* scriptures.

The transmitted versions in the world are numerous, and not all can be examined. Though they may not fully align with the grand principles of the numinous intent, they are roughly practicable. After the Shaoxing era, in the regions east of the Zhe River, many followed the *Forty-Nine Grades of Tiantai*, failing to understand the original intent behind the earlier compilations. At the outset of their prefaces, they directly stated: "The *Numinous Treasure Great Method* is the foremost of the thirty-six revered scriptures and the root of the nine grades of transcendents and numinous spirits." They claimed that all the compiled words in the methods were uttered by the Celestial Emperor. Yet they did not realize that talismanic memorials, purification rites, altar arrangements, written prohibitions, exorcisms, prayers, and apotropaic rituals were all established after the middle ages in response to circumstances, adapting to the times to assist the primordial transformations and promote the numinous winds. They were not methods originating from antiquity that could not be practiced in later ages.

Nevertheless, by selecting the essential wonders from the scriptures and gathering the talismanic chapters from various canons—some received from extraordinary individuals, others bestowed by transcendents—all that could establish merit and propagate transformation was compiled into the methods of the Middle Vehicle.

Yet these were not the words of the Celestial Emperor from the age of high antiquity. In each narrative passage, however, they would invoke the title "Mysterious Master," thereby displacing the ranks of the Celestial Emperor and styling the Savior from Suffering Heavenly Worthy as the Mysterious Master. They presumed that every word and discourse issued from the Heavenly Worthy, failing to scrutinize carefully—such was the prevailing tendency. Once the original source was lost, the very structure of the teachings grew increasingly distorted. Thus, in their talismans they sought the extraordinary; in their seals and scripts, they multiplied endlessly; in their ritual offices, they pursued the utmost exaltation; and in their practice, they indulged in deception. When transmitting these methods, they would pass down a single volume, copying one another in succession, with masters and disciples scarcely delving deeply, inquiring broadly, questioning, debating, or verifying. Delusion was transmitted as delusion, each mystifying their own doctrines.

Now, the Three Qi of Mysterious Origin—Primordial, Original, and Initial—are the root and origin of the myriad transformations. From the Three Qi, the Two Modes were established; once the Two Modes were fixed, the ten thousand things were born. Humans, endowed with the complete qi of central harmony, thus embody the great form of Heaven and Earth. As their qi and blood move, they intimately align with yin and yang, for the human body is modeled on Heaven and Earth in its generation and completion—not that this body *is* Heaven and Earth. The essence of cultivation lies in the gate of preserving the Three and guarding the One, which is the very foundation of talismanic texts and the dispatch of spirits. By qi uniting with qi and spirit resonating with spirit, one aspires to communion between Heaven and humanity in the realm of the indistinct. Such matters are not for those who lack even a rudimentary understanding of the Dao; the methods only hint at their subtle meaning.

The *Taishan* texts differ in their intent, yet they incorporate the "Flying Mysterious Three Qi Seal" from elsewhere into their rituals to authenticate memorials, as if the seal had a proper origin. This bears no relation to the registers of the *Dongxuan* or the methods of the *Lingbao*. Moreover, they do not realize that if qi can be "flown mysteriously," then the spirit is already ascending—how much less can the subtleties of the Three Qi be confined to a carved seal? Those who practice these methods today often contradict one another: seals share the same name but differ in their script, and some even combine characters from scriptures to form seals—countless variations exist.

A seal is a token of trust, a mark of authentication for official documents, like the seals of officials appointed in the world. Just as every office has its seal, from the sovereign and father to the scholar and commoner, all recognize it as a sign of authority. For instance, in practicing the *Tianxin* Orthodox Methods, the seal of the Bureau of Expelling Demons serves as the mark, for these are the statutes of orthodox practice, staffed by officials of the demon-expelling bureau—thus this seal authenticates its documents. In transmitting the registers of the *Dongxuan* rank, the *Lingbao* serves as the office. The old rituals only mention the Southern Bureau under the Three Heavens' Gates, with the *Lingbao* Great Dharma Office as its bureau, so its seal authenticates its documents—this is the proper insignia of the bureau.

Yet now they have added the "Seal of the Supreme Three Heavens," calling it both "Three Heavens" and "Supreme"—neither a rank of registers nor an office of methods. This is but one of the most glaring violations of principle. Beyond this, seals proliferate in confusion, their multiplicity a waste of misdirected effort. Recently, those who study antiquity have attempted to compile ritual codes and statutes, yet they still incorporate talismanic scripts and seal scripts from the *Tiantai* methods, mingling jade with stone, intertwining the orthodox and the heterodox.

As for ritual offices, since most people have not received true transmission, have not received registers at the ancestral altar, nor sought methods from masters and peers, they treat registers as ranks and methods as offices—practitioners have no choice but to comply. The *Tiantai* methods, however, style themselves as "Heirs Leading the Teaching" or even "Ancestral Masters," further inventing titles like "Jade Steps Immortal Ministers" and "Supreme Perfected Lords of the Great Ultimate" to adorn their credentials, evoking awe and dread.

Yet humans, as creatures, are endowed with pure essence to form this single spirit. As for their humble form, it is but the union of their parents' qi and blood into an embryo. As they grow, the hundred grains and myriad things nourish their bodies, from the subtle to the manifest—nothing but the dust of the earth. Thus, the *Thirty-Nine Poems of Yunfang* states:
*"The four great elements of this body are all yin—*
*I know not what thing is the yang essence."*
Indeed, the five limbs, hundred bones, blood, fluids, flesh, and marrow of humans are all yin in nature. Only the superior adept, refining the original and smelting the root, exhausts yin and purifies yang, becoming as clear as Heaven—this is the rank of immortals. Yet even they must receive registers from grotto-heavens and serve in the offices of immortal bureaus. When they ascend lightly, they must still account for merits and transgressions, tallying their deeds before they can stride upon the clouds and mist, soaring through the celestial vastness. The ranks of immortals are not lightly attained.

Yet in this degenerate age, ordinary mortals—earthbound, impure in substance—wear registers and transmit methods, serving merely as officials of the earthly realm’s teaching offices. They have not penetrated the subtleties of refining the Five Qi and Three Clouds, nor mastered the profound work of the Nine Returns and Seven Reversions. Drifting through the dusty world, their future is unknowable; tossed by the mundane waves, their past lives are obscure. The time of their ascension is distant indeed, yet they hastily claim exalted titles, styling themselves as immortals and perfected beings, using such designations in their credentials—blaspheming Heaven and flouting the Dao. How could "Immortal Ministers" and "Perfected Lords" be offices fit for the earthly realm?

For instance, in the ritual of offering to the Dipper to extend prayers and exorcisms, this is but one affair within the *Lingbao* Great Methods. Among the twenty-four ranks, it is merely called the "Northern Dipper Ritual for Eliminating Disasters." Yet those who practice the *Lingbao* methods in the *Tiantai* tradition, seeking to establish their own lineage and transmit it to others, saw the *Xuanji* registers from the Xuanhe era and thus compiled various doctrines to create the *Xuanji* methods. They established the Mysterious Numinous *Xuanji* Office, appending a postscript to trace their sources. Works like the *Northern Dipper Sutra*, *Pervasive Charts*, and others are listed thereafter. Though the words in their methods derive from these texts, who authorized the creation of this seal?

Holding the title "Director of the *Xuanji* Office," or for those born as commoners, styling oneself "Celestial Inspector of the Supreme Palace"—what does this signify? If there were indeed a *Xuanji* Office, it would be but a palace of the Dipper stars; for a mortal to preside over it would be to rank oneself among the Dipper stars. The office of inspector, unknown in Han or Wei times, later became a court appointment for provincial censors—a role far removed from the methods of the Dao. They fail to understand that one who receives the *Zhengyi* registers and practices the *Tianxin* orthodox methods may freely offer sincere prayers, draft petitions, and perform Dipper rituals—what need is there for further restrictions? Even when advancing to the *Dongxuan* ritual registers, the Northern Dipper rites remain but one affair within the methods; must one invent yet another title before presiding over them?

If every rank of fast or lineage of transmission required a new office, and every grade of ritual demanded a fresh title, then the twenty-seven ranks of ancient fasts and forty-two grades of rituals would necessitate the addition of dozens more official positions before they could be properly conducted. Would this not lead to endless confusion, rendering their offices and titles devoid of canonical basis? In all matters of presiding over fasts and rituals, submitting memorials and petitions, praying for rain or clear skies, delivering the dead and transcending the living, there is nothing that cannot be accomplished—why then establish so many varied titles, proliferating ranks and positions? The registers and ranks of the methods exist to complete the forms; talismans, seals, and script serve to express intent. Yet now, with ranks and titles carried to such extremes, some abandon the canonical compilations and resort to fabrication and deceit.

For instance, at the outset of a fast or ritual, the High Priest grandly displays a proclamation declaring that on a certain day, he silently ascended to the Celestial Court to report the affair—this is nothing short of absurd. The art of preserving form and abiding in the world finds its truest principle in the Golden Elixir alone; this is the proper focus of those who seek immortality. Beyond this, practices such as refining *qi* and ingesting mist, consuming elixirs and medicinal herbs, absorbing light and exhaling breath, or emulating the bear’s stretch and the bird’s reach—though varied—cannot directly achieve the coagulation of lead and mercury or the internal formation of the Golden Elixir. Thus, they are called the "three thousand six hundred minor methods of side doors," of which silent ascent to the Celestial Court is but one.

These methods, which involve the ascent and descent of inner workings to culminate in the Mud Pill Palace, may extend life and ward off illness when practiced correctly, but when misapplied, they risk disturbing the spirit and harming the will. Yet even those who specialize in such practices rarely achieve success in recent times; they are not methods by which one may penetrate heaven and earth to attain true realization. As for the inner flourishing of the fiery jujube, the external severance of yin demons, union with the Dao, the generation of a body beyond the body, the ascent of the spirit to face the Nine Purities, and the far-reaching vision to observe all things—these are the moments in the *Lingbao* methods when one beholds the Sacred Realm of Jade Clarity, where form and spirit are both perfected, cut off from the clamor of the dust, awaiting the appointed time to ascend directly to the Golden Gates. Those who attain this stage do not perform worldly rituals or enter the altar; having beheld the Celestial Perfected in person, they no longer require memorials, documents, or the cadences of ritual chant—this is no mere silent ascent to the Celestial Court.

Now, with altars raised high and mats spread wide, images displayed and rites arranged, documents piled high with copied petitions—these are the proper forms of ritual practice, yet they claim it as "silent ascent to the Celestial Court." To assert that one may present one’s intent directly to heaven is to deceive mortals; can heaven be deceived as well? The compilations are filled with deviations from orthodox principles. These texts emerged at the beginning of the Southern Crossing, nearly a century ago, and their heterodox doctrines have since spread throughout eastern Zhe, growing more entrenched with each passing year. Later students, accustomed to such practices, have come to accept them as normal, corrupting the canonical traditions without end.

The teachings of the Most High are revered without being exalted further, and slighted without being debased; they require no defense of right or refutation of wrong. Yet those who later display their ranks and practice these methods, violating the forms and losing the classics, not only incur guilt before the offices of the Three Officials and Five Emperors but also risk the scorn of future generations. Should discerning scholars arise, they may well echo the lament, "Is there no one left?" To attempt correction might provoke the anger of those who inherit these methods, so they sit idly by as the sacred texts are defiled, daring not to speak a word.

Whenever I observe these obstructions, my spirit trembles with fear. This is not mere speculation or personal conjecture; even a child of three, judging with an impartial heart, would recognize their errors. Fortunately, I have avoided entanglement in these false and deceptive paths and do not acknowledge the misguidance of later generations. I respectfully adhere to the essential teachings of my masters, consulting the established works of various schools to ensure conformity with ancient rites, and have compiled this modest collection. Though it may seem lacking in humility, I believe that to hold a position is to bear its responsibilities. Moreover, having long worn the registers and transmitted the talismans, I have been graced with the protection of the numinous and donned the cap of stars and feathers of transcendence. Though I have only roughly compiled the fundamental methods and do not rank among those directly ordained by the Heavenly Perfected, I have nonetheless been stained by inclusion among the offices of the earthly realm.

Furthermore, as one who bears hair and teeth, endowed with nature and form, every aspect of my being—down to the slightest detail—derives from the primordial *qi* of the Original Ancestor, the gift of August Heaven, the blessing of the Great Dao. How can this not be weighty? To hold a position yet shirk its duties—how can this be permissible? Thus, undeterred by slander, I have roughly assembled these writings. If my words somewhat accord with the canons, I shall share them with my fellow students. If they deviate from the established forms, I hope that those of higher understanding will correct them. Therefore, I briefly outline the beginnings and ends of this matter at the start of the scroll.

I dare not deliberately advance perilous arguments to elevate myself at others’ expense. My aim is merely to lightly revise the later additions, largely adhering to the old rules, aligning with reason and rooted in sources, without disdaining the commonplace. What strays from the canons and lacks foundation is not prized for its novelty. Just as Lu Xiujing distinguished the Three Caverns and Four Supplements, and Du Guangting established the classics and fixed the forms, I now make this account public to settle the methods. Thus, "those who speak shall bear no fault, and those who hear shall take heed."

Yet I, Yunzhong, have observed that compilers of liturgical manuals in recent times invariably conceal their essential techniques. Even those who serve as preceptors, though they themselves have gained no true attainment, still withhold and obscure texts that ought not be restricted. Some go so far as to alter ancient scriptures, excise established methods, and render them incomplete—all to parade novelty and peddle secrets, luring disciples to seek transmission from them. This is not confined to the Ritual Methods of the Numinous Treasure alone; all liturgical manuals suffer the same fate. The world has grown so shallow and dissolute as to reach this extremity.

To be sure, the subtle mechanisms and wondrous insights that enable one to ascend lightly and soar aloft ought not be openly recorded and widely disseminated. But methods for delivering the world, establishing merit, aiding others, and benefiting all beings—how can these be omitted entirely? Though I, Yunzhong, have not yet heard the teachings for transcending the world or the secrets of ascent, I have fortunately developed some discernment between orthodoxy and heterodoxy in the practices now current. In compiling this work, I take the commodification of the Dao as a grave warning and dare not deliberately conceal or omit anything. The cultivation, visualization, functions, and salvation rituals of the Numinous Treasure are all set forth in full. Nothing of substance is missing; every principle is grounded and attested, not a single detail omitted. Yet accounts of the bizarre and baseless, though detailed, are not included. Where meanings form a continuum, they are not split across two scrolls. Where methods are interdependent, they are not sundered. Scattered passages in old books are gathered and arranged in order. Matters touching on other texts are examined and explained. The annotations are organized by topic, all verifiable in practice. Even the most stringent precepts and prohibitions within the methods—those never before committed to writing—are now fully preserved in their proper categories.

Once this book is completed, I shall present it to the Supreme Mystery, announcing it to the Three Realms. Before Heaven, I shall vow to propagate the Perfect Teaching far and wide. Scholars of the Dao ought to broaden their knowledge and experience. Nowadays, in famous mountains and blessed lands, in remote regions and secluded valleys, in forests and springs, even amidst the dust of the marketplace, men of the Dao surely exist. The pity is that they cannot widely visit and study under many masters to distinguish true immortals. Yet they must at least gain some understanding of the various schools current today. Among both householders and renunciates who inherit and transmit the Numinous Treasure, how many lineages of the Numinous Treasure now remain? Only then can one examine the orthodoxy or heterodoxy, depth or shallowness of one’s own attainment. If one clings solely to the first teachings one received and rejects all others, sitting at the bottom of a well yet discoursing on the heavens, one is no true devotee of the Teaching.

May scholars further calm their minds and scrutinize the origins of things, lest they daily drift further onto paths of deviation and betrayal of the Dao. This is my, Yunzhong’s, deepest wish.

I, Yunzhong, have received transmission from three preceptors in the scriptural lineage, all of the Central Plains tradition. Their names are recorded at the end of this scroll. I do not presume to advance my own views to deceive the world. Rather, since the essential instructions of my teachers were mostly transmitted orally and committed to memory, I feared that with the passage of time they would be lost. Thus, I have arranged the ancient texts in order, concealing the transmission only lightly within them, all for the sake of the Teaching.

Preface by Jin Yunzhong, Disciple of the Numinous Treasure of the Cavern Mystery, Right Assistant Administrator of the Bureau of Ritual Execution, Office of the Southern Archives.

*Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure of the Cavern Mystery, Scroll One*
Compiled and Annotated by Jin Yunzhong, Master of the Numinous Treasure of the Cavern Mystery, Right Assistant Administrator of the Bureau of Ritual Execution, Office of the Southern Archives

**Section on the Precepts of this Method: The Ten Precepts**

**The Ten Precepts**

1. Maintain an impartial mind; do not deceive yourself.
2. Serve your lord and teachers with loyalty; honor and revere Heaven and Earth, father and mother.
3. Extend kindness and benevolence to all things; practice frugality and moderation in life.
4. Maintain purity and uprightness; do not form cliques or factions.
5. Reverently follow the supreme Daoist methods; deeply believe in cultivating the self.
6. Respect ghosts and spirits; do not treat them with contempt.
7. All clothing and food derive from the primordial qi of the Original Beginning; do not entertain extraneous thoughts.
8. Use ash-water to cleanse impurities; do not indulge in adornment.
9. Recite with the mouth and bow with the heart; do not exhaust the body.
10. After seven days of profound stillness, the radiance of spirit will become serene, and the sacred realm of Jade Clarity will be revealed.

**The Twelve Virtues**
Do not kill, do not harm, do not envy, do not covet, do not engage in licentiousness, do not steal, do not be greedy, do not be desirous, do not hate, do not slander, do not speak with florid embellishment, do not utter harsh words.

Yunzhong once reflected: What should those who adorn themselves with careful conduct strive for? Only by devoting oneself to upholding the Daoist methods and performing the rituals can one then transform virtue and distance oneself from transgression. The Dao of immortal cultivation does not merely consist of exhausting worldly practices. To attain inner integrity and outer purity, with clarity within and without, is the first step on the ladder of the Daoist methods. Even the loftiest perfected beings and supreme sages still accumulate merit through fasting and abstinence. Thus, precepts and disciplines serve to cultivate virtue and restrain the body and mind—this is the foremost duty of the student.

The methods by which the sages governed the world invariably began with cultivating the self and ordering the household, and only then could they govern the state and bring peace to the world. All things proceed from within to without. If the precepts of this method are placed first, yet one fails to practice them, the self loses its rectitude. Then, at home, one cannot properly guide one’s wife and children; abroad, one cannot gain the trust of friends. How, then, can one face the Supreme Emperor and commune with the divine?

The precepts and disciplines of the Daoist canon are scattered throughout the scriptures and edicts, with numerous clauses and items. It would be impractical to record them all here. The precepts of the Numinous Treasure method are to be integrated with the scriptures as they appear.

Regarding the Twelve Virtues, one version omits "do not speak with florid embellishment" and "do not utter harsh words," using "do not kill" and "do not harm" as the Ten Precepts. Another older version includes annotations beneath each clause. However, these twelve matters were originally established for those cultivating the Daoist methods. If one adheres strictly to their true meaning and acts accordingly, what harm is there? There is no need for exhaustive explanations. If interpretations stray slightly from the original intent, they may instead mislead later generations. Thus, I have now removed them, preserving only the original text.

---

**Seven Interconnected Matters**

1. Clarifying how the primordial qi of the Original Beginning first transformed into the Jade Script before giving rise to the myriad things.
2. Clarifying how the generation and nurturing of the primordial chaos shaped and refined the myriad things.
3. Clarifying how the Numinous Treasure naturally gave form to the sacred texts, encompassing all phenomena and serving as the pivotal mechanism of the Three Powers.
4. Clarifying how the Numinous Treasure is the ancestral teaching of the Three Caverns, giving birth to all sages.
5. Clarifying how the human body models itself after the Original Beginning, establishing the primordial chaos and the sacred embryo of the dharma-body.
6. Clarifying how, before the formless primordial qi of the Original Beginning took shape, what analogy could describe it? When it descended and congealed into qi, it transformed and gave birth to the myriad treasures. What form does it take in the present world? How can one refine this qi into an elixir and consume it to ascend as a perfected being?
7. Clarifying how attaining the Dao of the Numinous Treasure enables one to ascend at dawn in broad daylight, or to attain long life and transcend the world, or to achieve liberation through the corpse, among the myriad methods fully expounded in the scriptures.

Yunzhong carefully examined these matters: Though the Numinous Treasure is considered a middle vehicle of the Dao, it in fact encompasses the Three Caverns and contains all methods. It establishes the root and clarifies the source—students should understand its beginning and end.

Before the Dao took form, prior to Heaven and Earth, the natural ancestral qi initiated the birth of the myriad beings. When this qi coalesced into patterns and condensed into clouds as script, the sacred texts emerged. From this, teachings were established, disciplines were transmitted, and beings were delivered and guided—all through the application of the Daoist methods.

Yet the methods arise from the scriptures, and the scriptures contain the wondrous subtleties of the Dao. How could they be confined merely to the practices of fasting, cultivation, prohibitions, and incantations? If one can deeply penetrate the mysterious mechanism and glimpse the numinous mysteries, one must use the methods to understand the scriptures, and through the scriptures, awaken to the Dao. To comprehend the Dao within the Dao is to transcend the Three Realms and the Six Extremes.

Our singular spirit is not inherently deluded. Our singular qi naturally aligns with the true Dao. Yet in later generations, reckless and deceitful individuals have propagated absurd and baseless theories, making them unfathomable. They fabricate countless deceptions, confusing and misleading the world, drowning their own authenticity and destroying their own nature. How lamentable!

Thus, I have begun with the precepts to open the path, followed by clarifying the Seven Matters to first understand the essence and function of the scriptures. Only then can one examine the intent behind the Four Translations and the composition of the texts—this is the gateway to the methods. Such is the sequence of compiling the scriptures and methods in this work.

---

**The Four Translations of the Scriptures**

1. The Jade Script emerged before the void, and the divine script lay hidden within the primordial chaos. When the Crimson Clarity revealed the diagram, the Original Beginning proclaimed and expounded the secret names. This is the First Translation, known as the Great Brahma Jade Script.
2. The Dao Lord inscribed the secret names of the Jade Script, and the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign recorded its text. This is the Second Translation, called the Script of the Eight Assemblies of the Various Heavens.
3. The Dao Lord compiled and arranged the Numinous Treasure scriptures into the *Complete Scriptures*. This is the Third Translation, known as the *Luminous Chapters of Cloud-Script*.
   The Queen Mother of the West transmitted the Five Numinous Treasure Talismans to the Yellow Emperor, and the Dragon Might Master bestowed them upon Great Yu—both are contained within the scriptures. However, as the original text of the scriptures remained unchanged, these are not considered translations.
   When the Yellow Emperor sought the Dao on Mount Emei, he personally met the Sovereign and received direct instruction. When the Supreme Perfected transmitted the Dao to the Left Immortal Elder, this was also not a translation of scriptures, and thus is not referred to as such.
4. On the fifteenth day of the seventh month in the first year of the Yuanfeng era of the Han dynasty, the Queen Mother of the West transmitted these scriptures to Emperor Wu of Han. As the emperor did not understand the language of the Great Brahma, he altered the celestial script of the Jade Script into the common script of the world. This is the Fourth Translation.

Having carefully examined the *Scripture of Salvation for the Multitudes* (*Lingbao Duren Jing*), all ancient records of its transmission consistently affirm that the text was established through four translations, a principle so evident that it admits no arbitrary conjecture or speculative interpretation.

Before the Void, there was neither light nor form. After the Era of Vermilion Clarity, the Jade Script first manifested—this is the First Translation. The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign transcribed it into the Correct Sound—this is the Second Translation. The Lord of the Dao compiled and arranged it into scripture—this is the Third Translation. The Queen Mother of the West transmitted it to Emperor Wu of Han, who then rendered it into the common script of the world—this is the Fourth Translation. From this point onward, the scripture was transmitted among mortals without further additions or omissions.

Yet the Tiantai school presents an independent claim, asserting in the seventeenth fascicle of its *Canonical Regulations and Ritual Standards* that there exists a fifth translation. It falsely attributes the compilation of talismanic diagrams to the Perfected of Wondrous Conduct within the Registers of the Central Alliance, and further misrepresents the *Three Caverns Scriptures* of the Perfected of Wondrous Conduct as the *Great Dharma of the Numinous Treasure*. Such assertions are groundless.

When the Supreme Perfected Xu Laile transmitted the Dao of the Numinous Treasure to Master Ge, it was akin to the Celestial Master transmitting the Orthodox Unity teachings, or the Three Mao and Two Xu receiving the lineage of the Cavern of Perfection. These were the patriarchs of the Three Caverns’ transmission of the Dao—not a fifth translation of the *Scripture of Salvation for the Multitudes*.

Moreover, the meaning of "translation" denotes the conveyance of one language into another. It involves interpreting the words of one text to form the characters of another, much as an interpreter discerns the sounds of the four directions. If the *Scripture of Salvation for the Multitudes* had no fifth translation after its descent into the world, how could one willingly embrace such a fabricated theory? Thus, I rely solely on ancient records in compiling this account.

---

**Preface to the Fascicles of the Scripture**

Burying gold and jade to stabilize the Five Peaks, casting dragon tablets and jade discs into the abyssal seas, and forging the Nine Tripods to secure the Nine Provinces—these three practices exemplify the methods by which emperors and kings cultivate the Dao to pacify and perpetuate the mandate of their realms.

When the cycles of heaven and earth reach their end, the stellar lodges fall into disarray, the sun and moon lose their proper times of rising and setting, the four seasons deviate from their courses, and yin and yang fall out of harmony—these five conditions illustrate the means to dissolve celestial calamities.

Curing illness refers to using the scriptural methods to restore harmony and well-being. Dispelling poison and harm means averting and exorcising the baleful qi of the celestial divisions and their corresponding terrestrial punishments. Liberating the corpse denotes the Nine Refinements method for ascension—these three practices exemplify the means to ward off poison and harm in the lower realm.

Ascending to the Vermilion Palace, soaring to the Golden Towers, flying to the Southern Palace, feasting in the Jade Capital, roaming the Great Void, crossing to the Southern Palace above, ascending to the Upper Clarity, wandering freely in the Upper Clarity, advancing through the ranks of the Southern Palace, ascending into the Great Void, guiding the soul through the Vermilion Mound, and traversing the Three Realms—these thirteen practices exemplify the methods of ascension and liberation.

All attain longevity, preserve their allotted years, transcend the world, evade death, prosper their households, enable their ancestors to receive liberation, swiftly attain immortality, extend their lifespans, undergo corpse liberation, become Perfected of the Nine Palaces, ensure national peace, ascend to the rank of Immortal Elder, command the respect of demon kings, refine their forms in the Great Yin, become ministers of the Golden Towers to the Sage Lord, receive the homage of the myriad spirits, and gain the protection and sponsorship of demon kings—these seventeen outcomes exemplify the responses to meritorious deeds.

Presenting gold and treasures as pledges of sincerity and swearing oaths before the Ten Heavens—this one practice exemplifies the method of transmission.

---

**Note by Yunzhong:** Ancient records describe the transmission of the scripture through the offering of gold and treasures as pledges of sincerity and oaths sworn before Heaven, as well as the rule that it be transmitted only once every forty thousand kalpas, with oaths sworn before the Ten Heavens. These were originally divided into three separate entries. However, in the scripture’s preface, it is stated that the treasures of the upper heavens are not transmitted to the lower world, and that those who receive the transmission must offer gold and treasures as pledges of sincerity and swear oaths before Heaven—this refers to the proper procedure for receiving the transmission. Within the scripture itself, it is stated that according to the Mysterious Regulations, the text is transmitted only once every forty thousand kalpas. If a worthy individual presents gold and treasures as pledges of sincerity and follows the ancient protocols to swear oaths before the Ten Heavens, only then is the transmission granted. This precisely describes the formal procedure for transmission and should not be listed separately. Thus, only one entry is retained here.

---

Bringing calamity upon oneself, extending misfortune to nine generations of ancestors, and for revealing secrets or showing contempt—falling into hell: these three outcomes exemplify the consequences of transgression.

Within the scripture, the Great Dao is revealed as the Mother of the primordial qi, the secret names of the roots of existence, the wonders of the Jade Maidens of the Mysterious Perfection, and the ritual implements, music, forms, names, measurements, and the Dao of the Five Constants. These were all prepared in the Primordial Heaven, and the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign followed their inherent patterns.

In the Middle Antiquity, teachings for governing the world were composed, and the Great Dao thereby became concealed. Its origins in the Primordial Heaven were no longer known. The sixty-four sentences of esoteric Brahmanic speech within the scripture emerged prior to the opening of the Great Brahman’s diagrams, at the very inception of numerical reckoning. The cycles of inhalation and exhalation harmonize with yin and yang, and the count of breaths manifests in the pulse. Thus, one exhalation measures three inches, and one inhalation measures three inches. Extending this principle to greater lengths, inches accumulate into feet, and feet manifest in physical objects. From this arose the standards of pitch pipes, calendars, measurements, weights, the Five Planets, the Seven Governors, the Eight Trigrams, the Nine Palaces, and the Twenty-Four Solar Terms. The sages took these as their models, crafting instruments based on the length of a foot or the width of a finger.

The scripture encompasses all methods: the inner and outer elixirs, celestial divination, prohibitions, auspicious and inauspicious omens, techniques for divining the past and future, delivering the hidden and elevating the manifest, summoning the Perfected and invoking the numinous, blessing the nation and pacifying households, fostering prosperity and abundance, stabilizing and exorcising, repenting and petitioning—nothing is left unaddressed. The Western Numinous Tortoise Mother translated it into the common script and transmitted it to Emperor Wu of Han, which is why many elements in the scripture follow Han conventions.

Upon close examination, the *Great Dharma of the Numinous Treasure* comprehensively records its profound mysteries and systematically presents its regulations. Its categories and examples do not depart from the scripture. Every method and every secret resides within the scripture. Here, I briefly outline its general principles as the foundation for the exposition of its teachings.

The passage following the preface summarizes the essence and function of the scripture. The Tiantai school merely embellished its language, fabricating the "Secret Instructions of the Patriarchs" as the forty-ninth fascicle.

They, failing to deeply examine the principles and broadly survey the various compilations, presumptuously claimed the title of "Secret Instructions of the Patriarchs"—yet these were merely narrative passages, not the practical methods of application. Such individuals, lacking extensive reading, mistakenly regarded their work as rare and arcane. Here, I adhere strictly to the scripture in composing the preface and examples, refraining from fabricating "secret instructions" to deceive others. Scholars who grasp the general outline of the scripture through this may then advance to its practical application—this, too, is but the natural sequence of study.

**Section on Chaptered Exegesis and Application**
*The Supreme Numinous Treasure Wondrous Scripture of the Uppermost Rank for the Limitless Deliverance of Humankind*
*First Chapter: Account of the Mysterious*

The Dao spoke: "At *you* (酉), these two characters govern sudden darkness at death." Long ago, in the Azure Heaven of Primordial Green, within the Jade Prosperity Ascendant Heaven, the Celestial Void resounded with hymns. The Great Floating Li Emperor—whose name is concealed in hidden language—received the *Supreme Numinous Treasure Wondrous Scripture of the Uppermost Rank for the Limitless Deliverance of Humankind* from the Primordial Beginning.

**Chapter Two: Initiating the Cycle**
When the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning was to expound this scripture, he circumambulated ten times to summon the ten directions. "Was to expound" signifies the opening of this kalpic cycle, the revelation of the chart, and the emergence of the teaching.

**Chapter Three: True Responses**
From the realm of the Great Cavern downward, all worlds were naturally aligned. As he was about to ascend the throne, from *zi* (子) to *wu* (午), one was to pluck a hair and inscribe it with the *Catalyzing Birth and Pacifying Fetus Scripture* for ingestion. The Heavenly Perfected, Supreme Sages, and Exalted Worthies—those of wondrous conduct—folded the upper joint of their middle fingers to inscribe, thereby repelling malevolent spirits. An innumerable host arrived upon the void, riding vermilion clouds through the cinnabar firmament, their jade-green chariots and wheel-borne palanquins shaded by feathered canopies. At *hai* (亥), the flowing essence and jadelike radiance—nine hues in all—governed the kidney’s spherical symbol and cured dream-induced intercourse. Five-colored vapors billowed forth. At *you* (酉), one inscribed and ingested for scant qi. The Great Void shone with resplendent brilliance.

**Chapter Four: Establishing the Ultimate**
For seven days and nights, the sun, moon, stars, and constellations of all heavens—along with the jade celestial pivot—halted their revolutions. Divine winds stilled, and mountains and seas concealed their clouds. At *zi* (子), one swiftly ingested to regulate qi. The heavens were free of drifting haze, and the four qi shone with clarity. From the seventh day downward, this cured eye ailments and other illnesses; one inscribed, burned, and stamped the ashes for ingestion. The land, mountains, rivers, forests, and trees of the entire nation were leveled as one, without distinction of high or low. The earth transformed into azure jade, uniform in hue, as the host of Perfected attended the throne. The middle joint of the middle finger was used for pacifying dwellings and groundbreaking, and for consecrating earth in incantations.

**Chapter Five: Returning to the Origin**
The origin arose from the generative numbers of the Five Phases and stood upon their consummate numbers. The Mysterious Throne was the seat of the Dharmakāya. The Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning sat upon the void, floating above five-colored lions. At *wu* (午), one ingested to cure heart vexation, heart ailments, and malaria. When the scripture was expounded once through the element of water, the Great Sages of all heavens simultaneously voiced their approval. At that moment, the deaf throughout the nation regained their hearing. When expounded twice through fire, the blind regained their sight. When expounded thrice through wood, the mute could speak. When expounded four times through metal, the lame, paralyzed, and chronically ill all rose and walked. When expounded five times through earth, those afflicted with long-standing ailments instantly regained their forms. When expounded six times through water, white hair turned black again, and fallen teeth regrew. When expounded seven times through fire, the aged reverted to youth, and the young grew robust. When expounded eight times through wood, pregnant women, birds, and beasts—whether their offspring were born or unborn—all achieved perfect birth. When expounded nine times through metal, the earth’s treasuries were revealed, and gold and jade emerged. When expounded ten times, withered bones revived and rose as living beings. At that time, every man and woman in the nation turned their hearts in devotion, all received protection and deliverance, and each attained longevity. Those who practiced this Dao achieved immortality and deathlessness.

**Chapter Six: Profound Mystery**
The Dao spoke: At that time, the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning, at *qian* (乾), first summoned the Boundless Ones of the ten directions before focusing intention. When the scripture was expounded once, the Boundless, Limitless, and Utmost Perfected Great Spirits of the East, along with their innumerable host, arrived upon the void. When expounded twice, those of the South arrived in like manner. When expounded thrice, those of the West arrived. When expounded four times, those of the North arrived. When expounded five times, those of the Northeast arrived. When expounded six times, those of the Southeast arrived. When expounded seven times, those of the Southwest arrived. When expounded eight times, those of the Northwest arrived. When expounded nine times, those of the Upper Realm arrived. When expounded ten times, those of the Lower Realm arrived. After ten complete circumambulations, the Heavenly Perfected and Great Spirits of the Boundless Ten Directions arrived simultaneously. The men and women of the nation turned their hearts in devotion, their arrival like fine rain or dense mist. The innumerable host pressed so closely that half the land of the nation sank unevenly, beyond all restraint.

Thereupon, the Primordial Beginning suspended a single treasure pearl, as large as a grain of millet—vermilion millet, to be precise. After reciting the *Great Brahmā Hidden Language* forty-nine times and offering prayers, one ingested a single grain to cure all suffering. One visualized the host of Perfected entering the pearl, at *gen* (艮). The pearl hung in the void, five *zhang* above the earth. This was the method of entering the pearl’s millet-grain interior. The Heavenly Perfected, Supreme Sages, Exalted Worthies, and those of wondrous conduct—along with the Utmost Perfected Great Spirits of the Boundless Ten Directions and their innumerable host—all entered the treasure pearl. The celestial beings gazed upward, seeing only a shimmering radiance entering the pearl’s mouth. Once inside, their whereabouts became unknown. The people of the nation dispersed, and the land returned to levelness, no longer uneven or sunken. When the nation’s land had sunk unevenly, the treasure pearl remained suspended. Once all had entered its mouth, the land returned to levelness.

Within the treasure pearl, the Primordial Beginning completed the exposition of the scripture in full. The host of Perfected oversaw the deliverance, receiving it unto themselves. At that moment, joy and celebration were beyond words. *Zao Xian* was the inner taboo name. The ritual matters being roughly concluded, the deities of all heavens returned to their positions. In an instant, all was silent, without lingering resonance.

At that time, the heavenly and mortal beings who encountered the scriptural Dharma were universally delivered and saved, preserving their full lifespans without harm or injury, and the entire land turned in reverence. First, their hearts inclined in devotion; afterward, their reverence deepened. All cultivated hearts of goodness. This entailed the recitation of the Great Peace Incantation, conveying the intent of oaths, expiations, harmony, and unity: no killing, no harm, no envy, no jealousy, no licentiousness, no theft, no greed, no desire, no hatred, no resentment, no florid speech, no harsh words, equal and shared compassion, transforming strangers into kin, bringing national stability and people’s prosperity, and rejoicing in Great Peace. Only by practicing the twelve virtuous deeds above does one align with the Dao of equal and shared compassion, transforming strangers into kin.

**Chapter Seven: The Sanskrit Stanzas Unfolded**
When the scripture first emerged as teaching, the entire nation, having cultivated utmost sincerity, revered and honored it, and all attained deliverance across the world. The four characters "revered and honored" signify that practicing even one of these ensures deliverance.

**Chapter Eight: The Proclamation of Secrets**
The Dao declares: All that the Primordial Heavenly Worthy expounds within the scripture are the inner names and hidden rhymes of the myriad heavens’ Supreme Emperors, as well as the inner taboo names of demon kings and the concealed appellations of the hundred spirits—these are not ordinary words of the mundane world.

**Chapter Nine: The Perfected Sage**
This is the responsive merit and virtue of the Primordial Heavenly Worthy. Once the Perfected Sage has attained completion, the Realized One penetrates the profound and investigates the subtle, fully mastering its chapters. Reciting it ten times, the hosts of heavens intone in unison, and the ten thousand emperors offer rites. The heavens chant from afar, and the ten thousand emperors offer rites—thus it is called *The Scripture of the Great Cavern*. Rivers and seas fall silent, mountains and peaks conceal their clouds, the sun and moon pause their radiance, the celestial pivots cease their turning, all demons bind their forms, ghostly spirits lose their clarity, the dead return to life, and white bones become human once more.

The following on the sun and moon is an empty dharma: in samādhi, one may perceive all ghostly beings devoid of the Dao, and upon seeing their forms or hearing them, they vanish. If one’s merit is not yet perfected, they cannot be subdued. Without the power of samādhi, one may employ the later Cavern Vision method.

**Chapter Ten: The Ultimate Study**
Scholars of the ultimate study who recite it ten times will have the Five Emperors attend and guard them, the Three Realms bow in reverence, demonic spirits lose their sight, ghostly and demonic beings lose their clarity, and those on the verge of death are delivered, cut off from death and restored to life. The reason for this is that scholars’ defiled qi has not yet dissipated, and their bodies have not yet penetrated the true. Though they summon and command the ten directions, their majesty does not yet govern the celestial administration, and their virtue can only subdue earthly deities, bind demonic spirits, and avert death—but cannot restore life.

**Chapter Eleven: Exhortation to the Dao**
To recite this chapter lightly brings calamity upon oneself; to offer reverent devotion brings prosperity to one’s household, flourishing through the generations, forming good karmic affinities, warding off ten thousand disasters, and having divine beings guard one’s gate.

**Chapter Twelve: In Praise of the Mysterious**
The Venerable and Wondrous One strides alone above the Jade Capital—thus it is called *The Wondrous Scripture of the Great Cavern*. This scripture is venerable and wondrous, striding alone above the Jade Capital. It delivers boundless beings and is the root of the ten thousand Dao. Vast and majestic is the Great Brahmā, its virtue beyond measure. Above the Great Luo Heaven is the Jade Capital Mountain and the Purple Tenuity Supreme Palace, containing thirty-six Jade Capital Halls, each spanning a hundred thousand *li* in height and breadth, with eaves extending fifty-five thousand *li*.

**Chapter Thirteen: Cultivation and Recitation**
The Dao declares: Whoever recites this scripture ten times will have all the heavens assemble, and the suffering souls of their ancestors across billions of generations will immediately receive deliverance, ascending to the Vermilion Palace. After nine years of refinement, they undergo transformation and rebirth, becoming noble persons. Those who diligently study the ultimate scripture, fulfilling their merit and perfecting their virtue, all attain transcendence as immortals, ascending to the Golden Gates and roaming the Jade Capital in feasting. The merit of those who study diligently surpasses that of mere reciters.

**Chapter Fourteen: The Superior Study**
Scholars of the superior study who cultivate and recite this scripture will immediately receive deliverance and ascend to the Southern Palace. Those in the world who recite it extend their years and longevity, and afterward all attain the Dao of liberation through simulated death. Their ethereal souls temporarily vanish, avoiding the underworld, and they swiftly regain their forms, roaming the great void.

**Chapter Fifteen: The Unfolding of the Subtle**
This scripture is subtle and wondrous, universally delivering the boundless. All heavenly and mortal beings receive its blessings, and immeasurable fortune extends to the living and the dead. There are regulations and standards.

**Chapter Sixteen: The Covenant of Efficacy**

**Chapter Seventeen: The Mysterious Register**
Those who study deeply yet lightly divulge its secrets bring calamity upon their primordial ancestors. The world’s people must not transmit it; the prohibition against careless leakage is absolute—how could this be the only concern? When treasured and kept secret, its merits equal those of a hundred million generations. What heaven cherishes is not passed down to the lower world. Only the most devoted present gold and treasures, pledging their hearts in covenant with heaven before transmission. Those who lightly divulge or treat it with negligence bring misfortune upon nine generations of ancestors, condemning them to long servitude in the ghostly palaces. Previously, those who recited it carelessly brought disaster upon their descendants, for their leakage and disdain implicated their forebears.

The **Mysterious Register Chapter** states: The nine palaces and twenty-four *qi* spirits all reside within the body. Attending the scripture are the Five Emperors, jade lads and jade maidens—twenty-four each—who guard the divine writ inscribed upon the middle joint of the middle finger, protecting the body of the scripture’s recipient. First, wear the talisman and incantation; second, circulate the *qi* channels. Swallowing the four characters of the *yingwei* divine writ yields immediate efficacy. The Five Emperors, jade lads, and jade maidens—twenty-four each, totaling two hundred and forty—accompany the Emperor in procession.

**Chapter Eighteen: The Three Primes**
The Dao declares: In the first month, observe a prolonged fast and recite this scripture to sever the earthly bonds of past generations’ wandering souls, delivering them to the Southern Palace. In the seventh month, observe a prolonged fast and recite this scripture to attain divine transcendence; the names of the worthy are inscribed in the heavens on yellow registers and white tablets, erasing death and ascending to life. In the tenth month, observe a prolonged fast and recite this scripture for kings, emperors, lords, ministers, fathers, and sons, to stabilize the nation’s destiny, preserve heaven’s enduring existence, ensure unbroken succession, and secure eternal rulership. Those who recite it on the eight seasonal nodes become Perfected of the Nine Palaces. Don the nine, tread the one; three on the left, seven on the right; two and four as shoulders, six and eight as feet; five resides in the central palace, forming the solid core—this is the *huoluo* Dipper. On one’s life-destiny day, recite this scripture to purify the ethereal soul, perpetuate the myriad *qi*, avoid suffering and affliction, and radiate bodily light. The Three Realms attend in guard, the Five Emperors oversee the reception, and ten thousand spirits pay homage. Names are inscribed in heaven; when merit is fulfilled and virtue perfected, one ascends to the Great Clarity. The upper joint of the middle finger is the abode of the settled heart-spirit, the Central Capital of the Great Clarity.

According to the *Scripture of the Dragon’s Leap*: Above the Four Brahmā Heavens lie the Three Clarities. First, the Twelve Heavens of the Great Clarity, dwelling of the Nine Immortals. Next, the Twelve Heavens of the Great Clarity, governed by the Nine Perfected. Then, the Twelve Heavens of the Jade Clarity, dwelling of the Nine Sages. Together, thirty-six heavens, with the Jade Clarity as the highest.

**Chapter Nineteen: The Practice of the Dao**
Whenever reciting scriptures, performing the Dao, or enacting rituals, each must adhere to the prescribed visualization, transmitted orally and received in the heart, recited with the mouth and worshipped in the heart. All proceed from the *gen* direction to the point beneath the thumbnail where the hair is parted.

The Dao declares: On the day of practice, bathe in fragrant waters, observe purification rites, and enter the chamber. Face east, knock the teeth thirty-two times to ascend to the thirty-two heavens; bow in the heart thirty-two times. Close the eyes and silently envision the body seated amidst clouds of cyan, yellow, and white *qi*, inwardly and outwardly shrouded in mist. The Four Sagely Generals—Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, and Dark Warrior—stand guard. Lions and white cranes array to left and right; sun and moon illuminate the chamber, its interior resplendent. A circular image arises from the nape, its light suffusing the ten directions.

The Three *Qi*: Mysterious *qi* is cyan, primordial *qi* is yellow, and initial *qi* is white. These Three *Qi* all arise from the One *Qi*. Now abiding within the Three *Qi* signifies the practitioner’s contemplation of the Three and preservation of the One—this is the mother of *qi*, the true and constant Dao.

When this is vividly clear, recite the secret incantation:
*"Supreme Mysterious Origin, Most High Dao Lord, summon forth from within this servant’s body the Three and Five Merit Officers, the left and right attending envoys, the incense-bearing Golden Lad, the message-transmitting Jade Maiden, the Five Emperors’ direct talismans, and the incense officials of the day—thirty-two each. Entrust them with the incantation of the day to convey the following: Today is an auspicious occasion, a prolonged fast in the pure hall, the cultivation of this supreme scripture for the immeasurable deliverance of beings. This servant and [name], together reciting this scripture, seek the Dao of longevity."*

If reciting alone, face the direction of Wood Virtue, toward the sunrise, to draw in the cyan, yellow, and white *qi*, then recite: *"This servant and [name]..."*

The *Inner Chapters of the Great Cavern*’s *Principles of Cyclical Wind and Fusion* state: In the Palace of Fusang in the east lies the *ruo* tree. When the sun first rises, the *ruo* tree radiates light, and the cyan, yellow, and white *qi* billow atop its crown. The immortals in the palace recite scriptures and practice the Dao at this time to honor the Emperor’s virtue. Thus, when reciting this scripture, one should face the *jia-yi* direction—*jia-yi* being the east, hence the scripture’s injunction to recite facing east.

Recite the scripture to receive rebirth. May the prayers ascend directly to the presence of the Most High, the August and Venerable Primordial Sovereign of the Thirty-Two Heavens. Draw in the breath thirty-two times, then recite the scripture facing east—the direction of longevity, revered by all heavens.

The oral instructions for inscribing talismans in the *Great Cavern* prescribe facing east during the tenth month for Daoist practice.

When the four seasons lose their proper order and yin and yang fall out of harmony, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scriptures. When pestilential toxins spread and the multitudes suffer death and injury, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scriptures. When teachers and companions pass from this life, one should perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scriptures. The merit of purification rites and scripture recitation is most weighty: above, it dissolves heavenly calamities and preserves the Thearch; below, it wards off poisonous harm and delivers the multitudes.
