The Heavenly Perfected August Person of old transcribed these words to establish the correct pronunciation. Those who know these sounds and can perform purification rites while reciting them will have the Heavenly Thearchs dispatch Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings to descend and observe their persons, record their diligent practice, and memorialize the heavens. The myriad spirits will pay homage, the earth spirits will attend at their gates, and the great Demon Kings will safeguard and recommend them for ascent to immortality. Once their practice is complete, they may wander the Three Realms and ascend through the Golden Gates. These sounds repel all harm, dissolve all calamities, deliver all beings, and accomplish all ends—they are the spontaneous sounds of the Heavenly Perfected. Thus, when recited, Flying Heavenly Beings descend to observe, the Supreme Thearch chants from afar, the myriad spirits pay homage, the Three Realms attend in their chariots, the demonic hordes bow their heads, and ghostly spirits perish of themselves. The jade-like tones resound, and when the four characters *yǒu shàng* are written and swallowed, they cure deafness. The ten directions become solemn and clear, rivers and seas grow still, mountains and peaks swallow their mists, the myriad spirits tremble and submit, and the host of immortals is summoned. Heaven is free of defilement, earth is free of demonic dust, dark wisdom becomes profoundly clear, and the great measure is most mysterious. When written on *hài*, they open the heart. Truly, the *Lingbao* scriptures belong to the *Dongxuan* section, and the twelve divisions are all encompassed within the single scroll of the *Central Scripture for Delivering Humanity*. Their principles are profoundly obscure, and thus only the perfected sages who have already attained the Way and the true persons can fully grasp their chapters. Yet teachings manifest in accordance with the times, and methods circulate in response to the era. Though scholars may not yet be able to plumb their hidden depths, the scriptures have been translated into the written characters of this world—unlike the unintelligible barbarian speech of the Buddhists—and by following their correct principles and examining them carefully, one may yet fathom their general purport. Thus, from beginning to middle, the scriptural method is divided into forty chapters. Each chapter has its own meaning, and each meaning has its own purpose—this is the origin of the *Lingbao* teachings. Those who practice and uphold them, advancing to the immortal ranks of the *Dongxuan* and fulfilling the offices of the *Lingbao* methods, can they not first devote their hearts to this? Truly, one should thoroughly understand the original intent behind the division into chapters, and only then can the seven warp and eight weft scriptures be comprehended.

Scholars who delve deeply and investigate thoroughly shall naturally attain boundless perfection. The writings of Mount Tiantai have also been incorporated into the methods, with minor additions and alterations, and their title changed to *Great Scripture Exegeses*. Now, "exegesis" denotes the meaning of commentary. Since the *Scripture of Salvation* received annotations from Yan Dong during the Qi dynasty and later from Xu Youqi and others during the Tang, successive commentaries have proliferated, yet none may be called the *Method* itself. The forty chapters serve as the foundation of the method. Yet Mount Tiantai regards them as *Great Scripture Exegeses*—this is why they must be truthfully categorized and included, not to deliberately create distinctions.

**End of the Third Scroll of the Great Methods of Highest Clarity and Numinous Treasure**
**Beginning of the Fourth Scroll of the Great Methods of Highest Clarity and Numinous Treasure**

Compiled by Jin Yunzhong, Keeper of the Law in the Southern Bureau of the Dongxuan Numinous Treasure Master’s Office, Right Assistant of the Governance of the Golden Right in the Chutongfu

**The Seven Scriptures and Eight Wefts**

In the Great Primordial Stability, the divine radiance shines resplendent for seven days and seven nights. Penetrating the hundred spirits, it surveys the ten directions. Jade tablets reveal inner illumination. Refining the ancestral qi, one gives birth to the sacred embryo of the Dharma-body. The oral instructions for descending the five phases’ upright qi in inner refinement remain untransmitted. The millet-grain pearl, through accumulated divine transformations, forms the elixir. The oral instructions for descending the central principle to harmonize the five qi and unite the hundred spirits remain untransmitted. The above are called the *Seven Scriptures*.

The flowing essence and jade radiance of the yin-yang elixir remain untransmitted. Internally, it encompasses the nine cauldrons; externally, it aligns with the nine-colored *Dongyang Fu* of the Great Opening Diagram. The oral instructions for the flowing Brahman qi merging with the Great Yang and pervading the ten directions remain untransmitted. The recitation practices of the Three Palaces. Illuminating the subtle and obscure. The five grades of yin merits. Aiding life through yang virtues. Ascending and delivering across the boundless. The above are called the *Eight Wefts*.

Yunzhong humbly observes that the Dao of Numinous Treasure and the ranks of Dongxuan originated at the dawn of primordial chaos and unfolded before the kalpas of eons. When their radiance responded to the times and the teachings were established through scriptures, none departed from the *Seven Scriptures and Eight Wefts*. However, among their regulations and methods, some were recorded and included in compilations, while others remain untransmitted among humans. These have been itemized in their respective sections, and I dare not force explanations where none exist.

In the Numinous Treasure tradition of Mount Tiantai, these are called the *Recitation Wefts*. The first is *Taiyi Containing Flowers*, where jade dew welcomes the pearl. By visualizing and reciting it, one ascends to immortality without awaiting myriad practices—this is the *Weft of the Mysterious Transformation of the Pearl*. The second is *The Controller of Destiny Transforming Life*, descending in form and ascending again. Reciting it ten thousand times, one rides clouds and mounts dragons to ascend the great void in broad daylight—this is the *Weft of the Lion’s Mighty Spirit*. The third is *The Imperial Palace Dividing the Body*. With the three origins’ merits complete and the ten thousand perfections fulfilled, the entire body ascends in ascent—this is the *Weft of the Wondrous Vehicle of the Upper Palace*. The fourth is *The Elixir’s Inner Seat*, where the central fire achieves perfection. After six thousand merits accumulated, the virtue-moon unites with the nine perfected—this is the *Weft of Verification and Perfection in the Central Sanctuary*. The fifth is *The Elixir Valley Concealing the Aged*. With spirit and qi both preserved, the three thousand descend in practice. Registering in the Jade Capital—this is the *Weft of the Lower Origin’s Elementary Study*. The sixth is *The Three Qi Generating the Three*, uniting above with the Three Heavens. Creating a single body for the initiate. Dividing forms across the ten heavens. The form equaling the Heavenly Master. The demeanor natural, seated upon a lion, dwelling within the *Baozhu of the Empty Mystery’s Sunlight*. The five patterns of the primordial origin, circling ten times. Responding to and transforming the mysterious—this is the *Weft of Establishing the Divine Penetrations*. The seventh is *Inner and Outer Service*: the thirty-two sounds. The heart visualizes the Jade Lord. The Mud-Pill Palace of the Niwan, reciting the jade chapters, bowing to the Primordial Lord. After ten thousand recitations, nothing remains unaccomplished—this is the *Weft of the Jade Sounds of the Ten Thousand Spirits*. The eighth is *The Three Realms and Seven Origins*. Reciting a hundred thousand ten thousand times, the three realms may be delivered. The immortal elder’s cloud chariot—this is the *Weft of Expanding the Numinous across the Three Realms*. These are the *Wefts of Humans*.

Since the emergence of the Great Methods of Numinous Treasure, numerous compilations by various schools have appeared. Though they differ in gains and losses, none depart from the *Seven Scriptures and Eight Wefts* as their foundational source. Through accumulating merits, ascending to immortality, and delivering the world, the divine mechanisms and wondrous subtleties of the Dao lie concealed within. Yet the Tiantai tradition only divides the eight wefts by refinement and visualization, differing slightly from common transmissions. In the *Regulations of the Scriptures and Wefts* section, it briefly lists the names of the seven scriptures but does not record their contents. Those who have not seen the complete text must infer their meaning, thus establishing this section for recitation practices. While this does not obstruct principle, once the ancient methods are lost—where the names of the seven scriptures and eight wefts are all matters within the scriptures—it is like abandoning the net’s headrope, leaving scholars unaware of the path to take their first steps. How then can they aspire to ascend the hall and enter the chamber? Is it not difficult?

The *Chapter on the Flowing Evolution of the Primordial Net*

The Primordial Net is the path of primordial qi, the root of the Nine Heavens, located at the northwest corner, where it borders the Jade Clarity. To the southeast, it connects with the radiance of the Yang Passage, ascending to the Gate of the Divine Tiger of the Clear Palace. To the north, it extends into the wilds of the Cold Cavern, reaching upward to the Court of Divine Immortals of the Golden Portals. At the southern extreme, it aligns with the land of Great Elixir and Floating Blackness, its qi harmonizing with the light of the Cavernous Yang. To the north, it rectifies the Celestial Turtle’s alignment with the Canopy of Flowers, its qi traversing the Central Continent to the direct thoroughfare of Jade Capital. The eight winds converge at Tortoise Mountain in the west, the root of Heaven. For details, see the *Chapter on Exegesis and Application*.

To truly examine the Primordial Net is to grasp the root and pivot of Heaven, the warp and weft of qi. Before the source of the Dao divided, the Primordial Net was already established—this is the great structure of Heaven and Earth, the numinous axis of wondrous qi. It weaves through the Thirty-Two Heavens and penetrates the divisions of the Twenty-Eight Constellations. That which takes form above is called the Dao; that which flows below is termed the teachings. Practiced internally, it aligns with the body; applied externally, it revolves with method. This is the natural pattern of Heaven and Earth, modeled on the function and form of humanity.

Yet the illusory body of man, formed from filth and impurity, shaped in the womb—every hair and fiber—is but a thing of dust and decay. Only our singular spirit endures with Heaven and Earth from beginning to end, for both share the ancestral qi. Thus, the head is round like Heaven, the feet square like Earth; the eyes resemble the sun and moon, the body mirrors the expanse of the cosmos. The circulation of qi and breath corresponds precisely to the celestial measures. If one cultivates this to align with that, one may endure with Heaven, transcending impermanence.

Those who remain ignorant fail to awaken to its truth or examine its application, mistakenly claiming that the body contains Heaven and Earth and requires no external seeking. This is incorrect. The method of internal refinement, though vast as the three thousand six hundred side constellations, hinges on the true formula of the Golden Elixir. In the beginning, one pursues the two qi along the Yellow Path, uniting the three natures in the Primordial Palace. Upon completion, the yin soul vanishes without trace, and the yang spirit merges with the Dao. According to the weight of one’s merit and the rank of one’s endowment, one is appointed to the offices of the Immortal Bureaus or receives the scriptures of the Cavernous Realms. Yet one cannot claim that the body alone contains Heaven and Earth while nothing exists beyond, or that within there is form and spirit while nothing exists without. To grasp a single fragment of technique and assert that there is an inner but no outer—how grievously mistaken!

Some in recent times have recognized the error of this view, yet regretfully, without encountering a master’s guidance, they grope in vain for the essentials. Failing to fully embrace the internal, nor wholly devote themselves to the external, they fabricate a doctrine of "neither inner nor outer," straying even further from the truth.

Behold the azure expanse above—this is Heaven, adorned with the sun, moon, and stars as its patterns. The boundless and profound below—this is Earth, with its mountains, rivers, and peaks as its principles. The human body, with its four limbs and five constituents, is but one thing among all things between Heaven and Earth, distinguished only by its nature. To walk beneath Heaven and tread upon Earth, yet claim there is no Heaven or Earth beyond—how can this be?

Here, I have expounded the structure of the Primordial Net as the warp of Heaven, the constant. Next, I describe how the human body models itself upon Heaven and Earth, aligning with yin and yang in its form. Heaven endures through its ceaseless vigor; if one unites with the Dao and clarifies the spirit, one too may endure. This is not to say the body is Heaven unto itself, nor to advocate for "neither inner nor outer"—lest we mislead future generations. Thus, I must clarify this without ambiguity.

The Primordial Net is the essential path for the ascent of the spirit, the sublime vista of the Celestial Stairway. Once the source of the Dao divides, the divine heavens soar above the hollow peaks—beyond words, beyond the reach of sight or hearing. Those who awaken to its truth cultivate truth through truth, and external truth naturally responds. Those who recognize its wonder attain wonder through wonder, and external wonder naturally arrives. By extending the image of the divine heavens, the position of the Primordial Net—whether distant or near—becomes evident.

Within man, primordial qi opens the pathways of bones, vessels, and cavities, ascending to the crown, just as the Primordial Net’s path does in Heaven. The hun and po souls within the body are like qi within Heaven. To know their ingress and egress is to attain longevity and transcendence; to remain ignorant is to be a fool. One who has not mastered the arts and techniques, nor understood the ranks of officialdom, yet seeks an audience with the sovereign—how can this be?

When primordial qi gathers and fuses, it nourishes the hun and po, giving rise to true essence. True essence originates in the right kidney, the Gate of Life, located at the hollow of the spine. Below it lies the Great Bone, whose marrow permeates the body’s bones. This cavity is called the Tortoise Tail, and its ruler is the Queen Mother, who faces south to govern. From the Emperor’s perspective, it is called Tortoise Mountain of the West—a metaphor in Daoist teachings. It is also named the Golden Portals, for its residence in the west. To the right is the Golden Portals; to the left, the Jade Chamber, for jade resides in mountains and wood flourishes in moisture, dwelling in the east. It is also the source of Jade Water, the transformation of yang essence. Where essence congeals is called the Pure Abyss—this is where the qi of the Primordial Net originates.

The sacred diagrams are established here, the high altars rise from this point, and the Terrace of Fragrant Mist is founded upon it. At the center of the terrace, the honored one aligns directly with the heart—this is the Spiritual Terrace. The realm of Supreme Clarity lies above the Great Clarity, corresponding to the region below the heart. Beneath the heart’s suspension lies the liver. Two parts below the liver, the Northern Dipper’s seven stars reside. Their qi reaches the heart, their source ascending to the area beneath the tongue, called the Bubbling Spring. Its qi descends to the qi of the right kidney. Those who leak this qi fail to restrain the Bubbling Spring’s flow, a condition called "crossing blades." Crossing blades refers to the ground illuminated by the Dipper’s handle star, where its nature is stern and deadly, and its spirit belongs to the Realm of Desire.

Those who comprehend this Dao press the tongue against the upper palate, directly guiding the qi to ascend along the spine, connecting the spine to the head. Above the head lies the vital path to the Jade Capital—what is called the Western Tortoise Mountain, which borders the Jade Capital. Nowadays, people misunderstand, believing the Western Tortoise Mountain resides in the brain. Yet the Western Tortoise is separated from the qi of Jade Clarity by forty million layers of dwelling, while the central qi reaches directly into the heavens, where Mars, being the lowest, is the first to receive its qi. The heart belongs to fire, and when it ascends, resonance occurs. The sun and moon align with Mars, thus one roams between sun and moon.

Within the body, this corresponds to the two breasts aligning with the heart—the breasts being the root-source of the eyes. A person’s two breasts store essence to nourish the eyes. Thus, when one’s qi declines with age and the eyes grow dim, the breasts yield no milk, and the kidneys hold no essence. The Winnowing Basket and Dipper lie in the northeast of the heavens, serving as the celestial gate’s bolt—this is the position of Gen. In humans, this corresponds to the right shoulder’s Jianjing point. The body’s qi and vessels begin on the right. The celestial Dao’s movement begins in the northwest, proceeding westward to the Ox Mansion, where celestial affairs conclude. Yet nothing has yet arisen, so creation begins here—speaking of re-entering Mars. Though human qi completes one cycle, its ebb and flow depends on this, re-entering the heart. The progression through fire, wood, water, and metal follows the celestial degrees.

The heart, liver, kidneys, and lungs correspond to the qi transport points—these are the acupoints along the spine. Observing the spinal points reveals their arrangement above and below, left and right. Seeking their subtlety and tracing the throat’s circular path, one connects to the fontanel, where the mystery of mysteries resides, ineffable and beyond naming.

The realm of formlessness lies beneath the heart, within the hollow void, to the left of the Dipper’s bowl. From the Dipper’s mouth, press the tongue against the upper palate—this is called the Celestial Bridge—ascending through the Upper Clarity to reach the Jade Clarity. Thus, the vision of Jade Clarity resides in the head; the vision of Upper Clarity, in the Crimson Palace; and the vision of Great Clarity, in the Cinnabar Field. The heart is the Spirit Terrace, and so the discourse on the Spirit Terrace becomes evident.

In this practice, one guards—guarding resides in the heart. In this practice, one pays homage—homage resides in the head. These are the Three Flowers’ separation into the vast courtyard of Great Existence. Thus, the Heaven within Heaven gathers the meeting of the White Prime and the Origin in the heart, naturally attaining perfection in the head.

Cultivating the Lingbao Dao within the body culminates here, where affairs conclude, and no sound can contain it. The *Yunzhong*’s precise discourse on the primordial net’s unfolding in heaven was recounted earlier. Its embodiment in the human form is recorded here. Scholars must deeply understand why this body is so noble: it can become a true immortal, align with heaven and earth, refine form and spirit, and unite with the Dao’s mysteries.

Daoist teachings employ phenomena as metaphors and model themselves after heaven and earth to establish names. Following the nurtured body, they establish methods of action, progressing from action to non-action, from form to formlessness. Only then do they attain longevity equal to heaven and earth, merging with the Dao in truth. The practice begins within the body but does not end there.

**Primordial Net’s Unfolding Diagram**
*Yunzhong* notes: According to the *Zhen’gao*, the five planets’ diagrams are arranged facing south. Venus is positioned in the west, Jupiter in the east—this is the method of their application. The five planets’ concealments and traversals are irregular, unlike the Northern Dipper’s fixed configuration. Thus, their positions are uniformly assigned to the five directions, not following the stars’ actual locations.

*Yunzhong* examines astronomy: the five planets have no fixed positions. They may align like a string of pearls or cluster in the Well Mansion, halting, concealing, reversing, or progressing unevenly. Following the diagram in practice aligns with the five phases’ correspondences to determine directions—this is also the *Zhen’gao*’s approach. One must recognize that this diagram is for ritual use.

Like the twenty-eight constellations, which channel the qi of the thirty-two heavens, their affiliations differ. Here, the thirty-two heavens are arranged in a ring around the four directions, and the twenty-eight constellations follow astronomical positions to align the cardinal points, facilitating homage—this is not a matter of one constellation corresponding to one heaven’s qi. If one were to draw a heaven’s qi down to a specific constellation, the directions would become disordered, making application difficult.

When paying homage to the thirty-two heavens, begin with the Supreme August Yellow Brilliance Heaven and conclude with the Level Nurturing Jia Yi Heaven. Then, turn to the twenty-eight constellations, taking twelve steps per mansion, starting with the Winnowing Basket and ending with the Dipper. At the Dipper, rotate the body, return to the Winnowing Basket, and gaze back toward the Dipper’s handle to proceed. Homage to the five planets follows the same method, as detailed in the *Pure Brightness Scripture and Rituals*.

Ascend to the divine realm, entering the Northern Dipper’s midst. The Three Terraces’ six stars cap the crown as one traverses a Dipper’s seat. After six steps, align with the Three Terraces to exit. Circle left forty-nine steps, encountering Mars. Then proceed east eleven steps to the Great Yang, paying homage to the Filial Dao Immortal King. Turn right sixty-four steps, entering the west to reach the Great Yin, paying homage to the Filial Dao Luminous King. Spiral left to exit, then alternate left and right. After seven circuits like a ring, this is the Formless Realm. Stabilize visualization to perceive the Formless Realm’s immortals and perfected beings coming and going.

Thereafter, traverse the ten directions to pay homage to the thirty-two emperors and twenty-eight constellations. At each mansion, take twelve steps of the *ding* asterism, totaling three hundred thirty-six steps to return to the Dipper. Then borrow the Winnowing Basket’s asterism to proceed in a straight ring, gazing toward the Northern Dipper’s great handle and the Wind-Exchanging Mountain. Turn right, facing south forty-nine steps, re-entering Mars. Pass through the Great Yin, thirty-six steps to pay homage to Mercury. From Mercury, proceed east to the Great Yang’s side. Turn right sixty-four steps, facing east to pay homage to Jupiter. Return and proceed, borrowing Mercury’s asterism to exit beside the Great Yin. Eighty-one steps, facing west to pay homage to Venus. Proceed directly to the Dipper’s mouth, thirty-five steps to enter its center, paying homage to Saturn. Reverse course, re-enter the lodges of Venus, Mercury, and Jupiter, then gaze north toward the Jade Capital’s Golden Towers. Advance eight steps, bow deeply, and kneel.

State your rank and surname: "Your servant [Name], by fortunate alignment with this constellation’s blessings and encountering the true wind, enters stillness to concentrate spirit and reverently approaches the celestial gates. The body beyond the body ventures to the Jade Capital." Your servant, overwhelmed by gazing upon the heavens and beholding the sagely, prostrates in awe and trepidation. Bow twice.

Continue: "Your servant’s mortal bones are stubborn, and principle scarcely allows transcendence. By fortunate receipt of a teacher’s transmission, I dare to soar in spirit, undeterred by punishment, and humbly present my sincerity. I enter the ritual’s intent." Your servant, awaiting grace and command, respectfully speaks, bows twice, retreats to the original path, and allows the spirit to re-enter the fontanel.

**Incantation:**
*She chan she chan, tuo qiao li chen.*
*Wu jin chao zhen, shang ye qing yun.*
*Yu shi shen ren, bi zhai feng xing.*
*Ju bu yi qu, mi jue ling ling.*
*Hasten as the law commands!*

The *Right Primordial Net’s Flowing Evolution Diagram* is the path of the myriad heavens’ pure practices. It begins with the flight of spirit to gather the Dipper and concludes with the audience before the Emperor to present the primordial. If one can cultivate this with focused contemplation and disciplined practice, entering and exiting with mastery, ascending and responding without confusion, one may then submit memorials, command spirits and deities, and ultimately achieve the arts of shedding the mortal husk to ascend as a perfected being, merging with the primordial qi of the Brahma-realm. The methods of refining form and the techniques of presenting the primordial originate here.

On the Three Primordials, Eight Nodal Days, and the cyclical days of *jiazi* and *gengshen*, one enters the oratory, burns incense, sits facing north in equanimity, closes the eyes to still the mind, concentrates the spirit, and stabilizes intention. The breath flows gently, the spirit-wind does not stir. One raises the body to emerge from the crown, like a cicada shedding its husk, and ascends into the void of the mysterious. Proceeding according to the method, from the subtle to the manifest, from visualization to realization—this depends on the practitioner.

Yunzhong respectfully observes: This passage is the essential application within the method, the root source of memorials and petitions. Like the completion of the golden elixir or the generation of a body beyond the body, its benefits are profound. In recent times, the Lingbao methods of Mount Tiantai have often taught practitioners to operate solely within the body, failing to extend upward to the Muddy Pellet, the Twenty-Eight Constellations, the Thirty-Two Heavens, the Three Realms and Ten Directions, the thousand perfected and myriad images encircling the Muddy Pellet. The *Primordial Net’s Flying Steps* instead gathers the spirit into the brain, resembling the method of assembling the body’s spirits to present the primordial, akin to the technique of replenishing the brain and returning essence. Even the submission of memorials and the flight of spirit to make petitions are regarded as its untransmitted wonders. Yet some, observing similar functions in lesser methods, cling to these as secret techniques. Failing to grasp the essentials of Lingbao, they hastily adopt this practice. Fearing criticism from the discerning, their followers imagine their own spiritual marvels and refrain from speaking of them. How could they know that the *Primordial Net’s Flowing Evolution* traverses the Thirty-Two Heavens, passing through the divisions of the Twenty-Eight Constellations—this is the root pivot of the heavens? The human body mirrors this: one stabilizes the hundred spirits within the body and focuses the mind’s single thought, directing sincerity toward the upper realms to meet the Dao and present the primordial. This is not merely a matter of concentrating effort within the Muddy Pellet. By preserving the inner truth, the outer truth naturally responds; by comprehending the body’s transcendence, the heavens’ transcendence may be glimpsed. If the visualization is pure and unwavering, over time the spirit is refined and the substance transformed—there is no room for doubt. Yet if the spirit is returned to the body and attention fixed within the brain, this is mistaken. Scholars should deeply investigate this mechanism, approach it with an open mind, and avoid rigid attachment, so as to thoroughly grasp the principles of the true and orthodox Dao and together ascend to the realm of purity and tranquility.

The *Ranks of the Mysterious Heavens’ Sovereigns* and the *High Perfected and Supreme Sages* collectively record the mysteries of the heavens. The subtly existent and subtly nonexistent cannot be fathomed. When scriptures emerge, their mechanisms gradually become apparent. The *Three Caverns’ Orthodox Regulations* are profound in principle. Since the Great Tang dynasty, scriptures and decrees have been scattered and lost, patched together over time, mingling the true and false. Only those of discernment can distinguish their sources and comprehend their principles, thereby glimpsing even a fraction of their profundity.

The Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning is the source of the myriad transformations, the mysterious qi of the Dao. Beyond analogy or conjecture, it disperses to become qi and coalesces to form shape. Within it dwells spirit, forcibly named the Celestial Worthy, who resides in the Sacred Realm of Jade Purity. The Celestial Worthy of Numinous Treasure is the primordial qi of the Dao. In terms of teaching, the Primordial Beginning corresponds to the Cavern of Perfection, while this corresponds to the Cavern of Mystery, residing in the True Realm of Highest Purity. The Celestial Worthy of the Dao and Its Virtue is the originating qi of the Dao. In terms of teaching, from the Primordial Beginning to this point corresponds to the Cavern of Divinity, residing in the Immortal Realm of Great Purity.

The August Emperor of the Vast Heaven arises from the transformation of the Three Qi, transcending the limits of heaven and earth. He generates the myriad things yet does not bear them. When the Three Powers were first established, the qi was pure and lofty, accumulating yang to form heaven. As the source of the ten thousand transformations, how could it lack a sovereign? Thus, in terms of form and image, it is called Heaven; in terms of governance, it is called Emperor. He administers below the mysterious qi and is revered above the Three Realms, serving as the Lord of Heaven.

The Great Emperor of the Northern Culmen is the imperial throne within the Purple Tenuity Enclosure. According to the *Treatise on Astronomy*: The Southern Culmen sinks thirty-six degrees into the earth, while the Northern Culmen rises thirty-six degrees above it. The celestial form is inclined, half emerging above the earth and half returning within it. The myriad stars and qi all revolve leftward, except for the Northern and Southern Culmina, which serve as the pivot and remain unmoving, enabling the heavens to rotate. Mortals observe it in the north and call it the Northern Culmen, yet it truly resides at the center of the heavens, serving as the ancestral sovereign of the myriad stars, the secondary lord of the Three Realms, subordinate only to the Vast Heaven. It corresponds above to the primordial qi and is thus called the Great Emperor of the Northern Culmen of Purple Tenuity.

In the Lingbao methods of Mount Tiantai, however, it is claimed that the Great Emperor of the Northern Culmen of Purple Tenuity is the emperor of the myriad spirits and baleful forces of the Three Realms, deceiving the mortal world and profaning the supreme mystery. This is deeply alarming and should be strictly avoided by scholars.

The Great Emperor of the Heavenly Sovereign is located to the left of the Northern Culmen’s imperial throne. Four stars form a slightly curved, linked shape resembling a hook, called the Curved Array. The large star directly below it, positioned at its center, is the Great Emperor of the Heavenly Sovereign. He governs the myriad stars, his rank equal to the Northern Culmen, yet serving as the pivot, the Heavenly Sovereign also revolves with the heavens. Corresponding below to the originating qi and above to the Three Qi, within the Three Realms and above the myriad heavens, none surpass the supremacy of these Three Emperors.

Yunzhong privately reflects: Who does not know that the Three Purities and Three Realms’ Celestial Worthies are the Three Qi of the mysterious, primordial, and originating? Yet when qi coalesces, it forms shape; when it disperses, it returns to qi. This is the source of the myriad transformations, the ancestor of the Three Powers, the root of heaven and earth—beyond naming or conjecture. When the kalpa of Red Clarity commenced and the Great Dao radiated its light, whether through the refinement of the great void by fire or the recording of scriptures by the August Person, the true texts descended to the world, and the Three Caverns were proclaimed. Thus, there are the divisions of the Caverns of Perfection, Mystery, and Divinity, and the designations of the Heavenly Treasure, Numinous Treasure, and Divine Treasure.

In the middle antiquity and thereafter, ritual systems were established, with each of the Three Caverns possessing its own scriptures and registers—hence the designation of the Three Vehicles and Nine Grades.

The Dao in its concealment is unknowable; in its function, it establishes teachings. In the Lingbao ritual system of Mount Tai, Que Shu states: The Celestial Worthy of Original Beginning is the sovereign within the Dao; the Supreme Dao Lord is the sovereign within the Dharma; and the Supreme Lord Lao is the sovereign within the Teaching.

Alas! The origins of the Three Caverns, Four Supplements, ritual registers, and the Nine Grades of the Three Vehicles are interconnected and mutually permeating. To claim that each of the Three Purities presides over one division is a deception beyond words. One must wonder if they comprehend what the Three Purities truly are. It is like guiding the blind before them or having the sightless follow in their wake. With such doctrines, how can one hope to practice their methods to deliver the hidden and aid the manifest, or dare to expect their efficacy?

The Lingbao system of Mount Tai further states: The Heavenly August Emperor of the Purple Tenuity’s Upper Palace is the one beneath the Curved Array within the Purple Tenuity Enclosure. One may refer to it as the Purple Tenuity Enclosure or the Curved Array Palace, but to call it the Upper Palace of Purple Tenuity is to refer to the Mystic Capital’s Jade Capital Mountain, not the Purple Tenuity Enclosure. A single character’s discrepancy carries grave consequences.

In the Tang dynasty, the veneration of Lord Lao as the Sacred Ancestor Heavenly August Emperor was a ritual of ancestral reverence unique to the Tang court—distinct from the Heavenly August Emperor of the Purple Tenuity Enclosure. Those who, ignorant of antiquity and the present, recklessly invoke names and titles incur unforgivable transgressions.

There exists a discourse on the titles of the Sacred Ancestor Celestial Worthy, but as this position is no longer established in the present age, it is not recorded here—not by omission. This sacred rank was the founding ancestor of the Song dynasty, with the Great Sage of Primordial Heaven as his consort, now known as the Perfected Lord of the Nine Heavens’ Life Mandate.

Here concludes the fourth scroll of the *Great Rites of the Highest Clarity and Numinous Treasure*. The fifth scroll of the *Great Rites of the Highest Clarity and Numinous Treasure* follows.

The *Dongxuan Lingbao* Ritual Master of the Southern Bureau, Compiler Jin Yunzhong of the Right Wing of the Primordial Youth’s Initial Prefecture:

**Register of the Three Realms’ Palace Bureaus**

**Upper Realm**
The Supreme Great Luo Heaven, the Mysterious Capital Jade Metropolis, the Jade Clarity Realm, the Highest Clarity Realm, the Grand Clarity Realm, the Nine Heavens’ Great Emperors, the Nine Heavens’ Supreme Lords, the Three Qi Venerable, the Three Treasures Lords, the Celestial Pivot Institute under the Three Heavens’ Gates, the Terrace of Grand Mystery, the Four Heavens of the Seed People, the Four Heavens of the Formless Realm, the Eighteen Heavens of the Form Realm, the Six Heavens of the Desire Realm—together comprising the Thirty-Two Heavens of the Great Blessed Worlds and the Eight Brahmā Heavens. The Five Elder Lords’ Palaces, the Eastern Ultimate Azure Palace, the Eastern Florescence Superior Minister’s Palace, the Southern Ultimate Lord of Longevity, the Western Numinous Tortoise Gate, the Four Poles Perfected Kings, the Northern Ultimate Purple Tenuity Enclosure, the Heavenly Emperor’s Enclosure, the Supreme Subtlety Enclosure, the Cinnabar Numinous Upper Palace, the Han Bureau of the Fire Mansion, the Highest Clarity Primordial Youth’s Initial Prefecture, the Northern Culmen Mysterious Standard Prefecture, the Three Realms’ Demon Kings’ Palaces, the Five Emperors’ Demon Kings’ Palaces, the Grand Yang Palace, the Grand Yin Palace, the Northern Dipper’s Seven Primes Palace, the Upper Prime Celestial Officials’ Palace, the Pure Numinous Left Palace, the Primordial August Central Palace, the Cavernous Luminous Right Palace, and the Upper Prime’s Nine Prefectures, Thirty-Six Bureaus, and Three Palaces.

**Middle Realm**
The Central Marchmount Kunlun Mountain, the Ten Great Grotto-Heavens, the Thirty-Six Grotto-Heavens, the Three Hundred Sixty Famous Mountains, the Nine Ramparts, the Northern Capital Fengdu Mountain, the Northern Grand Supreme Lord’s Palace, the Palace of the Yin Heaven of Zhou’s Extinction, the Palace of the Heaven of Solemn Judgment for Grievous Offenses, the Palace of the Heaven of Dawn’s Endurance for Transgressions, the Palace of the Heaven of Serene Radiance for Sinful Qi. The six palace names and numbers are extracted from the *Declarations of the Perfected*; however, the fourth palace is recorded as "Serene Radiance," though it remains uncertain whether it should be "Serene Radiance" or "Serene Illumination." Later scholars should investigate this further. The Palace of the Seven Non-Heavens of Ancestral Numinosity, the Palace of the Heaven of Daring Governance over Linked Winding Realms, the Ten Kings Perfected Lords, the Cavernous Yin Metal Gate, the Northern Capital Prefecture, the Life Mandate Prefecture, the Five Paths Prefecture, the Yellow Springs Prefecture, the Venerable’s Palace, the Northern Dipper’s Ghost Officials, the Four Luminaries Perfected Duke’s Prefecture, the Transformation and Birth Prefecture, the Vast Cold Great Spirits, the Eastern Marchmount Emperor’s Palace, the Taishan Prefecture—this being the administrative seat of the Middle Prime’s Earthly Officials’ Palace, the Middle Prime’s Nine Prefectures, altogether Forty-Two Bureaus and Three Palaces.

**Lower Realm**
The Eastern Rosy Clouds Fusang Palace, the Yang Valley Divine King’s Prefecture, the Penglai Palace, the Penglai Capital Water Bureau, the Square Cauldron Azure Youth’s Palace, the Ten Continents, the Nine Rivers’ Water Emperors’ Palaces, the Four Seas’ Dragon Kings, the Four Watercourses’ Source Kings, the Five Lakes’ Lords, the Twelve River Sources, the Lower Prime’s Water Officials’ Palace, the Lower Prime’s Three Palaces, Nine Prefectures, and Forty-Two Bureaus.

Yunzhong has heard that the celestial perfected govern the upper realms, while ghosts and spirits preside over the hidden depths—matters inherently beyond the ken of mundane mortals. Yet practitioners of the Dao must attain some understanding of the fundamental principles of Heaven and Earth and possess a rough grasp of the origins and development of the teachings. Those who neither comprehend antiquity nor consult the scriptures, recklessly measuring all by their own conjectures, lead later generations astray—how lamentable!

The *Lingbao* rites respond to the world’s needs, and their protocols, memorials, and petitions must be grounded in established sources to be valid. In the *Lingbao* rites of Mount Tai, the Three Clarities’ Supreme Lords are listed as the Three Masters, the Savior from Suffering Heavenly Worthy as the Perfected Master, and also as the Mysterious Master. Later additions to the texts invariably place the Mysterious Master at their head, though these expanded works differ from the original canons. Moreover, a "Register of Immortal Bureaus for Cultivation and Application" was established, carving each phrase from the scriptures into a separate bureau. For instance, the line "must not be detained or forced into ghostly throngs" originally referred to souls destined for deliverance, liberated from the hidden realms and no longer subject to detention or confinement among ghostly multitudes—a continuation of the preceding text’s meaning. Yet it was misconstrued as establishing a "Bureau of Non-Detention" and a "Bureau of Forced Ghostly Congregation." Similarly, "nothing it does not repel, nothing it does not exorcise, nothing it does not deliver" describes the efficacy of the Great Brahmā’s esoteric speech, yet this was distorted into a "Bureau of Universal Repulsion," a "Bureau of Universal Exorcism," and a "Bureau of Universal Deliverance." The phrase "today, rejoicing in deliverance, passing through the gates of all heavens, with demon kings as witnesses and no obstruction at the celestial gates" was truncated by omitting "today," yielding a "Bureau of Rejoicing in Deliverance," a "Bureau of Passing Through All Heavens’ Gates," a "Bureau of Demon Kings’ Witness," and a "Bureau of Unobstructed Celestial Gates." The original intent described the scripture’s efficacy: after rejoicing in deliverance today, one passes through the gates of all heavens, where demon kings bear witness, and no obstruction remains at the celestial gates. Yet these phrases were arbitrarily severed and repurposed as bureau names. Further examples include the "Bureau of Immortal Bureaus for Cultivation," the "Bureau of Immortal Bureaus for Application," the "Bureau of Resplendent Immortal Bureaus," and the "Bureau of Immortal Bureaus for the Three Realms’ Orientation"—all fabricated and absurd, with no limit to such distortions. The phrase "orientation for the Three Realms" does not appear in the scriptures, while "resplendent" is a self-designation from the text: "The resplendent multitudes of all heavens unite in merit," referring to the majesty and virtue of the demon kings within the heavens, with no bearing on other matters or the existence of such bureaus. Yet over thirty phrases like "enumerated among the Grand Mystery" were extracted from the scriptures to form the "Bureau of Resplendent Immortals," entirely divorced from the original meaning. Such inventions number no fewer than two hundred bureaus, which practitioners treat as the ranks of generals and officials, invoking them at altars without understanding the true principles or feeling any shame.

The Three Caverns and Four Supplements comprise scriptures numbering tens of millions of fascicles; if every phrase were turned into a bureau, the scriptures’ proclamations and canonical texts would be reduced to nothing but bureau names, and their profound mysteries and abstruse meanings would remain unheard. Wang Shengqing’s *Compendium of Lingbao Rites* contains many critical examinations, yet even he retained several instances of converting scriptural phrases into bureaus, failing to excise them—a lapse in judgment. The Mount Tai compilations, however, are rife with forced connections and patchwork additions that severely obstruct reason, as seen in examples like the "Palm Offering Bureau" and the "Descending Saints Bureau."

From the Song and Qi dynasties through the Tang, and even into the Song dynasty, the grand Luotian Jiao rites established three thousand six hundred positions—yet even these encompassed all necessary roles without such bureaus. The Tian Shu Yuan (Celestial Pivot Institute) resides beneath the Three Celestial Gates, as detailed in the *Rituals for Memorial Offerings*. To rename it the "Southern Culmen Celestial Pivot Institute" is still an error. For the Northern Culmen marks the Central Heaven; only beyond it does one reach the Celestial Gates. The Southern Culmen, however, descends thirty-six degrees into the earth, directly opposing the Northern Culmen. To invert and confuse these directions—ignoring north and south—how can such petitions and memorials avoid violating ritual codes and transgressing proper form?

Yunzhong has now established the *Rank of the Mysterious Vault Sovereign* to clarify the origins of the Three Clarities, Three Emperors, and Three Qi. This is followed by the *Rank of the Three Realms’ Palace Offices* to complete the categories for petitions and memorials. For prayers of supplication, exorcism, transcendence, deliverance of the departed, and salvation of the living, these are already sufficient. Yet I fear scholars may dismiss this work as incomplete and lightly add spurious bureaus with reckless names, perpetuating endless harm—thus I cannot refrain from making this distinction.

**Rank of Retreat Chambers for Facing the Origin**
The retreat chamber must remain unstained by worldly filth and unentangled with secular affairs.

To establish an altar is to model earth after heaven. Whether one’s household is rich or poor, whether the dwelling is spacious or narrow, arrange the sacred ranks, face the imperial palace to pay homage to the Origin, adorn both inner and outer with solemnity, purify both body and mind as one. Therein, the true spirits are invoked through resonance, and the supreme Dao is met within the primordial vastness. This is not about recklessly inventing names to deceive the world and mislead the people.

In Daoist temples, the positions of the Three Realms’ Most Perfect Heavenly Thearchs are set forth. If residing in a secular dwelling, establish the Three Treasures at the center and array the host of perfected beings to the sides. When paying homage, simply face the imperial palace in contemplation.

Herein is a summary of the sacred ranks:

The Most High Lord of the Jade Clarity Sacred Realm, the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of Origin;
The Most High Lord of the Supreme Clarity True Realm, the Heavenly Worthy of Numinous Treasure;
The Most High Lord of the Grand Clarity Immortal Realm, the Heavenly Worthy of Dao and Virtue;
The August Thearch of the Luminous Heavens;
The Great Thearch of the Northern Culmen;
The Heavenly August Thearch;
The August Earth Spirit of the Rear Soil;
The Great Thearch of Longevity;
The Great Thearch of Azure Radiance;
The Lord of the Eastern Florescence, Wood Duke, Azure Youth Dao Lord;
The Primordial Lady of the Golden Mother of the Nine Numina, the Most Perfect and Real, at the White Jade Tortoise Terrace;
The Heavenly Worthy of Great Unity, Savior from Suffering, of the Eastern Culmen.

The above are the principal ranks; if no position is set, one may invoke them orally.

The Nine Heavenly Thearchs;
The Thirty-Two Heavenly Thearchs;
The Perfected Lords of the Five Fortunes, Ten Spirits, and Grand Unity;
The Eleven Luminaries of the Supreme Clarity;
The Seven Primes of the Northern Dipper;
The Three Great Thearchs of Heaven, Earth, and Water;
The Four Saintly Marshals of the Northern Culmen;
The Five Masters of Numinous Treasure;
The Filial Daoist Immortal King of the Solar Palace;
The Filial Luminous King of the Lunar Palace;
The Perfected Lord Ge of the Grand Ultimate’s Immortal Visitation;
The Most Perfect Lord of the Great Scribe of All Immortals, Wondrous Aid;
The Great Lord of Longevity of the Southern Culmen;
The Great Spirit Sima of the Salvation Office;
The Venerable Lord Han, Master of Life-Preservation;
The Exalted Spirits of the Offices of Life and Destiny;
The Exalted Spirits of Longevity, Fortune, and Deliverance from Calamity;
The Great Demon Kings of the Three Realms;
The Great Demon Kings of the Five Thearchs;
The Demon Kings of the Five Heavens;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit Kings of the Ten Directions and Boundless Realms;
The High Perfected of the Southern Prosperity Upper Palace;
The Great Thearch of the Northern Darkness, Fengdu;
The Great Thearch of the Eastern Radiance, Fusang;
The Sacred Thearchs of the Five Marchmounts and Five Heavens;
The Lords of the Six Heavens and Ten Caverns of Fengdu;
The Spirit King of the Solar Valley;
The Water Thearchs of the Nine Rivers;
The Sacred Hosts of the Twelve River Sources;
The Perfected Lords and Record-Keepers of the Grotto-Heavens and Blessed Lands;
The Immortal Hosts of the Three Hundred Sixty Named Mountains of the Kunlun Upper Palace;
The Perfected and Sacred Hosts of the Childhood Beginning Office, the Leisure Hall of Master Xiao, and the True Immortals of the Yi-Qian Retreat;
The Three and Five Merit Officials;
The Left and Right Palace Attendants;
The Left and Right Lords of the Dragon and Tiger;
The Golden Lads of Incense-Offering;
The Jade Maidens of Message-Transmission;
The Direct Talismans of the Five Thearchs;
The Incense Officials of the Day.

The above total thirty-seven ranks.

At dawn, compose the spirit and settle the will. Don proper cap and robe, first stand outside the door, gaze ahead, and contemplate the gods of the body arrayed in order. Then, knock the teeth nine times.

Then softly intone the incantation:

*"Great Radiant Numinous Spirits,
Ninefold verdant ascent.
Morning glow conceals its splendor,
Washing and refining the Five Spirits.
Proclaiming the chariot of the Six Harmonies,
The Seven Spirits attuned and balanced.
Knots unravel, dispersing;
The root of the embryo purified and cleansed."*

The *Rites of Talismanic Methods at the Altar* states: "When entering a chamber, first step with the left foot; when exiting, first step with the right." Yet this text instructs: "Lift the right foot to enter the chamber"—its correctness remains uncertain. Carefully compare and verify this with other scriptures and methods. Later, the *True Reports* records: "When entering the oratory, first place the right foot forward, then bring the left foot to align with it before proceeding as usual." This ensures one’s petition is conveyed and heard above. Thus, the error in the *Rites at the Altar* is known.

Knock the teeth nine times again and recite the *Incantation for Entering the Chamber at Dawn*:

*"Fourfold Radiant Merit Officials,
Messengers of the Way’s Transmission,
Jade Lads of Message-Bearing,
Jade Maidens of Incense-Attending—
Convey my words,
To the gods of this sacred chamber.
Primordial qi of the Upper Origin,
Enter this servant’s body.
Let the memorial I present
Be reported and heard above."*

Lift the right foot to enter first. Before the sacred altar, where flames blaze and incense rises in abundance, calm the heart and settle the qi. Visualize the Incense Officials and Messengers, the Left and Right Lords of the Dragon and Tiger, the Golden Lads of Incense-Offering, and the Jade Maidens of Message-Transmission standing in attendance beside the incense table. The sun and moon withdraw nine inches from the face; the Northern Dipper hovers overhead; the body faces forward, enveloped in threefold layers of deep, verdant qi. Then, hold the breath, compose the spirit, and bow reverently toward the mat—or hold the tablet and bow three times. Knock the teeth and, following the rites, present the petition. Whatever the heart supplicates, let sincerity ascend directly, swiftly reaching the Nine Heavens.

Hold the breath and exit through the earthly portal, reciting the *Incantation for Exiting the Chamber at Dawn*:

*"Emerging from yin into yang,
The myriad spirits unfurl.
Having opened the gates and completed the task,
I request the closure of the Yellow Chamber.
Jade Maidens of Incense-Attending,
Brightly prepare the divine palace."*

When entering the oratory to burn incense and pay homage to the Perfected, never glance back; when exiting, do not turn to look. While conducting the rites, refrain from speaking to others and keep the feet together when stepping over the threshold. Do not hold incense in the mouth, nor use hearth fire to burn it. On days of *wu-chen* or *wu-xu*, or during fierce winds, sudden storms, violent thunder, or flashing lightning, temporarily suspend the practice. Wait until the celestial qi has settled before resuming the dawn observances.

All the above are prohibitions within the method; transgression incurs fault.

At dusk, enter the oratory, concentrate the spirit upon the Nine Gods, align with the imperial mat below, and knock the teeth nine times.

The incantation reads:
"Mysterious Perfection of the Seven Stars,
Majestic Sovereign of the Ling Soul.
Radiance flows inward, illuminating,
Permeating and governing the Dipper’s spirit.
The Three Terraces gleam resplendent,
Seven essences entwine the numinous fluid.
Golden pendants and tiger registers
Guard and defend the Gate of Life.
Divine transformation pervades the void,
Drawing the wheel into the Purple Court."

Next, knock the teeth and recite the incantation for entering the oratory at night:
"Four Superior Merit Officers,
Dragon-Tiger Envoys,
Orthodox One’s primordial *qi*,
Jade Maidens attending incense.
For matters to be reported at night,
May the Luminous Youth and the Great Mystery Maiden
Accompany me within.
May the governance of the Yellow Chamber
Convey all petitions upward,
Making them heard above."

The rest follows the dawn observance ritual.

The incantation for exiting the oratory at night:
"Great Yin of the Mysterious Above,
Eight Windows open in clarity.
For matters reported at night,
May the Maiden transmit the numinous.
When affairs conclude, return to position,
And the myriad spirits will all be at peace."

Alternatively, one may sit upright within the oratory, concentrating the spirit and engaging in the secret practices cultivated in daily life—this is especially excellent. Or, if practicing other methods with distinct protocols, follow their respective guidelines.

As *Zhen’gao* states: "Whenever entering the chamber to burn incense, one should face the mat and bow in reverence, knock the teeth, and silently pray. Whatever is expressed, let it be with utmost sincerity, and one will surely receive a response."

Yunzhong respectfully notes from *Zhen’gao*: "Those who uphold the Dao should meticulously prepare their oratory chambers. This is to dispel malevolent impurities, cast aside worldly distractions, and create a space for dawn observances." Initially, such chambers were never given specific names.

During the Eastern Han, the Orthodox Unity Celestial Master cultivated inner perfection and performed extraordinary deeds externally. Traversing famous mountains, his beneficence extended to all beings, yet he never dared to presumptuously establish names or falsely exalt himself. In the first year of *Han’an* under Emperor Shun, the Celestial Worthy descended and personally transmitted the Dao’s decree, saying: "When I descended upon the Shu Mountains, I established the Twenty-Four *Zhi*, corresponding above to the Twenty-Eight Constellations and below to the offices of the Dark Registers, overseeing the life, death, sins, and blessings of the world. Recently, demonic forces have encroached, wrongfully harming the people. Thus, I commanded the Celestial Master to subdue the deviant and restore these *Zhi*." By the Tang dynasty, to avoid the taboo of Emperor Gaozong’s name, the world began calling them the Twenty-Four *Hua*. Hence, they are now collectively termed *Zhi-Hua*, originating in antiquity and later revived by the Celestial Master. The people born within the sixty-year cycle are assigned to these divisions, and in the Register of General Merit, one’s life destiny is sealed with the corresponding *Zhi*’s mark. The Celestial Master also revitalized the Dao’s fortunes, restoring the *Zhi* and establishing them as courts of blessing.

During the Jin, Xu Jingyang possessed the innate qualities of an immortal. After prolonged cultivation of the Supreme Dao, at over forty years of age, he resigned his office and returned east. By then, his practice had already gained renown. Traveling with the Perfected Wu to Songyang, he heard of the Yellow Hall Oratory in Danyang County, where the female master, Chen Mu, resided. He sought her to inquire about the Dao’s mysteries. Mu then presented the bronze talismans and iron charters left by Master Lan, the Golden Elixir’s sacred scriptures, and various esoteric precepts, along with the teachings of the Filial Piety Luminous King, entrusting them all to Master Xu. Later, Mu flew a thatched hut to the southern side of West Mountain, where Master Xu found the site and built a shrine, also naming it the Yellow Hall—now known as Chongzhen Abbey.

When the Perfected Lord first visited the flying thatch, he subdued malevolent spirits along the way. The next day, ascending the mountain’s peak, he pointed to a fissure in the spring halfway up and declared, "A strange entity lurks here, which will later cause calamity." He then established an oratory to suppress it—now called Longcheng Abbey. Upon returning to Yuzhang Commandery, he slew a monstrous sea serpent, leaving behind an altar and well to quell future disasters. The formations he arranged resembled the Dipper’s stars, including the Alchemical Transformation Oratory, the Ritual Rhythm Oratory, the Cinnabar Talisman Oratory, the Flowering Banner Purple Yang Oratory, the Huoyang Oratory, and the Arrayed Perfected Oratory. Many such sites exist, most now serving as abbeys and temples, fulfilling the Perfected Lord’s original intent: to pacify sacred mountains, subdue malevolent anomalies, and ensure their names endure with heaven and earth, their merits equaling the cosmos, their virtue profound and achievements lofty. Even those who ascended with their households did not act as common talisman-water practitioners, privately establishing names for themselves.

Those whose virtue does not match the Han Celestial Master should not presume to revive the *Zhi-Hua*. Those whose merits do not equal Xu Jingyang’s should not presume to establish oratory names. Beyond this, there is no scriptural basis—this is the universal consensus of the world.

In recent times, practitioners of the Numinous Treasure tradition have all acted with false arrogance, presumptuously establishing oratory names without weighing their gravity. Lacking humility, they surpass the Han Celestial Master and rival Xu Jingyang, even claiming: "In silent meditation, within the golden light, the oratory’s name manifests." Alas, is this not deceiving heaven? If one could behold golden light in meditation and receive celestial scriptures face-to-face, that would be the station of an Upper Immortal—hardly one to linger long among mortals. How could such a one remain in the world? This is not the proper way.

Those who uphold the practice should modestly abide by their station. Such presumption is no way to nurture disciples. If among the dust-bound there are superior scholars, or transcendent recluses dwelling in abbeys or households, they should prepare oratory chambers for rigorous cultivation. When traveling to distant lands or sojourning elsewhere, they may face the void and pay homage from afar, which can also move the Supreme Mystery. There is no need to presumptuously establish oratory names or falsely claim divine transmission to embellish deceit and delusion. This is hereby proclaimed and reported.

Following the old system, one may inscribe "Beneath the Dipper of the Three Heavens, South" as the placard. According to the rites performed, the "Bureau of the Great Numinous Treasure" may be used—what harm is there in this? Yet one must never yield to worldly custom to aid in deception. If a household of means establishes a Daoist abbey and displays its name, or constructs halls and pavilions to affix their placards, these are but secular titles for towers and pavilions, not to be presented before Heaven, Earth, or the spirits. In such cases, they may do as they please.

When holding the *cunsi* ranks, intending to perform the Dao or discourse on scriptures, one should first prepare fragrant water for bathing. Nowadays, only peachwood and white bedstraw, or light bamboo leaves, are boiled for the bath. Formerly, the "Five Fragrances Decoction" was used—comprising *qingmuxiang* (costus root), *gansong* (spikenard), clove, aloeswood, and *baizhi* (angelica)—all boiled together. The Tiantai method employs *xunluxiang* (frankincense), a substance forbidden by Daoists, not an ancient practice.

First, visualize the Three Dawns and sip the water while gazing at the bath. Recite the incantation:
*"True liquid of the Great Mystery, refining qi to quicken the numinous.
Bathed in azure radiance, chanting the Cavernous Scriptures.
Seven ancestors ascend as immortals; I soar to the Upper Clarity."*

When undressing to bathe, recite:
*"Palace of spirits shakes the heavens, black clouds part asunder.
Molten gold and fire bells gleam, casting boundless splendor.
Grant me communion with the true, roaming all heavens.
Measureless salvation of beings, summoning immortal destiny."*

When removing garments, recite:
*"Five Dipper robes arrayed, dragon and tiger attend the true.
The Three Luminaries revealed, ascending to Jade Dawn.
Shedding clothes to become immortal, grant me eternal life."*

For the bathing incantation, recite:
*"Jade springs of the Rain Pool bathe my form.
Within, refine the Five Viscera; without, open the Nine Gates.
Let qi flow freely, washing away corpse-filth and impurity.
Ten thousand cycles of protection, ascend in majesty."*

Entering the Imperial Court.

When donning the crown, recite:
*"Azure clouds layer in mystery, granting me communion with the true.
Crown and topknot summon immortals; the Five Qi gather the real.
Divine radiance shines forth, ascending to the Imperial Court."*

Take a cup of peach-bamboo infusion and drink first. Recite:
*"In ritual codes, drink precedes bathing; in scriptural methods, bathing precedes drinking.
Yellow spirits guard the opening; the Azure Emperor protects the soul.
Heavenly couriers roar, ten thousand demons lose their essence.
Corpse-blood is wholly cleansed; green worms vanish in form.
The Seven Po dissolve and transform; purple clouds arise of themselves.
Roam and feast in the Great Primordium; exalted perfected ones join in kinship."*

When dressing, recite:
*"Divine youths attend my robes; jade maidens burn incense.
Ascend to bow in the scripture chamber, where jade tones resound like chimes.
Deliver my seven ancestors, dispelling filth and calamity.
Prolong years and preserve existence; the cloud-rooted elixir endures."*

Enter the chamber and sit in quietude. Envision the void’s profundity, above the azure skies and purple clouds, the Thirty-Two Heavens’ Emperors in regal attire, holding jade tablets, standing upright, arrayed in all directions like stars encircling the Pole, in the manner of the audience at the Primordial Pearl.

Then strike the teeth once and, with focused mind, bow to each Heavenly Emperor in turn—this suffices as a simplified method.

Another method: envision the Thirty-Two Heavens’ golden towers and jade palaces, each Emperor dwelling within, then bow in the mind. Yet merely imagining the towers, halls, and palaces becomes cumbersome and taxing.

Once settled, face east and recite the scripture while bowing in the heart, beginning with the Great Sovereign Yellow Once-Heaven. Next, envision green, yellow, and white clouds of qi emerging from the Three Elixir Fields, filling the chamber in misty abundance, ascending to merge with the Primordial, Mysterious, and Original Three Qi of the Three Realms, blending with heaven and earth to pervade the ten directions. For the Three Qi all arise from the One Qi, and dwelling within the Three Qi manifests the adept’s practice of preserving the One amid the Three.

Next, envision the Azure Dragon emerging from the liver on the left, the White Tiger from the lungs on the right, the Vermilion Bird from the heart in front, the Dark Warrior from the kidneys behind, the Lion from the Lower Elixir Field below, and the White Cranes from behind the eyebrows—six each, arrayed to left and right. Behind the eyebrows lie the two small cavities of the Six Harmonies’ abode, from which a slender moon emerges: the sun as a purple-red light with nine rays, the moon as a yellow-white light with ten rays, each nine inches from the face, their radiance and mist filling the chamber in resplendent gold and jade. The rays return into the nose, permeating the four inches behind the brain at the Golden Flower Palace, where a wheel-like orb appears at the nape, vast as a chariot wheel, its luminosity blazing across the ten directions.

Once this vision is clear, recite the secret incantation—speaking aloud while the ears hear no sound is the secret incantation:
*"Supreme Mysterious Primordial Most High Dao Lord, summon forth from within your servant’s body the Three and Five Merit Officials, the left and right attending messengers, the incense-attending Golden Youths, the message-transmitting Jade Maidens, the Five Emperors’ direct talismans, and the daily incense officials—thirty-two each."*

These lines alone constitute the secret incantation; no other incantation exists. The following text is drawn from the scripture’s purport.

Envision each figure standing solemnly in attendance before you.

Draw qi thirty-two times—inhale, do not exhale. Another method: inhale through the nose, beginning with the Yellow Once-Heaven, permeating the entire form, thoroughly saturating within and without.

Facing east—the direction of longevity, revered by all heavens—burn incense, compose yourself, focus the mind, and recite with measured voice. Mere hasty recitation yields no benefit; errors may arise. Re-read the preceding thirty characters unhurriedly. Do not rush for the sake of completing repetitions, lest the effort be in vain. Modulate the voice in chanting to harmonize spirit and soul, ensuring the chamber’s incense qi remains unbroken.

For the first recitation, read from the preface to the end. Thereafter, begin with the *Original Beginning’s Mysterious Numinous Treasure Fundamental Chapter*, completing ten cycles as one full recitation. If urgent matters arise, briefly pause, then resume envisioning and recite the preface ten times as prescribed.

Upon completion, compose the spirit, still the mind, and gather in the Merit Officials, Jade Maidens, and others, saying:
*"Your servant has finished reciting the scripture. The Three and Five Merit Officials, left and right attending messengers, incense-attending Golden Youths, message-transmitting Jade Maidens, Five Emperors’ direct talismans, and daily incense officials—thirty-two each—who emerged from your servant’s body, now return to their golden chambers and jade halls. Those on the left return to the left; those on the right return to the right. Let none be misplaced. When summoned again, they shall arrive as before."*

It has long been heard that scripture recitation is the path of spirit refinement and the foremost practice of pure cultivation. First, one must grasp the scripture’s essential meaning; next, clarify the visualization during recitation. Read the text to comprehend its significance; follow its methods to still the spirit. Practiced outwardly, it can aid beings and establish merit. Cultivated inwardly, it can enable transcendence and deliverance from the world. Whether the spirit is enlightened depends on the practitioner.

If one merely recites with the mouth while the heart strays, speaks of integrity while acting in filth, voices the scripture’s words without cease yet harbors wicked thoughts, from youth to old age the practice yields no fruition—how then can one demand karmic response from ten thousand recitations?

Moreover, the profound principles within the scriptures were already mastered by perfected ones of ancient times, who first penetrated their chapters and thereby attained the extraordinary. On the days of practicing the scriptural methods, one should bathe in fragrant waters, envision the orb at the nape radiating light across the ten directions, and only then, with clarity, recite the secret incantation. This follows the stabilization of visualization.

Thereafter, secretly invoke the Supreme Mysterious Primordial Most High Dao Lord, summoning forth the Merit Officials and scribes from within your servant’s body. The secret incantation is not meant to be heard by the ears, ensuring the mind’s focus and the hundred spirits’ solemn guard. This expresses the intent of purifying the hall, practicing cultivation, and reciting scriptures to ascend directly to the Thirty-Two Heavens, drawing qi thirty-two times—all actions performed during the secret incantation. The principle is evident and beyond doubt.

Yet here, a spurious segment of secret incantation has been arbitrarily inserted into the scriptural method. Its wording bears no connection to the scripture’s meaning, making its rationale and application difficult to uphold.

The present scripture begins with the Supreme August Yellow Brilliance Heaven, where the Emperor Yulan presides in jade radiance; and the Great Ultimate Pacifying Nurturing Heaven, where the Emperor Daze governs the Dharma Gate—these are the hidden taboo names of the heavens, their secret appellations. By virtue of these, the scripture universally delivers celestial and human beings, its efficacy thus manifest: this is the first chapter. The first chapter speaks of the flying aerial sounds of the Desire Realm, extending to the point where the five destinies are about to turn—what then shall I do? This refers to the demon-kings’ chants in the aerial spaces above the Three Realms. Reciting them ten thousand times ensures the demon-kings’ protection and welcome, yet if one leaks or grows arrogant, calamity befalls even the seven generations of ancestors: this is the second chapter.

It is then summarized: these two chapters together comprise the hidden secret sounds of the celestial emperors of the heavens and the numinous demon-kings. The celestial emperors refer to the taboo names of the thirty-two heavens in the first chapter, while the hidden secret sounds of the numinous demon-kings refer to the demon-kings’ songs of the Three Realms. Thus it is said that both are the words of the Great Brahma. The phrase “both are” collectively refers to these two chapters. The meaning flows in unbroken sequence, the purport seamlessly connected—how could any addition or deletion be permitted?

Yet some claim that before these two chapters, there is missing text, that there were originally other words not included in the scripture. They have therefore fabricated two chapters to deceive later learners. The foolish, credulous of such proliferation, have added secret incantations and forged two chapters. These are not continuations from the Tiantai Dharma tradition but originated during the Liu-Han period. Now such theories have spread throughout the regions east and west of the Yangzi. However, such rumors cease before the discernment of the wise; men of insight and understanding will surely reject them together, preventing the further spread of heterodox doctrines—this would be most excellent.

In all scripture recitation and visualization, the inner responds to the outer. The One Qi divides into three, forming the Mysterious Primordial Beginning Three Qi. At the inception of the One Qi, there is no form, no name; when the Three Qi divide, they become the Three Honored Ones. Heaven employs this qi to initiate the creation of the cosmos; humans receive this qi to generate and nurture their bodies. Thus, the Three Qi issuing from within the body interlace throughout the chamber, ascending to resonate with the Three Qi in the heavens, filling the six directions. By preserving the inner truth, the outer truth naturally responds; by settling the spirit, heaven and earth all return. With time, one merges with the Dao and attains authenticity, transmuting into immortality and altering one’s substance. This is neither solely external nor neither internal nor external. Let the scholar examine this in detail.

The Liu-Han period refers to the Five Dynasties era.

Here ends *The Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure, Scroll Five*
*Here begins The Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure, Scroll Six*

**The Jade Slips of Numinous Chapters, Section on □□□□□□□**

Compiled by Jin Yunzhong, Registrar of the Southern Bureau of the Numinous Treasure Daoist Masters, Provisional Attendant of the Right in the Office of the Initial Repository

□□□□□□□ □□□□□□ □□□□□□ □□□□□□ □, □, □, □, □, □, □, □ *hong*, *ji*, *ji*, *fangzhong*, *biaode*, *feng*

The above forty-one characters are to be inscribed in cinnabar upon yellow paper. Upon entering the chamber, one recites them in silent meditation, or cuts them into fine circles, or burns them to ash and mixes with water in secrecy. Then, invoking the Most High, one purifies the water and ingests it.

**Oral Petition:**
*"Your servant [Name] humbly states: This servant, a walking corpse of the dusty realm, bears a coarse and humble form. By fortunate karmic destiny, I have been graced by the true wind. It is my duty to inwardly refine form and spirit, outwardly dispel delusion and falsehood, assist the great transformation of heaven and earth, and uphold the primal principles of the Dao and virtue. Yet my heart remains as obstructed as thatch, unable to discern the signs of qi. Having witnessed the Jade Slips of the Numinous Treasure, I know they can record qi and gather spirit. Today, in this pure hall, I perform the rites, ingesting the talisman and invoking qi. Reverently, I contemplate the Most High, the formless and nameless Perfect Great Dao, who initiated the root of yin and yang, established the embryo of heaven and earth. In compassion for the ignorance of later learners, You universally bestow the primordial true qi, infusing it within the four limbs and hundred bones, steaming the five viscera and six palaces. May it grant penetrating vision, nothing left unpervaded. By wielding this dharma, all demons are vanquished; the three disasters do not approach, and a hundred blessings converge. May I soon encounter a perfected one and swiftly receive true transmission."*

*"With utmost reverence, I present this oral petition. Your servant, trembling with awe, bows his head to the ground, prostrates twice, and respectfully speaks."*

The essence of the Jade Slips may be summarized thus: This is the ultimate origin of the Great Dao—ineffable, ungraspable by reason. Wondrous existence, wondrous non-existence—how could it reside in form or trace? Yet since the establishment of ritual methods, these numinous sounds have been translated to propagate true transformation. Thus, the written talismans and their strokes cannot be dispensed with.

Other versions record the □□ taboo names of heaven and earth, the □□ taboo names of the sun and moon, the radiant branches of the Dao: General Liang Gaojian, General Shuang; the inner taboo names of the Emperors of the Sun and Moon: *xuan*, *kuo*, *yi*, *gou*, *bi*, *qian*, *run*, *chang*, *kai*, *yu*; the taboo name of the Jade Sovereign; □□□□□□ the taboo names of the Southern Dipper; □□□□□□□ the taboo names of the Northern Dipper; (□□□ the taboo names of the Three Terraces; *hong*, *ji*, *ji* the inner taboo names of the Three Heavens; *yan*, *shan* the hidden taboo names of the Three Heavens; *fangzhong*, *biaode*, *feng* the true taboo names of the Three Heavens; □□□ the true taboo names of the Three Masters; *qiaoguangyin* the taboo names of the Three Masters; □ the taboo name of Zhenwu; □ the taboo name of Tianyou; □□□□□ the taboo names of the Five Marchmounts; □□□ the taboo names of the Three Paths; □□□□□□ the taboo names of the Six Ding; □□□□□□ the taboo names of the Six Jia; □□□□□□□ the inner taboo names of the Divine Tiger Lady: He □, Qiao □, Hou □, Wei □, Zhang □, Liu □; Jiang Ren’gui; the taboo names of the Great Sage Divine Tiger: □, □, □, □, □, □, □, □; Cui Shuxuan, Lu Jiquan, Deng Hengwen, Dou Yangguang (also named Yang Yanzhi); the taboo names of the Supreme Heavenly Perfected: Taiyi Heavenly Perfected, Taiyi Primordial Perfected, True Immortal Perfected One; the three true taboo names: *Dongxuanqian*; the taboo name of the Northern Culmen: *Tianming Changren Huan Ning*; the taboo name of the Supreme Emperor: □□□ *Wuyou Shou*; the taboo name of Taiyi: □□□□□□□; the taboo names of thunder and rain.

In total, one hundred and sixty-five characters comprise the Jade Slips. Additionally, there is a silent petition, recorded in the second section. The language may seem plain and unrefined, yet it does not touch the true essence of the Great Dao. For instance, the seven characters *kui*, *zhi*, *pi*, *ao* are found in the *Jade Chapters* and astronomical texts as star names. Other terms, such as the inner taboo names of the Three Heavens and the hidden taboo names of the heavens, are celestial sounds, not of this world’s script. They harmonize with the sounds of heaven, embodying the principle of sympathetic resonance.

Heaven and earth are the forms of the Dao; primordial qi is its root. Before the separation of the One, there was no form, no name. When heaven and earth first divided, writing had not yet been established. As celestial patterns took shape and earthly forms solidified, the ruler of heaven was simply called the Supreme Emperor. Later, as numinous chapters leaked secrets and fire refined the firmament, qi was bestowed to form writing, and talismanic diagrams gradually emerged. In the middle antiquity, teachings were established, translated into worldly script. Thus, heavenly perfected ones acquired titles, stellar lodgings gained names, astronomical canons were compiled, and earthly principles were distinguished. Hence, the scriptures contain the hidden names of the heavens—these are the names and titles of the celestial sovereigns and perfected ones. If we were to directly state the names of heaven as □ and earth as □, we would impose designations upon the unnameable. Though there may be some basis for this, it is unwise to divulge them carelessly, lest we be ridiculed by those of profound understanding.

Here, we compile forty-nine characters from the ancient Numinous Treasure methods, remnants from after the separation of heaven and earth, when scriptures and decrees had already emerged—merely the names of stellar images and numinous entities, slightly easier to verify in dharma texts and scriptural records. To claim that heaven and earth have surnames and names would be as absurd as the frivolous debates of the *Tai Mi*. Furthermore, ancient methods include internal refinement techniques: inscribe the Jade Slips’ forty-nine characters in cinnabar, place them in a small bottle, seal with seven measures of pure earth, and at dawn recite the incantation, drawing the qi of the five directions to blow into the bottle. Beginning on a *jiazi* day, after the second *jiazi* cycle, retrieve the Jade Slips from the bottle and burn them for ingestion. In ancient methods, this is called the *Internal Refinement of the Treasure Repository*. Since we have already presented the oral petition and ingested the Jade Slips, this method is not separately expounded here. It is overly bound to form and trace, not the direct and easy path.
