Nevertheless, as it exists in ancient texts, we dare not omit it, hence its outline is appended here.

**Section on the Three Mornings’ Radiant Luminaries**
The sun and moon adorn the heavens; the Dark Dipper stands at the center. Harmonizing the five planets, they regulate and rectify yin and yang.

The Three Mornings’ Radiant Luminaries govern the fundamental principles, their brilliance illuminating the six directions. Through them, the Three Powers are established, and the myriad beings draw sustenance to come into existence. Humans alone receive the harmonious balance of centrality, forming their upright physical bodies. If one can cultivate and refine spirit and qi, moderate and harmonize temperament, maintain external stillness and internal clarity, and align movement with the celestial measures, then one may gather and ingest the radiant luminaries, summon and absorb their numinous effulgence, drawing them into the body. Therein, the hundred spirits are purified and refined, and when this is extended throughout the world, the multitudes receive its blessings. As for the spreading of qi and the writing of talismans, these are but secondary matters.

If the purity of qi does not abide in the breast, or if the turbidity of emotions obstructs the numinous palace, then even if one obtains divine texts and secret incantations and directly encounters the Three Mornings, it will be in vain. The esoteric secrets of the Highest Numinous Treasure and the August Void begin with accumulating the One to generate the Three. When the heart and the Dao are united, one ascends to the realm of the Numinous Treasure. For those of the next rank, the light of the Three Mornings serves as the pivotal mechanism of the Numinous Treasure. From this passage, it may be known that Jin Guangsheng attained the Dao—his words are most wondrous.

The Divine Lord of the Eastern Minister, Controller of Destinies, said: Master Wang was once bestowed *The Supreme Clarity Hall’s Mysterious and True Upper Scripture*. After purifying his fast and resting his roots, he visualized the sun and moon within his mouth—by day, the sun; by night, the moon—each as large as a ring. The sun was crimson with nine rays of purple light, and the moon was yellow with ten rays of white light. He visualized swallowing the luminous essence of their rays, practicing this in secret without count. When not engaged in this visualization, he caused the sun and moon to return and reside in the Hall of Clarity on his face—the sun on the left, the moon on the right—so that the two luminaries merged their qi with the pupils of his eyes. This Dao can gather and circulate generative essence, harmonize the hun-soul and spirit, command the attendance of the Six Ding spirits, and secure the protection of celestial soldiers. This is the Dao of the Highest Perfected.

*The Scripture of the Supreme Mystery* must first be sworn to before practice, and only after practice may one hear the Dao of jade pendants and golden earrings. Ji Wei, the younger brother of Lord Mao, once maintained a long fast for three years before achieving it. Only after exhausting his solitary devotion was he able to attain it, whereupon his body became suffused with divine light, and only then did he receive the scripture. This is the Dao of the Mysterious and True—essential yet not burdensome. I have always treasured and guarded it, keeping it close at hand, and thus reveal it only to those who are cautious and discreet.

The *Supreme Scripture of the Mystical and True* had not yet descended to the world when the Perfected of the Great Void, the Red Lord of Southern Marchmount, transmitted this inner method: On the fifth night of each lunar month at midnight, visualize the solar emblem within the heart, as if the sun enters through the mouth, illuminating the heart’s interior and merging its radiance with the sun’s light. When complete, one should feel the heart grow warm, its rosy glow suffusing the face. After a long while, recite the incantation:

*"Great brightness nurtures essence,
Within, the cinnabar heart is refined.
Radiance merges in union,
Divine perfected ones come to seek."*

Upon finishing the incantation, swallow saliva nine times. Repeat this practice on the twenty-fifth and twenty-ninth days of the month. It sharpens perception, unblocks the hundred passages, imparts a jade-like luminosity to the face, and a golden luster to the body. After fifteen years of practice, the Great One will dispatch a treasure chariot to welcome the adept to the Great Empyrean. Though this method should be performed frequently, it need not be confined to these specific days. This passage is excerpted from *The Supreme Scripture for Dispelling Demons*.

The method of the Perfected of Eastern Flower for absorbing the solar and lunar emblems: Men absorb the solar emblem, women the lunar emblem. Practicing this daily without fail renders one keen and luminously clear, causes the five viscera to flourish, refines the hun-soul and po-soul, harmonizes the six bowels, and is the Dao of immortality and deathlessness.

**Solar Emblem**　**Lunar Emblem**

The Lady of Southern Marchmount said: The Palace of Great Square Jasper is the abode where the Azure Lord often resides. Those above are all lofty immortals of heaven, the lords and ministers of the Great Ultimate, and the dwelling place of the various Controllers of Destiny. Even those who have already attained the Dao and become perfected still practice the method of absorbing the solar and lunar rays. Simply visualize within the heart an emblem the size of a coin, crimson in color. Then visualize the sun’s nine rays ascending from the heart through the throat to the teeth, where the radiant beams return to the stomach. After a long while, with eyes closed, clearly visualize the heart and stomach, then exhale qi and rinse the mouth with saliva thirty-nine times before stopping. Perform this thrice daily. After one year of practice, all illnesses will vanish at once.

After five years of practice, the body will radiate luminous splendor; after eighteen years, one will surely attain the Dao. Walking beneath the sun, one will cast no shadow, and repel all malevolent spirits, ghosts, and inauspicious qi. Constantly visualize the sun within the heart and the moon within the *Niwan* (Mud-Palace). At night, absorb the moon’s essence: visualize the moon’s ten white rays descending from the brain into the throat, without passing through the teeth, then returning to the stomach, following the same method as solar absorption.

The above methods are those of the various Perfected Ones, recorded in the *Upper and Middle Chapters of the Great Wisdom Sutra*. By practicing them diligently, one will surely witness the Great Peace.

It is further said: The Way of visualizing the sun in the heart and the moon in the *Niwan* is simple and easily attainable. If practiced without interruption, it eliminates the Three Corpses, a hundred illnesses, and a thousand afflictions—it is the Way of refining the hun-soul and restraining the po-soul. When the sun and moon perpetually illuminate the body’s center, no ghost can escape its form. The Azure Lord now practices this; I am one such practitioner. I now impart this to you, that you may secretly teach it to those of sincere intent. This Way may also be practiced alongside the precious scriptural methods of solar and lunar absorption, and combining them is likewise excellent. The Purple Text contains sixteen characters for the sun and twenty-four for the moon.

The immortals perform a thousand tasks day and night yet feel no fatigue, for they are illuminated by the utmost diligence in the Dao—this must not be neglected. These are the words the Heavenly Ones imparted to Perfected Yang.

For ordinary practitioners, constantly visualize their own form as if seated before them, facing the Emperor on High, with the radiance of the sun and moon fully illuminating their body. The sun is on the left, the moon on the right, each nine inches from the face. Upon completing the visualization, knock the teeth thrice and softly recite the incantation:
*"Primal Origin, Supreme Perfected,
Dual Effulgences, Two Mysteries.
On the right, restrain the seven po;
On the left, embrace the three hun.
May my spirit be luminous,
And ever dwell with the divine."*

After reciting, knock the teeth twenty-one times, swallow saliva seven times, and cease.

This is the Way of the Thearch for refining the form, restraining the hun-soul, and controlling the po-soul, enabling one to attain spiritual clarity and the immortality of the divine transcendents.

**Upper Clarity Purple Text Method of Ingesting Qi**
*(Also called: The Crimson Elixir, Golden Essence, Stone Radiance, Water Mother, Jade Embryo Scripture)*

At sunrise, face east, knock the teeth nine times, and softly recite the names of the solar soul and the solar emperor:
*"Solar soul, Crimson Radiance,
Illuminating Unity, Verdant Veil.
Returning clouds, Scarlet Youth,
Mysterious Whirlwind, Blazing Image."*

After reciting these sixteen characters, clench the fists and visualize the five-colored flowing clouds within the sun approaching and enveloping the body, with the sunlight and radiant clouds entering the mouth.

**Upper Clarity Purple Text Method of Ingesting Lunar Essence**

At moonrise, face west, knock the teeth ten times, and softly recite the names of the lunar soul and the Lunar Lady:
*"Lunar soul, Warm and Serene,
Fragrant and Luminous, Veiled in Void.
Graceful, Empty, Spirit-Orchid,
Lush Blossoms, Curved Petals.
Pure Gold, Clear Tomb,
Luminous Countenance, Pristine Standard."*

After reciting these twenty-four characters, close the eyes, clench the fists, and visualize the five-colored essence-light of the moon entering the mouth. Also perceive within the moonlight a yellow qi, the size of an eye’s pupil, called the *Flying Yellow, Lunar Radiance, Jade Embryo Essence*. Those who cultivate this Way become immortals who ride the sun and moon.

The above methods are drawn from the *Upper Scripture* and various passages in the *Declarations of the Perfected*, representing the gateway to the practices of the loftiest transcendents. If the mind is not yet pure and the spirit not yet settled, one cannot hope for spiritual efficacy. Those whose strength is insufficient may begin with simpler methods of visualizing the spirits and invoking qi, which, though similar to common practices, can still yield true resonance and numinous response if pursued with utmost sincerity. Yet these remain within the realm of seeking through form and trace, as outlined in the following section.

**Method of Drinking the Dipper’s Radiance**

On the nights of the seventh, seventeenth, and twenty-seventh days of each month, when the moon and stars shine brightly and heaven and earth are resplendent, at dusk face the Dipper, burn incense, form the Dipper mudra, and from the hour of *xu* to *chen*, knock the teeth seven times—once for each recitation of a Star Lord’s name. First exhale turbid qi three times, then recite the incantation:
*"Mighty and numinous,
Divine radiance of the Seven Stars.
Inwardly and outwardly upright,
Merge with me now!"*
*(Swiftly, as the law commands.)*

After reciting, visualize the seven rays of starlight descending into the mouth, inhale and drink seven mouthfuls, then vigorously rinse with saliva and swallow. Calm the spirit and bow twice. Recite:
*"Divine radiance pours in,
Filling the five viscera and six bowels.
Preserve the true, expel the impure,
Swiftly, as the law commands!"*

With prolonged practice, efficacy will manifest in dreams of the sun, moon, and stars, or visions of dragons and tigers, thunder and lightning—these are the steps to ascent.

**Method of Absorbing Solar Radiance**

At dawn before sunrise, burn incense, face east, settle the qi, and stabilize the spirit. As the sun begins to rise, bow twice and close the eyes. Assume the proper posture, invoke the Solar Emperor and the divine immortals of the solar palace, and beseech them to descend their numinous rays to bathe your body. Pray for the blossoming of the five viscera and the radiance of the body. Silently recite the sixteen-character solar incantation, draw in the light, and swallow it until the abdomen is full. Bow twice and withdraw, continuing to absorb and swallow the light without fixed limit.

**Method of Absorbing Lunar Radiance**

At dusk as the moon begins to rise, face the moonlight, settle the qi, and stabilize the spirit. Bow twice and close the eyes. Assume the proper posture, invoke the Lunar Thearch and the divine immortals of the lunar palace, and beseech them to descend their numinous rays to bathe your body. Pray for the blossoming of the five viscera and the radiance of the body. Silently recite the twenty-four-character lunar incantation, draw in the moon’s white light, swallow it until the abdomen is full, then bow twice and withdraw. From the first crescent to the full moon, cease absorption after the full moon, as the lunar light wanes. Resume the practice the following month as before.

As a humble student of the middle way, I cannot claim mastery of these profound mysteries. Yet from the teachings of masters and friends, and glimpses of the scriptures and canons of our tradition, I have gained some insight—how could I remain silent? I share this in the hope that fellow seekers may benefit.

The Three Dawns are also called the Three Lights or the Three Marvels of Heaven, namely the sun, moon, and stars. The stellar bodies are too numerous to enumerate in full.

Beyond the Celestial Throne, only the Central Dipper stands preeminent among the constellations, regulating the celestial meridians and serving as the source of generation and transformation, the office of the throat and tongue—thus the pivot of all stars, and together with the sun and moon, the Three Lights.

When the Great Ultimate first arose, the pure *qi* formed heaven, and the radiant essence of *qi* became the sun, moon, and stars. The Dipper’s handle revolves at the center of heaven, and below, the Five Peaks and Four Waterways, the Nine Provinces and their territories, all living beings, mountains, rivers, grasses, and trees—none exist without relying on it for sustenance, all arising by its agency. Without it, heaven would lack the means to rectify its principles; without it, humanity could not refine form and substance.

Those who pursue the higher studies, cultivating subtle *qi* and emptiness, thereby illuminate the mystery within mystery and awaken to the Dao within the Dao. When primordial *qi* is unified as one, there is no need to draw in radiance or gather *qi*—yet this is no ordinary discourse for the common world.

From this arise methods and techniques: what art does not depend on the Three Lights? What practice can dispense with the Central Dipper? For those who tread the highest path, stillness and seated meditation, inward focus and *qi*-absorption remain essential even after attaining perfection. Those of lesser attainment may burn incense, gaze upon celestial images, recite incantations, and drink in light—though their forms may yet be constrained, their single-minded devotion may still yield response.

Other methods of *qi*-absorption follow the sun’s movement—one degree every twelve hours—and the moon’s shift of two palaces every five days, with accumulated minutes and calculations of waxing and waning. The Dipper’s pointer aligns with *Hekui* at *Xu* and *Tiangang* at *Chen*; the monthly determinant is fixed by the central *qi*, its direction calculated by the hour. Only then does one face the proper direction to draw in *qi*.

Though these methods exhaust their subtleties, they must not be mistaken for the true path of attainment, for they are not the primary focus of the supreme scriptures. The *Tianxin* Orthodox Method takes the Three Lights as its foundation, fulfilling its duty to respond to the world and dispel malevolence, and establishing the means for great transformation. In all its practices, past and present, the Three Lights cannot be set aside. The methods of orientation, hand seals, and stepping patterns follow a graded progression—no stage may be skipped.

The comprehensive and detailed teachings serve to empower the use of talismanic water. Those who grasp their essentials will indeed be persons of merit. Yet one must not dismiss these as mere commonplace sayings, for everything hinges on whether the heart is unified or divided.

As for the use of Sanskrit in solar and lunar incantations, this arose through long transmission in later ages. The supreme scriptures contain no Sanskrit; earlier masters have already debated this. In recent times, practitioners of the *Lingbao* tradition seek to establish their own school and refuse to align their teachings with the *Zhengyi* registers. Thus, they omit discussions of the Three Lights from the *Lingbao* texts, disdaining any resemblance to *Tianxin* thunder rites—yet how can the *Lingbao* tradition truly abandon the Three Lights?

The vault of heaven is not low, nor are the stars’ brilliance distant. Yet humanity dwells between them in solitude. By outward conditions, obtaining their *qi* seems difficult; by principle, however, it remains attainable, for all things possess it.

The conch and clam absorb the moon’s essence over time, until their shells glow with luminous clarity, producing pearls of radiance. The rhinoceros gazes upon the stars and moon, and eventually, halos form within its twin horns, taking the shape of stars or the moon. These creatures, though devoid of intellect, still receive the essence of the Three Dawns. Did they employ incantations, seals, or directional alignments? No—their hearts are free of thought and distraction, undisturbed and unadulterated. They see the moon and absorb the moon; they behold the stars and face the stars, single-minded and undivided. Thus, what is high and distant becomes near. How then can humans, the most spiritually endowed of beings, fall short of these creatures?

The trouble lies in humanity’s spirit being submerged amid worldly affairs, its intelligence flowing into schemes and stratagems. Even those who study the Dao often favor the strange and marvelous, their minds growing ever more scattered, their karmic responses ever more distant. This stems from exerting effort on the periphery while neglecting the root, failing to concentrate on the essential, and becoming mired in techniques. Without guidance from a true master, their labor spans eons in vain.

Visualization and invocation are not without purpose, but one must first settle the mind and stabilize the spirit. Focus the heart on the radiance of the Three Dawns, concentrate the will in a single thought of sincerity, and strive for resonance and communion—all while remaining unwavering and unyielding.

A survey of various methods for absorbing and refining *qi* reveals that most are compiled in this present work, all suitable for practice. However, calculations of orientation, measurements of *qi*-pulses, and similar details are not included here. If a method can yield verification, why fear its complexity? This is not an attempt to distinguish *Tianxin* practices but rather to acknowledge that the *Lingbao* teachings encompass the highest Dao. The preceding methods are appropriate for application, and thus should not be casually adopted from lesser sources.

The eighteenth fascicle of the *Lingbao Sutra* from Tiantai, titled *Methods for Latitudinal Cultivation*, details the practice of visualizing and communing with the Dipper, claiming the power to alter the registers of death. It instructs the construction of a bamboo frame, suspending a mirror to form the Dipper’s shape, stepping the Dipper’s pattern while lighting lamps, and using seven feet of crimson silk inscribed with the Dipper’s secret names, tied beneath the forehead and knotted at the back of the head. Wielding a sword, one sprays water and strikes a bowl forty-nine times, absorbing the *qi* of the Dipper’s stars, aiming to perceive the Dipper and River stars to attain immortality. Additionally, on the three seventh-day periods of each month at the *Hai* hour, one enters a chamber, places an incense burner atop the head in the manner of *lianding* refinement, visualizes the smoke ascending to pay homage to the Dipper, and then proceeds to the practice of exiting the spirit to commune with the primordial.

These methods resemble sorcery and assume the guise of shamans. Moreover, in the pursuit of immortality, propriety and ritual come first. The *Lingbao* tradition is the teaching of the Filial Piety Bright King, with filial devotion and fraternal respect as its core. Loyalty, integrity, filial piety, and reverence can move heaven and earth, stirring the spirits. As for abiding in the world, preserving form, prolonging life, and averting death—these require inner refinement and outer merit. When one’s time aligns with the ruler’s, one may bring great benefit to the world, eliminate great harm, extend vast kindness to all beings, and bestow blessings upon the four directions.

Before mastering the winds and clouds, one must withdraw one’s light and conceal one’s traces, guarding the body and retreating into seclusion. To the utmost of one’s strength, one ought to accumulate merit and establish virtue, aiding beings as the heart inclines and benefiting others according to circumstance—dispensing medicine and talismans, dispelling evil and rescuing from distress, returning to the Dao of utmost truth, and following a teacher of pure correctness. Thus may one’s luminous virtue reach august Heaven, and one’s name be heard in the Jade Palace. At such a time, the register of death may be erased, and the record of life inscribed.

Yet now, one teaches others the demeanor of sorcery and shamans, performing unorthodox nighttime curses and supplications. These practices neither conform to the standards of fasting and altar rites nor adhere to the protocols of memorials and morning devotions. To presume that such means could erase the register of death and inscribe one’s name above is the height of folly.

Looking up to the true teaching of the August Void Emperor, we find the tradition of simplicity and purity, which has not abandoned the ancient models. Thus, we broadly seek among the capped and gowned. Once admitted into the canonical disciplines, one dons the star-crowned cap and feathered robes, holds the tablet and unfurls the altar, enters the oratory to burn incense, and faces the primordial to present matters—like paying reverent homage to one’s lord and father, like standing before the awe-inspiring might of Heaven. Advancing and retreating follow proper form; morning devotions adhere to method. Composed and unhurried, one stabilizes the qi and concentrates the spirit, communing with the true and numinous in the midst of the indistinct, and directing a single thought to the Great Void above.

When concluding one’s words, one must first pray for the myriad years of the lord of the state, then petition for the ascension of the nine generations of ancestors. Only with filial piety and loyalty, upholding propriety and ritual, does one grasp the foundation of the canonical teachings.

The gateway of the Great Dao is utterly upright and free from deviation—how could it ever involve wrapping the head in red silk or wielding blades and chopping implements? To call such things "communing with the Dipper" is to mislead others most grievously.

Yet it takes the sixteen characters of the sun’s essence—Ziwen, Zhong, Rihun, and Zhu Jing—and the twenty-four characters of the moon’s spirit—Yuepo and Aimei Xiao—along with the names of the Dipper stars from Kuí to Piāo, compelling practitioners to invoke their images and summon their qi, then incorporates these into the forty-first section, "Praying for Favor and Atoning for Transgressions," styling it as the "Dao of the Three Luminous Realms of Lingbao" and calling it the "True Qi of the Three Realms."

Having neither examined their origins nor sought to avoid the established names of the Three Lights and Three Mornings, they instead claim uniqueness, renaming the qi of the sun, moon, and stars as the "True Qi of the Three Realms"—how can this be justified? In its eighteenth section, following the Dipper rites, it further introduces a method for "Morning Audience with the Origin," wherein one visualizes the spirits in a manner akin to the protocol of memorial petitions—this ought not be conflated with the Dipper rites.

Moreover, it records talismans for ascending through the fierce winds, the completion of the "Morning Audience with the Three Heavens," the establishment of celestial bureaus, the erection of oratories under exalted names, and daily assemblies of the immortal ministries within the oratory to dispatch spirits for administrative duties—all of it wildly fantastical. Its account of the "Chart of Western Tortoise Mountain" merely recapitulates the generative principles of source, warp, and flow found in the scriptural canons, yet in its delusion, it strays far from the original source.

From the practices of spirit visualization and Dipper rites onward, the text falsely designates its methods as the "Seven Scriptures of Lingbao"—this is incorrect. The seven scriptures and eight wefts of the original canon have already been systematically arranged according to the old format and incorporated into the present work as the sixth section. Scholars ought to examine these matters with equanimity, whereby right and wrong will naturally become distinct. One must not allow such extraneous doctrines to adulterate this book, so that it may truly serve as a reliable guide, as the ancients intended.

**Section on the Correct Perception of the Five Phases** □□□□□□□

**Ingestion of the Dipper Star Names**
For this method, write in cinnabar on yellow silk. Blend with yellow wax to form seven pellets, taking one each day, swallowed with pure water after purifying the mind. After forty-nine days, the eye of wisdom will brighten, enabling the recitation of ten thousand words without faltering or losing focus. □□□□□□.

**Six-Character Healing Method**
For this method, write in cinnabar on yellow paper to cure all illnesses. □□□□□□.

**Internal Infusion of the Six Ding Method**
For this method, at noon on the sixth day, write in cinnabar on yellow paper, forming each pair of characters into one talisman—six characters making three talismans. On the seventh day before dawn, upon waking, take the first two characters and swallow them with pure water. Wait and listen; when the first sound of a person is heard, inhale the qi and swallow it. Repeat this for the middle and lower sets over the next seven days. This is called the *Internal Infusion of the Six Ding*. After a full month of practice, whenever encountering malevolent spirits causing confusion, silently recite once, close the eyes for a long moment, and the Six Ding will report to the heart-spirit. Whatever emerges in the mind will reveal the cause of the ghost’s mischief, including the color of its garments and the number of its followers—all will be verified. These are the names of the Six Ding. □□□□□□.

The *Method of Dispatching Malevolence with the Six Jia*

This method is used when minor or nascent malevolent spirits commit transgressions. Write the talismans in cinnabar ink, burn them together with gold coins in fire, and the malevolence will immediately be expelled by the Six Generals into the sea, with strange omens appearing in dreams. These are the names of the Six Jia: □, □, □, □, □, □, □, □.

---

**The Talismanic Method for Treating Poison**

This method is applied when one is harmed by poisonous creatures, suffers from abscesses, swelling, cinnabar tumors, or ailments of the five viscera and six bowels. Write the talisman on the afflicted area, either swallowing it or applying it externally. No more than three characters are needed before recovery is achieved.
霐.

---

**The Method of Ingesting Characters on the Last Day of the Lunar Month**

On the last day of the lunar month, recite the talisman one hundred thousand times, and the memorial will swiftly ascend to the Three Heavens, with responses descending to the mortal realm.
防中表德.

---

**The Method of Reciting Characters on the First Day of the Lunar Month**

On the first day of the lunar month, recite the talisman ten thousand times. Within three months, there will be a response. For all disasters and calamities, silently recite it thirty-two times, and the misfortunes will naturally dissipate.
尝闻.

---

When the Great Ultimate first divided, the One gave rise to the Two, the Two gave rise to the Three, and the Three gave rise to the myriad things. Once the myriad things were established, the Five Qi came into being, originating from the Void and Nothingness. Thus, the Five Elderly Lords of the Dao became the root and origin of the Five Qi, manifesting within the celestial patterns. The Five Stars became the constant luminaries above, while on earth, the Five Peaks stabilized the realm. Among things, Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth formed the Five Phases. In humans, the heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys constituted the body. In affairs, benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust founded states and households.

The forty-nine secret talismanic characters align with the transformations of the Five Phases. When ingested by oneself, they purify the spirit and refine the qi. When applied to others, they dispel illness and expel malevolence. This is akin to summoning water with a *fangzhu* mirror or drawing fire through a yang tunnel—an art of inner resonance and outer response.

If one lacks inner authenticity yet seeks outer responses, or disrupts the Five Phases while desiring the fullness of the Five Qi, the attainment of karmic retribution will be difficult.

In the *Lingbao Methods of Tiantai*, the Five Phases’ true qi of the Jade Tablets is classified as a single category, with the forty-nine characters incorporated into other scrolls. However, the *Incantation for Upholding the Body with the Five Peaks* and methods such as *Shifting Scenery and Penetrating Light* are interspersed among them, obscuring the original text of the Five Phases. Thus, this work adheres strictly to the ancient method without daring to alter it.

*Concluding the Sixth Scroll of the Great Methods of the Upper Clarity and Numinous Treasure*
*Beginning the Seventh Scroll of the Great Methods of the Upper Clarity and Numinous Treasure*

The *Dongxuan Lingbao* Master of the Southern Bureau, Keeper of the Law Canon, Right Assistant of the Golden Harmony Bureau, Quan Tongchu Fu, compiles:

**The Five Sprouts of Internal Refinement**

The Five Sprouts are the Five Qi. In heaven, they are the Five Elder Thearchs; in the scriptures, qi congeals into script, forming the Five Sprouts’ true writ. Across the five directions, they are the Five Constants: the Eastern Azure Thearch, Spirit Awe-Inspiring; the Southern Vermilion Thearch, Blazing Might; the Western White Thearch, White Beckoning Rule; the Northern Black Thearch, Timely Radiance; and the Central Yellow Thearch, Containing the Pivot. In celestial patterns, they are the Five Stars; in terrestrial geography, the Five Peaks; in affairs, the Five Constants; in things, the Five Phases; and in the human body, the Five Viscera.

To cultivate the Dao of the Numinous Treasure and the methods of the Grotto Chamber, one ingests the life-generating qi of the Five Directions’ true perfection to refine the mortal frame.

**The Method of the Five Sprouts**

Invoke the descent of the Five Thearchs and Five Lads into the body, and wear the true writ, so their spirits reside within the Five Viscera to summon the essence of the Five Sprouts. This is practiced according to the four tones.

Regularly, on the day of *Lichun* (Beginning of Spring), at cock’s crow, enter the chamber, face east, and bow nine times. Sit upright, click the teeth nine times, and visualize the Azure Thearch of the Five Directions—the Five Thearchs—with the Azure Thearch governing spring and presiding over the life-generating qi of the east. He is nine inches tall, crowned with a green jade coronet, clad in a nine-qi azure feathered robe, riding a chariot drawn by green dragons, bearing a banner of plumes, followed by the nine myriad officers of *Jiayi* and the Elder of Hu. Suddenly, he transforms, generating azure qi like clouds that envelop and cover your body, entering through your mouth and descending directly into the liver palace. Further visualize Jupiter gleaming brightly in the east, illuminating your body. Then open your eyes, recite the incantation nine times, and swallow the twelve characters of the Eastern True Writ.

**Incantation:**
*"Nine Qi of the Azure Heavens, primordial essence of the Highest Origin.
August Elder, Venerable Spirit, clad in feathered azure.
Commanding the celestial officers, radiant and majestic star.
Scattering brilliance, flowing fragrance, refining and nourishing my form.
Feasting on morning mist, ingesting the essence of wood.
Firmly nurturing the Azure Sprout, preserving and guarding decrepit years.
Viscera brimming, jade mushrooms spontaneously grow.
Prolonging life for eons, countenance returning to youthful infancy.
Five Qi harmoniously merging, heaven and earth in solemn union."*

**The Twelve Characters of the Eastern True Writ**

Regularly, on the day of *Lixia* (Beginning of Summer), at cock’s crow, enter the chamber, face south, and bow three times. Sit upright, click the teeth three times, and visualize the Vermilion Thearch of the south, who governs summer and presides over the life-generating qi of the south. The subsequent procedure is the same as before. He is three inches tall, crowned with a red jade coronet, clad in a three-qi vermilion feathered robe, riding a chariot of cinnabar dragons and jade, bearing a banner of rice, followed by the thirty myriad officers of *Bingding* and the Elder of Yue. Suddenly, he transforms, generating vermilion qi like clouds that envelop and cover your body, entering through your mouth and descending directly into the heart palace. Further visualize Mars gleaming brightly in the south, illuminating your body. Then open your eyes, recite the incantation three times, and swallow the twelve characters of the Southern True Writ.

**Incantation:**

Visualize the Three Qi of the Cinnabar Heavens, the numinous youths of the Vermilion Palace. The Primordial Thearch, riding a tripartite chariot of crimson dragons. Crimson feathered robes take flight, brocade stoles radiant with light. Commanding the numinous officers, they govern the Dao of yin and yang. The Three Qi emit their brilliance, irrigating my Crimson Palace. The Red Child safeguards and stabilizes, refining the sprout and adorning the countenance. At dawn, consume the vermilion radiance, jade mushrooms filling and suffusing. Reversing the flow of kalpas, decrepit bones and youth alike. Longevity spans heaven and earth, eternally enjoyed without end. The body generates water and fire, transforming in a hundred directions.

**The Twelve Characters of the Southern True Writ**

On the day of the Beginning of Autumn, enter the chamber, face west, and bow seven times. Sit upright, click the teeth seven times, and visualize the White Thearch governing as before. He is seven inches tall, crowned with a white jade coronet, clad in a white feathered robe. Riding a chariot of white dragons and jade, bearing a plain banner, followed by the seventy myriad officers of *Gengxin* and the Elder of Mystery. Suddenly, he transforms, generating white qi like clouds that swiftly envelop and cover your body, entering through your mouth and descending directly into the lung palace. Further visualize Venus gleaming brightly in the west, illuminating your body. Then open your eyes, recite the incantation seven times, and swallow the twelve characters of the Western True Writ.

**Incantation:**
The Seven Gates of Golden Clouds, vast and luminous in the Western Splendor. Within resides the Pale Sovereign, the abode of the Primordial Thearch. Riding a tripartite chariot of white dragons, the Seven Qi towering. Lingering at the Jade Gate, scattering essence like crimson auroras. Venus emits its brilliance, fragrant mushrooms abundant. The mysterious profundity nurtures my body, cultivating my pale sprout. Bright stones gleam freshly, enduring through ten thousand kalpas. Sustained by flowing springs, nourished by Grand Harmony. The Nine Heavens’ Thearch bestows jade splendor. Preserving the years, halting the whitening, complexion and radiance flourish. Abiding with heaven and earth, the Three Luminaries share eternity.

**The Twelve Characters of the Western True Writ**

At the hour of the cock’s crow on the day of the Beginning of Winter, enter the chamber, face north, and bow five times. Strike the teeth five times, and visualize the Black Thearch, five inches in height, crowned with a dark jade coronet, clad in a robe of kingfisher feathers, riding a jade chariot drawn by black dragons, with a black banner borne before him, accompanied by five hundred thousand officials of the *ren* and *gui* cycles and the Qiang and Lao spirits descending. In an instant, the generative *qi* transforms and billows like clouds, resembling the light of shooting stars, enveloping one’s body and entering directly into the Palace of the Kidneys. Then visualize the Water Star gleaming brightly in the north, illuminating one’s body. Open the eyes, recite the incantation five times, and swallow the Twelve Characters of the Northern True Writ. The incantation reads:

The Northern Mysterious Heavens, the Five *Qi* scatter numinous radiance.
Above resides the Great Spirit, the Primordial Elder of Original Essence.
Riding dragons, bearing banners, they roam and feast in the Upper Capital.
This is called Primordial Auspiciousness, felicitous clouds spread their glory.
Flying mushrooms stream forth, abundant and overflowing in all four directions.
Jade maidens of mysterious profundity bathe my form.
The Palace of the Kidneys is filled and stabilized, withered sprouts grow firm.
The Five Palaces receive the true, ascending to commune with the divine.
The Five Elders descend to welcome, the Dao of immortality is swiftly attained.
Transforming water and fire, clad in robes of kingfisher feathers.
Soaring through the Great Void, roaming to the Purple Court.
Lifespan equal to the Three Luminaries, enduring through ten thousand kalpas.

The Twelve Characters of the Northern True Writ.

On the days of the equinoxes and solstices, enter the chamber, face the five directions, and bow twelve times. Strike the teeth twelve times, and visualize the Yellow Thearch, one foot and two inches in height, crowned with a yellow jade coronet, clad in a robe of five-colored feathers, riding a jade chariot drawn by yellow dragons, with a yellow banner borne before him, accompanied by one hundred twenty thousand officials of the *wu* and *ji* cycles and the Cang and Lao spirits descending. In an instant, the generative *qi* transforms into yellow clouds, enveloping one’s body and entering directly into the Palace of the Spleen. Then visualize the Earth Star at the center, illuminating one’s body. Open the eyes, recite the incantation twelve times, and swallow the Sixteen Characters of the Central True Writ. The incantation reads:

The Central Great Mountain, the Primordial *Qi* lingers and circles.
Above resides the Primordial Elder, governing the Four Numinous Ones.
Riding yellow dragons, clad in robes of five-colored feathers.
Revolving through the Nine Heavens, turning the jade pivot.
Radiant as the Seven Stars, streaming light scatters its brilliance.
Jade blossoms and fragrant mushrooms flow and soar in abundance.
Bathing my body, the Palace of the Lungs shines forth.
Nurturing the sprout, consuming essence, the myriad spirits all return.
Restraining the *hun* and controlling the *po*, refining the Eight Powers.
Within and without, all is pure and luminous, ever-living and undecaying.
Communing with the true and attaining the numinous, ascending into the Great Subtlety.

The Sixteen Characters of the Central True Writ.

After reciting the incantations, draw in *qi* according to the number of each direction, swallow the saliva, and ingest the True Writ.

**Method for Regular Ingestion**
At the hour of the cock’s crow, when the yang light first appears, face east, strike the teeth according to the number of each direction, rub the palms together until warm, and with the hands, wipe the face and eyes the corresponding number of times. Recite the incantation, beginning from the east and circling once. For the Eastern Blue Sprout, consume the blue sprout and drink the morning blossom. Then, with the tongue, stroke the inner side of the upper teeth, beneath the tongue, and the lips three times. Rinse the mouth until the Jade Spring fills it, then swallow nine times. Draw in the blue *qi* nine times, allowing it to settle in the liver.

For the Southern Vermilion Elixir, consume the vermilion elixir and drink from the Vermilion Pool. Then, with the tongue, stroke the inner side of the lower teeth, lick the tongue, and the lips three times. Rinse the mouth until the Jade Mushroom fills it, then swallow three times. Draw in the red *qi* three times, allowing it to settle in the heart.

For the Central *Wu* and *Ji*, the towering Great Mountain, consume the essence-*qi* and drink the Sweet Spring. Then, with the tongue, stroke the inner and outer sides of the upper and lower teeth, lick the tongue, and the lips. Rinse the mouth until the Jade Spring fills it, then swallow. Draw in the yellow *qi* twelve times, allowing it to settle in the spleen.

For the Western Bright Stone, consume the bright stone and drink the Numinous Liquid. Then, with the tongue, stroke the outer side of the upper teeth, lick the tongue, and the lips. Rinse the mouth until the Jade Mushroom fills it, then swallow seven times. Draw in the white *qi* seven times, allowing it to settle in the lungs.

For the Northern Mysterious Nourishment, consume the mysterious nourishment and drink the Jade Syrup. Then, with the tongue, stroke the inner side of the lower teeth, lick the tongue, and the lips three times. Rinse the mouth until the Jade Mushroom fills it, then swallow. Draw in the black *qi* five times, allowing it to settle in the kidneys.

After completing this, strike the teeth thirty-six times and swallow *qi* thirty-five times. Then recite the general incantation:

White stones towering, flowing springs welling forth,
Caverns like jade nectar—drinking it grants long life,
Extending lifespan.

Recite the incantation’s blossom, with the tongue stroke the upper, lower, and center, allowing the Jade Mushroom to fill the mouth, then swallow three times. Draw in *qi* twenty-five times, guide the *qi* and swallow it. With this, the method is complete.

I have often observed that the Dao of the Numinous Treasure lay hidden at the beginning of the vast primordial chaos, originating in the initial darkness of the cosmic abyss. Its profound mysteries are unfathomable, its wonders beyond measure. From the Middle Antiquity onward, teachings were established and texts bequeathed. Within the orthodox scriptures, myriad methods are fully expounded, yet their efficacy and manifestation depend on the practitioner’s personal attainment.

The method of the Five Sprouts gathers the generative *qi* of the five directions to refine the essence of the five viscera. The *qi* is subtle and elusive, not easily obtained. Thus, one ingests the True Writ to summon it, for *qi* coalesces into script, drawing one to the other. Establishing altars, setting up offerings, bowing with memorials, transcribing petitions, spreading *qi*, inscribing talismans, dispelling demons, and repelling delusions—these are the foremost practices. Refining and removing the yin obscurities, dissolving yin to nurture yang, aligning with the radiance of the Three Mornings.

As for the five viscera within the human body, they are but impure substances. Methods such as visualizing the liver emitting blue *qi* or the lungs emitting white *qi* belong to the practice of visualization and refinement, not to the Five Sprouts. Drawing in the generative *qi* of the eastern direction, ladling the morning blossom of the Wood Palace, infusing it throughout the body, and refining the liver and viscera—this is the meaning of the Five Sprouts. Refining the five *qi* of the five directions to cultivate the five spirits of the five viscera, if practiced long without cessation, how could one not realize their reality?

With prolonged refinement, the *qi* of the person merges with the *qi* of heaven, the spirit of the person unites with the spirit of the Dao—this is also the way of refining the spirit.

Here now is the translation of the *Five Sprouts True Writ*, all of which is secretly contained in the Supreme Scriptures, differing from common techniques. If scholars deeply penetrate its purport, they may activate and practice it. The forty-first section of the Tiantai method, "Praying for Favor and Atoning for Transgressions," expounds upon this, stating: The *Lingbao* possesses the Crimson Writ of Ancestral *Qi*, the numinous treasure of heaven. When it enters the human body, it generates the five-colored numinous mushrooms. This is explained as follows: the eastern blue sprout is the liver, the southern vermilion cinnabar is the heart, the western bright stone is the lungs, the northern mysterious essence is the kidneys, and the central *wu-ji* is the spleen. Curling the tongue to gather saliva, one swallows it according to the directions, regarding the head as Mount Tai. Concluding with the twelve hours of swallowing *qi*, this is called the method of "exchanging bones and transforming form." Yet it contains no invocations, nor any true writ, merely appropriating the meaning of the Five Sprouts and diverting its explanation to another path. It claims that swallowing saliva and *qi*, with fire responding to water and their convergence, forms a diagram of "child and mother, husband and wife," borrowing fragmentary theories from alchemical texts without completeness. While it names itself the numinous treasure of heaven, it directly identifies the Five Sprouts as the five viscera—such explanations are entirely unfit to serve as a method.

In the "Three Palaces Recitation Section" of the *Upper Chapters on Salvation*, radiant brilliance rises, dispelling heavenly calamities above and averting earthly disasters below, externally aiding all beings and internally refining the hundred spirits. The gateway to practice begins with single-minded devotion. The method of recitation focuses on visualizing the luxuriant *qi* and gathering the myriad spirits in their vast array. Thus, one may inwardly refine the body and outwardly permeate all things. If words do not leave the mouth and the ears do not hear sound, it is called "silent recitation." From beginning to end, one maintains visualization, adhering to the ancient method. Entering the oratory, burning incense, settling the mind, and calming the *qi*, one withdraws the light to gaze inward. Ten thousand thoughts do not intrude; sitting upright without leaning or slouching, one ensures the path of the ox-cart remains unobstructed and the *qi* of the dragon and tiger flows ceaselessly. Only then does one recite the scripture, adjusting the gravity of the matter and the internal or external application—whether reciting with spirit, heart, *qi*, or mouth—these correspond to the upper, middle, and lower *dantian*. Beyond this, there is "intent recitation," each with its own purpose: to deliver others from distress and dispel misfortune, to pray for favor or atone for transgressions for oneself, or to harmonize *qi* and time to preserve fortune. For emperors praying for rain or clear skies, aiding the times and rescuing beings, promoting the stagnant and dull, universally delivering the departed souls—whenever matters are urgent, one must enter the chamber, silently recite the divine writ, then proceed with the proper sequence of visualizations in the ritual and offerings. The details are fully set forth in the section on "Recitation, Visualization, and Maintenance." All must conform to the method. The first recitation covers the preface; the second begins with the scripture itself. Ten recitations constitute one cycle. Upon completion, one submits to the officials, the hundred spirits guard their positions, and one secretly presents sincere entreaties, ascending the spirit from the dwelling. This pertains to the fourth weft.

In the *Lingbao* sections compiled by Yunzhong, related matters have already been briefly addressed. Only in the Tiantai method is the "internal recitation" placed at the end of the fortieth section, "Delivering from Distress and Dispelling Disaster," where the deities Taiyi, Siming, Taokang, Wuying, and Baiyuan are each to inscribe the divine writ a thousand times. Another explanation divides internal recitation among the three *dantian*, yet this merely repeats the names without grasping the principle, claiming that in the first month one recites in the upper *dantian*, in the seventh month in the middle *dantian*, and in the tenth month in the lower *dantian*. It further states that the myriad spirits all recite together, leading to purification rituals and prayers where one writes on memorials, "Internally recited the *Dongjing* a thousand times," to offer to the true and dedicate to the deceased. Yet they do not know that the *Great Dongjing True Scripture* consists of thirty-nine chapters, each with two talismans, and belongs to the *Dongzhen* section. The forty chapters in the *Durenjing* method serve to explain the use of the *Durenjing*. The ancients regarded the *Durenjing* as a single scroll containing the wonders of the *Dongjing*, not equating the *Durenjing* itself with the *Dongjing* or placing it before the Celestial Thearch. To take the text of the *Durenjing* and call it the *Dongjing*—is this acceptable?

Another explanation claims it is supremely mysterious and wondrous, obtainable only after disciples exhaust their family wealth to offer to the master, leading its followers to believe it is unheard of in the world and to style themselves as "those who have attained the supreme Dao." A brief outline of its method states: visualize one’s body as withered wood, consumed by a great fire, transformed by harmonious *qi*. The perfected gather the spirit in the upper *dantian*, entering the Great Abyss Palace, pacing the Dipper in practice. There, one recites the *Dongjing* of the Primordial Beginning’s ancestral *qi*. As for refinement and deliverance, it regards only the upper *dantian* as the Celestial Thearch’s abode, the lungs as the Eastern Well, the red heaven within the head as issuing fire, the kidneys as true water, and the nine bends of their channels as the Nine Dark Regions, where the thousand souls and ten thousand spirits are all delivered and transformed. The so-called *Dongjing of the Primordial Beginning*, transmitted from other regions, merely extracts a passage from the *Durenjing* and presents it as such. The Tiantai method, kept secret and practiced in isolation, resembles the Buddhist practice of reciting Sanskrit dhāraṇīs of forty-eight lines, totaling one hundred seventy-six characters, or the mudrā of the Nine Palaces for memorializing the Celestial Thearch—all confined within the body, leading to the claim that one need not bow when paying homage to the true, for the Celestial Thearch does not depart from the mudrā of the Nine Palaces. Yet they do not know that in ancient methods, there exists a practice of not invoking the Purple Spirits, originally intended for those who sit in practice without sleeping. This does not apply to those who follow the regulations and serve the teachings. Moreover, those not yet freed from the worldly net overturn the Nine Palaces with even greater reverence than bowing.

The section on silent recitation exists in ancient methods, but to rename it "internal recitation" is incorrect. To claim that the myriad spirits recite it lacks any basis. The three *dantian* each have their own presiding deities; to divide them by the seventh, first, and tenth months is mistaken. They do not understand that recitation with the heart, *qi*, spirit, or mouth differs in principle, and visualizing the spirit and contemplating the true is not what the Tiantai method calls the "myriad spirits." In ancient methods, silent recitation involves reciting the entire scripture, which encompasses a vast array. By clarifying the spirit and refining the *qi*, one may commune with the true numina.

Should one now select merely a single passage from the scripture to serve as the basis for silent recitation, there is no need to alter its name to "Cave Scripture." Yet to abandon the main text of the original scripture and instead fabricate Sanskrit or foreign proofs is sheer delusion. According to tradition, the *Scripture of Salvation* (*Duren Jing*) originated in primordial antiquity, when the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign inscribed its text to establish the correct intonation. The four translations that entered worldly circulation were already in use by the time of Emperor Wu of Han. Only when Emperor Ming dreamed of the golden figure did the scriptures of the Śākya clan first enter China, and thus did Sanskrit come into being. To now claim that foreign sounds from the Śākya tradition constitute the ancestral *qi* texts within the *Scripture of Salvation*—even a child of three would laugh in disbelief.

In their altar rituals, practitioners sit upright in inner contemplation, claiming that within golden light the celestial script appears, often as a single character. The master admits to seeing only one character, understanding nothing of its meaning, and dares not reveal it. After the ritual, this single character is then interpreted according to the practitioner’s circumstances to divine fortune or misfortune—all derived from its strokes and dots. Though there may be dozens of such characters, the pattern remains the same. Their method begins with claims of light revealing names like Jingming, yet its absurdity and grotesquerie are evident. From silent recitation that perceives characters in luminous vision, it descends into summoning spirits to enter the altar and conduct affairs. Alas, this is the gradual descent from frost to solid ice. A single misguided thought sprouts from impropriety, and a thousand paths and ten thousand byways lead step by step into depravity. One fears that such practices will sink into the lowest depths, where no transgression is beyond reach.

Thus, the oral instructions for recitation must be guarded as secret and not lightly disclosed. Yet to conceal their mechanism entirely would risk leaving learners without a gateway, causing them to fall into the realm of false and heterodox teachings. Therefore, the profound is embedded here, awaiting the learner’s own realization.

The upper *dantian* is the Muddy Pellet, the middle *dantian* is the Crimson Palace, and the lower *dantian* is the Mysterious Pass. The methods include spirit recitation, heart recitation, and *qi* recitation. When words issue from the mouth and sounds are heard by the ear, this is vocal recitation. When the mouth utters no words and the ear hears no sound, this is silent recitation. Silent recitation encompasses differences between heart and *qi*, as well as the category of intent recitation. In all cases, one visualizes the body as the Primordial Beginning, seated upon a five-colored lion in empty space, illuminating inner and outer realms as if dwelling in the radiance of the blazing sun. Following the method in recitation, each has its governing principle: regulating the correct celestial measure, dispelling heavenly calamities, safeguarding and stabilizing the emperor, prolonging the dynasty’s prosperity, extending the years and increasing the lifespan of parents, beseeching blessings and dissolving transgressions—this is one category. Whether for others or oneself, repenting faults and praying for grace, preserving life and prolonging existence, averting disasters and transcending tribulations—this is another. Offering merit to the nine ancestors, universally aiding all souls, delivering and uplifting the shades of the netherworld, and all forms of posthumous salvation—this is yet another. Summoning, deploying, and governing actions—this is still another. Beyond these, the possibilities are too numerous to enumerate.

*Illuminating the Subtle and Obscure Grade*
This is the fifth weft among the Eight Wefts, fully recorded in the *Jade Mirror of Numinous Treasure*.

Red dim, ink black, grinding the true, sock-wax.
Numinous Treasure arises, turning solitary clerks to migration.
Can Han’s bright merit, all become precise angles.
Properly gathering souls, the merit gathers souls.

Summon the swift messengers of the eight directions, the deities of heaven and earth, and the myriad spirits to unite under the celestial mandate. First, form the Three Paths and Five Sufferings mudra, recite the incantation, and draw *qi* from the southeast to blow upon the mirror. With the brush, mark a dot at the *qian* direction, then eight dots for the eight directions.

Incantation:
Reverently invoke *Qian*, *Kan*, *Gen*, *Zhen*, *Xun*, *Li*, *Kun*, *Dui*, to gather and capture the lawless demonic spirits of the eight directions into my mirror to reveal their forms. Swiftly, swiftly.

Draw *qi* from the eight directions, blow upon it ten times, and together behold the sun and moon to receive and uphold it. Without expending spirit or *qi*, the forms within will be revealed.

*Shifting Scenery, Penetrating Light*
By the statutes of the Primordial Beginning and the edict of the Dao Lord, summon the Youth of Sunlight, the Youth of Moonlight, the Youth of Starlight, and the Youth of Opening Light. Mobilize the essence of the Three Luminaries and the Mysterious Dipper of sun and moon, transforming them into the Six Penetrating Divine Lights. Shining through and illuminating the ten directions of the world, myriad scenes and thousand truths shift before the sun, revealing forms to divine people and foretell the unmanifest future of objects, communicating with spirits and invoking numinous response.

Recite the incantation, draw *qi* from the Three Luminaries, and blow upon the brush or finger (using cinnabar for the brush, sesame oil for the finger) to inscribe a talisman in the hand. (Original talisman missing.) Blow *qi* again, recite the incantation, and draw *qi* to blow three times. A beam of light will appear, penetrating the seen and unseen, revealing even events yet to occur.

*Immortal Bureau’s Judgment Record from the Mysterious Treasure Mirror*
Red dim, ink black, grinding the true, sock-wax, Numinous Treasure.

First recite the incantation, inscribe the master’s heart seal in the air, and with the left hand gather it into the palm. Blow the *qi* of the five directions upon the person, then press down. Repeat three times, causing the appearance of red, yellow, and white colors.

Another incantation:

Carefully invoke the Talisman Envoy of Descending Perfection and the Spirit Summoner, commanding them to descend swiftly. Again draw *qi* from the Gate of Heaven and blow it forth, whereupon two talismans of cinnabar hue will appear in the palm—these belong to the "Talisman Methods for Approaching the Altar" section.

Another incantation:
Divine winds stir and blow,
Jade scripts resound with crystalline clarity.

Again draw *qi* from the southeast and blow it forth, whereupon the two talismans will tremble and sway.

Another incantation:
Reverently summon the Youth Who Opens the Dao of the East,
to descend with haste for me.
The five directions are invoked in like manner.

Again draw *qi* from the five directions and blow it forth, whereupon the youths of the five directions will appear. Only then may each be summoned and employed according to the method.

*Lingbao Dongxuan Illumination*
Heaven and Earth descend their *qi*,
Sun and Moon unite their forms.
Above the heavens, below the earth,
in such-and-such a place, manifest your presence.
(Draw and blow the *qi* of Heaven and Earth as per the usual method.)

**Swift Salvation of the Deceased: A Formula**
When approaching the altar to subdue demonic and wayward spirits, one must ensure that both the living and the dead receive benefit and deliverance.

First, recite the Prison-Breaking Incantation:
Most High Mysterious Origin, Supreme Lord of the Dao,
instruct your servant to wield talismans,
illuminating and shattering the dark prisons.
Let the sin-laden souls depart and be freed.
Hasten! As the statutes and decrees command.

(This incantation is drawn from the *Nine Heavens’ Brahma Chant Sutra*. Face the Gate of Heaven and silently recite it nine times.)

Next, summon the deceased soul, that it may swiftly depart from suffering.

First, recite the Water-Refinement Incantation:
Withered, revive; extinguished, live again.
Attain rebirth in the heavens,
once more receiving the Supreme Numen.
By the exhortations of the Nine Heavens,
return to the womb and infancy.
Defilements and burdens dissolve,
the corpse-soul revives.

(Place a vessel of water to the north, knock the teeth nine times, visualize three Jade Lads and seven Jade Maidens, swallow saliva seven times, recite the incantation seven times, and sprinkle the soul—then proceed to Fire Refinement.)

Incantation:
Radiance of sun and moon,
lingering in the Cavern of Yang.
Flowing fire enters the vessel,
refining and transforming yin’s miasma.
Corpse-filth vanishes,
all *qi* harmonizes in well-being.
Depart directly from the Five Sufferings,
ascend and soar to the celestial halls.

(Place a vessel of fire to the south, knock the teeth three times, visualize as before, exhale *qi* three times, recite the incantation nine times, and burn the True Form of Mount Fengdu to ashes.)

Incantation:
By the Primordial Talismanic Mandate,
demons are subdued and the decree fulfilled.
Protect and elevate the deceased soul,
delivering it to the Southern Palace for refinement.
The ashes of Mount Feng dissolve,
the Three Officials absolve its punishments.
Bonds are released, karma dissolved,
transformation and rebirth are granted.
According to its rank, refine and deliver it,
ascending to the courts of blessedness.

After reciting the incantation, press the tongue against the upper palate, visualize oneself as the Primordial Heavenly Worthy, silently recite the hidden words once, and imagine golden light filling the mouth. With two fingers, form the Jade Clarity Mudra, blow upon the paper, and release the mudra toward the northeast. The soul will immediately ascend to the Vermilion Palace, where it will undergo refinement according to its rank and be reborn in the courts of blessedness. This is not false.

The present method adheres to the precepts and regulations of the original scriptures, arranged in accordance with ancient texts. The sections on "Expounding the Essential Principles of the Celestial Net," "Facing the Origin and Entering the Retreat," "Recitation and Visualization," "Jade Tablets and Numinous Chapters," "The Three Mornings’ Radiant Brilliance," "The Five Phases’ Upright *Qi*," "Internal Refinement of the Five Sprouts," and "Cultivation and Recitation of the Three Palaces" are all practices for the adept to cultivate, ingest, and refine, forming the foundation for summoning the true and invoking the numinous.

Once internal cultivation is sufficient, one must extend it outwardly to others, curing illnesses, dispelling evil, delivering the hidden, and aiding the manifest—this is the foremost duty in establishing merit. Yet modern practitioners, unaware of the proper framework, treat the Lingbao Great Method solely as a means of deliverance, even inventing supplementary rituals to address ailments. Little do they realize that the Lingbao tradition is the essential method of the Middle Vehicle, a direct path for aiding both the living and the dead, applicable to all matters without exception.

Moreover, the principles governing the manifest and the hidden are one, with no fundamental difference between humans and spirits. At the outset of receiving a case, one must carefully assess the circumstances and weigh the severity of the matter. If malevolent spirits or demonic entities recklessly invade the living, defying heaven and acting without principle, their crimes are unforgivable. It is fitting to report them to the Supreme Mystery, notifying the relevant authorities, and to annihilate their forms and eradicate their kind—this is not cruelty.

However, if the souls of the deceased are trapped in sorrow, harboring resentment and grievances, or if hungry ghosts and forsaken spirits, lacking descendants and support, remain lost and unable to find the path to rebirth, they may cling to the living, their yin *qi* afflicting people and causing illness. In such cases, one must first examine the patient’s physical condition and trace the root of the affliction, avoiding the reckless conjectures of charlatans and fraudulent mediums.

Thus, the methods of illumination and summoning follow, verifying the facts, investigating the names, and refusing to trust false claims. Only after thoroughly understanding the circumstances, if the soul’s plight is truly pitiable and its spirit submerged, should one adhere to the ancient rites and employ the swift salvation method for the deceased. Calm the spirit, still the mind, and silently recite the numinous scriptures, performing the deliverance as prescribed. Then burn the True Form of Mount Fengdu or issue one or two talismanic mandates for deliverance, dispatching officials, generals, soldiers, and the relevant bureaus to escort the soul according to its karma and grant it rebirth—this is the utmost in perfection.

Yet even in affluent households that establish grand meritorious works and sponsor extensive rituals, summoning and deliverance often yield little result. To expect instantaneous salvation of the deceased through a single scripture or incantation in the brief span of a ritual is indeed difficult. The establishment of a retreat and the issuance of summons to the soul cannot be undertaken lightly. First, the high priest must be well-versed in the liturgical teachings, thoroughly understanding the correct principles. Next, the memorials and petitions must not conflict with established protocols. Furthermore, the sincerity of the retreat must be unwavering, with inner and outer resolve unified. The altar must be properly erected, and the rituals flawlessly performed. Even then, the success of the deliverance depends on the deceased soul’s spiritual awareness—if it cultivated virtue in life and its transgressions were not grave, the prayers may resonate, and the soul may manifest and receive deliverance. However, if even minor obstacles arise, the response may be distant and faint.

When ghostly afflictions entangle the living, it is either because the spirit harbors unresolved resentment or lacks descendants to perform sacrifices. Once the karmic retribution is fulfilled, the underworld no longer detains it. Yet if its understanding is not profound, it may remain deluded and unaware. Wandering as a malevolent force, it drifts and stirs up mischief. At such times, the ritual master must enlighten it with reason, admonish it with the Dao, and further invoke the teachings of the Supreme Perfected Ones, supplementing them with sincere and solemn devotion. In the space between breaths, the hidden soul may attain deliverance—this is no empty claim.

The living may thus be freed from the entanglements of illness and affliction, while the dead escape the torments of prolonged suffering. If a household is not impoverished yet fails to deliver its spirits, it may not follow this method—proper rituals of reverence should be performed as prescribed.

The *Lingbao Yujian* compiled at Tiantai includes a section under the "Five Phases of Orthodox Qi," yet mingles miscellaneous incantations within it, omitting any mention of swift deliverance for the departed. Thus, the noble intent of the ancient methods is no longer discernible. Therefore, I now return to the old standards and thoroughly clarify their principles.

One must understand that the ancients treated illness and dispelled malevolence to manifest benefit for both the seen and unseen realms. This is what scholars should take to heart.

*Shangqing Lingbao Da Fa*, Scroll Seven, concludes
*Qinglingbao Da Fa*, Scroll Eight

Compiled by Jin Yunzhong, Right Assistant of the Southern Bureau of the Dongxuan Lingbao Ordained Masters

**Chapter of the Great Primordial Stability**
For seven days and seven nights, the celestial bodies—the sun, moon, and stars—along with the jade armillary sphere, halt their revolutions. Divine winds fall silent, mountains and peaks conceal their clouds, the heavens are free of drifting veils, and the four qi shine in clarity. Across the land, mountains, rivers, forests, and trees level into uniformity, no longer distinguished by height or depth. The earth transforms into azure jade, devoid of any other hue. With each inhalation and exhalation, the four directions converge, each spanning six inches. One breath carries two unities, each extending three inches.

**Chapter on the Regulation of Breath and Stabilization of Qi**

Each *zhi* spans three inches, each *zhi* encompasses fifteen *fen*. The warp and weft of heaven and earth interlace in fifteenfold symmetry—thus did the Supreme Lord bestow the *Yellow River Chart* upon the Yellow Emperor.

Enter the chamber and sit in equanimity. With the hand, examine the pulse: four beats constitute one breath. Measure the practitioner’s ordinary inhalation and exhalation, gradually increasing the duration without undue strain. The breath should issue gently from the mouth, inaudible even to the ears. Once the breath is even, resume as before, accumulating effort over time. When qi settles and breath stabilizes, direct attention to the tip of the nose—three breaths for the nose, two for the cheeks, four for the brows. Then exhale subtly to complete one cycle. Continue the practice, accumulating to eighty-one cycles. After forty-nine days, incrementally extend each cycle, from one *shi* to a full day, and from one day to seven.

Thereafter, align the ears with the shoulders and the nose with the navel, gathering the six senses. Focus the mind upon the eyes. Initially, perception lies neither within nor without; observe the divine radiance. After three days, within the secluded chamber, a single point of spiritual light appears—steadfastly fix the spirit upon it. After four days, the light gradually brightens and expands. By the seventh day, the chamber is filled with divine radiance, and within this stability, all phenomena appear as yet unmanifest. After forty-nine days, within this stabilized state, all true spirits and spectral beings become visible—only then does one enter the Dao of penetrating vision and unobstructed sight.

I humbly submit that the *Scripture of Salvation* encompasses ten thousand methods. The *Great Primordial Stability* is the pivotal mechanism of these practices, the direct path of the Dao. It begins with stabilizing qi and preserving spirit, ultimately leading to the audience with the Primordial at the Gate of Heaven. Beyond this lies the ultimate realm of the Dao, beyond all conjecture.

For seven days and seven nights, the celestial bodies—the sun, moon, and stars—along with the jade armillary sphere, halt their revolutions. This describes the moment when the Primordial spoke the scriptures, an event in the heavens. Xue Youqi’s annotations briefly explicate its meaning. Applied to the human body: the sun and moon suspend their movement, the eyes do not blink; the divine winds fall silent, breath ceases to enter or exit; mountains and peaks conceal their clouds, qi no longer ascends or descends. Only then can one inwardly concentrate the spirit, the mind becoming profoundly still. Through the cultivation of stability, the spirit emerges, ascending to the upper realms, penetrating the myriad phenomena, and perceiving the ten directions—this method has already been detailed above.

The *Twenty-Five Chapters on the Great Stability of Divine Radiance* compiled by the Tiantai school claims that the jade armillary sphere’s pulse does not cease—this is a grave error. In the great practice of stability, the eyes must not blink, breath must not enter or exit, qi must not ascend or descend. Only then can the spirit depart, yet how could the pulse remain unmoved? The body would be as if dead, not the emergence of spirit.

It further states that the Heavenly Worthy floats in emptiness, with the original spirit residing in the Jade Pure Palace; that though the Heavenly Worthy is distant and wondrous, one may speak of it as dwelling in the Nine Palaces; that one already possesses the Heavenly Worthy within, and need not gaze upward to heaven—all such assertions are incorrect. It also claims that through wondrous transformation, a lion is formed, upon which the Heavenly Worthy descends into the cinnabar field, with green on the left, white on the right, red in front, black behind, and yellow at the center, hence the five colors. Yet it asserts that what is seen in seven days and seven nights are merely future events. Such a view fails to grasp that the emergence of spirit and penetrating vision lead to shedding the mortal form and ascending to the mysterious—how could the Heavenly Worthy of the five qi within the body be confined to the mud-pill palace alone?

To perceive the ten directions, to traverse the hidden and attain the wondrous, to behold the vastness of high heaven and deep earth, to witness the myriad sages and thousand perfected—all may be clearly seen, and one may wander with the Creator. Yet to claim that all one sees are future events—how narrow and shallow!

Later scholars seeking the ladder of practice and application must begin with the cultivation of stability.

**Chapter on Penetrating Vision of the Hundred Spirits**
Commence the practice of stability on the day of one’s life-star. After seven days, when the power of stability is established, only then proceed to penetrating vision. If the power of stability is not yet achieved, do not attempt it. Once breath is stabilized and spirit may emerge, the gaze extends ten thousand *li* beyond, no longer heeding objects before the eyes. After another seven days, visions gradually become clearer, though still indistinct. After a hundred days, success is attained: seated, one surveys the Three Realms and perceives the Ten Heavens.

It is also said that reciting and chanting the wondrous scriptures may qualify one as a Perfected of the Nine Palaces. The *Purple Salvation’s Inner Vision of the Central Realm of Luminous Flame* states: “Always desire to lie down with eyes closed, the body at ease, the breath subtle, as if in slumber, so that others remain unaware. Then inwardly gaze and listen afar to the four directions, extending the ears and eyes beyond ten thousand *li*. With prolonged practice, one may naturally perceive events ten thousand *li* away. With focused intent, one may see matters a hundred million *li* beyond. The ears may constantly hear the sounds of gold and jade, the music of strings and bamboo—this is the wondrous method.”

The “four directions” are a general reference. One should first arise in one direction, inwardly directing vision and hearing. Initially, there may be no semblance of perception, but with prolonged sincerity, one naturally enters the wondrous.

Upon examining ancient texts, I find that only after cultivating stability and emerging the spirit may one practice the Dao of penetrating vision. Yet regulating the breath is easily understood but difficult to master. It begins with one breath comprising four *zhi*, and over time, one breath may encompass eight *zhi*. With unceasing accumulation of effort, one may extend this to one *shi*. From one *shi*, it may extend to a full day, and from one day, seven days may be attained. Thereupon, gather the spirit as if in one’s own form, standing upright within the mud-pill palace, inwardly and outwardly serene, without the slightest attachment. Ascend directly through the crown of the head, sensing a body born outside the body, distinctly separate. The spirit departs the physical frame like a cicada shedding its husk, soaring through the vast emptiness, riding the qi to the celestial vault. One may pay homage to the constellations upon the celestial steps, present oneself before the Primordial at the Gate of Heaven, meet the assembled perfected, and ascend with the myriad qi—ultimately beholding the sacred realm of the Jade Pure. This is the wondrous subtlety of emerging the spirit, through which one may commune with the true and perceive the numinous.

Scholars who encounter enlightened teachers and, through cultivation and preservation, attain the realm of penetrating vision should advance further, never retreating or faltering.

**Chapter on Gathering and Refining the Ancestral Qi**

The phoenix curves its head to touch the crown, essence and breath concealed within. The dragon raises its head to strike the nose, its qi ascending upward. The tortoise retracts its head to contain its breath, essence and qi descending below. The serpent coils its body without straightening, primordial qi circulating throughout. The crane seals its breath with subtle respiration, essence returning to the cinnabar palace.

Reverently contemplating the Primordial Ancestral Qi—formless and nameless, at the dawn of kalpas, beyond all resemblance—once the Mysterious Net was established, the Two Images took shape. Heaven received this qi to become heaven, earth received this qi to become earth, and humans received this qi to become human. Even the moving and rooted beings, though humble in nature and form, are none other than transformations born of the Ancestral Qi.

Yet humans, though born from a portion of this qi, inevitably die when they lose it. Is this not because passions and desires muddle within, while power and profit enslave without? Unaware of their root source, failing to penetrate the true principle, their spirit grows dim and their qi dissipates. Unmindful of the great limit approaching, they ultimately fall into confusion and desolation, becoming mere shades below.

Now, by gathering and refining the Ancestral Qi, one may congeal the sacred embryo within the body. Once the sacred embryo is complete, a body is born outside the body. This passage broadly outlines the method of gathering and refining the Ancestral Qi within the body. Ancient texts record its name, but the oral instructions and techniques have not been transmitted—one cannot speculate or fabricate explanations.

The pulse reflects the heart’s color, forming the nine cauldrons within the body. Externally, it aligns with the nine hues, resonating above with the Great Brahmā, harmonizing with the hexagrams’ *qi*, and uniting with the Great Yang—hence some regard it as the Mother *Kūn*. The east inverts the nine days, guiding the two lines of *Qián*, revealing its mechanism.
