His successor, Zhang of Longxi, delved deeply into astronomy, mastered the classics and histories, and established the celestial divisions for posterity—truly a rare talent of the age. He was thus called *Lineage Master*. The third generation, Zhang of Zhen’nanjun, also achieved great deeds, yet his successors were merely called *Lineage Heirs*. For two thousand years and over thirty generations since, all have been titled *Celestial Masters, Lineage Heirs of the Teaching*—implying the transmission of their teaching and the succession of their master’s position, without daring to compare themselves to Zhang of Longxi by calling themselves *Lineage Masters*.

In the ancestral altars of the *Cavern Reality* and *Cavern Mystery* traditions, those who were not of the original surname but transmitted the teaching as disciples were called *Ancestral Masters*. When the temporal ruler permitted them to transmit registers and preside over the ancestral altar, overseeing the ordination of scholars across the land, the title was justified by the weight of the ancestral altar, and none questioned it. Beyond this, whether lay or ordained, those who receive registers and practice the methods are numerous and varied—how can they casually claim the titles *Ancestral Master* or *Lineage Master*?

Recently, in the western regions of Zhe, many have presumptuously styled themselves *Ancestral Masters*—they are all sinners against the teaching. I dare not propose novel doctrines, nor expound lofty theories. In compiling this method, I follow the ancient regulations; in practice, I adhere to the scriptures. For offices conferred upon myself, I defer with humility; in conducting rituals, I stand in awe of the celestial statutes. I dare not use any talisman or incantation whose origins are unclear, nor assume any rank or office whose title carries even slight weight. My sole aim is that those who practice may swiftly attain the true Dao, and that those who cultivate realization may soon achieve ascension—nothing more.

Having witnessed those who presumptuously assume exalted offices, violating protocols and transgressing regulations, I am deeply alarmed and fearful—fearing their retribution while hoping for their swift reform.

Consider Xu Jingyang, who cultivated the true Dao across kalpas, his merit towering above past and present. At the age of one hundred thirty-six, he received the celestial decree for ascension, wherein the heavenly writ proclaimed: *"The Imperial Edict summons the Daoist novice Xu..."*—the full text, though lengthy, need not be recounted here. Even such a lofty immortal, who ascended with his entire household, was styled merely as a *"Daoist novice."* Only after his ascension was he ranked among the true immortals.

In the Song dynasty, Wang Shichen could summon wind and rain with his breath, command thunder and lightning with a glance—already possessing the essence of a divine immortal. A stone inscription bearing his handwritten *Thunder Spirit Talisman* remains in the *Divine Transcendence Celestial Celebration Abbey* of Raozhou to this day. The fine script following the talisman reads: *"Sealed by Wang Wenqing, Minor Officer of the Five Thunders."* Each character measures no more than three or four *fen*. The ancients cultivated virtue deeply, conducted themselves with reverence, claimed titles with restraint, and approached affairs with awe. They would never dare to style themselves *Lineage Masters* or *True Sovereigns*. Even if destined for ascension and ranked among the high immortals, they remained humble in their earthly days—what harm did this do to their virtue and power?

After I, Yunzhong, received the methods and advanced to the *Dongxuan* rank, I was invested with the *Zhongmeng Register*. Yet I style myself only as a *"Disciple of the Dongxuan Lingbao"* because my ancestral name, *Ming*, precludes me from assuming a formal title according to propriety. Beyond the *Zixu Yangguang Register* of the *Dongxuan* department, the highest is the *Zhongmeng Register*, also known as the *Lingbao Register* in the teaching. Thus, I may avoid violating my family taboo. Others who receive the register should properly be styled *"Disciple of the Lingbao Zhongmeng, Southern Bureau Enforcer of Ritual Law"*—this follows ancient precedent. The title *"Assistant to the Canon"* is adopted in deference to my master’s instructions, for I dare not presume the title of an immortal.

Only the *Zhengfa of the Five Bureaus of the Tongchu*, belonging to the *Dongshen* department yet interfacing with *Dongxuan*, may be concurrently held in one’s title. All methods below this rank, though practiced, should not be included in one’s official designation.

Within the *Huayang Grotto-Heaven* of the Three Maoshan in Jinling lies the *Immortal Capital*, which houses the *Tongchu Bureau* and the *Xiaojian Palace*—reserved for male immortals who have attained the Dao—and the *Yiqian Palace*, for female immortals who have done the same. None but the highest-ranking immortals may enter. The Celestial Emperor appointed the Four Saints and the Heavenly Master as *Hereditary External Ministers of the Teaching*, bestowing methods to save the world—hence the name *Five Bureaus*. Beyond the bureaus lie the *Yizhi* auxiliary halls, which administer their affairs and serve as the esteemed abodes of immortals within the celestial halls. These matters are recorded in the foundational texts of the method and in works such as the *Zhengao*.

Among the immortal ranks of the *Five Bureaus*, there are seven grades—unlike any other worldly methods. Though the *Five Bureaus* transmit their methods to the mortal realm, the *Yizhi* remain the celestial offices of the grotto-heavens, existing in truth. Only true immortals may hold positions there. Mortal officials of the terrestrial realm may provisionally assume titles such as *"Provisional Right-Soul Administrator of the Tongchu Bureau"*—they dare not formally accept immortal offices. The seven positions within the method are likewise reserved for true immortals.

Though the *Lingbao Great Method* is exalted, those who administer its canons serve as terrestrial ritual officers. The *Five Bureaus’ Method*, though secondary to the *Lingbao*, holds its *Right Yizhi* as an immortal rank—hence the necessity of the term *"provisional."* Recently, some in various regions have been promoted to *"Outer Recorder of the Cinnabar Terrace"*—do they feel no shame in their hearts?

The *Lingbao* method comprises five ranks, and after the first five, one should not recklessly advance to titles bearing the term *"immortal"*—such designations are not easily assumed. Many in the world who have not yet entered *Dongxuan* yet perform *Ascension and Salvation* rites often concurrently serve in the *Southern Chang Refining Bureau* and handle *Huanglu* affairs—this is not in accordance with ancient protocols. The *Huanglu Court* is overseen by the *Three Officials*, and its seals and plaques are not to be used in the mortal world. Lin Shichen’s *Lingsu Thunder Regulations* permitted the use of the *Huanglu Court* seal for ritual practice, but this remains improper.

Lu Zhiguan, in his *Jade Hall Ritual Method*, employed *Zhengyi* register titles while performing *Dongxuan* rites—thus leaping a rank in official correspondence. To equate the Heavenly Master with the Celestial Emperor in weight is a grave error.

The titles of the *Tianxin* method and the seals of the *QuXie Court*, though not spurious, are misapplied when used to administer *Huanglu* affairs. They are far superior to the deceptive and false titles and seals employed by the Tiantai school. Those who earnestly refine their conduct and adhere to ancient protocols act with perfect propriety.

*Scroll Ten of the Shangqing Lingbao Great Method concludes*
*Scroll Eleven of the Shangqing Lingbao Great Method*

The *Dongxuan Lingbao* Master of the Southern Bureau, Holder of the Law Canon—*Yuantong Chufu Right Wing* Administrator Jin Yunzhong’s Compilation

**Chapter on Repenting Transgressions and Seeking Forgiveness**

The essence of cultivating the true lies first in minimizing faults. To persist in error is to drift far from the Dao. Though one may practice talismanic methods and aspire to the highest stages of the Way, if conduct remains unchecked, how can one subdue and command spirits? How much less could one advance memorials or deliver the living and the dead? The bureaus of merit and transgression miss nothing, not even the slightest detail.

During the Jin dynasty, Xu Yuanyou retreated into the mountains and forests, diligently cultivating his mind and savoring the Dao, gradually ascending to the ranks of the perfected. Yet the Three Officials dispatched Zhou Fang and others with a vermilion tablet of his transgressions, admonishing him: *"Those who study the Dao and revere life, aspiring to be enrolled among the immortals, who nest their dark minds in the distant and reverently serve the lofty spirits—must first accumulate worldly merit, ensure no calamities or evils assail them, let hidden virtue take root, and extend benevolence to all below. Only then may they tread the path of the perfected, ascend to the Azure Palace, and have their names recorded there."* Judging by this, those who have not yet reached Xu Yuanyou’s level—how could they remain ignorant of the need to minimize faults and cultivate themselves?

For those who uphold the law, practice its disciplines, and seek immortality through the study of the Dao, it is essential to repent and redress past transgressions while accumulating future merit and diligence.

Thus, the *Xuan'gang Lun* states: "Faults are to be corrected and never repeated; merit is to be established without weariness." This is called daily renewing one’s virtue, whereby Heaven itself grants its protection. If one merely performs the rituals of repentance in word and deed while the heart lacks the resolve to examine and amend faults—if one sins in the past only to repeat them in the future, adorning the exterior while corrupting the interior—then even if one exhausts the body and wearies the form, gazing at stars and worshipping the moon, observing fasts and upholding precepts, burning incense and reciting scriptures, all such efforts will be in vain.

There are those who boast grand words to deceive the world, claiming that if no sins are accumulated and no evils committed, what need is there for repentance? Or that one should abandon the teachings and disciplines altogether—this is yet another extreme of excessive correction. The balanced and harmonious middle way, neither excessive nor deficient, calls for repenting faults in the heart, reflecting on transgressions with certainty, adhering to the scriptures and upholding the teachings, following the established rites and procedures, erasing the record of sins from the courts of the Three Officials and the Five Emperors, and inscribing one’s name in the realms of the Ten Poles and Nine Empyreans. By establishing merit without slackening and elevating the body to ascend as an immortal, one assuredly has a share in this attainment, and nothing should obstruct one’s path. Those with resolve often succeed in their endeavors.

**Ritual of Repentance and Atonement**
Except for the day following the Autumn Equinox each year, one should regularly perform this rite on the Three Origins, the Eight Festivals, one’s own birthday, the days of *jiazi* and *gengshen*, and other auspicious occasions. Enter a quiet chamber, or a secluded place in a temple, abbey, or mountain wilderness. Burn incense and single-mindedly reflect on one’s faults and transgressions. First, sit solemnly beside the altar, deeply contemplating all actions and deeds since birth—every unwarranted fault and unwholesome act. Trembling with reverence, one reproaches oneself with remorse, baring the heart and spilling the gall, swearing never to repeat such errors. Overcome with shame, one feels unworthy to occupy this space.

Then, adjusting one’s robes and composing body and spirit, rise and ascend the altar to make one’s declaration. Where no altar is present, set up an incense table, arrange the altar cloth, and perform the rites of entry. Recite the incantation, offer incense, and follow the prescribed ritual of supplication and atonement. In the morning, begin facing east; at noon, facing south; at night, facing north. Divide the five directions, recite the appropriate repentance texts, and follow the established procedures. After the third offering of incense, perform the rites of obeisance, adhering to the natural protocol of audience.

Such matters are best conducted in secrecy, and solitary practice is preferred over elaborate ceremonies. Thus, only the texts for atonement in the four directions are compiled here, to be adapted as circumstances require.

**First, the Incense Prayer**
Dao incense, virtue incense, non-action incense, pure and spontaneous incense, wondrous cavern-real incense, numinous treasure wisdom incense, incense transcending the Three Realms, true incense of the Three Realms—filling the jeweled perch of Jade Capital, pervading the Dharma realms of the cosmos.

With this incense now offered, we reverently present it to the Spontaneous and Vast Great Dao, the Heavenly Worthies of the Three Realms, the August Emperor of the Azure Heavens, the Great Emperor of the Purple Tenuity, the August Thearch of Earth, the Thirty-Two Heavenly Emperors, the Ten Thousand Heavenly Thearchs, the Eleven Great Stellar Lords of the Upper Clarity, the Seven Primordial Stellar Lords of the Northern Dipper, the Heavenly, Earthly, and Watery Officials of the Three Offices, the Four Saintly Marshals of the Northern Culmen, the Five Masters of the Numinous Treasure, the Twenty-Eight Stellar Lords of the Four Directions, the Five Great Demon Kings of the Three Realms, the Flying Heavenly Divine Kings of the Ten Directions and Boundless Realms, the Great Emperor of the Northern Yin Fengdu, the Great Emperor of the Eastern Fusang, the Sacred Emperors of the Five Marchmounts and Five Heavens, the Grotto-Heavens and Blessed Lands, the renowned mountain retreats, the recording immortals and perfected saints, the divine officers and marshals of the Three Caverns and Four Supplements, the registers of the Dharma, and all the numinous officials and spirits of the Three Realms.

By the power of this fragrant cloud, may our offerings be universally extended. May jade blossoms scatter their radiance, and the ninefold *qi* congeal into mist. May the fragrant clouds rise in dense array, piercing through all the heavens. May the Golden Lad attendant of incense and the Jade Maiden messenger transmit our words to the presence of the Emperors, so that our prayers may be heard and our requests granted.

The humble servant [Name], on this auspicious day, having purified the heart and cleansed the body, beseeches the Perfected and invokes the Dao. First, we offer prayers for the imperial ancestral temples, the altars of soil and grain, and the ancestral spirits, that they may ascend to the Nine Empyreans and bestow blessings for ten thousand generations. May the present emperor’s foundation endure forever, his reign prosper and flourish. May his sacred longevity parallel heaven and earth, and his virtuous teachings equal the workings of creation. May all directions turn toward goodness, and the hundred grains flourish. May all beings with consciousness awaken to the Perfect Dao, and all boundless realms together ascend to the land of glory and joy. May the Great Teaching flourish and the true Dharma spread. With utmost reverence, we dare to present our humble wishes, venturing to address the imperial majesty. The servant’s heart trembles with awe and trepidation, overwhelmed with fear and urgency.

Then, prostrate in devotion, the servant [Name] takes refuge in the Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions—east, southeast, west, northwest, south, southwest, north, northeast, above, and below—the Thirty-Two Heavenly Emperors, the Twenty-Eight Stellar Lords of the celestial circuit, the Perfected and Sacred Ones of Heaven, the True Lords of the Five Marchmounts, the spirits of mountains, rivers, and seas, the grotto-heavens and blessed lands, and all the divine immortals and numinous officials.

Next, perform three bows, then face north (at night, north is given precedence). Kneel in prostration three times.

The humble servant [Name], with devoted heart, body, spirit, and life, takes refuge in the Heavenly Worthy of the Boundless Upper Clarity of the Numinous Treasure in the north and northeast, the Eight Heavenly Emperors of the North, the Perfected and Sacred Ones of the North, the Stellar Lords of the Dipper, Ox, Girl, Void, Danger, House, and Wall, the Black Emperor and True Lord of the Northern Marchmount Heng, the grotto-heavens and blessed lands of the North, the spirits of mountains, rivers, and seas, all the Perfected and Numinous Ones, and the divine immortals and officials of the Northern Realm.

We have heard that the Great Dao, in its compassion, opens the path of repentance for transgressions. The Perfected and Lofty Ones, in their transformative power, unlock the gate of atonement for sins.

Without invoking the mandate to entreat grace, how could one obtain release from transgressions and avert retribution? Prostrate, I reflect upon my foolishness, humble station, and dull, common endowment. By fortune, I have been steeped in the true wind of the Dao and have encountered the turning of its dispensation; long have I borne the registers of the law, yet have presumptuously defiled the cap and sash of office. Unable to exert myself to establish merit, I have instead persisted in sin. Unmindful of restraint, I have neglected diligent cultivation. I fear for the myriad ancestors and countless forebears of past generations, as well as for the thousand lives and accumulated kalpas of my own former existences—from the karmic causes of old down to the present life, in thought and deed, and for all within my household and among my kin—who have committed grievous evils and incurred profound transgressions, boundless and inexpressible, recorded in the celestial and terrestrial bureaus, inscribed in the palaces of the sun, moon, and stars, never to be absolved, forever without release. Dreading the advent of retribution, I tremble at the sprouting of calamity. Today, with devoted life, I prostrate and confess in full, seeking thorough purification.

May the heavens bestow forgiveness, may the Dao open its compassionate mercy, may the myriad sages send forth blessings, and may the host of Perfected Ones grant felicity. May the ninefold ancestors and sevenfold forebears of your servant, along with my own self, across ten thousand kalpas and a thousand lives down to this day—with their towering sins and world-shaking transgressions—have their evil roots extirpated and their records of wrongdoing erased. Thus may I swiftly attain the true Dao, encounter a genuine master, and enjoy peace and prosperity in body and life, while my disciples and followers dwell in tranquility.

For those in the world, it is said: may kin and family abide in peace. Moreover, I pray for the spiritual awareness of ancestors, the ethereal forms of masters and friends, departed kin, and forebears who have passed before—may they forever dwell in bliss and eternal freedom. May the six paths and three realms, the four births and ten thousand kinds, all be delivered and transformed.

Your servant’s heart is overwhelmed with repentance and supplication.

Three bows, then turn toward the east.

Your servant [Name], with devoted heart, body, spirit, and life, takes refuge in the Heavenly Worthy of the Boundless Upper Clarity of the Numinous Treasure in the east and southeast, the Eight Heavenly Emperors of the East, the Perfected and Sacred Ones of the East, the Stellar Lords of the Horn, Neck, Root, Heart, Tail, Winnowing Basket, and Girl, the Azure Emperor and True Lord of the Eastern Marchmount Tai, the grotto-heavens and blessed lands of the East, the spirits of mountains, rivers, and seas, all the Perfected and Numinous Ones, and the divine immortals and officials of the Eastern Realm.

We have heard that, as before...

Next, turn toward the south.

Your servant [Name], with devoted heart, body, spirit, and life, takes refuge in the Heavenly Worthy of the Boundless Upper Clarity of the Numinous Treasure in the south and southwest, the Eight Heavenly Emperors of the South, the Perfected and Sacred Ones of the South, the Stellar Lords of the Well, Ghost, Willow, Star, Spread, Wings, and Axletree, the Vermilion Emperor and True Lord of the Southern Marchmount Heng, the grotto-heavens and blessed lands of the South, the spirits of mountains, rivers, and seas, all the Perfected and Numinous Ones, and the divine immortals and officials of the Southern Realm.

We have heard that, as before...

Next, turn toward the west.

Your servant [Name], with devoted heart, body, spirit, and life, takes refuge in the Heavenly Worthy of the Boundless Upper Clarity of the Numinous Treasure in the west and northwest, the Eight Heavenly Emperors of the West, the Perfected and Sacred Ones of the West, the Stellar Lords of the Straddler, Harvester, Stomach, Hairy Head, Net, Turtle Beak, and Three Stars, the White Emperor and True Lord of the Western Marchmount Hua, the grotto-heavens and blessed lands of the West, the spirits of mountains, rivers, and seas, all the Perfected and Numinous Ones, and the divine immortals and officials of the Western Realm.

We have heard that, as before...

Next, turn toward the center.

Your servant [Name], with devoted heart, body, spirit, and life, takes refuge in the Heavenly Worthy of the Boundless Upper Clarity of the Numinous Treasure above and below, the Thirty-Six Heavenly Emperors of the Three Luminaries, Nine Empyreans, and Great Luo of the Boundless, the Five Venerable Lords, the Seven Perfected Ones of the Northern Dipper, the sovereigns of the celestial bureaus, the countless Perfected Ones, the dark realms of Fengdu, the true numina of the ten stages, the Thirty-Six Earthly Sovereigns, the Yellow Emperor and True Lord of the Central Marchmount Song, the grotto-heavens and blessed lands of the Center, the spirits of mountains, rivers, and seas, all the Perfected and Numinous Ones, and the divine immortals and officials of the Upper and Lower Realms.

We have heard that, as before...

Return to position and face the altar.

We, with sincere hearts and bowed heads, pay homage to the Supreme Boundless Dao of the Great Ultimate.
We, with sincere hearts and bowed heads, pay homage to the Thirty-Six Venerable Scriptures.
We, with sincere hearts and bowed heads, pay homage to the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterium.

Next, we make our declaration:
We, your humble servants [names], with utmost sincerity, reverently address the Boundless Great Dao, the August Perfected Ones on High, the mighty numina of the Three Realms, and the host of sages in the ten directions.
On this day, as we repent our transgressions and seek forgiveness, entering the oratory to cultivate the true Dao, we humbly present our supplications, beseeching your great pardon.
We pray that the underworld may erase our sins, that the immortal registers may inscribe our names, that we may encounter perfected beings, and that our studies be free from demonic trials.
How could we not redouble our virtuous thoughts, deeply reflect upon past errors, and aspire to unite with the true Dao, forever abiding in its subtle shade? May the ten directions rejoice together, and may our nine generations of ancestors receive blessings.

For this supreme cause, we recite the infinite and inconceivable merits of the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthies of the ten directions.

Next, exit the chamber as per the usual protocol.

The *Natural Audience of the Numinous Treasure* begins with invoking the sages, followed by paying homage to the ten directions, then the three prostrations of repentance, and finally the dedication of merits. The present *Five Directions’ Atonement* is an extension of the *Natural Audience of the Numinous Treasure*. Limiting it to the five directions is valued for its simplicity and ease of practice. Omitting the jade tones and Sanskrit chants is prized for its profound silence, which fosters resonance with the divine. All Dao-cultivating adepts, regardless of the rank of their registers, may perform this rite. With prolonged practice and deep introspection, sins will be eradicated, blessings will arise, and one will attain perfection and the Dao.

**Five Grades of Hidden Merit**

The scriptures state: When constellations deviate from their courses, the sun and moon lose their clarity, the four seasons fall into disorder, yin and yang fail to harmonize, the sovereign faces calamity, warfare erupts on all sides, pestilence spreads, and the multitudes perish—when teachers and friends pass away prematurely, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures.

This embodies the original intent of the scriptures and the fivefold efficacy of such practices. The method requires establishing a Numinous Treasure altar, gathering fellow practitioners, drawing pure water from the nine directions, and storing it in vessels of gold and jade—nine tripods inscribed with the names of the nine wilds and the nine provinces’ astrological divisions, buried in the pattern of the Three Dawns. Gold, jade, and quartz are used to fashion the symbols of the sun, moon, and five planets, which are then buried upon the altar.

Through steadfast practice, one observes the waxing and waning of calamities. The altar grounds must be purified, and the offerings favored by the divine prepared. The five types of disasters and misfortunes are recorded and presented to the high Perfected Ones of one’s affiliation. When the cinnabar heart aligns with heaven, the five merits are accomplished, and ascension is attained—this is called *hidden merit*. If divulged to outsiders, the merit is nullified. Such matters are prized for their secrecy and must not be disclosed to others.

**The Numinous Treasure Altar**

Select pure, uncontaminated soil, free of impurities and gravel, untainted by battlefields, execution grounds, slaughterhouses, or livestock pens. Construct a three-tiered altar.
The lower tier is square, nine feet on each side, and one foot two inches in height.
The middle tier is octagonal, seven feet in diameter, and one foot two inches in height.

The upper tier is circular, five feet in diameter, and nine inches in height.

Within the altar’s three tiers, arrange the sacred ranks and all requisite offerings.

**Altar Configuration**

**Celestial Bodies in Discord, Sun and Moon Losing Their Regularity**
This refers to the five planets encroaching upon one another, the nine luminaries straying from their paths, inauspicious stars emitting radiance, comets and broom stars flaring, lunar lodges moving out of sequence, celestial order disrupted, the sun turning pale and dim, the moon deviating from its course, or eclipses, obscurations, and halos of ill omen.

*Upper Tier*
The sacred ranks within the altar follow the presiding deities:
Heavenly August Emperor, Supreme Lord of the Grand Tenuity, Seven Primordial Lords of the Northern Dipper, True Lords of the Five Directions and Five Emperors, Lords of the Eleven Luminaries, Perfected of Wondrous Conduct.

*Middle Tier*
Lords of the Three Terraces and Canopy Stars, Lords of the Twenty-Eight Lunar Lodges, Three Official Emperors, Four Sacred Perfected of the Northern Culmen, Ten Directional Flying Heavenly Divine Kings.

*Lower Tier*
Great Spirits of the Eight Trigrams, Earth Deities of the Nine Provinces, Great Spirits of the Five Prisons, Twelve Monthly Generals, Twelve Hourly Wardens.

**Seasonal Disarray, Yin and Yang Out of Harmony**
This refers to spring enacting autumn’s decrees, summer frosts, winter thunder, incessant rain or drought, or qi and seasonal signs falling into disorder.

*Upper Tier*
The sacred ranks within the altar follow the presiding deities:
Vacuous August Heavenly Worthy, Five Emperors of the Five Directions, Three Origins, Three Palaces, Four Offices, Great Emperor of the Mulberry Tree, Divine King of the Valley of the Sun.

*Middle Tier*
Great Emperors of the Five Sacred Peaks, Earth Deities of the Nine Provinces, Dragon Kings of the Four Seas, Source Kings of the Four Waterways, Great Spirits of the Eight Trigrams.

*Lower Tier*
Great Spirits of Wind, Clouds, Thunder, and Rain; Earl of Wind, Master of Rain; Twelve Monthly Generals; Twelve Hourly Wardens; Earth Deity of the Altar Site.

**The Sovereign Facing Disasters, Warfare Breaking Out on All Sides**
This refers to powerful ministers monopolizing authority, treacherous officials wielding undue influence, bandits rising on all sides, rebellious ministers seizing territory, barbarian tribes resisting transformation, or frontier regions in turmoil.

*Upper Tier*
The sacred ranks within the altar follow the presiding deities:
Supreme August Lord of the Vast Heaven, Great Emperor of the Northern Culmen, Jade Vacuity Lord of Heaven, Heavenly Worthies of the Numinous Treasure in the Ten Directions, Ten Divine Perfected Lords of the Great Monad.

*Middle Tier*
Thirty-Two Heavenly Emperors, Lords of the Eleven Celestial Luminaries, Ten Directional Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, Great Spirits of the Nine Palaces.

*Lower Tier*
Earth Sovereign Lords of the Nine Ramparts, Great Spirits of the Five Sacred Peaks, Earth Deities of the Nine Provinces, Divine Generals of the Great Monad, Twelve Hourly Wardens, Earth Deity of the Altar Site.

**Pestilential Qi Spreading, the People Dying in Droves**
This refers to pestilential qi invading the seasons and harming the people, unpropitiated ghosts seizing the qi to spread plague, leading to wild demons, goblins, specters, and malevolent spirits, consumptive diseases transmitting from corpse to corpse, epidemics raging unchecked, or the people dying prematurely and violently.

*Upper Tier*
Supreme August Lord of the Vast Heaven, Heavenly Worthies of the Numinous Treasure in the Ten Directions, Heavenly Worthy of Longevity and Life Preservation, Perfected of Wondrous Conduct, Three Officials and Four Sacred Perfected.

*Middle Tier*
Three Origin Generals, Great Generals of Plague-Subduing and Plague-Slaying, Officers and Soldiers of Deliverance from Calamity in the Three Caverns’ Scriptures and Methods, Great Divine Healers of Heaven.

*Lower Tier*
Heavenly Soldiers and Cavalry Officers of the Five Directions, Earth Deities of the Nine Provinces, Venerable Spirits of the Year Star, Twelve Monthly Generals, Twelve Hourly Wardens, Earth Deity of the Altar Site.

**Deceased Teachers and Friends**
Those who impart even a single virtuous teaching are teachers; those who share even a morning’s study are friends. Transmitting the Dao and continuing the Dharma, united in purpose and bound by the same gate, their bond equals that of heaven and kin, their affection transcending life and death. After their passing, one should seek to perform posthumous rites, constructing a Yellow Register Altar as appropriate to the occasion. The procedures follow the methods of ascension and deliverance, which are detailed later and thus not repeated here.

**Three Dawn Symbols**
For the sun, use gold; for the moon, use jade. If lacking, substitute with silver, each one inch in diameter and shaped accordingly. For the five planets, use five-colored quartz, small as pellets. Bury each in the soil of the altar’s upper tier, nine inches deep. The sun is placed to the left, the moon to the right, and the five planets in their respective directions.

**Offerings Favored by the Perfected and Celestial Lodges**
Pipa lutes, phoenix flutes, seasonal flowers, fresh fruits, mountain spring water, pure rice, or five-colored grains dyed in five hues; green wood incense, spikenard, rush incense, fine tea, large jujubes, five-colored banners, five-colored embroidered silks.

**Offerings Favored by the Great Monad**
These are the Ten Divine Great Monads—commonly mistaken for comet stars, which is incorrect. Arrange ten positions within the altar:
Perfected Lord of the Five Fortunes Great Monad, Perfected Lord of the Fundamental Great Monad, Perfected Lord of the Great Wandering Great Monad, Perfected Lord of the Lesser Wandering Great Monad, Perfected Lord of the Heavenly One Great Monad, Perfected Lord of the Earthly One Great Monad, Perfected Lords of the Four Divine Great Monads, Perfected Lord of the Direct Attendant Great Monad, Perfected Lord of the Ministerial Fundamental Great Monad, Perfected Lord of the Popular Fundamental Great Monad.

Bamboo bows, reed arrows, talismanic armor and horses, soldiers, saddled horses, wooden swords, spears, blades, and halberds; scarlet and black paper money, five-colored silks, seasonal flowers, fresh fruits, fine tea, mountain spring water.

All offerings should be pure and immaculate.

**Nine Cauldrons**
Entrusted to the Two Officials within the altar:
Dawn Thorn Two, Stalwart Beam Seven, Treasure Harmony Six, Metal Yang Nine, Tripod Predict Five, Pleiades Ji One, Bronze Xu Four, Pole Star Qing Three, Azure Yan Eight.

In antiquity, cauldrons of gold, jade, bronze, and iron were used, but if these cannot be distinguished, substitute with new, clean ceramic vessels that can hold water, each fitted with a lid. Inscribe the names of the Nine Cauldrons in cinnabar on the exterior and the names of the Nine Provinces on the interior. Place them in the eight directions of the altar’s middle tier, arranged according to the Nine Palaces, with only the central cauldron of the Fifth Palace positioned beside the Second Palace. First, present prayers and memorials to the presiding Celestial Emperor, then submit petitions to the Three Realms’ numinous spirits within the altar. Next, draw pure spring water from the nine directions and pour it into the Nine Cauldrons. The Dharma Master orally presents the circumstances, then covers the cauldrons with their lids. Additionally, set up a separate pure mat, arranging offerings according to each deity’s preferences, and prepare ritual objects, seasonal flowers, and fresh fruits. Burn incense, light lamps, and make offerings in accordance with the proper method. Gather those of like mind and shared purification, virtuous practitioners of good conduct, without regard to number, to unite in purpose and collaborate in the fast and vigil, purifying the altar and cleansing away defilements.

Having submitted memorials to the local earth deities and spirits to guard and protect, one then rectifies the mind with utmost sincerity, focusing thought with unwavering devotion, all in accordance with ancient canons, and recites the *Wondrous Scripture of Salvation, Upper Chapter*. Incense is offered in the six ritual periods, the scripture chanted ten times through, so that the cinnabar heart pierces the Nine Ultimates, and a single thought reaches the Ten Directions—this is no mere mundane recitation as commonly practiced. If one is not the right person, if virtuous deeds are not gathered, if the mind wanders to the dusty chambers of the world while the mouth recites the scripture of the Most High, then even after days and months of accumulation, even after ten thousand repetitions, it shall still be difficult. When merit is perfected and virtue accomplished, the Nine Cauldrons are opened for inspection. Now, the cauldrons hold water, covered above, and if it remains clear and still as at first, this is the natural principle. Should there be even slight turbidity or other unusual signs, these are transformations of the ritual’s efficacy, reversals of the norm, all deemed ominous. From this, one may discern the impending calamities and dangers in the corresponding celestial divisions, which have not yet been fully resolved. Such was the pure sincerity of the ancients, who attended even to the finest distinctions. Some might say that redness portends a certain event, turbidity a certain disaster—this is but the petty art of shamans, not the grand purpose of the scripture, which above dispels heavenly disasters and below averts poisonous harms.

The ritual of offering incense follows its own established form. The exalted perfected ones arrayed within the altar each occupy distinct positions, as with the Eleven Luminaries each assigned to eleven stations. To conflate multiple positions into one inscription is not the ancient method. The scripture states: when performing the fast, offering incense, and reciting scriptures, one must adhere to the proper method of the fast. To approach antiquity more closely, one may perform the *Natural Audience of the Numinous Treasure*, which is also permissible, as it is the origin of the fast’s method.

Yunzhong notes: The scripture says: when the stellar lodges fall into disorder, when the sun and moon lose their proper times. Or when the four seasons lose their order, when yin and yang fall out of harmony. Or when the ruler of the state faces calamity, when warfare arises on all sides. Or when pestilence and poison spread, when the multitudes perish. Or when teachers and friends pass away—all these are occasions when one should perform the fast, offer incense, and recite scriptures. In an older version of a *Numinous Treasure* ritual, each line was treated as a separate section, divided into nine matters, closely examining the scripture’s intent. The first four clauses each consist of two lines of eight characters, their meanings interconnected. Beneath every two lines, it is said: "offer incense and recite scriptures." Only the line concerning the passing of teachers and friends stands alone, yet it too says: "offer incense and recite scriptures." Thus, nine lines are structured into five clauses. Therefore, the text transmitted by Master Yunzhong establishes a single *Numinous Treasure* altar, yet divides it into five ranks of sacred positions. Excluding the clause on the passing of teachers and friends, which follows the rites of transcendence, the four ranks of sacred positions have already been memorialized above—these are the five grades, derived from the scripture’s intent and the master’s transmission.

Li Shaowei says: The fast refers to the *Yellow Register* and other fasts, the five-scripture offerings of pacification and gratitude—these are no ordinary worldly fasts. The thrice-daily memorials move heaven and earth, summoning blessings and averting disasters. This altar is round above, octagonal in the middle, and square below—this is the *Numinous Treasure* altar. In ancient *Numinous Treasure* rites, altars were constructed with mud walls, and jade liquid was poured to memorialize the Emperor; their altars followed this same form. This accords with the original method of the *Numinous Treasure*, and its rituals are conducted throughout the year, not as mundane practices commonly performed. Its purpose differs from the immediate relief sought in disaster aversion and calamity transformation, and thus it is not included here.

The *Tiantai* method records this disaster-aversion and pacification rite within the "Deliverance from Calamity and Disaster-Dispelling" section. At its outset, it details the talismanic script of the Fire Bell, invoking qi to perform exorcistic healing—though its oral instructions remain unclear. Yet the original method’s refinement of the *Primary Jade Register* for youths bears no connection to this. Next, it prescribes scripture recitation on the eight solar terms, aligning with the Nine Palaces to safeguard and avert disasters across the Nine Provinces’ astrological divisions. This derives from ancient texts wherein scholars, following seasonal observances, wore talismans and practiced self-cultivation—a vestige of earlier traditions. Further, after reciting scriptures in the Nine Palaces, one is instructed to turn south, then east, and rotate a brick ten times—all of which deviates entirely from the original intent.

Moreover, while this *Numinous Treasure* altar is called the *Three Heavens’ Unified Qi Altar*, the three-tiered square altar of the *Yellow Register* is also termed a *Numinous Treasure* altar. This may stem from distinct sources, yet it does not emerge from the *Numinous Treasure’s* original method. Additionally, on the Lower Prime Day, an altar is erected, nine tripods are arrayed, and clear spring water is heated to a boil and poured into the tripods—such practices were never employed in antiquity. Most of its procedures diverge from ancient liturgical codes. Only the disaster-aversion rites performed on the Lower Prime Day, wherein the abundance or scarcity of water in the nine tripods—or the appearance of the five colors—is used to divine which of the Nine Wilds faces impending calamity, constitutes a form of divination applied *before* signs of misfortune manifest. This, at least, retains a commendable intent. Yet it should be conducted as a separate rite.

What is overlooked is that the scripture itself enumerates these five conditions, all of which require incense offering and scripture recitation. The subsequent chapter states in summary: "Whoever possesses this scripture may perform these meritorious deeds for the Heaven and Earth, the Thearchs, and the myriad people. On days of calamity, if one resolves to fast, burn incense, and recite the scripture ten times, all the heavens will record their name." The scripture’s intent is that the revolutions of Heaven and Earth, like the fortunes of sages and divine persons, are subject to decline. When misfortune looms and disasters begin to stir, one must act to rescue and resolve them according to the proper methods. Among these five categories, nine conditions represent the gravest calamities; by erecting altars and supplicating in accordance with the afflicted domain, boundless merit is accrued.

If one claims to preempt misfortune before it arises and forestall disaster before its omens appear, this is indeed virtuous—but it is not the prescribed practice. To treat it as routine dilutes its purpose, fundamentally contravening the scripture’s original intent. Thus, all its procedures, terminology, and doctrines diverge from the text. In the present compilation, the original scripture serves as the foundation, and ancient methods as the standard; no deviation from the scripture’s words in the name of "method" is permitted.

*Great Rites of the Highest Clarity and Numinous Treasure*, Scroll Eleven—concluded
*Great Rites of the Highest Clarity and Numinous Treasure*, Scroll Twelve

*The Salvation of Life and the Yang Virtue*, compiled by Jin Yunzhong of the Right Auxiliary Office of the Southern Bureau of Ritual Enforcement under the Master of the Cavernous Mystery and Numinous Treasure—Section Seven of the Eight Latitudes

How vast is the virtue of generation! The Dao delights in life, and thus generates heaven and earth. Heaven and earth delight in life, and thus generate the myriad things. Once born, man holds life as paramount. The divine immortals and superior scholars who study the Dao and cultivate the true, however, recoil at the burden of this illusory body. The world, failing to fathom their intent, assumes that practitioners of the Dao hold life in no esteem—this is not so. Those who attain the Dao do not cling to form or stain themselves with worldly desires; their original singular thought abides, serene and solitary. Thus, when they retain their form, it does not drift with worldly entanglements. When they shed their mortal coil, they do not perish with it. Their spirit refined and qi settled, they transcend the mundane and enter sagehood—yet when they glance back at this corporeal husk, is it not a burden? As Lord Lao said: "My great affliction is that I have a body." The Perfected of the Great Ultimate also praised: "Discard the body, yet the body remains." Both express this truth. For worldly men, it is otherwise: while the body endures, the spirit endures; while the form persists, sincerity persists. Once the body collapses, the hun and po scatter in disarray—some sink into darkness, some plunge into abyssal obscurity. Such death cannot be reversed. Is not the life already granted a joy? To crave life and abhor death is the common sentiment of past and present. The ceaseless generation of life is the fundamental principle of heaven and earth. Thus, the August Emperor, pitying the world, bestowed teachings and established rites to succor the distressed, uphold the imperiled, expel demons, and dispel delusion. Through memorials and jiao rites, blessings are invoked to prolong life—all to magnify the Dao’s virtue of generation and fulfill the people’s wish for life unending.

The ancient methods of the Numinous Treasure tradition include the *Salvation of Life and the Yang Virtue*, a practice of jiao rites and petitions to the Dipper Stars for life extension and salvation of destiny. Yet without receiving the proper writ, such matters are difficult to advance. Though this is a virtuous act of salvation, it cannot be concealed—hence it is called *Yang Virtue*. According to the ancient rites of the forty-two grades of jiao, the twentieth is the *North Dipper Jiao*. The present method establishes the *Mystic Pivot Numinous Altar*, with the North Pole Imperial Throne at its center, the host of perfected ones arrayed before it, encircled by the Northern and Southern Dippers. Its practice closely resembles the *North Dipper Jiao*. For the Dipper in the heavens is truly the master of the celestial pivot, bearing immense significance. Petitions for life extension and pardon are particularly under its purview. Thus, scholars must deeply embody the original intent of *Salvation of Life*, aligning with the ancients’ purpose, so that this rite may be properly conducted.

The method states: Within the mountains, rivers, and seas of the Lower Realm, amid cities, villages, and hamlets, dwell the spirits of water, stone, birds, and beasts; the unbalanced deities of the Five Phases; the fierce and malevolent ghosts of the lower earth; the hun of specters, demons, and baleful curses—all act wantonly, perpetrating strange and heterodox deeds, entangling and deluding the living, beyond remedy. Or within the Northern Darkness of Fengdu, the impure deities of blood and flesh, bound to ancestral spirits, the recently deceased, and both inner and outer kin, may stir lawsuits in the nether courts, extending misfortune to the living, compounding calamities—all beyond resolution. By erecting the *Mystic Pivot Altar of the Three Luminaries* upon purified ground, prayers are answered, and peace is restored.

The *Mystic Pivot Altar* is also called the *Three Luminaries Altar*. Select a secluded chamber or an open, quiet wilderness, and upon purified ground, construct an altar. Each tier rises one foot in height. The upper tier, two feet wide, centers on the *Central August Palace*, where the *North Pole Great Emperor* and *Heavenly August Great Emperor* are enshrined. The middle tier, three feet wide, arrays the *Nine Sovereigns of the Northern Dipper*, the *Southern Dipper*, the *Three Terraces*, and the *Sun and Moon*, all with lamps lit according to their celestial forms. The lower tier, six feet wide, arranges the *Generals of the Three Primes*, the *Twelve Earthly Branches*, the *Grand Year Star* of the current year, the *Envoys Qingyang and Tuoluo*, the *Four Duty Officers*, the *Earth God*, and other deities. Before them, a *Cavern Tablet* is placed, inscribed with the names of the two Dippers. Lamps are lit, and five-colored threads extend from the Dipper’s mouth to the tablet below. Following the rites, petitions are submitted to address hidden transgressions, concealed faults, and veiled sins; to harmonize the year and destiny; to dispel disasters; to purify the human realm; and to quell demonic disturbances. The responses are extraordinary, profoundly efficacious and divine.

If constructing a soil altar is unfeasible, use white clay to draw three tiers upon the ground and perform the rites accordingly, though a permanent altar is preferred.

**Flying Dipper Rite**: On a large paper *cloud-horse*, inscribe the talismans of the Northern and Southern Dippers in cinnabar upon the blank space of the saddle. For each stellar position, present one memorial and one horse, offering them star by star. The horses should appear galloping, as if soaring in flight. If a carved block matching the design is available, hire artisans to paint them.

**Northern Dipper Talisman for Harmonizing Year and Destiny (Life-Giving and Death-Averting Array)**:
Reverently invoke the *Five Star Spirit-Responding Lords* to harmonize the year and destiny of [Name].
*Swiftly, swiftly, as the Original Celestial Worthy commands!*

Below the talisman, inscribe:
[Name], born on [year, month, day, hour], under the governance of the [specific] Star Lord of the Northern Dipper, humbly confesses lifelong hidden sins and seeks pardon.
Write in three or five lines, then burn over the lamp flame.

**Talisman of the Two Dipper Star Lords**:
[Illegible characters]...

**Seven Primes Secret Transmission Talisman: Flying the Spirit**

First, pace the Northern Dipper, entering from the Dipper’s handle to its mouth and proceeding to the *Piao* star. Visualize the Dipper enveloping your body, then pace again into its mouth. Bow three times, meditate to project your spirit, and ascend directly into the Dipper. Summon the *Four Direct Envoys*, clearly stating the purpose of the offering. Witness your spirit’s entry into the Dipper.

Next, observe the *Qingyang* and *Tuoluo* Envoys descending to inspect the altar, then returning to report to the stellar perfected ones. The ritual master stands within the Dipper, awaiting their return.

Once complete, proceed to the Southern Dipper, following the same procedure as for the Northern Dipper. Witness the *Fire Bell Generals* and the *Six Star Lads* inspecting and reporting back. Thereafter, the Dipper stars descend. After a while, purple clouds and rare fragrances may appear, or crimson light may enter the chamber—this signals the descent of the Two Dippers. Avoid the presence of monks, nuns, mourners, women, chickens, or dogs.

Before the altar, arrange a table with lit lamps and candles, along with fresh seasonal fruits, sweet wine, and rare incense—avoid sandalwood and frankincense. If pure wine is unavailable, substitute with *xuanshui* (sacred water), ensuring utmost purity. Follow the rites to present petitions and announce the proceedings. Offer memorials, paper money, and horses, burning them in the fire. With utmost sincerity, all calamities will be dispelled.

This transmission of the *Numinous Treasure Great Rites* is an ancient text from the Central Plains. The present compilation strictly adheres to the master’s teachings, without daring to alter them. Generally, if a matter aligns with principle, there is no need for debate or distinction—how could one speak of divergent schools? Yet, as the Tiantai tradition has spread widely, many of its doctrines contradict antiquity. Its methods differ greatly from other schools. If left unexamined, people will inevitably doubt and hesitate, unsure of which path to follow. Thus, this account is offered out of necessity.

Where other texts differ from Tiantai, their divergences are noted. Where Tiantai aligns with other texts, its claims are verified. This is not a fabrication by Yunzhong without masterly transmission, nor an appropriation of Tiantai methods to compose a text. Moreover, Yunzhong’s compilation and practical applications retain many ancient forms not recorded in Tiantai methods.

The *Mysterious Pivot Petition* in the *Numinous Treasure Rites* is titled the *Life-Saving Yang Virtue Section*; its placement here follows the original text. Since Tiantai’s Du Dazhen established the *Xuanji* method, he favored novelty in every matter. Disregarding the ancient *Northern Dipper Offering* rites, he invented the *Mysterious Numinous Xuanji Prefecture Seal*, appointing *Inspectors* and claiming authority over the *Xuanji Prefecture*. Those who receive his teachings today violate both the celestial statutes and worldly propriety, offending both heavenly principle and human sentiment. Yunzhong has already discussed this in detail in the general preface.

Thus, one should adhere to the ancient rites, simply calling it the *Northern Dipper Offering*. The officiant should use their proper title and seal according to their tradition—such as employing the *Qu Xie Yuan* seal in the *Orthodox Tianxin* rites—without altering titles or modifying seal inscriptions. If one avoids calling it the *Northern Dipper Offering* and invents another name, even obscure designations adjacent to the Northern Dipper may be exploited to deceive the world. This risks reducing the matter to riddles like the "yellow silk, young woman" on the reverse of the *Cao E Stele*, later trivialized by commoners as guessing games. Distorting proper rites and forcing interpretations is mere child’s play. To thus profane the perfected ones—can one’s heart be at ease?

Furthermore, in documents submitted to the Dipper stars, which share the same protocol as the Celestial Thearch, some affix seals and label them as "Memorials to the Nine Mornings Jade Gate." This is an egregious usurpation of celestial decorum. Only the gates of the Three Clarities and the Jade Thearch may be called *Jade Gates*; the Dipper stars dare not presume such a title. From the stellar realm’s perspective, the *Purple Tenuity Enclosure* is well-documented. *Enclosure* refers to a walled garden or screen. Here, seven stars flank each side, with the *Canopy* covering above. The *North Culmen Great Thearch* and the *Celestial August Thearch* reside within, and the gap at its front is called the *Gate of Heaven*—this is the *Jade Gate* of the *Purple Tenuity Enclosure*. The Northern Dipper, however, lies before the *Gate of Heaven*, serving as the pivotal constellation, the throat and tongue of governance, issuing decrees and overseeing the four directions. Even the *Minister of State* in the mortal realm is called the "throat and tongue" of the court. The Dipper is the great minister of Heaven’s plenitude, its office most vital, its authority most weighty. Yet it cannot be revered as the Celestial Thearch, just as the *Minister of State* cannot be equated with the Son of Heaven. To call the Northern Dipper the *Jade Gate* is a grave usurpation and error.

Du’s lineage initially prized unconventionality, valuing the strange and novel, but ultimately strayed into ritual impropriety and discourtesy. Those who imitate such practices risk adopting an irreverent demeanor.

The Northern Dipper is also called the *Central Dipper*. When the rites pair it with the Southern Dipper, this follows the *Southern Dipper Scripture*. In truth, the Southern Dipper is the *Dipper* mansion among the Twenty-Eight Constellations, located in the northeast of the heavens. Though also called the *Southern Dipper* in astronomy, it cannot be paired with the *Central Dipper*. The ancient rites remain unchanged here, and this compilation dares not alter them.

**End of Scroll Twelve of the *Highest Clarity Numinous Treasure Great Rites***

**Scroll Thirteen of the *Highest Clarity Numinous Treasure Great Rites***

*Compiled by Jin Yunzhong, Right Attendant of the Initial Office of the Divine Youth, under the Authority of the Southern Bureau of the Numinous Treasure Dharma Masters*

**Section on Salvation and Refinement of Suffering Souls**

It is respectfully noted: the methods of the Middle Vehicle are the Dao of the Nine Perfected of the Cavernous Mystery. They originated with the Great Dao Lord of the Highest Clarity at the beginning of the *Yan Kang* kalpa, emerging from the Heaven of Yu Yu. Their scriptures comprise the eleven divisions of the *Cavernous Mystery*. By the second year of *Guang He* in the reign of Emperor Ling of Han, the Perfected of the Supreme Ultimate, Xu Laile, transmitted thirty-six scrolls of the *Highest Clarity Treasure Scriptures* and thirty-seven scrolls of the *Numinous Treasure Admonitions and Precepts* to the Immortal Elder Ge Xuan, later known as the Left Immortal Elder of the Supreme Ultimate. From this point, the teachings of the *Cavernous Mystery* and the Dao of the *Numinous Treasure* were widely illuminated in the world, and the Immortal Elder truly became the master who transmitted the teachings.

In recent times, the methods of ritual refinement and salvation have all been attributed to the "Refinement of Immortal Elder Ge." Some even omit the title "Immortal Elder" and refer to them simply as the "Supreme Ultimate Refinement," which is particularly unreasonable. For the Supreme Ultimate arises only after the Limitless, marking the beginning of Heaven and Earth—it cannot serve as the name of a ritual text. If one speaks of the "Perfected of the Supreme Ultimate," this refers to Master Xu; if one speaks of the "Left Immortal Elder of the Supreme Ultimate," this refers to Master Ge. Without the titles "Immortal Elder" or "Perfected," the term "Supreme Ultimate" must not be used alone in this context.

Upon examining the texts attributed to the "Refinement of Immortal Elder Ge," all schools take the *Precious Register for Ascending to Heaven* as their foundation. However, their liturgical forms and language are entirely modern in style, differing from the ancient rituals of the Immortal Elder. Often, people hear that the Immortal Elder once performed rituals to aid ghosts and achieved merit, so they adopt his name and compile books accordingly. Yet they fail to recognize that the Immortal Elder lived in the Eastern Han, and his literary style does not match that of today. Nevertheless, if the existing methods adhere to the canonical forms of the tradition, what harm is there in employing them? Why insist on inventing new names to achieve salvation?

If one’s will is pure, thoughts composed, form and spirit solemn, and devotion sincere, then responses will follow one’s sincerity. But if one approaches the matter with negligence, thoughts straying and intentions awry, even if one personally receives the jade words of the Heavenly Worthy, it will be difficult to extend grace to the dark realms. Records from past and present, witnessed and heard, show that many have succeeded through these methods—scholars should devote themselves to their study.

The ritual refinement texts I have seen number in the dozens. Though their general principles are similar, their invocations and vernacular prayers are often discordant, and their cadences vary, making them difficult to recite during rituals. The talismans and incantations compiled here are all drawn from the various methods of the *Numinous Treasure*, conforming to the orthodox methods of the *Celestial Mind*. All may be employed, while the opening invocations and ritual language are my own compilation, intended to broaden their application without becoming rigid.

If one wishes to report to the Emperor on High and notify the underworld bureaus at the outset, one should state the matter plainly, expressing only the intention to perform the ritual refinement for lonely souls. To claim adherence to the "Great Refinement Method of Immortal Elder Ge" or the like is groundless, for this is but one practice within the tradition.

Those who practice should distribute talismans and medicines to aid the living, and perform rituals to refine and succor the suffering souls of the dead. What matters is unwavering dedication over time. Many in recent times undertake this practice, zealous at first but negligent later—this is the common failing.

Rituals performed on the Three Primes, Eight Nodes, Four Pardons, *Geng Shen* days, *Jia Zi* birthdays, the first and fifteenth of the month, and the seventh day of the lunar cycle are especially auspicious. However, if unforeseen circumstances intervene even once or twice, the good intention may be thwarted. Some, on the appointed night, find ghosts and spirits awaiting at the ritual site, causing such alarm that they abandon their original resolve.

To sustain the practice long-term, it is best not to fixate on specific dates but to perform the rites whenever possible. One may conduct them once a month, or two or three times, or whenever time permits, or even on fortuitous days—without adhering to rigid rules. This way, the practitioner avoids the anxiety of missed deadlines, and the spirits are not left hoping for fixed offerings. Free from constraint on both sides, the merit deepens. Without attachment or stagnation, the practice may endure.

Those who disagree with this approach may set dates and await the proper times as they prefer. In the methods presented here, memorials and official notices are omitted for simplicity. However, grand *hu* feasts for universal salvation of submerged souls should follow the original canons and are not subject to this exception.

**Preparing the *Hu* Offering**
Use one *sheng* of rice, or two to several *sheng*, according to one’s means, to prepare pure cooked rice. Avoid all impure ingredients, and assemble it into a small *hu* vessel. No wheat-based foods are necessary. Those with greater means may offer more generously. The *hu* should be prepared on the evening of the ritual day.

Three talismans, the Summoning Talisman, five scrolls of True Writs, thirty to fifty copies of the Fengdu Mountain diagrams, ten copies of the Central Scripture of Numinous Writs, ten registers of the *Lu* for Ascending to Heaven, thirty to fifty sheets of paper money, pure water, candles or lamps according to one’s means, and incense. All the above items are to be used in greater quantity as one’s capacity allows. When performing merit according to one’s means, the aforementioned should be employed.

When conducting the ritual of deliverance and refinement, rise at dawn on the appointed day to bathe and purify oneself. Maintain fasting and purity throughout the day, and at dusk, proceed with the oral memorial. First, invoke the incense:

Incense of the Dao, incense of virtue, incense of non-action, incense of pure and spontaneous fragrance, wondrous incense of the Cavernous True, incense of numinous treasure and wisdom, incense transcending the Three Realms, true incense of the Three Realms—may it fill the Jade Capital and the Jasper Metropolis, pervading the Dharma-realms of the ten directions.

With reverence and care, I now burn this incense in offering to the Three Pure Ones and the Heavenly Worthies of the Three Realms, the August Emperor of the Dark Heavens, the Great Emperor of the Northern Culmen, the Compassionate Great Unity Savior from Suffering of the Eastern Azure Palace, the Great Emperor of Longevity of the Southern Culmen, the Azure Lad Daoist Lord of the Eastern Flowery Realm, the Primordial Lady of the Nine Numina of the White Jade Tortoise Terrace, the Venerable Divinity Who Delivers the Dead, the True Lord Han of the Nine Heavens Who Cherishes Life, the Great Divine Marshal of the Nine Heavens, the Venerable Divinities of the Southern Office of Life and Destiny—Controllers of Records, Prolongers of Lifespan, Augmenters of Years, and Deliverers from Tribulation—the Five True Lords of the Numinous Treasure, the High Perfected of the Southern Vermilion Heavenly Realm and the Scarlet Fire Mansion, the Rulers of the Southern Prosperity Upper Palace, the Officials and Generals of the Refinement and Deliverance Bureau, the Divine Tiger Summoning Officials of the Northern Kui and Mysterious Range Mansion, and the Jade Maidens, Divine Generals, and Officers of the Celestial Hosts.

May the Heavenly Compassion deign to attend and record this offering. May jade radiance scatter its light and the ninefold *qi* congeal into mist; may fragrant clouds rise in dense array, piercing straight through the myriad heavens. May the Golden Lad attendant upon the incense and the Jade Maiden transmitter of words ascend to the presence of the Emperor, that my petition may be heard and my request granted as spoken.

I, [Name], holding this ritual rank, presumptuously lay bare my mortal sentiments, daring to disturb the celestial hearing. I reflect that though my nature is cleansed, I have long relied upon the shelter of the Dao, yet have done no work to benefit others and have accumulated transgressions against my own person. Presumptuously, I seek to deliver both the hidden and the manifest, that the submerged and stagnant may ascend and be liberated.

On this night of the present month, at [location], I have prepared pure offerings to sacrifice to the Three Wretched Paths, the Five Destinies, the Ten Classes, the Four Kinds of Birth, and all lonely souls. I intend to inscribe and enact the *Precious Register for Ascending to Heaven* of the Most High, the True Talismans of Water and Fire, and the imprints of the Fengdu Mountain diagrams, universally performing refinement and transformation to deliver submerged souls.

Yet I, born with a mortal endowment, have not fathomed the true principle. I humbly implore compassion and forgiveness, that I may attain resonance and communion. May the Heavenly Compassion deign to bestow the *qi* of life, permitting me to inscribe and distribute these writs. I further beseech the Heavenly Decree to command the city gods, earth deities, officials of the yin realms, gatekeepers of the netherworld, the divine courts of ancestral sacrifices, the Yellow Springs and the Barrows of the Dead, the recorders of souls, and all relevant divine authorities and subordinate officers. May they all open the gates, release the imprisoned, and liberate the condemned souls. May they be ordered to come to the altar at the *hai* hour of this night to partake in the offerings, receive refinement, and ascend to partake of the mysterious grace, returning to their original true nature.

I await the Heavenly Grace, earnestly hoping for a manifest response. With utmost reverence and awe, I bow my head to the ground and prostrate myself, respectfully submitting this memorial.

Should the Orthodox Heart of Heaven Dharma be practiced, then dismiss the Divine Tiger Generals and Scribes, and instead summon the Youths of the Supreme Mystery’s Original Boundary, the Six Jia Open-Way Envoys, and the divine generals and soldiers who command troops to assist the Dharma. The procedures for the nocturnal invocation remain the same.

Next, address the officers and officials of the Numinous Treasure Great Dharma Bureau. When practicing the Orthodox Heart of Heaven Dharma, one may invoke the Northern Culmen Bureau for Expelling Evil. Today, by this decree, notify all the gods in their respective offices, the officials and officers of the Lower Prime Yellow Register Bureau for Liberation, the officers and officials of the Southern Prosperity Refinement Bureau, the two great generals He and Qiao of the Northern Culmen Mysterious Range Prefecture, the Seven Perfected Jade Maidens, the messengers of the Three Departments, the constable officers and soldiers, the local earth gods of the region, and the tutelary deities of the altars and boundaries. Let them hasten to the altar and report for duty.

Visualize the officers and officials of all bureaus arriving in full. Those in office shall reverently bear the sacred talismans, uphold the Great Dharma, take merit-making as their foundation, and diligently perform deliverance. This night, at the appointed place, prepare a feast to offer sustenance to the lonely souls.

Having already reported to the August Thearch and the Lofty Perfected, and issued the talismanic decrees, now summon all the officers, officials, and divine hosts of the various bureaus. Let them traverse all the dark passes and hidden prisons, the nocturnal palaces of the yin realms, the numinous mounds of the mountains and rivers, the city gods and earth deities, the Yellow Springs and the Barrows of the Dead, the recorders of the departed souls, and all relevant and subordinate places. Gather the beings of the Three Wretched Realms and Ten Classes, the Five Paths and Four Modes of Birth, as well as the wandering souls and flying spirits of the wilds without refuge, those with sacrifices and those without, those who met good ends and those who met evil, and all the lonely souls awaiting deliverance.

By the *hai* hour of this night, let them all assemble at the appointed place to await the rites of refinement and the rectification of their ranks for transcendence. Execute this with utmost urgency, and may a swift and manifest response be granted. May the grace extend to the ghostly realms, all by virtue of divine power. Hasten to comply!

Next, inscribe the talismans:
*The Precious Register for Ascending to Heaven*
This register’s proclamation may be written on the reverse or below the register:
"Liberate the beings of the Five Paths and Four Modes of Birth. Let the lonely souls and stagnant spirits depart from darkness and follow their karmic rewards to rebirth. Those in charge shall obey and act accordingly, executing the talismanic command."

On the day of the year, month, and day under the reign of *Tai Sui*, proclaimed below.

The ritual master of dharma rank, [Name], hereby performs the rites.

Sit upright and visualize the Savior of Suffering Heavenly Worthy suspended in the void, with the Greatly Compassionate, Greatly Merciful, and Greatly Benevolent Perfected One and the Savior of Suffering Perfected One standing in attendance to the left and right. Next, envision the Southern Dipper’s canopy above the crown, transforming the self into the form of a Perfected One. Then behold the Heavenly Worthy dispatching a Jade Maiden, who rides upon precious radiance, bearing the precious register and descending before you. Softly recite the central scripture once, then take up the brush to inscribe the talismanic characters, repeatedly writing the four syllables *Om Hūm Trāḥ Līḥ*. Recite the incantation aloud:

*"Supreme Mysterious Origin, Most High Dao Lord,
Command this servant to enact the talisman,
Illuminating the dark prisons,
Liberating the souls of the dead.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by law and ordinance!"*

Prepare ten talismans in total, each inscribed according to the prescribed form. Next, inscribe one talisman each for Water and Fire. Upon completion, recite the central scripture three to five times. Fumigate the talismans over incense and enshrine them in a pure place until nightfall for use.

**Talisman of True Fire**
*Taiyang qi*, *Li* mudra, inscribed in vermilion on yellow paper.
**Incantation of the Solar Essence**
*"Essence-pearl of the Solar Soul, gleaming with verdant radiance,
Revolving rosy clouds, dark flames, and whirlwind apparitions.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by law and ordinance!"*

**Talisman of True Water**
*Taiyin qi*, *Kun* mudra, inscribed in black on yellow paper.
**Incantation of the Lunar Essence**
*"Lunar essence, warm and resonant as the flute’s sigh,
Fragrant and lustrous in the void’s embrace.
Graceful, empty, and numinous as orchids,
Lush blossoms entwined in elegance.
Pure gold, limpid and bright,
Glowing countenance, towering in splendor.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by law and ordinance!"*

**Talisman of the True Form of Mount Fengdu**
(Previously detailed in the *Refinement and Liberation* section.)

Next, hold and recite the central scripture of the *Numinous Writ* thirty times; reciting more when time permits is especially auspicious.

**Talisman for Transforming Offerings**
To be employed in the rites of the pure night.

At a secluded, open space, arrange the offering of grain. No lamps or candles should be placed near the offering; instead, set up a small table several *zhang* away—greater distance is even better. Upon this table, place an incense burner, pure water, and lamps. Proceed with the ritual. This is because offerings to spirits should not be tainted by human breath or the proximity of lamps and candles. Yet today, many place them amid bustling crowds and bright lights, which is most improper.

Next, the officiant burns incense and approaches the altar to invoke the deities. Offer incense and invoke the sacred ranks, following the same procedure as at dawn.

*"With reverence, we gaze toward the celestial mercy, beseeching witness to our covenant and deliverance. May the jade tones gather qi, and the numinous winds amass mist. May the Purple Void flourish in splendor, aiding the myriad immortals. Holding the registers and grasping the ledgers, may all assemble before the Emperor. Grant that this humble servant’s petition be heard, and all be fulfilled as spoken."*

*"I, [Name], your servant of the ritual rank, dare not shun divine punishment but venture to address the celestial throne. Humbly, I pray for your radiant gaze and distant witness to this covenant. Reflecting upon my unworthy self—a mere mortal presuming to oversee the highest transformations—I forget my lowliness and dare to present this plea. Within the Three Paths and Nine Realms, among the ten kinds and four births of beings sunk in stagnation, rare are those who encounter good fortune, and few are touched by the mysterious grace. In the stillness of the hidden gates, they long to renew themselves but find no path. In the boundless sea of suffering, they yearn for liberation but see no way. This is the consequence of their past habits, and truly, their plight in delusion is pitiable. Were it not for the august heaven’s compassion and the great Dao’s mercy, how could these sunken souls escape the yin realms?*

*I, your servant, reverently follow the true teachings, devoutly preparing this feast of offerings. I announce the talismans of transcendence and refinement, and recite the secret scriptures of the Great Brahma’s Numinous Writ, to aid the myriad kinds and universally deliver the four births. Though my earnest devotion is but a small offering, may it lift even a few from the depths of darkness. Humbly, I pray the Dao’s compassion will take note, and the celestial workings will show forbearance. May the radiance of the Two Luminaries descend in secret, and the true qi of the Five Phases be spread abundantly. Entrust me with the refining power, permit me to proclaim and enact it. Illuminate the gloom to reveal brightness, rescue the sunken and raise them to deliverance. Your servant’s heart is filled with boundless gratitude and hope for your grace."*

Bowing deeply, he kneels and prostrates himself twice, then retreats to his original position.

Next, burn the summons talisman and the true scripture for transforming spirits and calling them forth. Proceed with visualization and ritual action.

The Bureau of the Numinous Treasure’s Great Law issues its mandate to the attending officers, following the dawn ritual’s form. Summon the Five Paths’ great spirits, the local earth gods, the deities of the village and domain, the lords of the Yellow Springs and the Barrows, and all masters of the place. Hasten to the altar!

*"Having already reported to the Celestial Emperor the matters previously mandated, now swiftly gather the wandering souls and stagnant spirits from the Nine Provinces’ territories, the Five Paths, Three Ways, Ten Kinds, and Four Births. Hasten to the altar to reverently receive the offerings and refinement, partake of celestial grace, attain ranks, and ascend to rebirth. Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by the Celestial Emperor’s law and ordinance!"*

Next, transform the offerings. Use the true scripture of the Five Paths, burning it at the four sides of the grain vessel according to one’s capacity. Visualize the life qi of the five directions descending into the vessel. Burn the talisman and blow its ashes over the vessel, scattering them into the air. In an instant, it transforms into a celestial kitchen, its wondrous delicacies filling the vessel, vast and towering. If not performing the Numinous Treasure ritual, use the *Talisman for Transforming Offerings* in place of the true scripture. Quietly recite the central scripture once for each direction.

The officiant stands at a distance and performs the summoning. If conducting the ritual alone, silently intone:

*"The Great Tenuous Yellow Banner of the Supreme Polestar,
The Numinous Pennant of the Peerless One commands.
Summon the Long Night’s Repository,
Open the path to receive the reborn souls."*

Solemnly extend the summons:

*"To the hosts of the Heavenly Path,
The hosts of the Divine Path,
The hosts of the Human Path,
The hosts of the Hell Path,
The hosts of the Hungry Ghost Path,
The hosts of the Animal Path,
The womb-born,
The egg-born,
The moisture-born,
The transformation-born,
Beneath the vast sky,
Within the Six Directions,
Those with masters and those without,
Those who embrace spirits and hold consciousness,
From the Three Ways and Nine Nights,
Of a thousand forms and ten thousand shapes,
Whether male or female in body,
Whether recently transformed or long departed,
The sunken spirits and stagnant souls—
All are summoned to come forth
And receive this deliverance and uplifting!"*

*"We have heard that the wondrous Dao lies hidden in obscurity, setting the ultimate standard through the movement of yin and yang. The supreme numen is elusive, shaping creation and dividing forms. Once the Two Modes were established, the myriad things were born, all emerging from the crucible of transformation, some returning to the sheltering canopy. Yet as the people and things multiplied, customs lost their simplicity. The age of primordial vastness faded, and the world grew ever more shallow. The vicissitudes of wealth and poverty, honor and lowliness shifted endlessly, each following its own path. The interplay of fortune and misfortune, prosperity and decline, drove them along divergent roads. The distinction between good and evil sprouted, and thus arose the separation of ascent and descent. Across the distant expanse of past and present, the silent darkness of the unseen realms stretches endlessly. If beings cannot follow their karma to rebirth, they remain bound by their conditions, mired in stagnation. Thus, those who ascend are few, while those who fall behind are many. Poverty and lowliness differ in life, but death levels all equally. Though one may have exhausted the heights of wealth and honor in life, in death, they must still escape the depths. If they did not serve in the courts of immortals, they must return to the ranks of the noble. Yet how can this be, when their merits vary in depth and their virtues differ in degree? Some, lingering in the old wanderings of Luoyang, still halt their chariots in the dark capital. Others, who held command in the military or stood among the ranks of war, knew only to exert themselves in loyalty and diligence, never sparing their bodies in the wilds. Their wives and children are far away, their sacrifices unheard. Their forms are lost, their spirits have no refuge. Some left home to study, or carried their satchels in search of teachers, seeking office and fame, only to stray from their original aspirations. Though they harbored talent and skill, their initial resolve went unfulfilled. Little did they know that the days and months would pass, and their allotted time would suddenly arrive. Others ascended the paths of officialdom, standing among the court’s ranks. Some achieved the utmost in fame and position, only to face peril; others had not yet attained high rank when their fate arrived.
