The myriad phenomena of the forest of existences remain formless and unfathomable in their solemnity. The ten directions encircle all, their vastness impossible to encompass. Yet, in purifying the fast to serve the Emperor, how could high and low be scattered and disparate? Only through utmost sincerity in moving the spirits should Heaven and humanity interact. Now, as the altar grounds are to be solemnized, bells and chimes sound in unison, their melodies composing the music of the celestial spheres, as if the spirits wander in the Emperor’s presence. The lofty tones of Brahman chant faintly resemble the scenes of the Mysterious Capital. We redouble our sincerity and join in praise. Next, the ritual proceedings commence, circling the altar before exiting. The High Priest enters the oratory to consecrate the water, while the Dao assembly continues the rites at the altar. A Daoist of dignified bearing is pre-selected to perform the *Rite of Prohibiting the Altar*.

**Rite of Prohibiting the Altar**
Visualize the Three Masters in the west. Envision the crimson-robed perfected officials descending upon the water vessel in the Dipper’s chariot, their swords placed at the Earth Gate. Offer incense and declare:
Your subordinate, [Name], with utmost reverence and trepidation, bows his head and prostrates twice, humbly addressing the sacred assembly.
We have heard that at the inception of the primordial qi, yin and yang were set in motion to establish the ultimate. At the beginning of the Two Modes, purity and turbidity initiated the unfolding of Heaven. Having nurtured the multitude of beings, the manifold transformations were thus revealed. Therefore, the Five Sections were disseminated, serving as the foundation of scriptures and canons. The Three Caverns were proclaimed, grandly inaugurating the lineage of teachings. They safeguard the kalpas, stabilize Heaven and Earth, bring fortune to the nation and peace to the times, dispel poisons and calamities below, deliver the hidden and aid the manifest, universally guiding Heaven and humanity.
We, your subordinates, are but illusory forms bound in delusion, dull and ignorant in our endowment. Fortunate to receive the transformation of the true and correct, we have gained access to the steps of the Dao and its methods. Unable to restrain ourselves in seclusion, we presumptuously aspire to labor in service. We present our words and list our requests, conveying the worldly entreaties. We establish offerings and perform fasts, expounding the canonical models of the August Void. Deeply aware of overstepping our station, we can only hope for your gracious favor. Daring to express our pressing concerns, we disturb the lofty ears of the celestial heights.
We, your subordinates, respectfully follow the petitioner’s intent, with all sincerity detailed in the memorial. Reverently adhering to the luminous statutes, we solemnly open the ritual seat. In the ninefold purity of the Dao’s realms, we pray for a single thought’s resonance. Among the true administrations of the Three Realms, we wish for the multitude of spirits to witness and reflect. For this humble and mundane domain is nothing but a realm of dust and俗. We fear that defiling impurities may rashly intrude, or that malevolent and deviant forces may not yet be expelled. Only by borrowing the pervasive radiance of Heaven may we hope to dispel the influences of pernicious sorcery.
We humbly beseech the exalted Emperor to deign to consider our petition. May the Heavenly Perfected and Great Sages graciously review our words. May they specially command the relevant offices to dispatch the divine generals, infusing the ritual water with numinous light and embedding majestic brilliance within the sacred blade.

The five qi intermingle in misty profusion, as water, charged by incantation, washes away the turbid vapors of pine. The Seven Stars blaze resplendent, and the sword, following the celestial pivot, annihilates demonic essences. The ten directions stand purified, myriad spirits attend in guard—commands issued reach even the farthest bounds, and words uttered resonate with all responsive beings. Your servant reverently simplifies the writ to preserve the numinous, awaiting the celestial grace of response.

Your servant, [Name], with utmost reverence and awe, bows his head to the ground in repeated prostration, respectfully declares.

Again simplifying the writ, he closes his eyes, raises the Mudra of the Supreme Emperor with his left hand, and the Sword Mudra with his right, then clasps them firmly at his side. Visualizing three steps and nine traces, he summons the Four Numinous Beings.

The Azure Emperor divides his spirit, gathering true essence in the Thunder position. His form extends a thousand fathoms, azure scales manifesting auspicious signs. His nature originates as the Green Dragon, descending to expel evil and sweep away filth, coming to stand at my left.

The Vermilion Emperor divides his spirit, gathering qi in the Fire Palace. Radiant crimson hues gleam with dazzling red wings. His form appears as the Vermilion Phoenix, incinerating malevolence and anomalies, coming to stand before me.

The White Emperor divides his spirit, condensing true essence in the Lake. His dark form of pristine purity roars with celestial resonance. His aspect is the White Tiger, executing deviance and severing monstrosities, coming to stand at my right.

The Black Emperor divides his spirit, nurturing essence in the Water Palace. Crimson serpents and dark tortoises unite in yin-yang harmony. This is called the Dark Warrior, solemnly guarding the altar’s bounds, coming to stand behind me.

Four Numinous Generals, hasten to arrive upon summons. Receiving the imperial decree, you race like lightning and wind.

Next, approaching the altar table, he takes up the water and sword, holding them in hand. For the sword proclaims might and issues commands, while water can scour impurity to restore clarity. Moreover, through recited incantations and the summoning of spirits, the invocation of qi, demonic traces vanish and defiling impurities dissolve without a trace. Reverently following the esoteric canon, he openly declares the celestial decree.

Holding the sword horizontally above the water vessel, he draws qi.

Reverently invoking the Demon King of the Azure Heavens in the East, descend your true qi into my water.
Reverently invoking the Demon King of the Vermilion Heavens in the South, descend your true qi into my water.
Reverently invoking the Demon King of the White Heavens in the West, descend your true qi into my water.
Reverently invoking the Demon King of the Black Heavens in the North, descend your true qi into my water.
Reverently invoking the Demon King of the Yellow Heavens in the Center, descend your true qi into my water.

Great Demon Emperors of the Five Directions, progenitors of the myriad spirits. Wielding banners and drums, you traverse the vast heavens, proclaiming your majestic glory, as all heavens unite in merit. Each descend your true qi into my water.

Your servant [Name], proclaiming the imperial decree of the Supreme Emperor:
My sword suffices to aid water and fire, its form modeled on Heaven and Earth. Its unyielding strength sharpens the blade tempered a hundred times, its snowy edge embodying the Seven Stars. Pointed to the sky, it causes malevolent stars to fall and darken; summoning thunder, purple lightning soars. Now wielding it to rebuke demonic vapors, all ghosts and spirits of the Three Realms are seized and subdued. With a single flourish, ten thousand miles are wholly purified, and earthly realms’ demonic essences are utterly extinguished.

Spraying water once:
My water flows only as directed, congealing or dispersing in due time. Earth’s six qi achieve the power of moisture descending, while Heaven’s one generates the nature of supreme softness. As mist and dew, it engenders without limit; as frost and snow, it enforces stern order with constancy. Now using it to cleanse the altar grounds, I universally summon the upright qi of the Five Heavens. With a single spray, the Six Directions are all without dust, and the earth’s expanse levels into gleaming jade.

Spraying water once.

Next, reciting the Tianpeng Incantation, he sprays water once more.

Then, reciting the incantation, he proceeds to the East to establish the boundary.
Reverently invoking the Limitless Numinous Treasure officials, Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, envoys, functionaries, and soldiers of the East, descend through the void to arrive at the altar grounds. Deploy spirits and distribute qi, search out demonic essences, drive away ghostly bandits—those guilty shall not be spared.
I establish the boundary from the Earth Gate to the East.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute and ordinance!

Reverently invoking the Limitless Numinous Treasure officials, Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, envoys, functionaries, and soldiers of the South, descend through the void to arrive at the altar grounds. Deploy spirits and distribute qi, search out demonic essences, incinerate ghostly bandits—those guilty shall not be spared.
I establish the boundary from the East to the South.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute and ordinance!

Reverently invoking the Limitless Numinous Treasure officials, Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, envoys, functionaries, and soldiers of the West, descend through the void to arrive at the altar grounds. Deploy spirits and distribute qi, search out demonic essences, execute and behead ghostly bandits—those guilty shall not be spared.
I establish the boundary from the South to the West.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute and ordinance!

Reverently invoking the Limitless Numinous Treasure officials, Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, envoys, functionaries, and soldiers of the North, descend through the void to arrive at the altar grounds. Deploy spirits and distribute qi, search out demonic essences, scatter and disperse ghostly bandits—those guilty shall not be spared.
I establish the boundary from the West to the North.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute and ordinance!

Reverently invoking the Limitless Numinous Treasure officials, Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, envoys, functionaries, and soldiers of the Center, descend through the void to arrive at the altar grounds. Deploy spirits and distribute qi, search out demonic essences, bury and conceal ghostly bandits—those guilty shall not be spared.
I establish the boundary from the North to the Center.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute and ordinance!

Next, holding the sword horizontally over the water, he summons the troops and horses.
Reverently invoking the soldiers and cavalry of the Heavenly Immortals, Earthly Immortals, Flying Immortals, Perfected Ones, Divine Humans, Sun, Moon, and Constellations, the Nine Palaces and Five Emperors, the Three Rivers and Four Seas, the Five Peaks and Four Waterways, and the City Gods and Earth Spirits. Array your ranks within and beyond the altar grounds to guard and defend its boundaries. Should there be lingering corpses, old qi, or essences of earth, wood, or stone that do not comply with the Dao, consign them beneath the Dipper’s pivot, buried a thousand fathoms deep, never to move or act again.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by statute and ordinance!

Proceeding to the Ghost Gate, he traces a character for "ghost" on the ground with his sword, then thrusts the blade into the ghost’s heart. Reciting the incantation, he sprays the ground and withdraws the sword.

The Nine Heavens issue their mandate, universally proclaiming to the myriad spirits. Hastening to summon the Heavenly Perfected, all assemble in the imperial court. The Great Unity gazes downward, the Twin Sovereigns attend in form, scrutinizing and suppressing deviance, governing qi and seizing life.

Should any inauspicious forces dare test the divine luminaries,
the Dao of the Azure Sovereign commands the marshaling of spirit troops—
seven gods assume their stations, the Celestial Blade advances to the right,
sword brandished at the vanguard, fire-bells flung in radiant arcs.
The armored couriers are spurred to action, tiger-soldiers and Heavenly Ding,
wind and fire join in battle, striking down deviance and strangling pernicious essences.
Above, they overawe the Six Heavens; below, they seize demonic spirits.
Once awed, once seized, the myriad malevolences are obliterated in form.
The divine halberd sweeps like lightning—no treachery or deviance shall arise.
The Immortal August One holds the tally; those who dare delay the mandate
shall be executed and punished for defying the tally and violating the command.
Let each be reverent, each be vigilant, to preserve this Yellow Tranquility.
The edict of the Nine Heavens is proclaimed—let the ten thousand spirits heed with reverence.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by the Supreme Emperor’s statutes and ordinances!

Next, return to one’s station, restore the water and sword, take up the tablet once more,
and withdraw with a bow. Then ascend the altar to perform the overnight rites,
each according to its proper protocol.
Exiting the oratory, proceed to the master’s tent, observing all sequential rites—
all are found in the *Thirty-Five Ranks of the Yellow Register’s Sequence*.
The protocols for overnight rites and the establishment of fasts are contained
in the *Protocols of Master Guangcheng* and will not be repeated here.
All methods for visualization upon ascending the altar, exiting and entering the chamber,
and the High Priest’s burning of talismans and recitation of secret incantations
are detailed in the *Forty-Second Rank: Altar Talismanic Methods*.
The external protocols for conducting fasts are fully set forth herein.

Here ends *Scroll Twenty of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Rites*
Here begins *Scroll Twenty-One of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Rites*

**Scroll Twenty-One of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Rites**
*The Altar Talismanic Methods, Compiled by Jin Yunzhong of the Right Auxiliary Office of the Primary Bureau of the Southern Court of the Numinous Treasure Daoist Masters*

Whenever establishing an altar for a fast, within ten or seven days prior to the formal petition, first inscribe in cinnabar on green silk the *Talisman for Descending Perfected Ones* and the *Talisman for Summoning Spirits*. Arrange their positions, prepare incense, fire, lamps, candles, pure tea, seasonal fruits, and offerings. The master burns incense morning and evening, recites the central scripture, and devoutly invokes the talismanic messengers. Alternatively, one may carve the talisman’s form onto a lacquered plaque for veneration, or ascend the altar to pay homage, summoning and refining spirits, and invoking divine generals. Both talismans must be inscribed and burned first before proceeding; all employ the seal of the Numinous Treasure Great Rites Bureau.

*Talisman for Descending Perfected Ones*
*Talisman for Summoning Spirits*
Inscribe these two talismans in cinnabar on green silk, and offer incense and flowers to their messengers. After seven days, a thousand perfected ones may descend, and ten thousand spirits may be summoned by writ. When establishing the great Yellow Register altar or conducting refinement rites for the deceased, inscribe them on yellow silk, burn to ash, and scatter to the ten directions—then a thousand perfected ones and ten thousand spirits will gather at the altar, and numinous resonance will be achieved. Those whose faith is not steadfast will be tested by the Five Marchmounts. Without these talismanic texts in a great fast, true spirits will not descend, and all efforts will be in vain. In refinement and summoning rites, without them the Three Officials will detain the soul, and no manifest response will occur. In all altar rites of profound vision, these two talismans are primary. They are the divine script of the Nine Heavens’ Great Radiance, concealed in the Mysterious Palace and not transmitted to the lower world. Whoever leaks this Way will have their soul sink into the Northern Bureau, forever bereft of immortal hope.

*The Three Dawns’ Wisdom-Light Talisman*
Use yellow paper, nine inches long and three inches wide. Inscribe three cinnabar talismans, fumigate them over incense, and employ the *Jade Emperor’s Oral Formula* to visualize the Primordial Celestial Worthy of Original Beginning, descending a stream of wisdom-light to permeate the talisman. When invoking the light, twist the paper into a torch. The High Priest and two Daoist adepts each hold one. The High Priest invokes the light into his hand, returns to his position, then distributes them to the left and right adepts, who scatter and infuse them in sequence.

*Morning Entry Incantation*
Four Luminaries’ Merit Officers, Messengers of Communicating with Perfected Ones,
Transmitting Jade Lads, Attendant Pure Maidens of the Oratory—
for this servant’s communication, may the oratory’s true spirits
and the Upper Prime’s generative qi enter this servant’s body,
so that all my petitions may be heard above.

*Exit Incantation*
Exiting yin to enter the viscera, the myriad spirits open the passageways.
When affairs are concluded, I request the Yellow Chamber be sealed.
Attendant Pure Maidens of the Oratory, clearly guard the divine palace.

*Night Entry Incantation*
Four Upper Merit Officers, Dragon-Tiger Messengers,
Orthodox Unity’s generative qi, Attendant Pure Maidens of the Oratory—
for this night’s petition, may the Illuminating Lad and the Upper Prime Maiden
accompany me into the Yellow Chamber,
so that all my communications may be heard above.

*Exit Incantation*
The Mysterious Upper Supreme Yin opens the eight windows.
Whatever I have declared, may the Maiden communicate the numinous.
When affairs are concluded, return to your positions; the myriad spirits silently repose.

For left and right foot placement, see the *Morning Audience and Entering the Oratory* section. When entering, always lead with the right foot; when exiting, lead with the left. Before entering, visualize the Incense Official’s Messengers and the Dragon-Tiger Lords flanking the incense table. At dawn, also visualize the Four Luminaries’ Merit Officers, Messengers of Communicating with Perfected Ones (one each), Attendant Jade Lads of the Oratory, and Transmitting Jade Maidens (two each)—six in total, arrayed left and right. At night, visualize the Four Upper Merit Officers, Attendant Pure Maidens of the Oratory, Illuminating Lad, Upper Mysterious Maiden (one each), and Dragon-Tiger Messengers (two)—six in total, arrayed left and right. "Entering the chamber" refers to entering the Earth Chamber. When ascending the altar, visualize and recite secret incantations to the left of the Earth Chamber. When exiting, visualize the officials, generals, and jade maidens transmitting the fast’s sincerity, then dispersing. In all Three Caverns’ scriptural protocols, the jade maidens’ entry and exit employ these incantations. Recently, some shallowly learned individuals, seeing these incantations in the *Orthodox Unity’s Essential Pointers* applied to morning audiences, have claimed them as part of the Cavern Mystery’s ritual registers. Such arbitrary alterations, driven by a fondness for novelty, are unreliable.

*Ascending the Altar*
When ascending the altar, first offer incense to the Six Canopies. Next, one attendant carries the hand censer, and one rings the chime, leading the master to ascend the altar. The High Priest and Daoist adepts divide left and right, standing in order before the altar. Before entering the altar’s interior, the High Priest first enters the Earth Chamber, ascends the inner altar, and the adepts follow. Recently, some have merely circled as usual, with the High Priest trailing the adepts, entering the Xun Chamber to the outer altar’s rear before bowing. The High Priest should enter the Earth Chamber first, while the adepts stand aside, allowing the High Priest to pass through—this lacks solemnity. Thus, the *Jiangshi Established Rites* also states: when ascending the altar, the High Priest leads; when exiting, the High Priest follows. This accords with ancient protocols and is most fitting. The High Priest recites secret incantations upon entering the Earth Chamber, and all adepts enter the altar. The Precentor circles to the central altar’s east, facing west; the six officers stand at the central altar’s west, facing east. The High Priest and the fast’s sponsor ascend the Heavenly Gate together, enter the inner altar, and offer incense to the ten directions. During the day, begin with the east; at night, begin with the north. Next, offer incense at the imperial table. The High Priest burns incense, recites secret incantations, and visualizes as prescribed. The officials in attendance offer incense. When finished, exit the Heavenly Gate, circle left to the central altar, and face north. The High Priest returns to his position, offers incense in the hand censer, and recites secret incantations. Then proceed according to protocol until the censer is returned. The chime-ringer intones the *Hymn of Studying Immortality*, leading the way, followed by the adepts. The High Priest exits the inner altar through the Heavenly Gate to the central altar’s foremost position. The adepts exit the Earth Chamber, recite incantations, circle through the Xun Chamber, proceed to the master’s tent, turn toward the oratory, and enter as usual.

All gates outside the altar are to be sealed, leaving only the Xun Chamber open. The central altar is entered and exited through the Earth Gate, while the inner altar is entered and exited solely through the Heavenly Gate. Recently, some have taken to entering both the central and inner altars through the Earth Gate and exiting through the Heavenly Gate—this is entirely incorrect. Both the *Rituals of Master Guangcheng* and the *Dharma of Lu Jianji* state: "Enter through the Earth Gate, ascend through the Heavenly Gate, and offer incense to the Ten Directions." This has been the ancient practice, and one must not follow vulgar custom.

The inner altar emulates Heaven, thus entry and exit are through the Heavenly Gate. The central altar symbolizes Earth, hence entry and exit are through the Earth Gate—this must not be altered.

**Morning Visualization:**
At dawn, visualize *qi* of azure clouds filling the ritual hall. Azure dragons and lions, eight in number each, guard as prescribed in the scriptures, securing the altar as the central axis. Front and rear are defended. Heavenly immortals, earthly immortals, sun, moon, and stars, the five emperors’ legions, nine hundred million cavalry, overseers of the fast, and officials of the Three Realms array themselves to left and right.

This follows the initial visualization of the Three Supreme Lords upon the altar, seated in the Heavenly Treasure Terrace with the scripture to the left and the master to the right, as if in solemn audience. Then the host of immortals and myriad spirits take their stations, forming the Mystic Terrace’s immortal assembly. Subsequent rituals proceed in order, consistent across the three daily audiences, differing only in *qi*.

Next, visualize azure *qi* rising from the liver like ascending clouds, with azure dragons and lions within it. Heavenly immortals, earthly immortals, flying immortals, and the five emperors’ legions of the five directions envelop the bodies of all present in the ritual hall. This begins with visualizing the azure *qi* of Heaven descending from above, while one’s own azure *qi* emerges from within, merging and filling all space.

At night, *qi* withdraws; at dawn, sunlight has yet to shine. The power of Wood flourishes, and azure *qi* arises naturally. The heavenly, earthly, and flying immortals are the divine soldiers and cavalry invoked at the altar’s founding. The Five Emperors are the Azure Emperor of the East, the Vermilion Emperor of the South, the White Emperor of the West, the Black Emperor of the North, and the Yellow Emperor of the Center—these are the true *qi* of the five directions, governing the seasons and their sequences, commanding legions to protect the ritual altar as their duty.

Thus, the ritual officers—First Mystery, Second Mystery, Third Mystery, and Four Beginnings—are all deities of the seasonal nodes, corresponding to this system. Further visualize the five viscera and five sacred peaks, the true *qi* of the Five Emperors, emerging from the nose to envelop one’s body, filling the altar with radiant light that illumines the Ten Directions. A circular halo appears above the head, bright as the sun and moon, while the body shines golden, revealing all within and without.

These Five Peaks are not external but correspond to the five viscera within the body, as depicted in alchemical diagrams. The earlier reference to the Five Peaks’ legions invokes the spirits of mountains and rivers, who dispatch their forces to guard the altar. Thus, the visualization of Heaven’s azure *qi* naturally extends to the legions—these are external, not internal.

All such practices operate through internal-external resonance. The middle passage again mentions the Five Emperors of the five directions, who are the deities of the four seasons’ *qi* and nodes, as previously described. Here, the Five Emperors refer to the *qi* within the body, for when *qi* is numinous, spirits are born. As in the *Perfect Scripture of the Great Cavern*, the Five Emperors appear in the visualization of the spine—this pertains to the Heavenly Treasure, and thus is not frequently cited in the Numinous Treasure rites.

The five viscera are detailed in the *Inner Radiance of the Yellow Court*; one may consult it for further study. For altar rituals and fasts, simplified methods suffice: merely visualize azure *qi* from the liver, white *qi* from the lungs, yellow *qi* from the spleen, vermilion *qi* from the heart, and black *qi* from the kidneys, first filling the body, then emerging from the nose like ascending clouds. Within each of the five *qi*, an emperor appears, clad in flowing ceremonial robes matching the direction’s color. The *qi* fills the ritual hall, and as one’s body rises with its lightness, inner and outer shine brilliantly. No longer a vessel of blood and filth, a halo like the sun’s disk forms behind the head, illumining the Ten Directions and gilding the body in radiant light.

**Noon Visualization:**
Visualize *qi* of yellow clouds filling the ritual hall, with qilin and lions guarding front and rear as before, along with heavenly and earthly immortals—all as in the dawn rite. Further visualize yellow *qi* rising from the spleen like ascending clouds. The five viscera, five sacred peaks, and the true *qi* of the Five Emperors emerge from the nose. Ascend the altar at the *si* hour (9–11 AM) and descend after the fourth quarter of the *wu* hour (noon). As the sun nears its zenith, yang *qi* flourishes. The spleen, which governs Earth, dominates the four seasons and arises in the South through the Fire-Earth cycle. This corresponds to the nurturing of primordial *qi* below, but one must not exceed the central *qi* of noon, lest the visualization clash with the hour, resulting in grave error.

**Evening Visualization:**
Visualize *qi* of white clouds filling the ritual hall, with white tigers and lions as before. Further visualize white *qi* rising from the lungs like ascending clouds, with white tigers and lions within it—all as in the dawn rite. Visualize the five viscera, five sacred peaks, and the true *qi* of the Five Emperors emerging from the nose, as in the morning method. Ascend the altar before sunset, while *qi* is not yet fully yin, and white *qi* flourishes, aligning with the primordial *qi* to harmonize the visualization.

The primordial *qi* within the body resides in the lower cinnabar field, while the lungs are the mother of Water. Lung *qi* flourishes at dusk, as Water is about to arise. Thus, white *qi* from the lungs merges with the celestial *qi* above.

I have observed in Master Guangcheng’s *Du Jun’s Compilation of the Yellow Register Fast Rituals* the following: "According to the ancient *Golden Register* rites and the old *Yellow Register* methods, on the eve of the fast’s commencement and at the time of announcing the merits, one first performs the *Natural Audience* before proceeding with the fast."

Thus, the *Initiation Rites of the Fast* states: "Proceed first with the *Natural Audience*, and after the *Three Bows*, announce the fast’s supplementary offices, recite the precepts, and proclaim the prohibitions." This method has been transmitted from Master Lu and Celestial Master Kou through the ages, and over time, all have regarded the *Natural Audience* of the *Numinous Treasure* as the origin and ancestor of fast rituals. Therefore, the *Natural Audience* is performed first to demonstrate that one has not forgotten its roots.

Recently, however, foolish and mediocre scholars, failing to grasp the intentions of the ancient worthies—misled by Zhang Yunguang’s errors—have followed his misguided example. They first appoint the *Six Offices* before the *Mysterious Master*, establish the regulations, and confer the tablets, only then ascending the altar. They claim this follows the fast method of Master Jianji, yet their ignorance has led them to such extremes. Some even imitate and perpetuate this practice, not only inviting the transgression of disordering the Dao but also incurring the sin of slandering the worthy. Those of discernment in the teachings should jointly reject this.

Within the old methods, there is a transmitted error: during the *Natural Audience* at the time of initiating the fast and announcing merits, one should pay homage to the *Numinous Treasure Celestial Worthy*, yet the title of the *Jade Treasure August Celestial Worthy of the Supreme Heaven* is not transmitted. This slightly deviates from the original intent of the *Natural Audience*. It may be due to the passage of time and scribal errors. This ritual has now been corrected accordingly.

This is not a matter of presumptuous conjecture, but rather where ritual propriety naturally leads—so states Master Du. In all the ritual codes of Lu Jianji and Zhang Qingdu, even the slightest divergence is meticulously examined against the original sources, with obsolete texts discarded, as Master Du establishes his own school of thought.

Regarding the three colors of blue, yellow, and white:
At dawn, one visualizes blue *qi*; at noon, yellow *qi*; and at dusk, white *qi*. The commentary further explains: these are the primordial origins of Heaven and Earth. Thus, the *Scripture of Spirit Generation* states: "The blue, yellow, and white *qi* constitute the Three Realms and Three Palaces, the foundational origins of all generations." This aligns perfectly with the ritual codes of Lu Jianji, with no discrepancies. It is therefore clear that the three daily audiences involve visualizing the blue, yellow, and white *qi*.

In recent times, Lu’s ritual codes have become fragmented and incomplete. Though I, Yunzhong, have examined several versions that closely resemble one another, those transmitted in eastern Zhejiang uniformly alter the noon visualization to red *qi*—a matter of grave consequence. For the blue realm pertains to Heaven as the Jade Clarity Realm, and to humans as the Upper Cinnabar Field, its *qi* rooted in the liver. The yellow *qi* pertains to Heaven as the Highest Clarity Realm, and to humans as the Middle Cinnabar Field, its *qi* rooted in the spleen. The white *qi* pertains to Heaven as the Great Clarity Realm, and to humans as the Lower Cinnabar Field, its *qi* rooted in the lungs. These principles derive from the orthodox scriptures. Thus, the *qi* within the body harmonizes with the *qi* of Heaven, each in its proper time.

Yet some, having received transmitted ritual codes with minor variations, claim these as Lu Jianji’s definitive teachings—though such interpretations may not align with the underlying principle. Master Du Guangcheng, while noting divergences in Lu’s codes, did not fail to address them. During the Tang dynasty, Lu Jianji’s texts showed no alteration in this regard. However, with the passage of time and repeated transcriptions, errors have proliferated, not limited to this single instance, and even minor discrepancies exist among the original codes. Guangcheng explicitly clarified their origins and lineages. The color of *qi* visualized at noon is a matter of great importance in the fast. Had Lu Jianji’s codes prescribed red *qi* at noon while Guangcheng’s specified yellow, how could he not have detailed their differences?

Guangcheng’s codes, presented to the Supreme Mystery and pledged before Heaven and Earth, have been practiced by later generations with manifest responses. Not even the *Established Rites* of the Jiang lineage, which claims to surpass Guangcheng in textual verification and to surpass the ancients in breadth of study, can match this. Thus, in their altar rites—from the establishment to the dispersal of the altar, and in the Nine Audience codes—they must rely on Master She’s texts. Yet in matters of ritual structure and procedures, they sometimes adopt Master Du’s phrasing and sometimes reject his arguments. Such inconsistencies pervade the *Established Rites*. Claiming superiority over predecessors and surpassing all others, they meticulously reexamine each detail, making their own selections to forge a distinct school. They ought to have entirely rewritten Guangcheng’s ritual texts, discarding his wording to eliminate the flaws of inconsistency and impurity, thereby establishing a lasting model. Yet by rejecting his theories while retaining his language, they risk the blemish of a single oversight in a thousand considerations.

The noon visualization of yellow *qi* is precisely as recorded in Du Guangcheng’s *Altar Establishment* and *Nine Audience* codes. The *Established Rites* incorporates his wording but alters the noon visualization to red *qi*, thereby rejecting one of the three daily visualizations—implying that Du’s teaching is incorrect. If the theory is unsound, how can its language be included?

I, Yunzhong, having been ordained as a preceptor and received transmission of Du Guangcheng’s ritual methods, dare not alter them. Yet among the teachings of my revered masters, it is said: "At the inception of primordial chaos, the Two Modes remained unformed. From the source of the Great Dao, the Three *Qi* were yet unmanifest." Only after the Primordial Unity divided did the Three Spirits emerge, thereby nurturing Heaven and Earth and shaping the myriad things. The Dao is their foundation, the true ancestor of all *qi*. From the One dividing into Three arose the Primordial Three *Qi* of Mystery and Origin. Together, they are called the Great Dao; separately, they are the Three *Qi*. In form, they are named the Three August Ones of the Supreme.

Without this *qi*, Heaven cannot move, Earth cannot stabilize, and humans cannot live. The Three *Qi*, also termed the Three Primes in the scriptures, are the ancestors of the gods and spirits of Heaven and Earth, the origin of all existence. Within the Six Directions, all is the *qi* of the Dao. Where the Dao resides, the Three Primes abide. From utmost emptiness arises numinosity; from supreme numinosity, spirit is born. Thus, the fast altar establishes only the Boundless Great Dao, encompassing the Three *Qi* in its totality. The One *Qi* transforms into Three *Qi*, initially unnameable and formless. When gathered into form, they become the Three August Ones of the Supreme.

Teachings are established through scriptures, and scriptures are transmitted by masters. Thus, scriptures and masters are listed together. In practice, one venerates the master’s dignity and the scripture’s authority. First, one visualizes the Three August Ones of the Supreme within the Heavenly Treasure Terrace, with the Thirty-Six Divisions of August Scriptures to the left and the Great Master of the Mystery Center to the right—this is the teaching of the scriptures. From scriptures to masters, and thence to the thousand perfected and myriad spirits, all are the *qi* of the Dao. The Three August Ones of the Supreme are the ancestors of *qi*. The ritual codes and methods of the fast are transmitted only by masters, hence the veneration of the master.

In this way, self and other, Dao and scripture, remain distinct. Yet through *qi* harmonizing with *qi* and spirit summoning spirit, the mechanism of resonance and the path of response are achieved. Here, the arts of calculation arise—waxing and waning, flourishing and declining, each corresponding to the *qi* of its season. Within the human body, too, the Three *Qi* exist, yet submerged in a single form, they cannot manifest their numinosity.

Without first borrowing the *qi* of the Dao, one cannot invigorate the *qi* of the self. Without settling the spirit of the self, one cannot summon the spirit of the Dao. Thus, the three periods of dawn, noon, and dusk must not err—this is the *qi* of generation and life, filling the *qi* of one’s body to abundance.

The blue-green *qi* resides in the human body within the Upper Cinnabar Field, its root in the Liver-Wood, flourishing between *yin* and *mao*. Therefore, one seizes the moment before dawn, riding the Wood’s ascent. At the altar of the fast, first visualize the *qi* of blue-green clouds, suffusing the ritual space—this is the mysterious *qi* of Heaven. Then contemplate the blue-green *qi* rising from the liver like ascending clouds—this is the mysterious *qi* of the body. Thus, the *qi* of Heaven and the *qi* of the self merge. Thereafter, the hosts of immortal soldiers, the thousand perfected and myriad spirits, encircle and guard the altar—this is the principle of resonance and response.

The yellow *qi* resides in the human body within the Middle Cinnabar Field, its root in the Spleen-Earth. Its flourishing is entrusted to the four seasons, not confined to *zi* alone. Among the Five Phases, only Earth dwells in the Central Palace, lacking a fixed season of generation; its birth arises from Fire. Fire flourishes at *wu*, thus Earth thrives by borrowing the generative *qi* of its mother. Therefore, at the noon audience, first visualize the *qi* of yellow clouds, suffusing the altar—this is the primordial *qi* of Heaven. Then contemplate the yellow *qi* rising from the spleen like ascending clouds—this is the primordial *qi* of the body. Thus, the *qi* of Heaven and the *qi* of the self merge. Thereafter, the hosts of immortal soldiers, the thousand perfected and myriad spirits, encircle and guard the altar—this is the principle of resonance and response.

The white *qi* resides in the human body within the Lower Cinnabar Field, its root in the Lungs. Metal flourishes between *shen* and *you*, at the hour of sunset, thus one rides the Metal’s ascent. At the evening audience, first visualize the *qi* of white clouds, suffusing the altar—this is the original *qi* of Heaven. Then contemplate the white *qi* rising from the lungs like ascending clouds—this is the original *qi* of the body. Thus, the *qi* of Heaven and the *qi* of the self merge. Thereafter, the hosts of immortal soldiers, the thousand perfected and myriad spirits, encircle and guard the altar—this is the principle of resonance and response.

The three *qi* correspond to the Three Fields, yet they issue from the liver, spleen, and lungs—all according to the ritual codes and scriptural norms. The liver, spleen, and lungs are the roots of *qi*; the Upper, Middle, and Lower Fields are its abodes. Now, Wood and Fire are both yang; Metal and Water are both yin. Earth, among the Five Phases, governs Fire as its mother, thus borrowing Fire to determine its season of flourishing. The liver pertains to Wood, which generates Fire—all three are yang in nature. Therefore, though the blue-green *qi* roots in the liver, it belongs to the Upper Field as yang. The lungs pertain to Metal, which generates Water—both are yin in nature. Thus, though the white *qi* roots in the lungs, it belongs to the Lower Field as yin. Only the spleen emits yellow *qi*, corresponding to Earth. Heaven’s five and Earth’s ten converge in the Central Palace to generate Earth, residing at the extreme of Heaven and Earth’s numerology as the root of yin and yang. Its source lies in the Middle Field, flourishing with its mother between *si* and *wu*. Hence, dawn is aligned with blue-green, noon with yellow, and dusk with white, harmonizing with the Three *Qi* of the Mysterious, Primordial, and Original. Through this, one refines the mortal to become a sage, verifies the degrees, and attains communion with the perfected—all fundamentally derived from this principle, which cannot be fully expounded in words.

The methods of practice are scattered throughout the scriptures. The manifestations and colors of *qi* vary greatly, and these are not the same as this method of cultivation. The blue-green, yellow, and white *qi* employed in purification altars are preserved within the various classics and canons. As for Du Guangcheng’s compilation, his retention of the blue-green, yellow, and white *qi* in purification altars follows the *Scripture of Natural Ritual Propriety*. The external Lingbao scriptures are vast, yet only the *Scripture of Salvation* encompasses all methods. Bestowed by the Primordial Beginning and transmitted with commentary by the Dao Lord, it serves as the essential mechanism of the Middle Vehicle. Even should heaven and earth be remade, this scripture cannot be abandoned. The purification rites originate from the Lingbao tradition, a fact universally acknowledged in both ancient and modern times. When performing purifications, the great Lingbao method is taken as the foundation.

The *Scripture of Salvation* states: Enter the chamber, face east, and strike the teeth thirty-two times to ascend through the thirty-two heavens. Bow in reverence thirty-two times, close the eyes, and silently envision the body seated amidst clouds of blue-green, yellow, and white *qi*, both within and without shrouded in mist. There appear the Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, Dark Warrior, lion, and white crane, arrayed to the left and right—this is the method described by the Dao Lord. When reciting scriptures, one cultivates by unifying the three, for chanting the scriptural text may continue from dawn to dusk without fixed hours, thus necessitating the inclusion of the Mysterious, Primordial, and Original Three *Qi*. The phrase "both within and without shrouded in mist" refers to the merging of human *qi* with the *qi* of heaven, the way of resonance between heaven and humanity. Within *qi* arise images, hence the appearance of the four numinous beasts and the like.

In morning purification rites at the altar, the three periods are fixed and unalterable, each aligning with the flourishing of *qi* in the human body to facilitate celestial resonance. First, one visualizes clouds of *qi* filling the purification hall, then imagines the *qi* within the body rising like clouds, harmonizing with the method of resonance described in the scriptures. As *qi* fills and forms images, in the morning one visualizes the Azure Dragon and lion; at noon, the qilin and lion; and at dusk, the White Tiger and lion—consistent with the usage in the scriptures. When reciting scriptures, one envisions them collectively; in purification rites, one visualizes them separately—there is no difference in principle.

Though Master Du’s work is based on the *Scripture of Natural Ritual Propriety*, in Lingbao practice, the methods employed follow the standards of the Most High Dao Lord’s scriptures. Those who preside over these rites must study them deeply. The method of visualization is to be cultivated in daily life as what ought to be practiced, so that when one approaches the altar, one may evoke what is otherwise difficult to evoke.

If at the noon audience one emits red *qi* from the heart, given that fire flourishes at noon, the reasoning is sound. However, one must first visualize clouds of red *qi* enveloping the purification hall. Yet in the celestial realm, none of the ancient scriptures ever speak of red *qi* existing within the three realms. This differs entirely from Master Du’s teachings. In recent times, there have been those who presumptuously exalt themselves.

Those who focus solely on rites of vast emptiness and boundless freedom, seeking to emulate Zhuangzi and Liezi yet falling short, do so merely to deceive the world and steal fame. Thus, in the conduct of fasts and the setting of jiao rites, they employ grand words and lofty discourse to conceal their deficiencies. Many scholars, failing to examine the depth of their teachings, are led astray by their ignorance. As for the Primordial, Original, and Initial Three *Qi*, they speak of them as if tracing back to an undifferentiated beginning. From the Nine *Qi* they reduce to Three *Qi*, and from the Three Realms they condense into One *Qi*. Yet they do not discuss the transformation of the Three Worthies—Primordial, Original, and Initial—nor do they investigate the division of the Three Colors: blue-green, yellow, and white. This is nothing but boastful talk meant to delude others.

The Three *Qi* as blue-green, yellow, and white are also described in the *Scripture of the Three Primes’ Precepts and Admonitions*. It states that when *qi* first congeals, it forms the blue-green, yellow, and white Three *Qi*, placed within the Three Palaces of the Upper Prime. The central *qi* is that of Blue-Green Yang; to the left is the Original Yellow *Qi*, and to the right is the Cavernous White *Qi*, governed by the Heavenly Officials. All these belong to the Jade Purity and are encompassed within the Upper Prime, where the Primordial, Original, and Initial Three *Qi* divide and coalesce.

When the Yellow *Qi* descends and disperses, it forms the Original, Cavernous, Chaotic, and Numinous *Qi*, condensing the essence of Ultimate Yellow. Thus are established the Three Palaces of the Middle Prime, governed by the Earthly Officials. When the White *Qi* descends and disperses, it forms the Chaotic and Moist *Qi*, condensing the essence of Divine Brightness. Thus are established the Three Palaces of the Lower Prime, governed by the Water Officials. This is the division of the Three *Qi* into the Three Primes, as outlined in the scripture.

As for the Three *Qi* residing in the Three Fields within the body, this does not mean that the human body is directly equated with Heaven and Earth. Rather, humans emulate Heaven and Earth to form their bodies, and thus the Three *Qi* are contained within. Heaven is pure yang, condensing the light and clear *qi* to form above. Though Heaven is not the *qi* of Wood or Fire, among the Five Phases, Fire flames upward, being purely yang without doubt. Fire is born from Wood, and Wood is the mother of Fire. The fundamental nature of Wood is that when it grows from the earth, it rises; when placed in water, it floats. Metal, Water, and Earth are all denser than Wood. Fire resides in the southeast—how could it not belong entirely to yang? Being wholly yang, it is above, and thus the Blue-Green *Qi* resides in the Upper Field, symbolizing Heaven. Using the mother while the child follows, the *qi* issuing from the liver becomes the root of the Blue-Green *Qi* within the body. Heaven, with its Blue-Green Yang *Qi*, forms the Three Palaces of the Upper Prime, and thus the Blue-Green *Qi* within the body dwells in the Upper Field.

Water is wholly yin, endowed with the most yielding nature to moisten below. Among the Five Phases, Water’s nature is to seek the low; when placed on earth, it seeps; when forced to a height, it flows, ever-changing yet always settling beneath Earth. Water’s pure yin is also without doubt. Water is born from Metal, and Metal is the mother of Water. The fundamental nature of Metal is that it emerges from Earth, being hard, solid, and heavy. Earth, Water, and Fire are all lighter than Metal. Water, being Metal’s child, resides in the northwest—how could it not belong entirely to yin? Being wholly yin, it is below, and thus the White *Qi* resides in the Lower Field, symbolizing Water. That Water dwells in the Lower Field yet is not Black *Qi* but White *Qi* also follows the principle of the child following the mother, for the *qi* issues from the lungs, becoming the root of the White *Qi* within the body. Water, with its Divine Brightness *Qi*, forms the Three Palaces of the Lower Prime, and thus the White *Qi* within the body dwells in the Lower Field.

Earth, thick and heavy at its root, stabilizes the center of the Two Modes. Earth is Kun and belongs to yin, yet its body is formed of soil. It rightly occupies the Central Palace, and thus the Yellow *Qi* resides in the Middle Field to symbolize Earth. Moreover, the Middle Field is the Crimson Palace. That it emits Yellow *Qi* rather than Red *Qi* is because the *qi* issues from the spleen and dwells in the place of its birth, the child following the mother. Just as the Blue-Green *Qi* does not reside in the liver but in the Upper Field, and the White *Qi* does not reside in the lungs but in the Lower Field, the Three Fields are the dwellings of the Three *Qi*.

According to the *Scripture of the Great Cavern* and the *Scripture of the Yellow Court*, three inches inward between the eyebrows is the Upper Cinnabar Field; the heart, called the Crimson Palace, is the Middle Cinnabar Field; and three inches below the navel is the Sea of *Qi*, the Lower Cinnabar Field. Visualizing the Three Fields and Three *Qi* within the body follows the model of the Three Primes and Three Palaces. Thus, the division of the Dao’s Crimson *Qi* manifests in the body’s function and substance.

Visualizing the blue-green, yellow, and white Three-Colored Clouds in the celestial realm as the Three Beginnings—Primordial, Original, and Initial—is the foundation of the Dao and the source of *qi*. When ordering the Five *Qi* within the body, one does not abandon the function of the Five Phases. Metal and Wood interact; Water and Fire descend and ascend. One must seek the Yellow Matron to mediate within the Central Palace, uniting the Four Images into the Great Elixir. Here, Metal and Water are yin, Wood and Fire are yang, with Earth as the foundation. Thus, the Three *Qi*—blue-green, yellow, and white—are the origin of all methods and the root of all transformations. They initiate the Six Poles and establish the Eight Directions, give birth to the Three Powers and nurture the myriad things. Vastly they encompass Heaven and Earth; minutely they enter the tip of a hair—where do they not pervade as the blue-green, yellow, and white Three *Qi*?

The ritual codes of successive dynasties have been practiced for ages, and the ancient scriptures are all clear on these matters. If one were suddenly to take yellow for red, not only would proper principle be difficult to reconcile, but Heaven’s principle would also be violated. In conducting fasts and visualizing the blue-green, red, and white Three *Qi*, it is evident that one must not mislabel them as the Primordial, Original, and Initial Three *Qi*. Within the body, they are the sources of Wood, Fire, and Metal, born of the liver, heart, and lungs. Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth—the Five Phases—are all equal, yet one discards Water and Earth to employ only Wood, Fire, and Metal—how can this be reasonable? The heart, liver, spleen, lungs, and kidneys—the Five Viscera—form a single body, yet one discards the spleen and kidneys to employ only the liver, heart, and lungs—there must be a definitive explanation. If one speaks in terms of yin and yang, then Wood and Fire belong to yang, while Metal belongs solely to yin. Among the Three *Qi*, this would result in two yang and one yin, their weight and lightness unequal.

Neither does it align with the Three Realms above nor accord with the inner elixirs of the *Dan Jing*. The practice of visualization in ritual altars begins at dawn: first, one contemplates the azure clouds overhead, then the azure *qi* within the body, ascending like clouds. At noon, one visualizes the yellow *qi*; at dusk, the white *qi*—all following this pattern. These are the *qi* of the Three Palaces within the body, corresponding to the *qi* of the Three Realms in the heavens above. Subsequently, one proceeds with the invocation of martial forces, descending the upright *qi* of the Five Directions. It is further clarified that one visualizes the *qi* of the Five Viscera and Five Peaks, the true *qi* of the Five Emperors, emanating from the nose to envelop the body and fill the altar. Here, the Five Viscera are paired with the Five Phases, employing the *qi* of the five colors—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth.

If the aforementioned azure, yellow, and white *qi*, emanating from within the body, are not to be equated with the Primordial, Original, and Initial Three *Qi*, then does this not imply that the functions of the five *qi* within the body each have their own governance? Beyond these explanations, some may seek to substitute the Primordial, Original, and Initial Three *Qi* of the heavens with the azure, red, and white *qi*. Even if one were to argue this before the Original Celestial Worthy, the just and balanced discourse would not yield. The principles of antiquity and the present are decisively unassailable.

There exist private collections of scriptures whose contents are likewise unreliable. Thus, I dare not follow such teachings. Lu Jianji’s ritual manuals have recently been altered by others, rendering them difficult to verify. Master Lu distinguished the origins of the Three Caverns, categorized the Four Auxiliaries, discerned authenticity from falsehood, and examined right from wrong—his achievements surpass those of antiquity and are incomparable to later generations who blindly boast. The two or three preceding arguments are so well-founded that they could not have originated from Master Lu. His works, transmitted from the Song and Qi dynasties to the present—nearly a thousand years—have been copied with varying errors.

Du Guangcheng’s ritual manuals, composed during the Great Tang, not only examined the ritual codes of the Three Caverns but also took Lu’s protocols as their standard. Had such teachings existed in Lu’s works, how could Du have omitted their details from his writings? Even minor discrepancies in other matters are meticulously recorded—how could he have overlooked this? Thus, Lu’s texts remained uncorrupted during the Tang. What I have observed, however, already contains inconsistencies. If such matters did not originate from Master Lu, then the teachings of Cheng and Guangcheng would not only sow confusion within the tradition but also incur the sin of slandering the worthy.

For twenty years, I have boldly practiced and adhered strictly to Guangcheng’s established forms. All fellow disciples who have received and followed this text may do so with confidence. If errors arise in the noon visualization of yellow *qi*, it is not due to Du Guangcheng’s careless use of the *Weiyi Ziran Jing*, nor is it a fault of the Lingbao Great Rites, which follow the *Duren Jing* of the Most High Dao Lord in employing the azure, yellow, and white *qi*—such practice is not to be abandoned.

As for the arrangement of the Three Treasures, the Most High Boundless Great Dao should not be visualized as the Three Worthies or the position of the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center. If the Three Worthies of the Most High are added, then the methods of visualization recorded in the *Lishi Weiyi Jing* would be rendered improper—this, too, is not my fault. I follow the transmissions of the Three Masters as recorded in the scriptures, and my teacher in turn followed Du Guangcheng, who based his work on earlier texts. The azure, yellow, and white *qi* are fundamental to the visualization practices of the *Duren Jing*. Though other scriptures may differ, one should not abandon the foundational source of the *Duren Jing* in ritual practice.

The *Feitian Shibu Miaojing*, comprising thirty-six scrolls, mostly consists of mutually transmitted and copied texts. A few scrolls were printed later, being works of later engraved editions. Among them, the *Duren Jing* is of such antiquity that its authenticity cannot be questioned. The Lingbao Great Rites take the *Duren Jing* as their foundational text, with the visualization of the azure, yellow, and white *qi* as their essential practice. To conduct rituals and fasts while forsaking the foundational principles of the Lingbao tradition—citing obscure and tangential evidence—is impermissible.

Du’s ritual manuals have been followed for four or five hundred years, and later generations must not alter them, for their volumes remain intact. Unlike Lu’s texts, which have endured for ages and become fragmented, they cannot be so easily corrupted. Some recent additions—such as the alternate titles for the Three Worthies of the Most High and the appended verses to the Three Treasures—are the inventions of private individuals. Though these may temporarily confuse the multitude of extant copies, over time, truth and falsehood will become clear.

Fellow disciples who practice this text may proceed with confidence, unburdened by doubt. One may forthrightly report to the Celestial Emperor that the azure, yellow, and white *qi* are employed in the Three Audiences. As I, Jin Yunzhong, now follow Master Du’s ritual manuals, there should be no cause for suspicion. Should any impropriety arise, it is not due to Du’s misguidance of later generations, for the visualization of the Three *Qi* truly originates from the scriptural standards of the Most High Dao Lord. What, then, should I fear?

**End of the Twenty-First Scroll of the *Shangqing Lingbao Great Rites***
**Beginning of the Twenty-Second Scroll of the *Shangqing Lingbao Great Rites***
*Compiled by Jin Yunzhong, Right Assistant of the Governance, Registrar of the Southern Bureau of the Lingbao Dharma Masters*
**Section on Talismanic Methods for the Ritual Altar: The Arrangement of the Three Treasures in the Ritual Altar**

Within the Boundless Dao of the Most High, the Thirty-Six Revered Scriptures stand to the left, and the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center stands to the right. These are the inscribed positions of the Three Treasures, as recorded in Master Guangcheng’s ritual manuals. In all regions where these rites are observed, the original text remains precisely thus—seventeen characters in total, without variation or addition. Recently, however, some have recklessly altered the text, incorporating it into Lu Jianji’s *Ritual of Simplicity*. For instance, the act of offering three pinches of incense with the prayer "May it reach the Three Realms" finds no further elaboration in Du Guangcheng’s manuals. Yet now, the titles of the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High have been appended, followed by the Three Treasures, each assigned to one of the Three Realms, and arbitrarily inserted into Master Du’s ritual texts. Those who first introduced such innovations deserve the most severe condemnation. Neither the unseen nor the manifest realms will tolerate them; the wrath of heaven and humanity alike will descend upon them. To disrupt the teachings and deceive the world is to invite the loss of one’s soul—truly, no pity is warranted. Their nine generations of ancestors will be implicated, a fate most lamentable. The punishment is grave, the calamity profound, and the retribution far-reaching. Yet the Dao is not unkind; it is humanity that brings this upon itself. Let later scholars take heed.

**The Offering of Three Pinches of Incense:**
First pinch of incense: "May it reach the Grand Clarity Realm."
Second pinch of incense: "May it reach the Highest Clarity Realm."
Third pinch of incense: "May it reach the Jade Clarity Realm."

Next, bow reverently and hold the ritual tablet, reciting the incantation in secret:
*"The incense is the scattered radiance of jade blossoms, the congealed smoke of the Nine Qi. The fragrant clouds form a dense canopy, ascending straight to the Nine Heavens. The Golden Youth who attends the incense and the Jade Maiden who conveys words shall transmit my petition, making it heard before the Celestial Emperor. May all that I declare be granted as spoken."*

According to Master Guangcheng’s ritual manuals, the offering of incense proceeds thus: the first pinch is dedicated to the Grand Clarity Realm, the second to the Highest Clarity Realm, and the third to the Jade Clarity Realm—nothing more. Yet in recent times, miscellaneous ritual texts have circulated, claiming instead:
First pinch of incense: "May it reach the Jade Clarity Realm, in offering to the Supreme Dao-Treasure."
Second pinch of incense: "May it reach the Highest Clarity Realm, in offering to the Supreme Scripture-Treasure."
Third pinch of incense: "May it reach the Grand Clarity Realm, in offering to the Supreme Master-Treasure."

Some attribute this to Lu Jianji’s *Ritual of Simplicity*, unaware that Master Lu, who established the teachings and set the model for ten thousand generations, meticulously examined the scriptures to distinguish truth from falsehood across the ages. Having attained liberation and ascended to the ranks of immortals, his compiled ritual texts, though few, were all grounded in scriptural authority and systematic principles. Later generations, failing to investigate their origins, have ascribed many eccentric and novel practices to Lu’s ritual manuals. This abuse was already prevalent during the Tang dynasty. To deceive later learners and slander the worthy ancestors is a grievous offense.

For example, in the *Established Rituals*, it is written:
First pinch of incense: "May it reach the Jade Clarity Realm, in offering to the Wondrously Non-Existent Supreme Emperor, the Self-So Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginnings, the Supreme Dao-Treasure."
Second pinch of incense: "May it reach the Highest Clarity Realm, in offering to the Wondrously Existent Supreme Emperor, the Jade Clarity Great Dao Lord of the Empty Sovereign, the Supreme Scripture-Treasure."
Third pinch of incense: "May it reach the Grand Clarity Realm, in offering to the Perfectly True Supreme Emperor, the Venerable Lord Lao of Myriad Transformations and Primal Chaos, the Supreme Master-Treasure."

Moreover, a clear annotation beneath these lines states: "From Master Guangcheng’s ritual manuals." Yet Master Guangcheng’s works have circulated widely from antiquity to the present, and such phrases have never appeared. It is unclear from whence they originate. Furthermore, in Master Du’s forty-scroll corpus of 230,000 characters, the titles of the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High do not appear in this form, nor are the Three Treasures ever assigned to the Three Venerables, each governing one. Master Jiang, erudite and well-versed in ritual teachings, would not have made such claims. If this doctrine were drawn from obscure or esoteric texts, later scholars could not be expected to know; but to attribute it to Master Du is unfounded. Master Du’s expansive teachings and writings contain not a trace of such eccentric language. Reading his works, one can well imagine his character—how, then, could such a doctrine be falsely ascribed to him? It is unlikely that Master Jiang would have done so; perhaps it was an error in the carving or printing of his texts. Alternatively, the version of Master Du’s ritual transmitted by Master Jiang may have been altered by later hands without proper verification. Master Du’s manuals have spread throughout the world; if only a privately held copy contained such additions, how could they have been universally inserted into every household’s version?

The Boundless Dao of the Most High is the ancestor of the myriad *qi* and the source of all transformations. The forms of heaven and earth, the myriad beings and kinds, all emerge from the Great Dao. The scriptures are the writings of the Dao, and the masters are the ministers of the Dao—they, too, arise from the Dao. Thus, in the ritual altar, the Boundless Dao is established, with the Thirty-Six Revered Scriptures to the left and the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center to the right. For the Dao is fundamentally a single *qi*, formless and nameless. When this single *qi* divides into three, it becomes the Three *Qi* of the Mysterious, Primordial, and Original, and from the emptiness, spirits are born—hence the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High. Though all transformations and beings emerge from the Dao, the Three Venerable Ones serve as its principal embodiments. In the establishment of the teachings, during the Dragon Han kalpa, the *Dongzhen* scriptures were revealed; during the Crimson Brightness kalpa, the *Dongxuan* scriptures emerged; and during the Highest Sovereign kalpa, the *Dongshen* scriptures appeared—these constitute the Thirty-Six Scriptures. With the revelation of the scriptures, the teachings flourished, and the transmission of the scriptures and teachings depended upon the masters. Thus, the establishment of scriptures and masters in the ritual altar is the foundation of the ritual manuals.

The Three Venerable Ones of the Most High are all manifestations of the Great Dao; the scriptures of the Three Caverns are all true scriptures; and the teachings of the Three Vehicles are all transmitted by masters. To assign the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginnings alone to preside over the Great Dao and serve as the Dao-Treasure is indeed appropriate. Yet the Three *Qi* and Three Venerables are fundamentally of one body. If the Dao Lord and Lord Lao were excluded from this arrangement, then the Dao Lord and Lord Lao would be without the Dao.

Moreover, to assign the Dao Lord alone to preside over the scriptures and serve as the Scripture-Treasure and Scripture-Transmitter would be inappropriate. If this role were exclusively attributed to the Highest Clarity, then the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginnings and Lord Lao would be without scriptures. Furthermore, to regard Lord Lao solely as the teacher of humans and heavens and thus make him the exclusive Master-Founder, or to claim that the Mysterious Center is Lord Lao’s transformed body—these are rigid and untenable positions. Such assertions appear only in texts like *The Veritable Records of Lord Lao*. If these claims were true, then Lord Lao, as a Heavenly Venerable, would be deemed the Supreme Emperor; if he manifested a transformed body to propagate the teachings, he would merely be the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center, and one should not trace his origins to name him as such.

According to the *Scripture on the Ritual Dignity of Masters*, within the Heavenly Treasure Terrace, the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High are enshrined, with the thirty-six sacred scriptures on the left and the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center on the right. This arrangement signifies that scriptures possess form, masters take shape, but the Great Dao is formless and beyond conception. Since the Dao is the primal origin, governing all life, serving as the ancestral root through kalpas, and forming the foundation of the Three Realms, it is fitting to enshrine the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High, assisted by the scriptures and attended by the masters—this principle is self-evident. How, then, could one claim that the Dao Lord exclusively presides over the scriptures while Lord Lao serves solely as the master?

Furthermore, the titles of the Three Venerable Ones in the scriptures are simply the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginnings, the Most High Dao Lord, and the Most High Lord Lao. Their alternate titles are the Heavenly Treasure Lord, the Numinous Treasure Lord, and the Divine Treasure Lord. When named after the Three Realms, they are called Jade Clarity, Highest Clarity, and Supreme Clarity; when named after the Three Caverns, they are called Cavern of Perfection, Cavern of Mystery, and Cavern of Divinity. Such is the established convention.

In the ritual manuals of Master Jiang, the titles of the Three Venerable Ones differ, yet in the *Guangcheng Ritual*, such exalted titles were never used. Master Du, as a Grand Academician of the Chongyuan Institute and a chief minister of the Tang court, honored Lord Lao as the imperial ancestor. Thus, he bestowed upon him the august title *Sacred Ancestor Golden Portal Wondrous Non-Existent Heavenly Emperor*. When Master Du compiled the ritual codes during the Tang, how could he dare to discard the court’s exalted titles and replace them with the mutable and chaotic theories of later ages? The claim in Master Jiang’s ritual manuals that the sacred titles of the Three Venerable Ones and the division of the Three Treasures derive from Master Du’s works is unfounded.

As for Lord Lao’s title *Supreme Virtue Emperor of Primordial Chaos*, this was an honorific bestowed by the Song dynasty and did not exist in the Tang. Moreover, the Three Treasures of the Most High, though divided from a single *qi* and originating as one body, are fundamentally without hierarchy or distinction. Between the wondrously non-existent and the wondrously existent lies the ineffable, which defies differentiation. To designate the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginnings as the Wondrously Non-Existent Supreme Emperor and the Dao Lord as the Wondrously Existent Supreme Emperor is a principle that cannot be justified.

In the second year of the Guangming era, Master Du Guangcheng presented his *Chart of the Primordial Chaos of the Three Realms* to the court. In its preface, he stated: "The Heavenly Venerable is the primordial origin of the ultimate Dao, spontaneously arising. When dissolved, it becomes *qi*; when condensed, it takes form. It is neither non-existent nor existent, neither form nor emptiness, without end or beginning, eternally abiding. Dwelling in the upper realm, it is the origin of the myriad heavens; in the middle realm, the root of the myriad transformations; in the lower realm, the most venerable of the myriad transformations. Without a name to honor it, it is forcibly called the Heavenly Venerable. For the people of the world revere it as they do Heaven—gazing upon it, it is boundlessly high; striving to reach it, there are no steps. Vast and obscure, it cannot be fathomed by reason, expressed in words, ascended by stages, or measured by lifespan. It gives birth to the myriad things yet does not govern them; it guides the myriad transformations yet does not speak. Most exalted and supreme, it is called the Heavenly Venerable."

This is Master Du’s discourse. Since the *Chart of the Primordial Chaos* has been carved in stone and disseminated throughout the world from the Tang to the present, its contents are widely known and cannot be privately altered. Given the origins and development of Master Du’s theories, how could he have designated the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginnings as the Wondrously Non-Existent and the Dao Lord as the Wondrously Existent?

Consider the beings of the world: they possess form and substance and may be called "existent." The spirits of the yin realm, being formless and bodiless, may be called "non-existent." As for the Heavenly Venerables of the Three Realms, to call them "existent" would be incorrect, for they cannot be seen or exhausted; yet to call them "non-existent" would also be incorrect, for they give birth to heaven and earth and nurture the myriad things. From the ancient scriptures and classics to the works of Zhuangzi, Liezi, and the hundred schools, none have definitively asserted their existence, nor have they decisively denied their non-existence. If the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginnings is fixed as the Wondrously Non-Existent, then he cannot be said to exist—thus, the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginnings would be no more than a yin spirit. If the Dao Lord is fixed as the Wondrously Existent, then he cannot be said to be non-existent—thus, the Dao Lord would be no more than an ordinary person. Such a view utterly fails to comprehend the nature of the Three Venerable Ones. If this theory were truly derived from Master Du’s ritual codes, then even the most ignorant and vulgar would surpass Master Guangcheng in understanding.

Master Jiang’s works have been widely published. If later scholars do not examine Master Du’s complete writings, they will mislead future generations—how profound would such an error be! Should any scripture claim that the Celestial Venerable of Primordial Beginnings is the Wondrously Non-Existent Supreme Emperor and the Dao Lord is the Wondrously Existent Great Emperor, unless these words issue from the golden mouth of the Heavenly Venerable himself, they must be the fabrications of mortals. Those who first propagate such falsehoods deserve punishment without pardon. If such claims lack any basis and are arbitrarily asserted, then to slander Master Du Guangcheng in this manner—does one’s conscience remain untroubled?

It is unclear who interpolated these ideas into Master Du’s ritual codes, leading Master Jiang to be misled as well. As for the tablets of the Three Treasures inscribed on ritual altars, all traditional versions of Master Du’s ritual codes state simply: *The Most High Boundless Great Dao*, *The Thirty-Six Sacred Scriptures*, and *The Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center*—these three positions alone. In Master Jiang’s *Established Ritual*, however, the central tablet reads *The Most High Boundless Great Dao*, the left reads *The True Writs and Treasure Talismans of the Thirty-Six Sacred Scriptures*, and the right reads *The Three Venerable Ones of the Most High, the Saints of the Ten Directions, and the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center*.

Master Jiang does not annotate his sources, yet the world claims his teachings derive from Lu Ke. Upon examining Lu Ke’s works, however, one finds that in Zhedong such transmissions are indeed written thus, while in other regions most versions remain identical to Master Du’s ritual codes. Moreover, the texts of Lu Ke’s codes are of great antiquity, rife with errors. Yet where principle resides, there stands the Boundless Great Dao and the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High. Thus the scriptures say: *“Above, there is no further ancestor; only the Dao is the body”*—these are the Three Venerable Ones. Again, it states: *“The Thirty-Six Sacred Scriptures to the left”*—the true writs and treasure talismans are already contained within the scriptures, so it seems unnecessary to add these four characters. This may still be tolerable. But to further append the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High to the master’s position—is not the Boundless Great Dao itself the Three Venerable Ones? Does this imply that beyond the Three Venerable Ones there exists another Great Dao? Moreover, the scriptures are merely the books expounded by the Three Venerable Ones. Now, with the scriptures placed to the left and the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High occupying the master’s position to the right, the Three Venerable Ones are thus positioned below the scriptures. If the Three Venerable Ones descend to become the master, then the Great Dao no longer has a sole sovereign. The Three Venerable Ones and the Great Dao cannot be divided into two separate paths. If the Great Dao is these Three Venerable Ones, and the master’s position is likewise occupied by the Three Venerable Ones, this inevitably leads to repetition. Or if the Three Venerable Ones in the master’s position are not the Three Venerable Ones of the Great Dao, then there would be two sets of the Most High’s Three Venerable Ones. Among the various scriptures and canons, some may have different origins. If they are not to be ranked equally with the Dao, the scriptures, and the master as the Three Treasures, then to regard the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High and the Saints of the Ten Directions all as masters—what objection could there be? Yet if their provenance does not pertain to ritual affairs, it becomes difficult to cite them indiscriminately.

Within the ritual altar, since the central position is already occupied by the Most High Boundless Great Dao, the master’s position cannot again be occupied by the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High. The *Scripture on Ritual Dignity and Etiquette* explicitly states: *“First visualize the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High in the Heavenly Treasure Terrace, with the Thirty-Six Sacred Scriptures to the left and the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center to the right.”* This aligns with the earlier principle that the Great Dao is formless and thus visualized as the Three Venerable Ones. Supported by the scriptures and transmitted by the master, this arrangement matches the inscribed tablets, its reasoning evident and beyond doubt. Now, if the Three Venerable Ones are moved to the master’s position, the scriptural instructions cannot be followed, nor can one visualize them thus during the ritual. In Master Jiang’s *Established Ritual*, at the outset of the visualization, he cites the *Scripture on Ritual Dignity and Etiquette*, saying: *“First visualize the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High, with the scriptures to the left and the master to the right.”* Yet in the remaining position tablets, he appends the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High to the master’s position. Thus, while others in his lineage must visualize the Three Venerable Ones at the Great Dao’s position, and again at the master’s position, his followers alone must visualize six Venerable Ones—one might call this thorough. But if the Three Venerable Ones are visualized at the master’s position, then the Great Dao has nothing left to visualize. Since the Three Venerable Ones have been relocated to the master’s position, Master Jiang ought to have omitted the visualization passage from the *Scripture on Ritual Dignity and Etiquette* to align with the position tablets and avoid self-contradiction. The proper course is to unify them according to principle. This is not a matter of clinging to one’s own views to refute others, nor of citing unrelated scriptures to fabricate falsehoods. How could the Three Venerable Ones of the Most High share the same position as the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center? Neither in heaven nor on earth does such a principle exist.

Furthermore, in the position tablets, if one follows Master Du’s ritual codes—placing the Thirty-Six Sacred Scriptures to the left and the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center to the right—what obstruction arises? What matter is left incomplete? What principle is violated? What standard is transgressed? Why then append redundant phrases and embellishments? Yunzhong does not stubbornly uphold Master Du Guangcheng’s texts to the exclusion of all others. Yet when reasoning fails, when heaven is deceived and the world misled, one cannot blindly follow. Though compelled to clarify, this is not a task he relishes. Yunzhong does not wish the world to adopt this teaching, nor does he dare claim Master Jiang’s argument is unsound. Since Yunzhong has received the transmissions of his three masters in this manner, and upon examining the scriptures finds the same, he dares not deviate in practice or proclamation before the Emperor on High. Thus he outlines these points for fellow practitioners of the shared lineage. This is not an attempt to coerce others into agreement.
