Those who do not share Yunzhong’s aspirations need not adopt this teaching. Followers of Master Jiang’s lineage should not proceed by this path but seek other grounds. Since Yunzhong finds its reasoning unsound, he dares not follow it—how much less when it is falsely attributed to Master Du’s ritual codes? Yunzhong’s wanderings have been extensive, and he has encountered many fine editions of Master Du’s ritual codes, practicing them for a long time. None contain such teachings, hence his strong disapproval. His conviction is absolute and unshaken; though heaven and humanity are vastly distant, the oversight of divine response is swift. Those who perform this ritual should, along with the prior visualization of the green, yellow, and white *qi*, jointly report to the Emperor on High in plain terms.

Yunzhong transmits this as received. Should any part be incorrect, he willingly bears the responsibility. Yet since Yunzhong teaches what he has been taught, and does not claim these are his own innovations or alterations to the ancients’ texts, he will incur no blame.

**Burning the Talismans**
After the secret incantation following the offering of incense (with three pinches), the true writ and the talismans for descending spirits and summoning numina are burned. This is recorded in the *Comprehensive Methods of the Numinous Treasure*. The true writ is the celestial script from the *Central Chapter of the Numinous Writ of the Primordial Beginning*, carved into woodblocks and stamped in cinnabar on light yellow paper. Before burning, visualize the Celestial Worthy of the Primordial Beginning in the Heavenly Treasure Terrace, as when expounding the scriptures like a millet-grain pearl.

Next, burn the true writ and blow the ashes into the air, visualizing the boundless hosts of the utmost true and great spirits of the ten directions arriving upon the void. Burn and scatter the talismans for descending spirits and summoning numina, envisioning the overseers of the fast, the true numina of the Three Realms, and the myriad chariots and riders encircling and attending the Three Worthies.

**The Imperial Table**
The imperial table is the central table before the Supreme Emperor. It is also called the *Dong* table. *Dong* means "to penetrate," signifying the passage through which the true and the numinous communicate—the place where incense is burned. In the oratory, it stands before the Jade Purity; on the altar, it stands before the Three Treasures. The verse for scattering flowers reads: *"From the Dong table, the censer’s smoke arises; the incense of the effortless Dao and virtue."* This refers to this table. Some from distant regions mistakenly refer to the ritual table as the *Dong* table, which is incorrect.

**The Ritual Table of One’s Position**
This is the ritual table. At the beginning of the fast, the morning memorial is foremost. Standing reverently before the lofty perfected, one fears disorder in speech, so the ritual text is established. Holding the jade tablet upright, one must not grasp the scroll, hence the ritual table is placed before the position where the high priest stands—thus called the "table of one’s position." Since the Song dynasty, the tables used in various regions have been simple horizontal desks, barely sufficient to hold the ritual texts. Therefore, when offering incense and reciting the secret incantation in the hand censer, it serves as the invocation. The intent is to proclaim the words while the heart visualizes the Supreme Emperor.

Jiang’s *Established Rites* places the incense burner on the ritual table, but this practice has not been universally adopted. Moreover, the ritual tables in most places are not so spacious; placing the incense burner to one side would be improper. While a larger ritual table might be desirable, narrow altars cannot accommodate it. Thus, for the incense of one’s position, it is convenient to follow the old custom of offering incense in the hand censer.

**The Incantation**
*"Through form, the empty is revealed; the heart is conveyed by incense. What the heart reaches is neither fire nor smoke. Let your servant’s petition ascend directly to the Nine Heavens. The true numina partake and respond without need for words."*

**Another Incantation**
*"The Dao is studied through the heart; the heart is conveyed by incense. As incense burns in the jade censer, the heart abides before the Emperor. The true numina gaze down; the immortal lattices draw near. Let your servant’s petition ascend directly to the Nine Heavens."*

The master typically transmits the former incantation. As it is a secret incantation recited inaudibly, the heart visualizes the audience with the Supreme Emperor—hence the phrase *"without need for words."*

**Paying Respect to the Master**
Whenever the cantor recites from the ritual text, each participant pays respect to the master while visualizing as prescribed. The high priest closes his eyes and envisions the Three Worthies of the Most High upon the Heavenly Treasure Terrace, with the thirty-six divisions of the sacred scriptures to the left, the Great Master of the Mysterious Center to the right, the Ten Perfected and Five Emperors, and the assembled immortals in attendance, as in the assembly of the host of perfected upon the Jade Capital Mountain. Next, he contemplates the direction of the scripture master and bows three times in his heart, saying: *"May the master attain the immortal Dao; may my person ascend and be delivered."*

Master Guangcheng said: *"Jing* (scripture) means 'distant.' The scripture master is the distant master, the master of one’s master. Through the master’s transmission, one does not forget the origin." Next, he contemplates the direction of the register master and bows three times in his heart, saying: *"May the master attain flight as an immortal; may he deliver me, and may my seven generations of ancestors ascend early to the heavenly halls. May I attain the true Dao and ascend into the formless."*

Master Guangcheng said: *"Ji* (register) means 'to rely upon.' The transmission of the true and the study of the Dao depend upon the master-disciple relationship. The register master is the disciple of the scripture master and the master of the deliverance master." Next, he contemplates the direction of the deliverance master and bows three times in his heart, saying: *"May the master attain deliverance and ascend as a lofty immortal; may he deliver me from the five sufferings and eight difficulties, inscribe my name in the immortal register, and let me forever be a perfected person."*

Master Guangcheng said: *"Du* (deliverance) means 'to advance.' He delivers my mortal body, advancing it to the ranks of the Dao. From mortal to perfected, none do not rely upon the master—this is one’s own master." The three masters are the scripture master, the register master, and the deliverance master. The Dao cannot be without a master. Even in minor arts and single instructions, none are transmitted without a master. How much more so for one who bears the scriptures and registers, performs the great rites, presides over fasts and offerings, and delivers humans and heavens—how could this be without a master? In ancient times, when transmitting registers, the one who possessed the register was regarded as the master. From the middle ages onward, with the establishment of ancestral altars, it was no longer permissible for the master to deliver. Thus, the transmission of scriptures and the bestowal of registers were combined, with the ancestral altar serving as the master. If one inherits and practices the Lingbao ritual for memorials and fasts, one should visualize and bow to the three masters according to the method received. If, apart from the register, one has also received the transmission of scriptures from someone, this should also be included. However, if one were to omit the master who transmitted the method due to having received the scriptures, this would be improper. The practice of scriptures is the thread of the Dao; other methods are the application of the scriptures. The transmission of the scriptures is truly the foundation, and if the one who transmits the method is not counted among the three masters, this would be partial. The method arises from the scriptures; apart from the scriptures, it is not the method. Those who practice heterodox teachings and miscellaneous methods outside the orthodox teaching are not included in the visualization and reverence at the altar.

**The Five Directions’ Guardians of the Numinous Incantation**
Each line consists of four characters. The beginning of the eastern direction is called *"Ninefold Radiance of the Azure Heaven."* The beginning of the southern direction is called *"Southern Vermilion Heaven."* The beginning of the western direction is called *"Heaven of the Seven Qi."* The beginning of the northern direction is called *"Northern Mysterious Heaven."* The beginning of the central direction is called *"Yellow Center Regulating Qi."*

Recently, it has been observed that in the south and north, the character for "direction" (*fang*) is included, while in the east, west, and center, the character for "direction" is added, making each line six characters. This is a matter of the ancient scriptures’ composition having different sentence structures—how could one arbitrarily add to them? Those of discernment should correct this. However, the visualization pertains to the proper *qi* of the five directions, not the three primordial clouds. The three designations combine to generate the nine *qi*, which in their dispersion become myriad distinctions. Dividing their greatness into the five *qi*, in heaven they are the five stars, on earth the five peaks, in humans the five viscera, in things the five phases, and in affairs the five constants.

Now, by reciting the incantation, one visualizes and invokes the proper *qi* of the five directions to expel malevolent vapors and purify the ritual altar. The *qi* of the east pertains to wood, its season is spring, and its ruler is the Azure Emperor. The remaining four directions follow this pattern. Thus, the armies of the Five Directions and Five Emperors are governed by these deities.

The method of visualization and invocation is as follows: in an instant of focused thought, one envisions the true *qi* of each direction, corresponding to its color. Within each *qi*, there are divine soldiers and officials who respond to the incantation, guarding and protecting the ritual altar. Recently, some have used talismans for the Five Directions’ guardian spirits, but these do not belong to the *Dongxuan Lingbao* tradition and are therefore not employed here. Instead, we adhere to the guardian incantation transmitted by former masters, as recorded in the *Scripture of Essential Explications of the True Writ* and also found in the *Golden Register of Simplified Writs*.

**Striking the Ritual Drum**
Master Guangcheng states: The ritual drum serves to rectify the inner spirit-*qi* and dispel outer demonic influences—it is the first act in all ritual proceedings. Striking the teeth on the left is the Heavenly Bell, on the right the Heavenly Chime, and in the center the Ritual Drum. The rhythm follows eight beats as a measure, and three sets of eight—twenty-four in total—correspond to the twenty-four spirits of the three divisions and eight luminaries within the body. The ritual drum dispels demonic forces externally and gathers the twenty-four body spirits internally; it is not performed in vain.

**The Ritual Brazier**
The Most High Lord Lao of the Three Primordial *Qi* of the Supreme Three Heavens summons forth the Three and Five Merit Officials within our bodies, the Left and Right Attendant Envoys, the Left and Right Incense-Bearers, the Courier Dragon Riders, the Golden Lads Attending Incense, the Jade Maidens Scattering Flowers, the Five Emperors’ Direct Talismans, and the Incense Officials of the Day—thirty-six of each. Let them emerge in solemn array. We hereby notify the local earth gods and true officials of this domain.

We now reverently burn incense and perform the Dao rites, offering this for [Name], for state and family, in the grand *Huanglu* fast. We pray for the prolongation of Heaven’s mandate, the prosperity of the nation, and the well-being of the people. All sincere supplications are set forth in the memorial text. May the life-*qi* of the Most High’s ten directions and true perfected beings descend and flow into our bodies, that our entreaties may swiftly ascend to the presence of the Perfect, Boundless, Supreme Dao—the August Jade Sovereign of the Limitless Heaven.

This ritual was established by Lu Jianji and Du Guangcheng. While their versions differ in certain details, Master Guangcheng, though basing his work on the *Golden Register Simplified Texts*, cross-referenced the scriptures and precepts of the Three Caverns, leaving nothing undetailed. The present incense-offering rite follows the original *Dongxuan* format, which admits no further alteration. The invocation of the Most High, Mysterious, Primordial, Fivefold Numinous Lord Lao to summon the spirits within our bodies—this pertains to the *Zhengyi* incense-offering rite of the *Dongshen* division and differs from the present form.

Recently, some have presumed to alter the text at will. For instance, the line “thirty-six of each emerge in solemn array, notifying the local earth gods” has been changed to “thirty-six of each emerge; summon the local earth gods to swiftly come forth and receive notification.” This is a grave error. The original text refers to the thirty-six spirits within the body, all of whom emerge in solemn array, surrounding the practitioner front and back to notify the earth gods and fulfill their duty of transmitting sincerity. It should not be altered to read as if the earth gods themselves are to swiftly emerge.

Jiang’s *Established Rites* also briefly outlines the incense-offering rite but with variations. For example, the *Golden Register Simplified Texts* omits the Left and Right Attendant Envoys beneath the Three and Five Merit Officials. Another version omits the phrase “Incense Officials of the Day” beneath the Five Emperors’ Direct Talismans. Many such discrepancies exist. The present text follows Guangcheng’s version as definitive, for while variant texts—including those of Zhang Wanfu and other Celestial Masters—predate Guangcheng, he has already edited and refined them, swearing oaths to Heaven in their execution. Thus, his version is to be upheld.

As for the phrase “the presence of the Perfect, Boundless, Supreme Dao—the August Jade Sovereign of the Limitless Heaven,” Guangcheng’s research is exhaustive. The “Boundless Supreme Dao” refers to the Primordial Three *Qi* of the Mysterious and Origin in aggregate. These Three *Qi* coalesce into the Three Realm Celestial Worthies in form and disperse as *qi*; together, they are called the Supreme Dao. Moreover, *qi* is the ancestral origin of the myriad *qi* and the root source of Heaven and Earth—most revered and supreme. That which transcends form is called Heaven; since Heaven has form, how could it lack a sovereign? Thus, the August Sovereign of the Vast Heaven is the ruler of Heaven. The sincerity of the fast is rooted in the Supreme Dao and governed by the August Sovereign of the Vast Heaven; hence, it is said to “swiftly ascend to the presence of the Perfect, Boundless, Supreme Dao—the August Jade Sovereign of the Limitless Heaven.” This encompasses all origins without omission.

Recently, some have added “the Three Clarities, Supreme Thearchs” to “Boundless Supreme Dao.” Jiang’s *Established Rites* briefly addresses this, noting that recent additions of the “Three Clarities, Supreme Sages” cling to superficial forms and do not conform to ritual standards. However, it does not systematically analyze the ritual texts or elucidate the principles to dispel worldly confusion. Since the Jin dynasty under Lu Jianji and the Tang under Zhang Qingdu, and later with Guangcheng’s compilation of ritual methods, no one has altered these words for hundreds of years. Yet now, some still introduce strange innovations into the incense-offering text, perpetuating errors without correction. Such transgressions are what scholars must deeply guard against.

**Commanding Demons**
The High Priest turns left and stands facing west at the Ghost Gate. The Cantor proceeds to the Heavenly Gate and stands facing east. The High Priest knocks his teeth three times, swallows saliva three times, and visualizes the sun and moon before his face, entering through the nose into the Cavern Chamber’s Golden Flower Palace. Two-thirds of the way between the eyebrows, it divides into the Twin Cinnabar Fields. Further inward by three-tenths into the bone is the Terrace Gateway. Directly inward by seven-tenths, to the left is the Azure Gate and to the right the Purple Gate. Three inches inward from between the eyebrows is the Cinnabar Field Palace, also called the Mud-Pill Palace. Four inches inward is the Flowing Pearl Palace. Five inches inward is the Jade Emperor’s Palace. One inch directly above the Hall of Light is the Heavenly Court Palace. One inch above the Yang Cavern Chamber is the Ultimate Perfection Palace. One inch above the Cinnabar Field is the Mysterious Cinnabar Palace. One inch above the Flowing Pearl is the Supreme Sovereign Palace. These are the palaces listed in the *Perfect Scripture of the Great Cavern*.

Master Wucheng cites the *Nine Palaces Formula*, stating that five inches inward is the Jade Emperor’s Palace, also called the Golden Flower Palace. The nine palaces each span one inch square. The Golden Flower lies south of the Cavern Chamber. Radiance emerges from the back of the head, forming a resplendent nine-colored orb that penetrates the Jade Pillow, illuminating the ten directions. It revolves with me as I recite the secret incantation, which must not be audible to the ears. Those who violate this will incur fault. Beware.

**Secret Incantation:**

Within the Yellow Center, strategize qi to sever demonic traces,
Inspect and restrain fierce spirits, sever the roots of wayward elders.
The Supreme Lord issues a decree to the Supreme Lord’s Chamber,
Urging the Northern Emperor to hasten to the Jade Palace.
Receiving the mighty command, proclaim it to the Demon Kings—
Five qi billow and surge, clashing with fate.
The secret jade scriptures now flourish in full.

As the Three Heavens turn bright, the Six Heavens reach their end—
How wise the adept!

It is essential to note that the protocol for summoning demonic forces has been recorded in fasting rituals since antiquity. From Lu Jianji to Du Guangcheng and other masters, all compiled their works in accordance with ancient codes, mandating the summoning of demonic forces during the three daily audiences—no room for doubt. Jiang’s *Ready-Made Ritual* states that Zhao Daosheng’s *Yellow Register Ritual* summons demonic forces only at the noon audience, following the *Zhenghe Golden Register*—both rooted in ancient tradition. However, the *Golden Register Ritual of the Daoist Altar* commissioned by Emperor Xuanhe arranges its sequence such that demonic forces are summoned during all three audiences, followed by *Step Void*, the setting of the offering, and then the dispersal of the altar rites. This version was compiled by Yang Jie. Other ritual manuals prescribe that when incense is offered in the hand-held censer, the incantation "Through emptiness, form manifests; the heart transmits through fragrance" is used—a slight variation from the incantation for holding the jade censer while visualizing the Nine Heavens. As the teachings flourished, the examination and refinement of ritual codes became meticulous. Thus, the imperial *Golden Register Ritual* largely adheres to ancient methods.

Jiang’s *Ready-Made Ritual* further cites Zhang Qingdu, who said: Before the Heavenly Worthy expounded the scriptures, the demon kings of all heavens roamed the vast skies, wielding power and spreading poison. After the Heavenly Worthy preached, the demon kings submitted to transformation, and thus the assembly of sagely generals would first command the demon kings to lead the way. Jiang adds: The scriptures state that demon kings respectfully receive their duties and thereby attend upon all heavens. Therefore, during *Step Void*, one first visualizes and commands the demon kings. Yuan Zhong insists that this passage refers to Zhang Qingdu’s explanation that after the scriptures were preached, the demon kings submitted to transformation, receiving divine mandates to universally sweep away inauspicious forces. Whenever the Heavenly Emperor is to travel, the demon kings are commanded to lead the way—this is one interpretation. Yet to directly apply this meaning to justify commanding demon kings before *Step Void* is somewhat inadequate. If the Heavenly Emperor is to travel and the demon kings are to lead the way, then when offering incense to the ten directions, the Three Worthies are already visualized at the altar’s center. From the invocation of the sagely to the proclamation of words, the repentance toward the directions—all are addressed to the Emperor, with the deities already long present in the altar. The demon kings should clear the path and fulfill their duties at the very moment the Emperor descends to the altar. Why wait until *Step Void* to command them? Such reasoning is flawed.

Moreover, the sequence of the audience rites proceeds as follows: First, the High Master offers incense to express reverence and convey sincerity. Next, the furnace is activated to announce the intent of the fast, manifest the body’s spirits, summon the local deities, and proclaim the register. Each then declares their dharma rank, as the High Master and Daoist assembly state their positions and names. Together, they sincerely petition the sagely hosts, articulating the High Master’s purpose in receiving the words and conducting the fast. Up to this point, all are the High Master’s words. Having stated the purpose of receiving the words, the Green Petition is then proclaimed to express the fast-officiant’s innermost sentiments. Once the officiant’s intentions are thus revealed, the morning’s merit begins with prayers for the emperor, universal blessings, the liberation of the nine generations of ancestors, and the well-being of the living—this is the meaning of the threefold offering of incense. All requests and prayers are contained within these words. For the deliverance of the deceased, one considers their accumulated sins in life. For the protection of the living, one fears their past transgressions. Though earnest in seeking blessings and grace, if misfortunes remain entangled across the ten directions and three realms, and sins are recorded in the celestial and terrestrial courts, how can the mysterious grace descend, or the records of evil be erased? Thus, one pays homage to the Heavenly Worthies of the ten directions, repenting toward each quarter, extending to the sun, moon, stars, mountains, rivers, and peaks—all beseeching the absolution of transgressions and the erasure of sinful records.

All these actions take place within the fast altar, yet the officials of the three realms are involved in examination and judgment. The sagely hosts and protective deities of the fast merely assist and guard. Next, one models the practice after the Jade Capital of the Jade Clarity Heaven, the Jade Metropolis of the Mysterious Capital, the Seven-Treasure Mystic Terrace of the Golden Watchtower, and the Supreme Palace of the Purple Tenuity—where the sagely hosts of all heavens gather thrice monthly, and from the Heaven of Pure Tenuity downward, all pay homage to the Primordial Beginning. This is recorded in the *Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure*.

Master Guangcheng states: The *Ten Verses of Step Void* originate from the *Scripture of the Jade Capital Mountain of the Mysterious Capital of the Numinous Treasure*, wherein the sagely hosts of the ten heavens circumambulate the Jade Capital Mountain, chanting verses of perfected cultivation. The scripture says: When establishing a fast and practicing the Dao, the Four Heavenly Emperor Kings ride cloud chariots of green, drawing eight-jewel jade carriages. Perfected beings and jade maidens hold flower banners, leading with phoenix songs and following with celestial harmonies. White cranes and lions roar in unison, burning incense and scattering flowers as they float through the air, venerating the rites and listening to the Dharma’s sound. At this time, the recording of sins and blessings, the relevance or irrelevance of documents, the summoning or dismissal of petitions—all depend on the circumambulation of *Step Void*. As the heavenly perfected deities, vast and boundless, descend from the void without regard to distance, the cosmos must first be purified. This is not limited to the confines of a single altar.

The method requires the High Master to secretly employ divine radiance and reverently proclaim the Dao’s decree, summoning the Northern Emperor by the Supreme Lord’s command to dispatch the Demon Kings, inspect and restrain fierce spirits, and sever the roots of evil. As the jade scriptures flourish, the Three Heavens turn bright, the true teachings spread, and the immortal Dao prospers. The roots of evil are sealed, the demonic path vanishes, yin qi crumbles, and the Six Heavens cease. Within the six directions, the Dao’s qi overflows, ascending to the nine skies and pervading the ten thousand realms. Countless sagely hosts can then float through the void, observing and listening to the Dharma’s sound.

Thus the High Master’s ability to proclaim the Supreme Lord’s decree and evoke such resonance lies in their mastery of internal refinement through exhalation and inhalation, embryonic breathing, and tranquil spirit-cultivation, whereby the Mud-Pill Palace becomes radiantly luminous—with but a single visualization, divine radiance shines forth. Further empowered by the Supreme Lord’s incantations and commands, the Demon Kings receive their charge. Thereupon, in reverent fulfillment of the Celestial Emperor’s mandate, they sweep clean the cosmos, purifying all realms near and far, so that the host of sages may float through the void to listen to the *Step-in-Emptiness* hymns.

This efficacy extends beyond the confines of a single altar’s inner or outer precincts, nor is it limited to the assembled perfected of the precept-retreat. It is precisely for this reason that such rites are performed after the repentance and thanksgiving liturgies, yet before the *Scattering Flowers* and *Step-in-Emptiness* ceremonies. At the inception of ritual protocols, the teachings are established through scripture. Once the circumambulation of the *Step-in-Emptiness* is complete, the proper observance is to venerate the scriptures.

Thus it is said: “The demon kings of heaven stand in reverent protection, and the world receives great blessings.” This arises from upholding the scriptures, maintaining the precepts, contemplating the Dao, and dispelling desires—such is the merit that elicits veneration. Next, it is proclaimed: “As the scriptural Dao flourishes and spreads, households and nations prosper. With unceasing cultivation, one enters the Great Vehicle, enabling the seven generations of ancestors to ascend, while the practitioner’s own form transcends the mundane.” Here, a second bow is rendered. For those who cherish the scriptures and savor the Dao, who dwell within the teachings to attain immortality, ultimately becoming companions of the Dao—refining their corporeal form to transcend the tribulations of the Three Realms and deliverance from the sufferings of hell—the very source of such merit lies in the scriptures. Thus, the rite concludes with three prostrations. Such is the significance of the threefold veneration of the scriptures.

From the retreat to the scriptural recitation, one hears the scriptures and awakens to the Dao, cultivates authenticity and bears the talismanic registers, propagates the teachings to deliver gods and humans. Now, the retreat officiant repents of transgressions and venerates the Ten Directions, entreating blessings from the celestial realms, extolling merit and bowing to the scriptures. Thereupon, gratitude is offered to the Three Treasures, the dharma ranks are solemnly invoked once more, and in reverence before the celestial gates, a universal repentance and thanksgiving is performed—not merely directed to the Ten Directions and the sacred peaks and watercourses, but encompassing all, hence called the *Great Thanksgiving*. Only then does the recitation of vows resume at the incense burner, its principle now fully elucidated.

As for those like Zhao Daosheng, who regard the summoning of demons as an exclusive focus on internal visualization—claiming the Supreme Lord never leaves the Mud-Pill Palace, the host of perfected reside within the body, and the demon-summoning operates solely within the corporeal frame—such an interpretation misconstrues the scriptural intent and misidentifies the true source. It is akin to silently petitioning the Celestial Emperor, reporting retreat affairs within the upper cinnabar field—an egregious error.

Indeed, the Mud-Pill Palace contains the Nine Palaces, and the body harbors the myriad spirits; how could this be otherwise? From the *Cavern-Real Heavenly Treasure* Dao to the Three Vehicles of the *Numinous Treasure* and *Divine Treasure* teachings, all encompass cultivation within the body. Some practices emphasize internal focus, while others harmonize inner and outer dimensions. When the Dharma Master enters seclusion to sit upright, refining form and spirit, this is the internal aspect. Ascending the altar to pay homage, expounding the rites and conducting the retreat—this is the engagement of mortal sincerity to reach the Celestial Emperor. Submitting memorials and petitions, projecting the spirit to visit the celestial heights—this is the spirit’s departure from the body to approach the lofty heavens. Repenting before the perfected, performing circumambulation, burning incense, descending the Five Qi to purify the altar, uniting the Three Primes to invoke the Great Dao, summoning the Demon Kings to purify the Six Directions, emulating the Jade Capital in chanting the *Step-in-Emptiness*—all these are the resonant pathways of inner-outer correspondence, the means of evoking spiritual response. How could the summoning of demons be entirely confined to the body’s interior?

Others claim that yang arises at *zi* and culminates at *wu*, while yin arises at *wu* and culminates at *zi*, and that the intersection of yin and yang necessitates summoning demons at the *wu* hour. This, too, lacks scriptural basis and stems from rigid adherence to internal cultivation. If the Jade Emperor and the Three Pure Ones never leave one’s body, and the thousand perfected and myriad spirits all reside within, then why erect altars, conduct retreats, or draft memorials with itemized petitions? If the retreat officiant addresses the self, the self knows—and the Mud-Pill Palace knows—then all ritual documents, retreats, and offerings could be dispensed with. This directly contravenes the sagely masters’ intent in bequeathing liturgical protocols to save the world.

The twenty-seven ranks of retreats and forty-two grades of offerings each possess distinct hierarchies and classifications; how could one focus solely on internal practice while neglecting the scriptural registers and retreat observances? As for the harmonization of metal and wood, the pairing of *kan* and *li*, the coagulation of mercury and lead, the descent of the dragon and the subjugation of the tiger—these pertain to internal alchemy and have no external dimension. Yet they cannot serve as the foundation for liturgical protocols or the conduct of retreats and offerings in the world. Scholars must understand the origins and currents of both internal cultivation and external refinement. Those who uphold the teachings and perform the rites should clarify their fundamental principles, lest they mistake south for north and fall into confusion and error.

To assert that demon-summoning incantations are purely internal practices, with demon kings and spirits all residing within the body, is a principle difficult to reconcile. As the *Step-in-Emptiness Scripture* states:

> “Looking up and down, I contemplate the Supreme Lord,
> The radiant splendor flourishes in the cinnabar field.
> Glancing left, I raise Yu Yi,
> Gazing right, I accompany Jie Lin.
> The Six Perfections crown the Brahman conduct,
> Dao and virtue renew in paired progression.”

This describes the constant contemplation of the Supreme Lord, practicing the superior methods of the sun and moon, such that Dao and virtue are daily renewed—achievements cultivated internally yet manifesting externally. Further:

> “Heaven-endowed with transcendent talent,
> Delighting in reciting the subtle and profound scriptures.”

This means that without transcendent talent, one cannot grasp the subtle scriptures or fully comprehend their chapters and profound principles. Again:

> “The qi of profound emptiness and great harmony,
> Exhaling and inhaling the essence of rosy clouds.
> Embryonic breathing stills the hundred passages,
> In solitude, I master the Three Conveniences.
> The Mud-Pill Palace shines with luminous splendor,
> And I attain the Golden Flower Immortal.”

This speaks of awakening to the deep mechanisms of the scriptural instructions, applying them through exhalation and inhalation, practicing embryonic breathing to attain secret techniques, illuminating the Mud-Pill Palace, and ultimately achieving true immortality in unity with the Dao—an internal refinement culminating in success. If this is so, then even the demon kings of heaven will respectfully receive their charge, not merely offering protection but enabling one to ascend and pay homage to the myriad heavens.

Thus it is said: when demon kings respectfully receive their charge, one may ascend to pay homage to the myriad heavens. All that brings this about arises from the accumulation of merit through fasting and precepts. Therefore, the text concludes: “All begins with fasting and precepts, / Merit accumulates to bind past affinities. / Soaring through the Great Void, / One is borne aloft to join the exalted immortals.”

To fly through the vastness of the heavens is to achieve lightness of being—no longer confined within the body. If the demon kings remain within the body, dwelling only above the head, then they receive their charge in the field of the body and pay homage to the Heavenly Emperor in the Mud-Pill Palace. Though this may bring success, when one’s allotted span is exhausted, one becomes but a corpse-guarding ghost, not a true immortal. Such homage to the Mud-Pill Palace marks only the beginning of cultivation; it is not the ultimate attainment. To ascend into the empty mystery and serve as minister to the Three Realms—this alone is true immortality. The practice of inner refinement and the lightness of ascent in the heavens reflect the intent of the *Scripture of Pacing the Void*.

Now, in the ritual altar, when commanding the demons, one first visualizes the sun and moon entering the nostrils, then the radiance of the Cavern Chamber shines forth. This is because the luminosity of the Mud-Pill Palace has not yet arisen spontaneously, so one relies on visualization to proceed. Since one’s body has not yet become a true immortal, one cannot immediately command the demon kings; thus, one invokes the authority of the Most High to enact the rite. This practice aligns in principle with the chapter on pacing the void. Hence, the tenth chapter of *Pacing the Void* also states: “Scattering flowers to declare my vow, / Grasping the tally to summon the demon kings.” This expresses the same meaning.

The scriptures speak of immortality as a natural attainment, while altar rites employ provisional methods. Once the Way of Embryonic Breathing is perfected and the radiance of the Mud-Pill Palace shines forth, one need not visualize sun and moon—light will illumine the ten directions; one need not recite secret incantations—the demon kings will receive their charge. Yet to reach this stage, one must not personally tread the ritual altar or seek fame among the worldly. These are the regulations of fasting rites, and thus they are set forth in detail.

Here ends *The Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure of Highest Clarity*, Scroll Twenty-Two.
*Here begins The Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure of Highest Clarity, Scroll Twenty-Three.*

The Master of the Cavernous Mystery and Numinous Treasure, Keeper of the Southern Bureau’s Enforcement Codes, Provisional Youth of the Initial Office, Right Guardian of the Golden Just Middle Compilation presents:

**Section on Memorials and Petitions**

Memorials follow ancient forms. Though the ritual documents of each age differ, the structure of memorials admits no private alteration. For instance, in the Yellow Register Retreat, five standard memorials have always been used, all in vermilion script: the *Memorial of the Plain Chariot and White Horses*, the *Memorial to Break Fengdu and Release from Sin*, the *Memorial to Open the Road*, the *Memorial for Bathing and Refining the Transcendence*, and the *Memorial for Ascending and Delivering the Deceased Soul*. Recently, some have altered or rearranged these forms. Yet the master’s transmitted tradition cannot be changed with the times; thus, the ancient forms are followed.

**Memorial of the Plain Chariot and White Horses**

Your servant [Name], holding the register and office of the Numinous Treasure of Highest Clarity, with reverence and awe, bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and respectfully addresses the exalted heavens:

I have heard that to deliver and assist the hidden souls, their ascent truly depends upon the mysterious blessings of the Dao. To issue and proclaim the true talismans, their announcement must rely upon the divine officials. With humility, I dare to express my earnest devotion and presumptuously address the lofty heavens.

Your servant, residing in [State] Prefecture, [County], [Location], holding the Daoist office of [Rank] [Name], together with his household, respectfully undertakes the establishment of the Great Yellow Register Grand Fast of the Most High for [number] days and nights. This offering is made to augment the nation’s fortune, universally bless all living beings, open the path for the deliverance of the seven generations of ancestors’ souls, and broadly rescue the lonely spirits of the Nine Dark Realms. Gathering the merits of good deeds, we seek to transcend and deliver the deceased [Name], that they may swiftly ascend to the Dao-realm.

Your servant, moved by the sincerity of these words, finds them impossible to suppress. Having already prepared and submitted the memorial petition, I now presume to address the boundless heavens. In reverent accordance with the ritual codes, I have established the altar precinct, performed the circuit of the Dao, recited the scriptures, and offered morning audiences to the Perfected, repentances, and thanksgivings. Today, I proclaim and enact the primordial talismanic decrees: the Golden Register and White Tablet, the True Talismans for Deliverance from Suffering, the Most High’s Edict of Pardon and Birth in Heaven, the Most High’s True Talisman for Breaking Open the Earth-Prison, the True Talisman for Rescuing Lonely Souls, the Nine Dragon Decree of the Eastern Ultimate Azure Palace, and the Jade Seal of the Great Unity’s Mysterious Darkness and Primal Divine Tiger.

By these means, I deliver the seven generations of ancestors—parents and kin—of the deceased [Name], along with all categories of lonely souls, that they may all assemble at the fast’s altar. On the [day] of [month], the imperial altar was established at dusk, summoning the deceased spirits to manifest signs of response and guiding them to attend the Perfected. On [day], at dawn, the main fast commenced, unfolding over three days. Universal offerings of grain were distributed, broadly aiding the lonely souls; their spiritual consciousness was refined and delivered, and the precepts and talismans were transmitted.

Your servant respectfully invokes:
One Great General of the Plain Chariot and White Horses,
One hundred and twenty Official Lords, Generals, and Clerks,
One Clerk of the Mysterious Capital’s Water-Chestnut Dragon Post,
One Flying Celestial Divine Person,
One Messenger of the Nine Dragon Decree of the Eastern Ultimate Azure Palace.

These are commanded to proclaim and transmit the talismanic decrees, announcing them to the Three Officials and Nine Bureaus, the one hundred and twenty offices, the Five Thearchs’ Examiners, the clerks of the Six Palaces, the officials of the Fengdu Palace, the officers of punishment and judgment, the Five Marchmounts and Nine Dark Realms, the sources of rivers and springs, the Five Paths’ Capital, the Great Spirits of the Dark Abyss, the Four Drainages and Three Rivers, the Nine Jiang and Eight Seas, the Yellow Springs and the Fields of Hao, the Earth-Shrine Lords of the Nine Provinces, the Heavenly Prisons and Earthly Hell, the Dark Passes and Nether Roads, and all kings and rulers—all are to receive and heed the talismanic decrees.

May the seven generations of ancestors, parents, and kin of the deceased [Name], along with the lonely souls of the Nine Provinces’ domains, the Three Paths and Five Ways, the ten thousand kinds of the Four Modes of Birth, and all suffering spirits of the dark realms, be granted pardon. May their myriad sufferings be wholly dispelled, may they depart from the earth-prison, forever bid farewell to the eternal night, and behold the light. May their transgressions be absolved, their evil roots severed and extinguished, and by virtue of these meritorious causes, may they undergo refinement and be reborn.

With compassion, O Most High, discern and respond to this single entreaty.

Your servant, relying upon the Direct Envoys of the Two Officials, the Merit Officers of the Three and Five, the Attendant Envoys of the Left and Right, the Clerks of Yin-Yang Divine Decisions, the Scarlet Talisman Chariot Clerks, the Clerks of the Gale-Riding Posts, the Memorial-Mounting Envoys, and the Flying Dragon Riders—these officials are commanded to carry this petition to the Three Heavenly Courts of the Most High, awaiting the proclamation of response.

The *Plain Chariot and White Horse Memorial* follows the old format as such. In recent times, some have added *Officials of Purification and Altar Guardians* after the requesting officials, petitioning for their descent together. Others have altered its name to the *Purification Memorial*, omitting the *Great General of the Plain Chariot and White Horse*. Each follows their master’s transmission or personal judgment. In this method, the old formula as transmitted by the master is preserved. Those of different lineages may follow their own traditions.

Purification is the duty of subordinate officials—dispelling impurity and expelling malevolence to await the descent and inspection of the Imperial Perfected. It is not fitting to request the Supreme Emperor to dispatch Dharma officials for purification.

We have followed the *Fengdu Release-from-Sin Memorial* and the *Petition to Open the Way*, both of which take universal deliverance as their aim. Though the retreat officials may offer prayers for a single individual, the benefit naturally extends to all souls in the hidden realms. Moreover, the hells are too numerous to describe in full, and the instruments of interrogation too many to recount.

Thus the Master of Vast Accomplishment said: “Hells are so named because they are prisons beneath the earth. Yet the examination and judgment of sinful souls may also occur in the yin palaces within cities and settlements—these too are called hells.” The *Sutra of Karmic Retribution and Conditions* states: “For yang sins and yang transgressions, worldly officials judge them; for yin sins and yin transgressions, the dark officials preside.” It speaks of thirty-six hells. The *Scripture of Immortal Precepts* mentions eighteen hells, the *Orthodox Unity Scripture* eight great earthly hells, and the *Sutra of Conditions* twenty-four hells under the Three Officials of Fengdu. The accounts in the various scriptures are thus too vast to exhaust.

What the scriptures leave unspoken knows no bounds. As for instruments of torment—golden hammers and iron staves, forests of swords and mountains of blades, cauldrons of boiling oil and searing coals, fire chariots and pits of filth—these too are but briefly sketched in the scriptures to evoke their dreadful aspect, that they may warn the world and deter men from sin. Yet in the *Chapter on Expiating Sins*, it is said that copper pillars and iron beds, once tools of torment, become instruments of precious transformation, and cauldrons of boiling oil and furnaces of fire become lamps of cool radiance. To enumerate the torments of hell in full would be endless, and in the end would only narrow their meaning.

For instance, in the *Chapter on Opening the Road*, to list the names of the Great and Lesser Iron Enclosures, the Hell of Unrelenting Torment, and others would be overly restrictive. The names of hells are too numerous to know in full. Thus, in the *Chapter on Right Conduct and Judging Sins*, the text merely speaks of confronting accusations, balancing accounts, and reconciling enmities, without recounting the forms of each infernal instrument. In the *Chapter on Opening the Road*, it broadly refers to the palaces and caverns of Fengdu and the boundless hells, without exhaustively naming each one. In this way, the words remain concise while their meaning deepens, the phrasing spare while its scope widens. For in the art of exposition, one cannot exhaust all things in sequence.

The realms of the hidden and the dark are too numerous to name exhaustively. Thus, by employing general terms to encompass all matters, every place where hells exist is embraced by imperial grace, and all who suffer the torments of infernal instruments receive mysterious pardon. Why must one specify each name to dissolve their sins or define each location to amplify the merit of the fast? If the Supreme Lord extends compassion, none shall remain beyond deliverance. Scholars must therefore broaden their minds and not cling to the shallow and narrow. This is the foremost principle in the study of the Dao—petty and constricted minds cannot embody the expansive spirit that liberates heaven and humanity.

**Chapter on Ritual Ablution and Refinement for Deliverance**
*From the Register of the Orthodox Numinous Treasure’s Dharma Ranks*
Your humble servant, [Name], prostrates in awe and reverence, bowing twice with head touching the ground, respectfully submits:

I have heard that when form and spirit temporarily dissolve, the entanglements of worldly dust still cling. When the hun-soul and consciousness scatter and wander, the root of the numinous remains unrecovered. Without refinement, how can rebirth be attained? Thus, I knock upon the gates of heaven to express my mortal sincerity.

Your servant, acting on behalf of the household of [Official Rank, Name] of [Prefecture, Subprefecture, County, Place], humbly petitions to perform the rites for the deliverance of the departed soul, guiding it to ascend to the realm of the Dao. With utmost reverence and rightful cause, I shall lead the ritual current, establishing the altar on [date] and conducting the *Great Fast of the Supreme Yellow Register* for [number] days and nights. Through reciting scriptures, circumambulating the Dao, repenting before the perfected, and invoking the descent of talismans, I shall summon the soul for deliverance, universally extending salvation to the stagnant spirits of the Three Paths and the myriad kinds of hidden souls. May all bathe in the divine nectar, melting away the dust and filth; may they return to the transformation of the Dao, reintegrating with yin and yang.

For this purpose, I respectfully invite:
- Five *Ling Tongzi* (Numinous Youths) from each of the Five Directions, totaling twenty-five;
- One hundred twenty *Jie Hui* officials, generals, and soldiers;
- One *Huan Zhuo Furen* (Lady of Ablution) and one *Huang Hua Yu Nü* (Jade Maiden of Yellow Splendor).

May they descend at once to draw the *Yellow Splendor Divine Water*, refine the *Plain Essence of the Corpse*, the *Numinous Fat Jade Liquor*, the *Sweet Dew Golden Nectar*, and infuse them into the fragrant bath. Thus shall the delivered souls and hidden spirits be cleansed of yin impurities, washed of worldly toils, purging both inner and outer roots of karmic debt, dissolving the filth of heat and affliction.

Then, the Five Directional Youths shall:
- Invoke the *True Qi* of the *Azure Numinous First Elder* of the East, feeding them the *Nine Qi Azure Nectar*;
- Invoke the *True Qi* of the *Cinnabar Numinous True Elder* of the South, feeding them the *Three Qi Cinnabar Splendor*;
- Invoke the *True Qi* of the *Luminous Numinous August Elder* of the West, feeding them the *Seven Qi Plain Essence*;
- Invoke the *True Qi* of the *Five Numinous Mystic Elder* of the North, feeding them the *Five Qi Mystic Spring*;
- Invoke the *True Qi* of the *Primal Numinous Primal Elder* of the Center, feeding them the *One Qi Yellow Splendor*.

Thus shall all refined souls receive this nourishment, stabilizing their hun and po, and naturally generating the Five Spirits.

I further invoke the *Hundred-Forged, Thousand-Harmonized Jade Liquid*, the *Flowing Light of Venus*, and the *Primal August Scattered Nectar* to dispel stagnation, purge impurities, refine body and mind, and illuminate wisdom.

Additionally, I beseech the *Orthodox Qi of Yin and Yang*, the *Numinous Nectar of Metal and Wood*, to descend from the *Cinnabar Heaven Realm*, the *Vermilion Mound Fire Palace*, and the *Southern Prosperity Upper Palace*. May the *Refinement and Deliverance* officials, lords, generals, and soldiers descend to the altar, refining and delivering the departed souls, awakening their original nature. May their form and spirit be restored, reborn in the land of blessings, forever sheltered under the Dao’s shade.

With utmost reverence, I humbly implore the Supreme’s discerning mercy.

Your servant respectfully concludes.

[Seal] *Void Practice*. The closing follows the previous format. Any omissions in the square envelope shall adhere to the prior model.

---

I have further heard: when a person lives, flesh and blood form the body, and the circulation of *ying* and *wei* qi brings illness and pain. As the *Daode Jing* states: *"My greatest affliction is that I have a body."* For the body is the burden of the spirit. The *Book of Transformations* by Song Qiqiu of recent times says: *"Time itself harms me not, yet sinews and bones do; I feel no pain, yet blood and flesh cause it."* These words nearly grasp the Dao.

Once the spirit departs, the hundred bones become mere rotting earth. Where then are the former wounds of limbs, the ailments of heart and belly? Yet if the singular spirit lingers—whether bound by karmic confrontation or sunk in delusion—it may suffer endless rebirth. But if its original nature is awakened, deliverance follows in due course.

Thus, the Supreme’s intent in establishing rituals and the purpose of fasts lie in building merit through scripture recitation and Dao-circumambulation, illuminating the obscure and awakening the lost. The *Chapter on Ritual Ablution and Refinement for Deliverance* addresses the soul’s passage through the *Great Yin*, where it is ensnared in the net of sins. First, its dust and filth must be purged; then, its spirit and consciousness gathered, temporarily reuniting yin and yang to reestablish its foundation and return to the human path. Initially human, it became a ghost; through the deliverance of the Supreme Mystery, its spirit is reassembled, and the ghost becomes human again. At the moment of rebirth, it receives the *Decree of the Celestial Lord*, the *Nine Qi Generating Spirits*, and a renewed body.

Yet one fears the fast’s merit may not reach heaven, and the *Two Qi* may not descend upon the departed soul. If, as in older ritual texts, one requests divine physicians and celestial medicines to heal past illnesses or mend broken bones, this strays far from the Dao. Not only does the human form perish while the spirit endures, but the *Orthodox Qi of Heaven and Earth and Yin and Yang* refines and transforms the departed soul, restoring it to life. Why then worry that its spirit suffers incurable afflictions?

Thus, following the transmission of my late master, I dare not conform to the vulgar or transcend the world. Should the teachings differ, I shall adhere to my master’s method.

Thus, with due reverence, I dare not overstep.

**Memorial for Ascending and Delivering the Departed Soul**
*By [Rank] [Surname] [Given Name], Servant of the Registers of the Upper Clarity and Numinous Treasure Methods, with awe and trembling, bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and respectfully addresses:*

I have heard that the boundless grace of the teachings lifts those mired in stagnation to higher realms, and the infinite merit of the fast delivers the shades of the underworld to transcendence. May You deign to take note and, in the end, bestow Your compassionate mercy.

I, in accordance with the residence of [Official Title] [Surname] [Given Name] and their household at [Prefecture] [Subprefecture] [County] [Place], have reverently undertaken the grand fast of the *Yellow Register* of the Most High, lasting [number] days and nights, to offer prayers for the departed soul and guide it to ascend to the immortal realms.

Having followed the ritual instructions and conducted the rites as prescribed, I have performed the ceremony for delivering the bound and offering souls, the sacrificial refinement of the departed’s original lineage, and the salvation of the nine dark and stagnant shades. By the power of the Dao and the grace of Heaven, I now humbly invoke:

The Lords of the Southern Palace—
the *Lord of Life Mandates*,
the *Lord of Records*,
the *Lord of Longevity*,
the *Lord of Augmented Destiny*,
the *Lord of Deliverance from Calamity*,
and the *Lord of Ascension*—
each one, to ascend and deliver the departed soul, raise it to the Southern Palace, inscribe its destiny upon the jade tablets, and record its name in golden script.

I further invoke:
the *Great Divine Marshal Sima*,
the *Holy Mother of the Protective Chamber*,
and the *Youth of Cavernous Yang*,
to refine the departed soul’s jade-like eyes and temper its form, purify its body with yellow blossoms, inscribe its living name upon the purple registers, and accord it rank in the vermilion palace. May it, ever dependent on Your sheltering care, forever attain carefree wandering.

In profound reverence, I beseech the Most High to distinguish and heed my plea.

I respectfully conclude.

The dimensions of the memorial envelope may be adjusted as needed, following the previous format.

According to *The Essentials of the Orthodox Unity*, when submitting memorials in the twelve months, the names of the Most High’s palaces are specified, and for daily submissions, the names of the palace bureaus are given. This pertains to the regulations of the Orthodox Unity tradition, to be observed accordingly.

However, this memorial’s method belongs to the *Cavernous Mystery* rank and is found in the upper scriptures, differing in origin from the Orthodox Unity. It is thus termed the *Upper Clarity Ritual Form*, though it incorporates Orthodox Unity memorials. In the past, there have been instances where palace bureaus were not used. While *The Definitive Collection of Daoist Regulations* now stipulates their inclusion, such usage is not deeply appropriate. Moreover, for disciples of the Numinous Treasure, submitting memorials to the *Lord of the Dao of the Most High* has always been directed to the Three Heavenly Bureaus alone.

Having repeatedly presented such memorials before and after, and having received numinous responses, I dare to compile and continue this text—not out of personal inexperience or to mislead the world. Let scholars examine this carefully.

**Memorial Envelope:**
Length: one foot, two inches, and eight fen; width: two inches and eight fen, measured by the ancient ruler. Made of yellow silk, sealed in a bag, and wrapped in a yellow gauze cloth.

**Memorial Tablet:**
Shaped like an incense table, with curved legs, draped in a yellow gauze cover on all sides.

**Writing the Memorial:**
Conducted in a quiet chamber, with no one passing through.

Before the appointed time, sweep and purify the space. At the moment of the ritual, use the *Fu of Dispelling Filth*, fumigate with vinegar and charcoal. Those who are to inscribe memorials, petitions, or documents must first bathe, change into fresh garments, and enter the chamber to write all required texts.

Each line shall contain seventeen characters, with eight fen of space above and a continuous "ant-trail" margin below. (One account holds that the "ant-trail" should not be continuous, but if the characters are too close to the lower edge of the paper, strokes may be lost—thus, a continuous "ant-trail" is proper.) Each line shall be one cun and two fen in width; the paper shall be one chi and two cun in height. From beginning to end, the number of lines must be odd. Leave two blank lines before the *Fǎwèi* (Ritual Position). The *Fǎwèi* through the phrase "prostrate twice" shall occupy a single line. The phrase "the above words" shall be aligned with the preceding line’s indentation.

The characters *chén* (臣, "your servant") and personal names, as well as the characters *guǐ* (鬼, "ghost") and *sǐ* (死, "death"), must not appear at the beginning of a line. The character *shēng* (生, "life") must not hang at the end of a line. Cover the table with a clean cloth before writing. Leave three blank lines after the date and month; if the text is lengthy, continue on additional sheets. Immediately burn any leftover paper scraps—do not let them scatter onto the bed, mat, or floor.

Use only new and clean brushes and ink; do not mix them with others. Characters connoting misfortune or impurity must not appear at the beginning of a line but should be placed in the middle, concealed from view. No women, Buddhist monks or nuns, chickens, dogs, cats, or other animals may enter the chamber where the memorial is written. While writing, one must not speak or cause disorder. Do not leave the chamber before completing the text. Do not set down the brush before finishing a character. When dotting the brush, face the memorial—do not read aloud. The phrase "I have heard" shall be written with the characters *wén dī* (闻低) aligned with the preceding line. The phrase "reporting below, your servant" shall be followed by three blank lines.

The servant’s surname shall be indented two cun and four fen. Before the *Fǎwèi*, no surname is written; at the point of the servant’s surname, it shall be introduced as "the servant, surnamed..."—for example, "the servant, surnamed [X], residing in [Y] jurisdiction, at [Z] hermitage, engaged in purification rites," and the like. Since the surname is absent at the beginning of the memorial and only the servant’s name is used within, it is here, in the concluding section, that the surname is declared—lest the document end without it. Those who write the servant’s full name here err against the proper form.

As recorded in the memorial template previously transmitted by my late master, High Master Gao: "The servant, surnamed Gao, of Huizhou Prefecture, Qimen County, at Ziyuan Hermitage, engaged in purification rites"—this does not pertain to my own lineage, but may be followed as convenient.

Leave three blank lines after the servant’s surname, and three blank lines after the *Sacred Position of the Most High*. Conclude with the date and month. Memorials must be written without interruption across days; filling in "Your Majesty" must not be delayed. When submitting the memorial, face east by day and north by night.

A standard memorial sheet shall have seventeen lines, each containing seventeen characters. Only the *Yellow Silk Vermilion Memorial* allows twenty-four characters per line; otherwise, follow the standard form. By ancient rule, the sixty *jiǎzǐ* spirits are not to be included in the memorial.

When writing, place paper beneath the hand to prevent sleeves from brushing the text. Grind ink with forty-nine leftward turns of the inkstone. Do not lick the brush, nor exhale breath onto the memorial. By proper method, one should hold fragrant water in the mouth, burn incense, and face north while writing. Those inscribing memorials must not tread upon impurity. If one has encountered birth, death, or defiling pollution, another must be chosen for the task.

The paper must not be torn; characters must not lack strokes. In summer, one must not write while lightly clad or bare-bodied. Do not lean on the table while writing, nor pick at or smear corrections. Once written, do not allow others to read the text, nor place it where people pass by.

The *Sacred Position of the Most High* shall be written in a single, meticulously aligned line—do not constrain it by fixed measurements. The ancient rule of three cun in length, if insufficient to accommodate the content, may result in disorder. The characters *Bìxià* (陛下, "Your Majesty") shall not be written in small script; only careful, standard calligraphy is valued.

When presenting the memorial, place a copy before the throne while the original is displayed. Set the brush to the right of the *Sacred Position* and the dragon-headed writing knife to the left. The ritual master shall kneel before the altar, dispatch the memorial, then pass it over the incense. Roll it tightly, seal it within the envelope, recite the *Opening the Envelope Incantation*, place it inside, add a piece of *chenxiang* (agarwood), and bind it with three passes of green silk thread. Formerly, a wax seal was used—though solid wax is impure.

Now, only paste adhesive is used, sealing where the thread binds the envelope. Next, place it into the outer case.

Hand it to the attendant incense master, who shall reverently carry and uphold it according to the prescribed form.

**Memorial Offerings and Ritual Colors:**
The Son of Heaven uses bolts of silk by the *pi* measure; nobles and marquises use bolts by the *zhang* measure; commoners use forty-nine *chi*.

**Offerings:**
- Cash: twelve thousand *wen*
- Salary rice: one *shi* and two *dou*
- Oil: one *dou* and two *sheng*
- Incense: five *liang*
- Paper: one hundred sheets
- Brushes: two large, three small
- Ink: three sticks
- Inkstones: two
- Golden fish: one
- Jade wild goose: one
- Dragon-headed writing knife: one, six *cun* in length, with a blade of copper or iron and a dragon head of half a *liang* of silver
- Salt: one *jin*
- Fermented beans: one *jin*
- Firewood: fifty *jin*
- Charcoal: fifty *jin*
- Ritual towels: two
- Life talismans: one for each year of age

**Ritual Formula:**
"In presenting the memorial with its full offerings, one bears witness to the sincerity of the heart. If the heart seeks merit and virtue yet begrudges wealth and goods, the divine spirits shall not accept it. Should the supplicant be a reclusive scholar or a destitute household, the master shall provide on their behalf."

**Memorial Pass:**
*Office of the Great Rituals of the Numinous Treasure*

Herewith, this Office now acts on behalf of [Name], who has reverently established the Great Yellow Register Daoist Retreat of the Most High for [number] days and nights, to invoke blessings for the nation’s peace and the realm’s stability, and to deliver salvation to the hidden and benefit the manifest. In accordance with the ritual statutes, we humbly present this memorial, one sealed document, respectfully submitting it to the Gates of the Three Heavens, to be duly memorialized as required.

To the right, this Pass is issued to the official courier bearing the memorial, together with all attending officers, the Two Official Direct Envoys, the Three and Five Merit Clerks, the Left and Right Official Messengers, the Flying Memorial Attendants, the Five Thearchs’ Direct Talismans, the Twelve Hourly Direct Envoys, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Decision Clerks, the Scarlet Talisman Chariot Clerks, the Strong Wind Post Riders, the Post-Horse Memorial Couriers, the Flying Dragon Cavalry Officers, and the myriad hosts of officers, generals, and clerks—ten thousand chariots and a hundred thousand riders. They are commanded to bear the memorial aloft, ascend to the Celestial Palace, and present it in timely fashion. No delay shall be tolerated; it shall be executed with the swiftness of shooting stars.

Thus, this Pass is issued.
In the year [Year], cyclical year [Stem-Branch], on the [Day] day of the [Month] month, at the [Hour] hour, this Pass is sealed.

[Ritual rank and titles of the officiants are fully set forth.]

The Retreat Officer, [Surname] [Name], respectfully prepares:
- [Number] copies of the *Middle Section of the Numinous Writ of the Primordial Beginning*
- Cloud Horses
- Gold Coins

The above items are respectfully presented in full.

the Memorial-Officers of the Three Heavens’ Gate;
the Escort Immortals of the Three Heavens’ Gate;
the Urgent-Qi Spirit-Officials of the Flying Memorials in the Dharma;

the Five Thearchs’ Direct Talismans;
the Twelve Hourly Direct Envoys;

the Twelve Scribal Assistants;
the Jia-Zi Officials and Clerks;
the myriad hosts of officers, generals, and clerks—ten thousand chariots and a hundred thousand riders.

We humbly implore Your Sagely Compassion to deign to regard and examine this reverent memorial.

**Yellow Silk Vermilion Memorial**
From the *Ordinances of the Master of Vast Accomplishment*, each line of the full text contains twenty-four characters. The memorial is presented without a Pass.

[Ritual rank and titles of the officiant are fully set forth.]
Your servant [Name], with utmost reverence, prostrates and bows twice, respectfully addressing the Most High, Boundless, Supreme Dao, Perfectly Real, and Spontaneously Self-So, the Golden Gate of the Seven Treasures and Jade Palace:

We, Your servants, base and foolish, have presumptuously partaken in the Great Dharma. Our merits are but specks of dust and dew, while our transgressions weigh like mountains. Overwhelmed with shame, body and soul are at a loss. With utmost reverence, we prostrate and bow twice.

We, Your servants, truly humble and insignificant, have fortunately relied upon past blessings. We have encountered the wondrous transformation and rejoice in this undeserved favor. Though unworthy of the Mysterious Office, we are charged with the duty of salvation. Though our nature is dull and our learning dim, we pledge our sincere devotion and uphold the wondrous teachings. Seeing righteousness, we think of courage, and day and night, our hearts are earnest. Given the circumstances, how dare we not make this known?

Now, residing at [Place] in [County], [Prefecture], [Province], the Daoist official [Surname] [Name], having listed their name, prostrates and presents this memorial.

We have heard that the Supreme Orthodox Dharma, the Great Register of the Yellow Register Retreat, dissolves the sins of past lives and the present existence—those of the heart, mouth, and intent. It benefits the Emperor above and all beings below, safeguarding the nation and the household, averting disasters and harm, augmenting blessings and longevity, resolving transgressions and faults, delivering the Nine Ancestors and Seven Generations, and all departed spirits. It saves and delivers both the living and the dead, bestowing universal grace.

We respectfully offer the Ten Directions’ Golden Dragon Pledges, the life-thread silk, incense, flowers, oil, and candles—all requisite offerings—to attest our sincere hearts and present this memorial.

Through our practice of the Dao, repentance, and confession of past transgressions, we sever calamities and misfortunes, accumulate merit, and deliver the deceased [Name], enabling their ascension to the Dao’s realm. Our words are sincere and earnest; the principle demands this presentation.

We reverently lead a single altar of Daoists, strictly following the *Yellow Register Simplified Text of the Lower Primordial*, the ranks of the numinous immortals, and the chosen [Place] to establish the altar and enact the Mysterious Ordinance’s form, modeling Heaven and Earth. With the gold dragons and silk banners we have brought, we consecrate the Ten Directions, beseeching Heaven and invoking the mandate to save and deliver both the living and the dead. Together, we exhort and encourage one another, purifying our hearts and striving in devotion, surrendering to the Perfectly Real.

Our prayers and wishes are to conduct the Supreme Yellow Register Great Retreat for [Number] days and nights, with nine daily audiences and ten recitations of the scriptures. Beginning on [Day], the retreat is established and the rites commence. Concluding on [Day], we perform the gratitude-offering Pure Offering, encompassing the three hundred and sixty divine positions.

We reverently report the merits and dissolve the altar, casting the dragon into the mountains and waters, and presenting the cinnabar-written memorials to the numinous altar. We prostrate and present this memorial to the Nine Heavens, humbly beseeching the Most High, Boundless, Supreme Dao, the Primordial Celestial Honored One; the Supreme Dao Lord; the Most High Lord Lao; the Most High Elder; the Supreme Mysterious Elder; the Ten Directions’ Spontaneously Self-So Numinous Treasure Celestial Honored Ones; the perfected great sages who have attained the Dao; the perfected lords and elders; the Celestial Thearchs and Heavenly Emperors; the Heavenly Master Lords; and the Great Dharma Masters of the Mysterious Center.

May You deign to examine our memorial and take pity on our sincere hearts. As above, we beseech You to command the officials to proclaim to the Ten Directions’ Five Elder Thearchs, the True Immortals of the Five Marchmounts, the Three Officials and Nine Bureaus, and the true spirits of the Ten Realms. Deliver the deceased [Name] and their Nine Ancestors and Seven Generations, whether karmically connected or not, treating enemies and kin equally, and all departed souls. Enable them to emerge from the eternal night and the Nine Dark Realms, ascending to the Southern Palace. Clothe their dry bones, restore their decayed forms to bloom, end the cycle of rebirth, and transform them into the gate of blessings. In their resting places, protect their corporeal forms, restore their spirits, and reunite them with the light and the dark.

For the retreat sponsor [Name], may all sins of past and present lives be eradicated, grievances resolved, calamities averted, disasters dispelled, life prolonged, and destiny preserved. May the living and the dead flourish, and their kin enjoy peace. We pray that the Seven Luminaries shine brightly, the Two Modes endure, the Six Harmonies remain pure, the imperial reign be prolonged, yin and yang harmonize, the Nine Grains yield abundance, pestilence be forever banished, auspicious signs daily increase, the nation prosper, the people be at peace, and the world attain great tranquility. May we eternally encounter the Dao’s grace and preserve primordial auspiciousness.

We reverently dispatch the celestial immortals’ troops and horses, the perfected immortals’ troops and horses, the earthly immortals’ troops and horses, the sun and moon’s troops and horses, the stellar constellations’ troops and horses, the Five Thearchs’ troops and horses, the Three Rivers and Four Seas’ troops and horses, and the Five Marchmounts and Four Waterways’ troops and horses—each numbering nine hundred million ten thousand chariots.

Within our bodies, each of us bears the registers of the Three Caverns and Four Supplements, the true immortal officers and attendants of the Dharma, the numinous treasure officials, the overseers of the retreat, the Three-Five Merit Clerks, the Left and Right Official Envoys, the Incense-Attending Golden Lads, the Message-Transmitting Jade Maidens, the Five Thearchs’ Direct Talismans, the Flying Dragon Cavalry Clerks for transmitting memorials, the Flying Memorial Officers, the assembled officers, generals, and clerks of the memorial, the Talisman Envoys for descending the true and summoning the numinous, the Lads for descending the true and summoning the numinous, the Direct Envoys of the Most High, the Direct Envoys of the Three Realms, the Scarlet Dragon and Golden Dragon Post Officers of the Mysterious Capital, the Great General of the White Horse and Plain Chariot, the officers, generals, and clerks, the Bathing and Purification Officers, the Refining and Deliverance Palace Generals of the Southern Prosperity Upper Palace, the Divine Tiger Summoning Officers, the Jade Maiden Spirit Soldiers, the various departments of the Orthodox Dharma, the officers and clerks jointly pursuing souls and capturing spirits, the City Gods and Earth Rectors, the House-Protecting Generals, the local earth gods, the true officials and deities of the neighborhood, the deities and spirits of the Three Realms, the altar-monitoring divine generals, and all those overseeing, protecting, transmitting commands, and safeguarding the retreat. May those who have diligently performed their duties be fully adorned.

Following this memorial, may it ascend to the Mystic Capital, where merits shall be enumerated and rewards bestowed. Upon audience at the Immortal Palace, may ranks of the Perfected be advanced, noble titles elevated, and appointments made according to grade—high and low alike—all to be promoted in accordance with the rites of the Great Perfected.

We, Your servants, have yet to master the Daoist arts in full; in our reverence and humility, we have erred in deportment and transgressed against the statutes, failing to conform to ritual propriety. We fear reproach from the Four Offices, punishment from the Five Emperors, and the accumulation of myriad faults and sins. We humbly beseech Your pardon, that through compassion for our ignorance, we may be spared from condemnation and penalty.

The true officials within the five constituents of our bodies, having fulfilled their duties, shall each return to their respective palaces within us. May we, Your servants, through the study of the Dao attain the Dao, through the pursuit of immortality achieve immortality, and forever become Perfected Ones, radiant as the Three Luminaries, enduring with the Five Qi.

We implore the Most High and the assembled Venerables to discern and show mercy.

Your servants respectfully entrust this memorial to the Flying Immortal Direct Envoys of the Two Offices, the Merit Registrars of the Three and Five, the Attendant Envoys of the Left and Right, the Yin-Yang Spirit-Decision Clerks, the Vermilion Talisman Chariot Clerks, the Just Wind Courier Clerks, the Post-Horse Memorial Clerks, the Flying Dragon Riders, and the Heavenly Immortal Riders—twenty-four of each. Bearing this memorial, may they ascend to the Three Heavenly Courts of the Most High and await the decree.

We, [Name], with utmost reverence and trepidation, bow our heads to the ground, prostrate ourselves, and bow again to make this known.

(Three lines left blank)

Your servant, of the [Surname] clan, residing in [State] at [Location], hereby conducts this offering through incense and refinement.

(Three lines left blank)

To the Most High, Formless and Nameless, the Void and Spontaneous, the Utmost True and Great Dao, the Supreme Primordial Venerable, the Golden Portal and Jeweled Jade August One:

(Three lines left blank)

In the year [Year], the [Month] month, the [Day] day, at the [Hour] hour, this memorial is respectfully presented at the altar of the retreat.
