This vermilion memorial, in accordance with the teachings of Master Guangcheng, is to be inscribed on six *chi* of fine, well-woven yellow silk, using the final width. Red borders shall be drawn, and the text written in vermilion, with twenty-four characters per line. The first line shall contain the name and title, continuing through the "bow again" to the end of the line. The phrase "make this known" shall occupy a line by itself, centered.

No character denoting "life" may appear at the end of a line, nor may "ghost" or "death" occupy the beginning of a line. No line may end with a truncated personal name, nor may the character for "servant" (*chen*) begin a line. The format of memorials must be strictly observed, with no crossing out, smearing, interpolations, or damage that mars the text. Precision is paramount. Even in worldly memorials, meticulous calligraphy is required—how much more so when addressing the Heavenly Perfected? Failure to adhere to these standards risks divine censure, the memorial’s failure to reach its destination, or even the incurrence of fault. How then could resonance with the Most High be achieved?

The presiding Dharma Master shall personally inscribe the memorial, completing it within twenty-four sections. In ancient times, silk was ruled with lines for writing, a practice still observed by elder Dharma Masters who uphold the old methods. Modern silk, being thinner, may require backing with paper to prevent ink bleed. My late teacher used thick, pristine yellow paper for ease, which is equally suitable. While silk adheres to ancient tradition, its fibers may produce residual *qi* when burned, and the ruled lines become indistinct. This memorial, however, is accompanied by the officers, generals, and clerks as it ascends to the Heavenly Court, so no additional documents are required—it is presented directly during the dispersal rites at the altar.

Yet many in the world blindly follow Master Guangcheng’s template for the yellow silk memorial. They fail to recognize that in ancient times, grand retreats were conducted with the primary intent of praying for the sovereign’s well-being and the nation’s prosperity, followed by personal blessings, then broad salvation, and finally deliverance for the deceased. The memorial’s intent was thus coherent from beginning to end, making the template appropriate. In modern retreats, however, prayers for peace focus solely on the individual, neglecting the nation’s welfare. Memorials for the deceased fixate on the departed, ignoring universal salvation. High-ranking Dharma Masters, catering to the retreat sponsor’s wishes, obsess over ensuring the sponsor receives the full benefits, lest they be diminished. Thus, the five yellow registers of the *Huanglu* retreat now entirely omit prayers for the sovereign and the nation, and the emphasis on universal salvation has waned. To then employ Master Guangcheng’s format for the vermilion memorial creates a stark contradiction with the preceding five registers—is this not deceiving Heaven?

The memorials I have composed retain the ancient intent, making this vermilion memorial compatible. If, however, one uses only contemporary memorials, pandering to the sponsor’s desires, this vermilion memorial is wholly unsuitable.

Moreover, Dharma Masters today lack concern for all beings. During retreats, they tremble with anxiety, fearful of even the slightest displeasure from the sponsor, lest they forfeit future commissions. They flatter incessantly, never daring to voice dissent. How then could they discern right from wrong or expound upon the orthodox canon?

In ancient times, those who sponsored retreats dispersed wealth and treasures to broadly aid the departed in the netherworld. First, this dissolved their own miserliness; second, it honored the sovereign, delivered the nine generations of ancestors, and extended blessings to the common people, universally benefiting the realm; third, it broadly salvaged the beings of the Five Paths, Four Births, Three Realms, and Ten Classes, even encompassing birds, beasts, grasses, and trees within the retreat’s grace. Through such means, one safeguards family and self, ensuring boundless fortune and longevity. Through such means, one delivers ancestors and the deceased, enabling their transcendence. If retreat sponsors were to heed my humble words, they might expand their benevolence.

Alas, those who preside over retreats today, when facing sponsors, are so preoccupied with flattery that they dare not broach this subject. In my ordinary capacity, I have conducted retreats and offerings in accordance with these principles, and sponsors have never insisted on their private agendas. If fellow practitioners could likewise uphold integrity and dignity for the sake of the Daoist tradition, rather than being constrained by meager offerings or compelled to bow and scrape, it would be a blessing for our tradition.

Ultimately, the gain or loss of wealth is determined by one’s karmic destiny.

Poverty and wealth, lowliness and eminence—each has its destined portion. To seek the crooked as though it were straight, or to employ flattery in pursuit of favor, is truly in vain.

*End of the Twenty-Third Scroll of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Rites*
*Beginning of the Twenty-Fourth Scroll of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Rites*

**Petition for Salvation from Suffering**
The Daoist official of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Register, your subject [Name], with utmost reverence and trepidation, bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and respectfully addresses this petition.

On the [day] of this month, your subject has, on behalf of [Name] of [Prefecture, Subprefecture, County, Location], established an unsurpassed Yellow Register Grand Retreat of [number] days and nights, to deliver and uplift the deceased [Name] and the souls of the male and female ancestors thus invoked. A grand offering of sustenance has also been set forth to universally deliver all lonely and wandering spirits.

Your subject has heard that the ceaseless revolving of the great transformation arises from its inherent conditions, and that boundless salvation stems from the vast vow of compassion. Relying upon the numinous grace of the Dao, your subject ventures to lay bare his humble devotion.

With utmost reverence and trepidation, your subject bows his head to the ground and prostrates himself.

Your subject humbly reflects that the great transition of life and death is inescapable, for all things must have a beginning and an end. The karmic consequences of good and evil determine whether one ascends or descends. Moreover, after the body has passed through the Great Yin, the soul abides in the endless night, forever cut off from the light of the sun, silently trapped in the netherworld, unable to transcend the dark prisons. It is only through the compassionate teachings of the Divine Master that the sunken souls of the black earth may be universally uplifted.

Yet your subject, lacking in profound understanding of the ultimate truth, is ashamed of his ignorance. Though unworthily occupying the office of ritual proclamation, he has vowed to exhaust his efforts in the work of salvation. Thus, he records his sincere prayers, beseeching deliverance. He reverently invokes the **Celestial Worthy of Compassion and Salvation of the Eastern Peak, Supreme One of the Azure Palace**, Sovereign of the Heavens.

Your Majesty’s Dao is as all-embracing as heaven and earth, and your grace extends to both the living and the dead. You open the gate of the utmost truth to guide and receive, and expound the teachings of great transformation to nurture and perfect. Your radiant majesty permeates all, bringing purity and peace to the nine lands. Your divine blessings spread throughout the ten directions, illuminating all with prosperity and harmony.

Your subject humbly implores that your mercy flow into the Fengdu underworld, bestowing protection upon the Yellow Springs. May you dispatch the flying celestial deities and specially command the Salvation Lads to descend with the talismanic decree of the Nine Dragons, unlocking the six gates of the netherworld. May all the lonely spirits of the ten thousand kinds, and the stagnant souls of the three evil paths, receive your extraordinary favor and together ascend to the immortal realms. May the souls thus invoked and delivered be freed from the obstacles of their many lives, refined and transformed, and forever attain carefree wandering.

With this petition, your subject respectfully submits his plea.

With utmost reverence and trepidation, your subject bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and respectfully concludes.

In the year [Year], the [Month] of the [Cyclical Year], your subject [Name], in his humble capacity, respectfully submits this petition.

**Petition for the Refinement and Deliverance of Souls through the Orthodox Yin-Yang Qi**
The Daoist official of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Register, your subject [Name], with utmost reverence and trepidation, bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and respectfully addresses this petition.

On the [day] of this month, your subject has, on behalf of the faithful official [Name] of [Prefecture, Subprefecture, Location], established an unsurpassed Yellow Register Grand Retreat. On the night of [day], he will refine and deliver the souls present at the assembly, universally saving all lonely spirits and the ten thousand kinds of the three evil paths. On the night of [day], he will refine the soul of [Name].

Your subject has heard that the root of life is bestowed by destiny, and form arises from the differentiation of qi. To lose this root and stray from the truth is to invite calamity and retribution. To escape the realms of suffering, one must rely upon meritorious deeds. Thus, your subject ventures to present his urgent plea, daring to intrude upon the lofty hearing of the heavens.

With utmost reverence and trepidation, your subject bows his head to the ground and prostrates himself.

Your subject earnestly considers that when the body is destroyed, the spirit departs, and the soul scatters while the po sinks. Having passed through the Great Yin, they are entangled in the net of suffering. Without the orthodox qi of the perfected truth, the spirits of the dark and obscure cannot be uplifted. Your subject, though of mediocre talent, has unworthily assumed the leading office. Fearing his lack of mastery over the profound mysteries, he truly despairs of achieving spiritual resonance.

Now, the faithful official [Name] and all the assembled officials, soldiers, and common people have reverently prepared the sacred space, respectfully opened the ritual platform, prayed to heaven and earth, arranged the images, and performed the rites. They have laid bare their grieving hearts and poured forth their sincere devotion.

Your subject reflects that the stagnant souls of the nine springs do not awaken to the original source of their single nature. Relying upon this humble cause, he seeks to illuminate their past lives.

He reverently invokes the **Golden Mother of the Nine Numina, Supreme Perfected of the White Jade Tortoise Terrace**, and the **Jade Sovereign of the Eastern Flower, Lord of the Azure Lad, Prime Minister of the Wooden Duke**.

You are the ancestors of the Two Qi and the origin of the ten thousand beings. You established the ultimate in the primordial heavens, bestowing blessings and nurturing all things, delivering and saving according to the needs of each. Moved by compassion, you respond to the cries of suffering.

Your subject humbly implores that you extend your vast mercy and broadly bestow your great grace. May the souls, spirits, and consciousnesses receive the divine radiance of metal and wood. May their original root and source fully recover the orthodox nature of yin and yang. May the nine netherworlds cease their trials, and may the ten thousand kinds receive your favor.

Overwhelmed by the urgency of his plea, your subject respectfully submits this petition.

With utmost reverence and trepidation, your subject bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and respectfully concludes.

In the year [Year], the [Month] of the [Cyclical Year], your subject [Name], in his humble capacity, respectfully submits this petition.

---

**Petition to the Nine Heavens Sovereign**
The Daoist official of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Register, your subject [Name], with utmost reverence and trepidation, bows his head to the ground, prostrates himself, and respectfully addresses this petition.

On the [day] of this month, your subject has, on behalf of [Official Title and Name] of [Prefecture, Subprefecture, Location], established an unsurpassed Yellow Register Grand Retreat of [number] days and nights, to deliver and uplift the distant ancestors of [Name] and all others, enabling them to together ascend to the realms of goodness. He universally delivers the ten thousand kinds of the nine provinces and all lonely spirits. On the night of [day], he will refine and deliver the souls present at the assembly, the male and female souls thus invoked, and the principal soul of [Name].

Your subject has heard that when the primordial unity first began, the two images congealed and divided the numinous. The nine luminaries took form, enabling the ten thousand beings to receive their destinies. Without returning to the root and reverting to the source, how could one recover their nature and gather the true?

Daring to presume upon the celestial statutes, your subject respectfully submits his humble plea. He knows he has overstepped his bounds and is truly filled with trepidation.

With utmost reverence and trepidation, your subject bows his head to the ground and prostrates himself.

Your subject reflects that he is but a dusty and mediocre talent, dull and ignorant. Unversed in the rhythms of qi, he has presumptuously assumed the numinous office of salvation. Unfamiliar with the canonical rites, he has rashly taken up the leading role in the sacred altar. He recalls that when humans die, they become ghosts, and only through refinement can they begin the journey back to life.

Only through smelting and refinement can ghosts be delivered and restored to human form. Without the alchemy of transformation, how could they receive their new substance? As wood shines and metal gleams, so too does the work of harmonizing qi bring forth radiance. When yin reaches its extreme and yang returns, one must rely on the shelter of the life-generating spirits.

With utmost reverence, we turn to the August Emperor of the Nine Heavens. Above, You uphold the Three Realms, loftily enthroned in the layered skies. Through non-action, the myriad beings flourish of themselves; without speech, the ten directions are pervaded by Your grace. Moved by compassion for those sunk in suffering, You specially bestow the blessings of nurturance. You spread the life-essence across the nine limits, completing the ten-month gestation. You grant the purest qi of the Five Phases, so that the body becomes replete with the hundred spirits. Bending down, You rescue the yin souls and swiftly elevate them to the yang realms. Those trapped in the three paths, their spectral forms stagnant, are all relieved of their penal labors. The orphaned souls of the ten thousand kinds alike attain the joy of renewed life.

Your subject, overwhelmed with gratitude and urgency, respectfully presents this memorial for Your august perusal. With utmost reverence and trepidation, your subject bows his head to the ground and prostrates himself, again bowing to offer these words.

In the year... month... day, your subject [Name], holding such-and-such office, respectfully submits this memorial.

Yunzhong has observed that the format of memorials is an ancient institution, its origins long established. The five chapters now compiled for use in the Yellow Register Retreat also follow ancient rites. The invocatory phrases therein still adhere to the transmission of the masters. The vermilion memorials for the dispersed altars follow the style of Master Guangcheng, with only minor additions of the divine officials and generals invoked in the ritual. As for presenting memorials before the Celestial Emperor, this practice arose in middle antiquity and became a secular convention, thus it is fitting to adhere to the ceremonial forms of both ancient and modern courts.

The *Memorial for Salvation through Refinement*, the *Memorial for the Refinement and Deliverance of Souls*, and the *Memorial to the Nine Celestial Emperors* compiled by Yunzhong all follow the masters’ instructions, though the wording is presumptuously composed by Yunzhong himself. He does not dare claim it is entirely appropriate, but only that it does not contradict the *Cavernous Mystery Numinous Treasure Refinement and Deliverance* texts in practice. Those of lofty attainment may replace it with more majestic prose, provided it does not violate the ritual canons—this too would be excellent.

The Nine Celestial Emperors are addressed in nine separate memorials, which is particularly thorough, though each must be presented individually. Arranging them according to the sequence of the nine qi would be ideal. Yunzhong, lacking talent, cannot fully accomplish this task; he must await later scholars to perfect this model for posterity.

**Green Petitions**
For the Yellow Register Grand Retreat, seven petitions are required for the dedicated altar rites:
1. Jade Clarity,
2. Highest Clarity,
3. Supreme Clarity—these three pertain to the Great Dao.
Next are:
4. Wu Heaven,
5. Northern Culmen,
6. Celestial Sovereign—these correspond to the Three Qi and govern the heavens.
7. Earth Only—this is the consort of Wu Heaven.

Herein lies the utmost reverence and supremacy. For smaller-scale retreat and jiao rites not dedicated to a specific altar, one may follow the chapter format and address the ranks of the Great Dao.

Additionally, in Yellow Register retreats and jiao rites, there are petitions to the Great Emperor of the Southern Culmen and the Heavenly Worthy of Salvation, each with their own conventions. Since the Sui and Tang dynasties, following the masters’ transmissions, court Green Petitions have listed the sacred ranks, a practice continued in the Song dynasty. Below is a Green Petition from an inner court jiao during the Jingde era of Emperor Zhenzong’s reign, preserved for reference, along with contemporary formats.

**Green Petition from the Inner Court Jiao of Emperor Zhenzong**
On the day of [Year], in the cyclical year [X] of the reign [Y], the [X] month, the [X] day of the new moon, the [X] cyclical day, the Filial Son and Heavenly Sovereign, Your Subject [Name], respectfully dispatches the Inner Palace Attendant [Name] to bow in proxy at the Chaoyuan Hall of the Great Inner Palace, inaugurating the Yellow Register Grand Retreat for [X] days. On the concluding day, with utmost reverence, a Luo Heaven Grand Jiao is established, comprising 2,400 divine positions.

With profound reverence, we kowtow and humbly address the Primordial Heavenly Worthy, the Most High Lord of the Dao, the Most High Lord Lao, the Three Clarities and Sacred Hosts, the Ten Poles and Lofty Perfected, the Northern Culmen Star Lord, the Nine Luminaries Star Lords, the Northern and Southern Dipper Star Lords, the Three Primordial Emperors of Heaven, Earth, and Water, the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center, the officials and attendants of the Three Realms, and all the numinous spirits.

We reflect that the Three Heavens and Two Earths cover and sustain all without partiality. Yin’s gloom and yang’s warmth govern generation and transformation beyond comprehension. Encompassing the myriad spirits above and discerning the myriad beings below, they respond to compliance with auspicious omens and to defiance with calamities. Thus did the former kings hold them in awe, and the ancient sages establish their bounds.

Your subject, inheriting the legacy of his ancestors and governing the multitudes, observes the lofty heavens to take his model and follows the precedents of the former sages to maintain their achievements. Now, with the frontiers pacified and the years abundant, what meager virtue of mine has aligned with this felicitous destiny? How could I forget the caution of steering decay or the admonition of treading deep waters? To repay the blessings of the divine, I reverently inaugurate this jiao altar.

We humbly pray that You bestow fortune upon the state and blessings upon all beings, that the two qi may be free of pestilence and the eight winds forever still the weapons of war. May the ten luminaries traverse the heavens without deviating from their proper courses, and the four seas mark the earth without surging waves. May the black-haired people all live in peace, and the myriad kinds thrive in harmony. May the court be steadfast in its manifold achievements, and the realm be spared the three disasters. We earnestly implore the mysterious spirits, prostrating ourselves with sincere devotion.

Your subject, overwhelmed with awe... [text incomplete]

To the Most Sacred Heaven, with utmost reverence, we present this solemn petition.

**Yellow Register Petition Formula**
On the [day], the [day]th day of the [month] in the year [year], cyclical year [stem-branch], at [location] in [prefecture/state/county], the Daoist officiant [name and title], respectfully entrusts Master [name] of the [scripture/register] Dharma to inaugurate the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Fast of [number] days and nights at [location]. May it supremely benefit the state and universally bless all beings. May it open the path for the ascent of the seven generations of ancestral souls and broadly deliver the nine realms’ lonely spirits. Gathering these meritorious fruits, we dedicate them specifically to deliver the departed soul of [name], that they may transcend to the realms of goodness.

With utmost reverence, we prostrate and present this petition, supplicating the Supreme, Formless, Nameless, Void, Spontaneous, Perfectly Real, Great Dao, the Most High Primordial Honored One, before the Golden Portal and Jade Threshold.

Your subject, overwhelmed with awe, gazes toward Heaven and longs for the Sacred with fervent devotion, prostrating in utmost sincerity, respectfully submits this petition.

**Yellow Register Scattered Altar Jiao Petition**
On the [day], the [day]th day of the [month] in the year [year], cyclical year [stem-branch], at [location] in [prefecture/state/county], the Daoist officiant [name and title], respectfully entrusts Master [name] of the [scripture/register] to inaugurate the Supreme Yellow Register Grand Fast of [number] days and nights at [location]. May it supremely benefit the state and universally bless all beings, ascend and deliver the departed ancestors, and broadly rescue the lonely spirits. Gathering these meritorious fruits, we dedicate them to the deliverance of the soul of [name], that they may transcend to the realms of blessedness.

Upon the completion of the fast, we reverently conduct the Pure Jiao of the Three Realms’ Lofty Perfected Ones, encompassing the three hundred and sixty divine stations, to manifest our gratitude for Heaven’s grace.

The minister humbly prostrates and presents this memorial, reverently invoking the Supreme Dao—formless and nameless, void and spontaneous, the utmost true and great, the primordial honored one of the Golden Portal and Jade Sovereign. Your servant, though unworthy, dares not but gaze toward Heaven, yearning for the sagely presence with utmost reverence and trepidation, and thus respectfully submits this petition.

This memorial’s sacred rank pertains to the worship of the Great Dao, distinct from the memorials addressed to the Three Realms’ Heavenly Worthies. For the Three Qi constitute the Three Realms, and the Three Realms are the Great Dao. This single hierarchical rank encompasses the Three Qi, embracing and unifying the primordial unity—nothing is left incomplete. If one were to employ the rites of the *Dongxuan Lingbao* while using the memorial format of the *Taiqing* tradition, it would constitute a grave transgression of protocol, both logically inconsistent and improper.

For instance, in the memorials of Orthodox Unity (*Zhengyi*) masters, where the *Taiqing* rank is used, the blue petitions (*qingci*) must likewise conform to that rank. Alternatively, if divided into the Three Realms, they address the Heavenly Worthies accordingly. Now, if the Great Dao’s rank is used exclusively, the Three Realms are not separately venerated. When distinctions in rank are made, the titles are as follows: in the Jade Clarity Realm, the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning, Void and Spontaneous; in the Highest Clarity Realm, the Supreme Dao Lord, Celestial Worthy of the *Dongxuan Lingbao*; and in the Great Clarity Realm, the Supreme Lord Lao, Celestial Worthy of the *Dongshen* and *Daode*.

Recently, some have used the title "August Emperor of the Void" beneath the Heavenly Worthies, which is incorrect. The August Emperor of the Void holds a distinct rank of its own. Likewise, those who designate the Dao Lord as the "August Emperor of Wondrous Existence" and the Primordial Beginning as the "August Emperor of Wondrous Nonbeing" demonstrate a profound misunderstanding of the ultimate Dao. The Heavenly Worthies embody qi, and thus the Dao. The One Qi divides into Three, forming the Three Realms. Born of the same qi, to speak of its existence is inexpressible, and to speak of its nonexistence is untenable. All three dwell within the realm of wondrous nonbeing, for the Three Realms share a single body. To assign one Worthy to wondrous existence and another to wondrous nonbeing would imply that existence cannot become nonexistence, nor nonexistence existence—how far this strays from the Dao!

Such eccentric innovations, distorting the sacred ranks of the Three Realms’ Heavenly Worthies, violate ancient traditions and contravene ritual canons. These practices originate chiefly among the Daoists of eastern Zhejiang. Having traveled extensively across rivers and lakes, I have observed that such deviations are less prevalent elsewhere. The *Orthodox Unity Memorials and Taiqing Ranks* states: "The Supreme Lord Lao of the Great Dao, the Three Heavens, and the Ultimate Void; the Supreme Elder; the Heavenly Thearch; the Heavenly Elder; the Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital; the Nine Qi Elders; the myriad layers of Dao qi; the twelve hundred officials; and the Jade Sovereign of the Great Clarity." This rank pertains exclusively to the Great Clarity and belongs entirely to the *Dongshen* tradition. Thus, it is appropriate for Orthodox Unity fasts and jiao blue petitions. Separate memorials may still be offered to the Jade Clarity and Highest Clarity Realms.

For this reason, it is preferable to address the Three Realms’ Heavenly Worthies collectively. Beyond these, the memorial to the August Heavenly Sovereign reads: "The Supreme One Who Opens Heaven, Holds the Talisman, Governs the Calendar, Embodies Truth, and Upholds the Dao—August Jade Thearch of the Vast Heaven." For the Northern Pole: "Great Emperor of the Purple Tenuity at the Center of Heaven and Northern Pole." For the Heavenly Sovereign: "Great Emperor of the Celestial Palace of the Curved Array." For the Earth: "August Earthly Sovereign Who Receives Heaven’s Mandate, Emulates the Law, and Embodies Profound Virtue and Radiant Light."

All other fabricated and uncanonical language must not defile the celestial realms. Exceptions are made only for those outside our tradition. Having examined ancient models of fasts and jiao from beginning to end, I find that all memorials and petitions are meticulously prepared—this is the responsibility of the high officiant. The blue petition, however, expresses the sincerity of the fast’s sponsor and serves as the basis for the high officiant’s ritual actions, known as the "transcribed petition." The blue petition lays bare the liver, and the cinnabar script symbolizes blood—thus conveying the sponsor’s utmost sincerity. Its language should be concise rather than verbose, plain rather than ornate, pouring forth the heart’s truth to implore the August Thearch.

In recent times, those skilled in literature indulge in florid excess, while those with strong memories cite historical anecdotes. Even in Confucian examination essays, one should not invoke history to interpret the classics—how much less appropriate is it to reference mundane records of a post-celestial world before the primordial August Thearch? Modern memorials and rhapsodies often quote passages out of context, while blue petitions have become riddles akin to child’s play. That such texts dare be transcribed and presented is truly lamentable.

If Daoist scriptures are to be cited, one must carefully consult the texts preserved in the *Daoist Canon*. Recently, authentic and spurious works have become entangled, making distinctions difficult. For example, the Chongdao Abbey in Tongbo, Tiantai, was established at the end of the Five Dynasties by King Qian of Wuyue. The scriptures in its repository were hastily compiled by young Daoist novices and Buddhist temple attendants, who copied them en masse to fill the collection. Written in silver ink on blue paper and bound into scrolls, these texts were produced under pressure to meet quotas amid the political fragmentation of the time. As a result, errors abound—omitted characters, missing phrases, entire passages rendered unreadable, and crude, obviously fabricated language. The extent of their inversions and mistakes is beyond enumeration.

Nearly three hundred years have now passed, spanning several generations, and the origins of these texts have faded from memory. Thus, it is claimed that the Daoist canon indeed contains such scriptures. Those of profound discernment can naturally distinguish right from wrong, but the shallowly learned cling to them as orthodox scripture. Might one cite or employ them? In Yunzhong’s observation, the confusion of scriptures and teachings across the land is no less severe than at Tiantai. Moreover, in places Yunzhong’s feet have never trod—books his eyes have never beheld—such errors abound. In distant regions and remote commanderies, within Daoist abbeys and jade palaces, countless scriptures have lost their correctness. Scholars must scrutinize them carefully and not apply them indiscriminately.

Among the various miscellaneous scriptures used for worldly affairs, people often extract entire sentences to incorporate into their compositions, yet these frequently contradict reason. The views of the vulgar, when offering prayers for the deceased, invariably extol the virtues and deeds of the departed, recounting their diligent labors in life—how does this align with the intent of petitioning Heaven for forgiveness? Which child does not love their parents? If one wishes to praise their conduct, one should seek the brush of a master to compose epitaphs, biographical accounts, sacrificial texts, or elegies, wherein their deeds may be recorded in full. Such words are not of this category. Is it to boast of the deceased’s merits and parade them before the world? Does one suppose the departed are unknown to Heaven?

In prayers for healing or averting disaster, one fails to repent of faults or acknowledge blame, instead harboring resentment toward Heaven and reproaching others. Some borrow phrases from classics and histories to serve as petitions for blessings, or seek rank and emolument, or crave longevity and felicity, describing these desires in extravagant terms without modesty or restraint—what do they take Heaven to be? From ancient times to the present, the printed *qingci* have been vast in number. Many are magnificent in literary splendor, yet few conform to ritual standards. The ritual masters of former generations would prepare *qingci* in advance, scrutinizing each character to ensure compliance with the ritual forms before submitting them. The revered masters of Yunzhong were well-versed in ancient and modern learning, upright and unyielding. Even when great nobles requested the performance of fasts and offerings, they would examine the *qingci* for accuracy, never submitting them merely to conform to vulgar expectations—how could they fear the reproach of the patrons?

Scholars and gentlemen of lofty standing, if their texts deviate from Daoist canonical forms, may be reasoned with. But when ignorant commoners present coarse and vulgar petitions, how can one deign to offer them in prayer? In recent times, the ways of the world have grown increasingly decadent. Ritual masters, bending to the times, have abandoned all sense of integrity and shame, fearing only that patrons will not employ them—how could they concern themselves with the propriety of the words? Among them, those unversed in ritual teachings and ignorant of principle, who rashly perform the rites, are hardly worth reproaching. Such petitions may not ascend to the heavens, and the Perfected Ones will surely respond—but considering their ignorance, one may apply the *Spring and Autumn*’s principle of holding the worthy to account.

Those well-versed in canonical texts, though they recognize the impropriety, dare to indulge sentiment and comply with vulgar demands, unafraid of divine scrutiny or punishment. They passively submit to the dictates of the unlearned, transcribing their crude words for submission—what punishment do they deserve? The opening of a *qingci* reads, “In the such-and-such year of the reign of [Dynasty Name],” a form established since antiquity. Recently, some have claimed that the character *wei* (維) offends Heaven’s taboos and have replaced it with *shi* (時). Yet the meaning of *shi* pertains to inscribing beams, writing on walls, or recording prefaces—it denotes the year and month of composition so that later readers may know the circumstances of the time. But *qingci* are written and burned in the altar at the very moment of offering, not stored for future use across years or dynasties. To place *shi* at the beginning—what meaning does this convey?

The Lady of Purple Tenuity stated that the writings of the celestial realms are not the defiled traces of the mundane world. All hidden taboos of the heavens are celestial characters, unrecognizable to the world. As scriptures descend in successive eras, they are translated into worldly writing, thus acquiring mundane characters. The names of the celestial realms and the taboos of the Perfected Ones should not be avoided before the supreme majesty of the Great Dao. From Heaven, the Dao has no name, and without name, the hidden taboos of the heavens exist. Only after the division of Heaven and Earth, as scriptures descended, did the world come to possess them. Now, the mundane character *wei* is mistakenly deemed a taboo of the Great Dao—even if scriptural evidence existed, it should not be followed.

Since the Tang dynasty, successive courts have presented jade tablets to the Heavenly Thearch, all uniformly beginning with *wei* in the year designation. For over a hundred years since the Sui, only *wei* was used. Why, then, has this taboo arisen only recently in petitions to Heaven? The court does not use *huang* (皇) in the imperial title, for *huang* means “great.” The Son of Heaven, though he styles himself a subject before Heaven, should not omit *huang*. Yet the court omits the dynastic name because the following text includes “the heir of the Song, Son of Heaven,” avoiding repetition. When ministers address the Son of Heaven, they say, “In the such-and-such year of the reign of the August Emperor,” a usage consistent through antiquity. Some stone inscriptions also attest to this. Those who claim *wei* offends Heaven’s taboos have no basis for their assertion.

Here, a *qingci* from the Jingde era is recorded, along with one from Jiang’s *Licheng Yi*, which includes a Tang-dynasty *qingci*—their forms are similar. In court rituals, the sacred positions of all emperors are listed, following ancient precedent. In private petitions for individual positions, seven scrolls are offered: one each for the Three Clarities, the Three Enclosures, the August Heaven, the Northern Culmen, the Heavenly Thearch, and the Queen of Earth. In ordinary Jiangdong fasts, sometimes only the August Heaven is petitioned, as the sovereign of Heaven to whom affairs are subordinate. When the Three Realms are collectively addressed as the stages of the Great Dao of the Supreme, only one scroll is used.

Petitions are expressions of earnest sincerity. Court *qingci*, addressing the Supreme Thearch and extending to the officials of the Three Realms, are for universal prayer. Thus, in the Northern Dipper fasts, *qingci* are also presented, though the wording should distinguish between weighty and light matters, and the term “memorial” is not used.

Moreover, there are reckless charlatans who deceive the world, claiming that *qingci* petitions are directed solely to the Heavenly Thearch, while those for the Dipper Stars may be written on white or yellow paper. They absurdly assert that *qingci* can distinguish ranks within the paper itself, even equating their memorials with those presented to Heaven—how preposterous! Do they not know that *qingci* (green petitions), *sushu* (plain documents), and *danshu* (cinnabar writings) embody the meaning of "carving the liver and dripping blood"? When addressing Heaven, one uses terms like "present" or "memorialize"; when addressing the ranked immortals, one says "submit" or "offer"—nothing more. The wording must be carefully weighed, never equated with that for Heaven.

At the outset of a *qingci*, the petitioner’s native place, name, location of the fast, and purpose are already stated; within the text, only the sorrowful plea remains. If one or two couplets describe the altar’s construction, the performance of Daoist rites, or the burning of incense and lighting of lamps, the logic becomes redundant. The text must be concise and precise: a single thought arises in the heart, and the myriad spirits witness it in the void. One need only express the plea earnestly—why require verbose, overflowing documents to move Heaven?

In ordinary fasts and Offerings where I, Yunzhong, am not involved, when assisting others, I often receive requests from scholar-friends to compose *qingci*, and many presumptuously accept. Yet the writings of the unlearned should not be transmitted far, so I refuse to include them in ritual manuals, merely noting the vulgar errors here.

This matter rests entirely with the High Priest (*gaogong*), who must be well-versed in ancient and modern precedents, meticulously examining ritual canons. When transcribing and presenting petitions, they must scrutinize them rigorously. Should any transgression occur, the officiating official is not without fault, and the High Priest’s punishment is doubled—how can one not be vigilant, how not be cautious?

Whenever I, Yunzhong, participate in fasts and Offerings, serving as the chief officiant, I do not compose *qingci* myself. If the petition’s intent contains even the slightest impropriety, I must report it to the fast’s sponsor and amend it before use—and the scholars have never refused to heed me. Petitions that wholly violate ritual standards are never transcribed or presented.

My rise or fall is entirely determined by fate; why would I flatter or ingratiate myself with scholars to seek petty gains? This is truly the teaching of my master, and by nature, I dare not slight the scholars of the fasts or profane the Supreme Thearch.

For Yellow Register fasts, the Offering to disperse the altar is conducted only after the fast concludes, as a thanksgiving to the spirits for safeguarding the altar grounds and conveying sincerity. Once the rites are complete, the Offering expresses gratitude to the true spirits. This differs from the forty-two types of independent Offerings.

Thus, the *qingci* in a fast are pleas for mercy and forgiveness, articulating the purpose of the fast. The *qingci* in a thanksgiving Offering, however, recount the fast’s shortcomings, petition for grace, and express gratitude. For example: "The fast’s rites have concluded, yet I fear errors in the ceremonies"; or "The departed soul has attained deliverance, bathed in the profound grace of the Dao"—this is the intent of *qingci* in thanksgiving Offerings.

Common fast sponsors, if not composing the petitions themselves, often delegate the task to others. Scholars, preoccupied with official examinations, may lack the time to refuse. Thus, they request *qingci* for the fast, then again for the Offering. Even those skilled in composition merely describe the fast and Offering, ignorant of the Daoist purpose behind post-fast Offerings.

Scholars versed in the Classics often model their petitions on classical exegesis, resembling examination "topic breakdowns." Those trained in *ci* and *fu* poetry mimic secular correspondence. For instance, when recommending deceased parents, they borrow lines like *"Sheng wo qu lao"* ("Born me with toil")—a phrase from the *Book of Songs* meant for private reflection, not for addressing a sovereign. How can one casually adopt such language when petitioning Heaven? Another example: *"Mu xi ju wo"* ("Mother nurtured me")—equally inappropriate.

Some scholar-officials write in their *qingci*: *"Having passed the age of knowing fate, I have repeatedly disgraced the observance of customs."* The phrase *"fifty and knowing fate"* is Confucius’s self-description, acceptable when speaking before others. But to state *"knowing fate at fifty"* as a veiled reference to age—is this fitting for Heaven?

In petitions for the deceased, one finds: *"Ju zhu yun mai, ai dao he qiong"* ("Dwelling in the clouds, grief knows no end"). The intent is *"ri ju yue zhu"* ("days and months pass"), but if one omits *"ri yue"* ("sun and moon") and uses only *"ju zhu"*, what is this? What does it mean? Another example: *"How could I expect a dream’s brief absence, only to see eighty years suddenly pass."* Using *"a dream"* to describe death is acceptable in elegies or miscellaneous writings, but omitting *"years"* and using only *"eighty"*—does this mean eighty days or eighty years?

Phrases like *"suddenly afflicted with river fish’s illness"* (a euphemism for diarrhea) or *"swiftly inciting the sigh of the crack’s steed"* (a riddle for death) are especially irreverent. The saying *"Life is like a white colt passing a crack"* is a metaphor—how can it be used when petitioning the Supreme Thearch? Lines such as *"Jade Capital and Golden Gates, treading the eight scenes’ clouds and mist; Round Peaks and Square Isles, dwelling in the three mountains’ towers and pavilions"*—if these are requests to deliver the deceased, can the Supreme Thearch act upon them?

Or consider: *"Morning dew has dried, vainly does the mournful wind howl."* This is idle phrasing. *"Morning dew dries quickly"* illustrates the fleeting nature of life, but if one uses only *"morning dew has dried"* out of context, it merely describes sunrise—how can this be used for Heaven?

As for poetic forms, there are *cangtou* (hidden head), *xiehou* (cut-off tail), riddles, and double entendres—none of which belong in petitions to the Dao.

Removing the first one or two characters from a line is called *cangtou* ("hidden head"). Su Dongpo once composed a playful verse: *"Virtue and goodness reach the age of standing firm; / Rare are the years my father has attained."* The first line alludes to the saying *"At thirty, one stands firm"*—implying his mother was thirty—while the second draws from the proverb *"Seventy is rare"* to suggest his father had reached seventy. This is an example of *cangtou*.

Omitting the last one or two characters from a line is called *xiehou* ("cut-off tail"). Someone once wrote a poem about a stone: *"The Milky Way’s loom is stilled; / An immortal holds the armrest in hand."* This refers to the *"Milky Way’s loom stone"* and the *"immortal’s armrest stone."* Su Dongpo also wrote: *"It alone can end a life; / Nothing else can undo all things."* The original full lines read: *"Wine alone can end a life; / Nothing else can undo all things like wine."* Dongpo removed one character from each line to adapt it into lyrics, exemplifying the *xiehou* style. During the late Tang, Zheng Rong was known for such witticisms, earning the nickname *"Xiehou Zheng the Fifth."*

Describing something without naming it is called *yinyu* ("hidden speech"). A recent poem reads: *"Soughing, it rises from the house—a thousand fathoms of jade; / Billowing, it hangs in the air—a single wisp of cloud."* The first line refers to bamboo, the second to incense. This is the *yinyu* form.

Using a line’s meaning in one sense while implying another is called *shuangguan* ("double entendre"). Su Dongpo wrote: *"Rain from the western mountain at sunrise— / No clear skies, yet skies are clear."* The word *"clear"* (*qing*) ostensibly refers to weather but subtly alludes to *"feeling"* (*qing*), suggesting *"no affection, yet affection exists."* This is the *shuangguan* technique.

Such devices belong to the realm of poetry, lyrics, and miscellaneous writings. In letters, they may be used among peers of equal status. When addressing high-ranking officials or submitting memorials to the court, however, they are inappropriate. Yet in recent times, *qingci* memorials to Heaven often employ *cangtou* and *yinyu*, deploying unconventional forms to plead for mercy or favor. How can one’s conscience allow such irreverence? This is but a brief overview.

Beyond these, there are many who fail to observe taboos, and all who violate the forms and canons of the Daoist scriptures fall into this category. Without careful study, they merely seek to preside over ritual affairs—how can the office of *gaogong* be so easily assumed? The ignorant are not worth reproaching, while the discerning dare not speak out. Greedily offering favors to curry favor with ritual officials, flattering worldly sentiments while deceiving the Creator—how alarming this is! The use of liturgical texts carries no small consequence. If a *gaogong* does not diligently examine and broadly consult, seeking what is most fitting, but instead approaches matters without discrimination, to whom shall the fault be ascribed? Though Yunzhong’s words are of little account, fearing that Heaven must not be trifled with, I cannot help but set forth this one ten-thousandth of my concern. Those of noble aspiration will surely heed this humble intent. As for the ignorant, they may well respond to such upright admonitions with slander and clamor. Yunzhong’s discourse is directed toward those of profound understanding. In time, may there be those who grasp this meaning—it would serve as an aid to the teachings.

*The Twenty-Fourth Scroll of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Rites concludes*
*The Twenty-Fifth Scroll of the Supreme Purity Numinous Treasure Great Rites*

The Master of Dongxuan Lingbao Rituals, Keeper of the Southern Bureau’s Enforcement Canon, and Right Adjunct of the Golden Chamber of the Youthful Repository, Jin Yunzhong, compiles the *Regulations for Memorials*

The Three Caverns have transmitted their regulations, and the Five Scriptures have unfolded their splendor, their mechanism established since antiquity—only the Dao of Dongzhen stands preeminent. Though its descent has flowed long, it was not until the late Warring States period that the Three Mao Perfected Lords first revealed auspicious signs at Mount Juqu, establishing their ancestral altar. Thereafter, figures such as Director Xu, Xu Yuanyou, Minister Yang of Destiny, and Perfected Guo followed in unbroken succession, none failing to refine the Supreme Dao, recite the Cavern Scriptures, and propagate the teachings of Jade Purity, without imposing cumbersome formalities.

The regulations of Dongzhen originally contained no protocols for memorials. It was not until the Han dynasty, when the Orthodox Unity Celestial Master emerged in response to the cosmic mandate, that statutes and ordinances were promulgated. Thus, the rituals of purification and the radiant standards of ceremonial conduct became the hallmark of the Dongshen Dao and the foundation of the Orthodox Unity tradition.

During the Eastern Wu, the Left Immortal Master Xuanguan received the *Categorized Rituals of Dongxuan Lingbao*, transmitting the protocols for memorials to the Celestial Emperor and the esoteric methods of soaring steps. By the Jin dynasty, Xu Jingyang practiced the teachings of the Filial Dao and the Luminous King, introducing techniques for expelling demons, severing toxins, and establishing merit for the salvation of the world. All these belong to the Dao of Dongxuan and the lineage of Lingbao, an unbroken truth from antiquity to the present.

The Lingbao method of memorial prostration is a forbidden and secret text of Dongxuan. From the wondrous inner practices of the Supreme Ultimate Immortal—soaring in spirit to petition the Emperor—to the transmission of the auspicious realms of the Supreme Mystery, it enables the refinement of the true self and the tempering of form, far beyond mere transcription of memorials for mundane affairs. To transmit it to the unworthy brings calamity upon oneself; to disseminate it without proper petition dooms nine generations of ancestors.

If the officials and generals invoked in the memorial—such as the Yin-Yang Divine Envoys, the Just Wind Courier Officers, the Post-Horse Memorial Officers, or the Flying Dragon Scribes—are to be employed, they must be used in conjunction with the Orthodox Unity memorials, for the bureau of the Just Wind Couriers admits no dual paths. As for the various functionaries of memorial review and verification, since practitioners first receive the registers of the Capital Merit, their roles may be combined or omitted as needed.

However, the Merit Officers and Jade Maidens, the methods of seal-script talismans, the techniques of shielding qi, visualizing spirits, treading the Dipper’s steps, and soaring in flight, the initiation of audience with the Primordial, and the communion with the Dao to attain the Perfected—these belong exclusively to the categories of Dongxuan and the original canons of Lingbao. Above, they do not usurp the rites of the Great Cavern of Jade Purity; below, they do not intermingle with the methods of Orthodox Unity or Dongshen. The Dao has its roots, like refined gold or flawless jade. Even the slightest admixture renders it counterfeit. Only through absolute purity and singular focus can resonance be achieved. The Immortal Master cultivated this and attained the Dao, becoming Perfected. Sima Chengzhen, having obtained its secrets, once secluded himself on Mount Shaoshi, disseminating these Dongxuan memorial methods to the world. Those who encounter them must guard them closely. Without swearing oaths to Heaven and Earth and receiving transmission before the altar, they must not be lightly employed. Those outside this lineage should especially refrain from practicing them. Better to dismiss them as invalid and discard them than to treat them with negligence.

When at leisure, one should first cultivate stillness. This stillness is not the lifeless void of the Buddhists but approximates the heart-fasting and sitting-in-forgetfulness of the Confucian Yanzi. Inner thoughts do not stray outward; external distractions do not intrude. In profound tranquility, one abides continuously, as if present yet not present. Within stillness, movement arises, and from it, methods and arts are born. Embracing the Three Qi to fill the interior, gathering the One Spirit to stand at the center, one establishes this wondrous foundation, forgetting both self and world. Gradually, this spirit becomes light and ethereal, rising imperceptibly from the body, riding the void and harnessing qi, ascending weightlessly. Following the method of soaring steps—whose secrets are scattered throughout the texts—scholars must discover them for themselves. It begins with what all know, but its culmination lies beyond mortal comprehension. Without relying on elaborate calculations, merit naturally flourishes; without forced promotion, the form refines itself; without projecting the spirit, the spirit departs on its own; without striving for the true, the true naturally manifests. Applied to memorials, it severs delusion and falsehood, annihilates malevolent spirits, transcends the living and the dead, and averts neighboring calamities. Myriad methods converge into one, simple yet not cumbersome—truly the pivot of Lingbao and the path of the Perfected Immortals.

**Purification Before Memorial Prostration**
Whenever presenting a memorial, first cleanse external impurities. Bathe and change clothes, using fragrant water for washing, then don fresh garments before entering the quiet chamber. If the body is unclean, the spirits will not reside within, the methods will lack efficacy, and the rites will fail to reach Heaven.

**Decoction for Bathing**
Peach bark: half a catty
Maoxiang: half a catty
Huoxiang: half a tael
Fragrant Angelica: half a tael
Linglingxiang: half a tael
Grind into coarse powder and decoct together.

**Talisman for Internal Purification**
*Incantation:*
The workings of Heaven and Earth,
The essence of sun and moon,
Radiate through the four seas,
Severing evil spirits.
Slay demons, dispel illness,
The body shines with light.
Divine water sprinkled,
Ten thousand misfortunes vanish.
*Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by law!*

Recite the incantation, write the talisman, burn it to ash, and mix with pure water to ingest. Place another copy beneath the memorial table, ensuring no one sees it.

**Regular Talisman Ingestion**
Those who present memorials should habitually recite the sacred texts and ingest talismans, resonating with the numinous qi to refine the body and spirit, thereby ensuring efficacy when the time comes. The talismans for regular use are contained within the methods. To enumerate them here risks carelessness and neglect, so no fixed format is established. Simply use proven talismans from daily practice, ingesting them as needed.

**Method for Ingesting the Memorial to Notify the Spirit**
When approaching the altar to present a memorial, three days prior, briefly outline the memorial’s intent on a thin sheet of paper, two and a half inches wide, and write in fine script. Then enter stillness, visualize the spirit, and swallow the memorial. This is the function of memorial prostration.

The Lingbao method of "memorials with intent" pertains to urgent and confidential matters, differing in detail from the above.

In recent times, those who have heard of this method and received its transmission call it the "Memorial of the Heart," measuring three inches and three fen in length—this is indeed the memorial for notifying the spirit of the heart. However, many nowadays mistakenly use this format for the "Memorial of the Heart" to petition Heaven, which is a grave error.

The format for ingesting memorials has already been received through altar vows and will not be repeated here.

**Burning Talismans in the Incense Burner When Presenting Memorials**
This is a commonly used talisman, also known as the "Master Artisan Talisman." According to ancient ritual, it is burned in the incense burner on the altar table when presenting memorials and prostrating. One must not disregard it simply because its name is familiar.

**Blank Space Before and After the Memorial**
For Orthodox Unity memorials, twelve small seals are used. From the second bow to the section following the Great Year, all are sealed. One school’s seals include borders. Another school’s small seals, like talismans, omit borders. Thus, in Orthodox Unity memorials, no blank lines precede the Great Mystery Capital, whereas in the Dongxuan (Cavern Mystery) tradition, blank space is left before and after the memorial. All talismans are written according to the prescribed format, without the twelve small seals. Only the "General Memorial Seal" is used on the year and month.

Some, seeing the "General Memorial Seal" recorded in the *Divine Empyrean Register*, hastily claim it belongs to the Jade Clarity (Yuqing) and Cavern Realms (Dongzhen) Department. They fail to recognize that before the rise of the Divine Empyrean teachings, the Dongxuan memorial system had long used this seal since before the Five Dynasties. The text of the "General Memorial Seal" is derived from the *Lingbao Great Charter for Ascending to Heaven*, merely omitting its lower portion. When used by the living, it serves as an "ascension memorial," providing evidence in the celestial court. The seal signifies mark and trust—this is its essential meaning.

The Dongxuan memorial system employs the "General Memorial Seal," which is part of the original Lingbao canon. Some, upon seeing such practices—a single talisman or seal—borrowed from other texts, mistakenly label them as "Jade Clarity Lingbao." This is incorrect. The *Great Charter for Ascending to Heaven* has always belonged to the Dongxuan Department. When issued to the deceased, the nine characters of the "Messenger of the Nine Mysteries" include phrases like "summon the soul and ascend." When used by the living as a seal, the lower text is omitted—how could this then be attributed to the Dongzhen Department? The *Divine Empyrean Register* merely includes it among its auxiliary materials. Neither its register nor its methods explicitly claim this seal does not belong to the Dongxuan Lingbao tradition. At the time, the Divine Empyrean was regarded as the "Celestial Altar," encompassing all methods. Thus, one or two Lingbao talismans were incorporated into its register. This does not justify altering the ancient system’s categories.

**Lingbao Memorial Presentation Ritual**
The High Priest establishes the oratory, ingests the talisman, and visualizes the proper procedures. Thirty-six offerings of wine and fruit are arranged in two rows along the side halls. With full ritual dignity, the High Priest proceeds to the oratory, leads the officiant to the master’s altar, and announces the matter at hand. Upon completion, he ascends the outer altar to the Earth Gate and recites the "Entering the Gate Incantation." He then ascends the Heavenly Gate, offers incense on the Ten Directions’ incense table, burns the incense talisman, and presents incense at his proper station.

The High Priest moves the ritual table to the right side of the altar, facing northwest. He then visualizes the Four Numinous Beasts guarding his body, the sun and moon illuminating his form nine inches from his face, the Northern Dipper covering his head, and the demon-quelling banner before him. He pays homage to the master as in the fasting ritual.

He visualizes the Three Generals descending from the Heavenly Gate: the Upper Prime’s black *qi* at the left kidney, the Middle Prime’s black *qi* at the right kidney, and the Lower Prime’s red *qi* at the heart. He envisions red-clad officials and soldiers guarding the altar grounds.

The Cantor intones, and each pays homage to the master while maintaining visualization as prescribed. The High Priest recites the incantation:

**Incantation:**
At the Great Beginning, the Primordial True,
The Five Elders in lofty reverence stand.
The Supreme Constancy shines in hidden radiance,
No darkness left unillumined.
Above, they govern the Nine Heavens;
In the center, they command Mount Feng;
Below, they pacify rivers and seas,
The twelve river sources.
The Eight Mighty Divine Incantations,
The Five Sacred Scriptures of the Numinous Register.
Summon dragons to float upon the waters,
Gather *qi* and amass clouds.
Ten thousand spirits shattered and fallen,
All slain without reprieve.
Sun, moon, and five planets,
The Northern Dipper’s seven origins.
All heavens, all earths,
All waters, all mountains.
Heavenly Kings at leisure,
The Five Emperors bearing banners.
Celestial Soldiers lead the way,
Golden Tigers rush behind.
Fierce beasts of Heaven,
Seal and close the four gates.
What is called arrives instantly,
What is summoned hastens forward.
The Red Script of the Radiant Fall,
Wind and fire without pause.
Whatever is commanded,
The Golden Dragon swiftly transmits.

The Cantor intones, and the ritual drum is sounded twenty-four times.

O Most Supreme Three Heavens, Primordial Origin of the Three *Qi*, Most High Lord Lao, summon forth from within this servant’s body the Three and Five Merit Officers, the Left and Right Attendant Envoys, the Left and Right Incense-Bearers, the Courier Dragon Riders, the Incense-Attending Golden Youths, the Message-Transmitting Jade Maidens, and the Five Emperors’ Direct Talismans—thirty-six each of the Direct-Day Incense Officials—emerge. Let those who emerge be arrayed in solemn attire. Notify the local earth gods and the deities of the soil and grain of this domain. This servant now burns incense and offers it with sincere intent, that all sentiments and supplications be fully conveyed in the memorial text. May the life-*qi* of the Most High’s Ten Directions’ Orthodox True Ones descend and flow into this servant’s body, that this servant’s entreaties swiftly reach the presence of the August Heavenly Jade Emperor of the Limitless Great Dao.

Each declares their ritual rank:

This servant, [Name], along with the assembled altar officials, humbly and with utmost sincerity, respectfully addresses the Limitless Great Dao, the August High Perfected, the Imperial Lord of the Sun Palace, the August Sovereign of the Moon Mansion, the Seven Origins of the Northern Dipper, the Three Origins’ Lords of Heaven, Earth, and Water, the Four Sage Marshals of the Northern Culmen, the Five Virtues’ Stellar Lords of the Five Directions, the Twenty-Eight Constellations of the Four Quarters, the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center, the Orthodox Unity Perfected of Serene Response, the Three Masters of the Numinous Treasure Scriptures’ Transmission, the Left Immortal Elder of the Supreme Ultimate, the Perfected of Thorough Response, the Grand Historian of the Nine Provinces’ Immortals, the Lofty and Illustrious Great Envoy, the Perfected of Divine Merit and Wondrous Aid, the Ancient and Present Transmitting Perfected Masters, the Sagely Hosts of the Three Caverns’ Altar, the Divine Immortals of the Numinous Treasure Registers, the Sagely Multitudes of the Cavern Mystery’s Ritual Codes, the Flying Heavenly Divine Kings of the Ten Directions, the Three Perfected Lords Tang, Ge, and Zhou, the Inspectors of the Fast, the Numinous Treasure Officials and Attendants, the Thousand Chariots and Ten Thousand Riders of the Memorial, and all true numina.

This servant has heard that the August High Perfected are the sovereigns of the Mysterious Culmen’s utmost reverence. The Jade Capital and Golden Gates, the Purple Clarity’s supreme heavens—gazing upward, they are distant and unfathomable; looking toward them, their vault is boundless. Their majesty permits no verbal approach, their form admits no ascent by steps. Though the paths of high and low diverge, and the tracks of sage and mortal differ, yet the offices of ritual codes and memorials are established, and the teachings broadly expound the rules of flying petitions. Though communication between heaven and humanity occurs in the space of offerings, it is truly the master’s guidance that connects in the moment of contemplation. Only by issuing forth one’s spirit may one ascend to the Emperor; by purifying one’s person, one is permitted to reach Heaven. In an instant, soaring and ascending, the response is swift and sudden. Before presenting the sealed memorial, the true chariot is first expected to descend. Summon forth the gods within the body, reverently welcome the heavenly officials, and may the original vows be upheld, the mysterious compassion steered. Bowing in submission and offering sincerity, this servant now respectfully invokes.

**Invoking the Memorial Officials’ Ranks:**
Incense is offered, tea is presented, and the initial offering rites commence.

Again declaring their ritual rank:
This servant, [Name], humbly and with utmost sincerity, respectfully concludes the address to the Limitless Great Dao, the August High Perfected, the Sagely Hosts of the Sun, Moon, and Stars, the Three Officials and Four Sages, the Five Masters and Perfected Lords, the Divine Immortals of the Three Caverns’ Scriptures and Registers, and the Three Generals of the Origins.

May all gaze upon this true compassion and deign to grant their penetrating insight. The Numinous Treasure bestows its codes, broadly demonstrating the standards of fasts and cultivations. The true wind universally permeates, the mysterious transformation is abundantly spread. Through the true masters opening the gate of aid and deliverance, the sagely hosts above unfold boundless grace. The myriad regions look up in reliance, and for a thousand ages, all follow. How could a latecomer of the earthly realm presume to praise? It is truly the sagely masters of the upper realms who condescend to guide. Still, we pray for compassion and aid, and in the end, bestowance and support.

This servant reports on behalf of [Name], who has roused his will with diligence and submitted words with fervent urgency. Reverently gazing toward the Teaching Master of the Jade Capital, the Venerable Master of the Golden Gates, may the Merit Officers of the present day and hour be dispatched, and the memorial-transmitting officials be ordered to the altar to convey the supplications, ascending the memorial as prescribed. May the ritual codes be made manifest, that the response and retribution be made clear. Daring to extend this humble offering, this servant exhausts his foolish sincerity.
