**Incense-Offering Rites:**
This servant humbly and with redoubled sincerity addresses the Limitless Great Dao, the August Sagely Masters, the Three Perfected Lords Tang, Ge, and Zhou of the Three Origins, the Memorial-Transmitting Divine Officials of the Three Heavenly Gates, the True Officials who guide and advance, the Register-Keeping Officials above, the Flying Memorial Attendants within the Dharma, the *Qi*-Hastening Merit Officers, the Courier Station Magistrates and Assistants, the Four Divisions’ Inspectors of Merit and Petitioners, the Examiners of Deceit and Upholders of Rectitude, the various lords and officials, the Precious Memorial Presenters, the Three and Five Merit Officers, the Left and Right Attendant Envoys, the Five Emperors’ Direct Talismans, the Day and Hour Officers, the Direct-Day Incense Officials, the Year-Star Official Lord, the Ten Stems’ On-Duty Generals and Officials, the mountains and rivers, streams and valleys, seas and peaks, grotto-heavens, the divine officials and generals, the thousand chariots and ten thousand riders of the memorial, and all true numina.

Prostrate in reverence, we acknowledge that the boundless celestial heights above cannot be approached by mortal means. With utmost humility and devotion, only the divine may be reached. To exhaust the subtleties of meditative contemplation, we rely wholly upon the numinous efficacy of transmission and presentation. Today, so-and-so, in observance of ritual protocols, submits this memorial to initiate affairs, offering these written petitions, desiring that they penetrate the loftiest exalted realms. Without the celestial officials to convey them, how could these earthly words attain such profound penetration? Humbly we present these modest offerings, invoking the descent of the divine steeds, that they may witness this sincere devotion and bestow their sacred blessings. Aid the practitioner’s meditative visualization, guide them upon the cloud-path to ascension. Lead forward the Perfected Officials, escorting before and behind; the Register-Keeping Officials above shall review, examine, and transmit these supplications. May this earnest sincerity swiftly meet with manifest response. We dare conclude with three libations, thus completing the jiao rites.

*Reading the Memorial for the Spirit-Money and Horses:*
We address the Fivefold-Bodied Perfected Officials, the Eight Radiant Divine Clerks, the Golden Halls and Jade Chambers, and all exalted numina. Prostrate in reverence, we note that the Nine Palaces are arrayed at the head, venerating the Celestial Thearch of the Mud-Pill Palace. The Five Qi govern the center, harmonizing the hundred spirits within the body. To grasp the true mechanism, one must activate its wondrous function. Moreover, in the transmission of scriptures and conferral of registers, bonds are severed and tally-tokens divided—whenever there are prayers and entreaties, the Dharma rightfully brings salvation and relief. Today, we present this memorial, ascending to the Cinnabar Gate. The spirit of the upright qi of this body shall petition the exalted perfected ones of the Three Realms. From the mortal to the sacred, from earth to heaven. First, they traverse the Gāng winds, offering passage through the floating void; they regulate the qi through Horn and Neck, revolve to shield the form with Winnowing Basket and Dipper; they pay homage at the divine palaces of the Two Luminaries, cross the stellar bureaus of the Five Constants. Through the Desire Realm, the Form Realm, the Formless Realm, and the Seed People, they ascend to the heights of the Golden Gates, presenting their audience before the sacred ones of Jade Capital. The petition’s affairs concluded, they return once more to the body. In strict accordance with ritual statutes, we dispatch the generals and officials.

Kneeling in reverence, they dispatch the officials. With utmost care, they send forth from within this servant’s body the True Officials of the Five Bodily Vessels and the Merit Scribes; the Twelve Executors of Law and Transformers of Yin-Yang from the Upper Three Heavens; the Twelve Lords and Clerks who Dissolve Disasters, Dispel Calamities, and Resolve Adversities; the Great Generals who Establish Standards and Supervise Merit in the Central Realm; the Vanguard who Effect Merit and the Rear Guard who Effect Punishment; the Post Station Commanders and their Deputies; the Fourfold Supervisors of Merit and the Audience Heralds; the Flying Memorial Attendants within the Dharma; the Qi-Urging Scribes; the Three-Five Scribes; the Left and Right Envoys; the Direct Attendants of the Five Thearchs; the Jade Lads and Jade Maidens; and the Yin-Yang Divine Seal Clerks—all emerge.

Those who emerge don their solemn regalia and manifest vestments, their caps and sashes adorned with hanging tassels, their dignity and bearing impeccably arrayed. The Merit Scribes wear crimson yang headbands, crowns that reach to heaven, black silk unlined robes, and sashes bearing dragon-headed swords, holding the audience registers in their hands. The Envoys wear dark yin headbands, crowns of the Nine Virtues, vermilion unlined robes, and sashes bearing tiger tallies, carrying jade tablets in their charge.

The Direct Scribes stand at the four directions, the Three-Five Scribes stand at the center, the Healing Scribes patrol and guard this servant’s body, the Left Envoys plant their standards at the fore, the Right Envoys hold their banners at the rear, the Yang Divine Seal Clerks stand to the left, the Yin Divine Seal Clerks stand to the right, the Upper Scribes stand at the upper direction, the Middle Scribes stand within the body, the Qi-Urging Scribes hasten the qi of the ten directions, the Upper Envoys gaze afar toward the heavens, the Middle Envoys survey the eight directions, the General Envoys encircle this servant’s body, the Celestial Couriers and armored soldiers, the Wolf Clerks and Tiger Warriors, the Inspectors of Deceit and Cavalry Scouts, the General Commanders and Archers, the Celestial Ding Warriors, the Clerks who Rectify and Uphold, the Clerks who Gather and Nourish Spirits, the Clerks who Capture and Consume Ghosts, the Clerks who Absorb and Ingest Qi, the Clerks who Neutralize and Devour Poisons, the Clerks who Seize and Consume Essences, the Clerks who Execute Talismans and Destroy Shrines, the Gāng Wind Couriers, the Post Horse Memorial Clerks, the Flying Dragon Riders, and all other officials—all assemble and station themselves to this servant’s left and right, front and rear.

All receive this servant’s proclaimed words, distinguishing and transmitting them to the local earth gods of this place, the rectifying deities of the domain, the supervising and summoning inspectors, the Left and Right Lords of Universal Balance, the Twenty-Eight Treatments, the Thirty-Six Quiet Abodes, the Seventy-Two Blessed Lands, the Three Hundred Sixty Named Mountains, the Upper Palace of Kunlun, the Grotto-Heavens and Sea Peaks, the Two Mysteries upon the Dao, the Three Origins and Four Beginnings, the Twenty-Four Qi, the Twelve Hourly Spirits, the August Heaven and Venerable Earth, this year’s Grand Year Star and Great Yin, the various officials of the sixty celestial stems and earthly branches, the wind qi and infused qi, the village and hamlet altars, the four directions and eight quarters, the Nine Yi and Hu Elders of the East, the Eight Man and Yue Elders of the South, the Six Rong and Shi Elders of the West, the Five Di and Qiang Elders of the North, the Three Qin and Cang Elders of the Center, the Primordial Qi of the Mysterious Origin, the twenty-six thousand divine immortals, the river sources and stream valleys, the mountain forests and marsh elders, the Twelve Stream Perfected, the root origins and fundamental beginnings, the lords of this native land, and the numinous officials and generals of the altars and granaries.

With unified sincerity, they reverently address the Most High, the Formless and Nameless, the Void and Spontaneous, the Utmost True and Great Dao, the Most High Dao Lord, the Jade Sovereign of the Upper Clarity.

This servant, by virtue of karmic affinity, has been so fortunate as to receive the transmission of the teachings and the Dharma. On the day of the covenant, it was pledged to circulate and propagate them. I vowed to spread and exalt the true wind, to invigorate and proclaim the wondrous Dao, to eternally uphold the nation’s destiny, and to universally succor living beings. For all who submit in sincerity, it is fitting to transmit and memorialize their pleas.

Now, with utmost care, there is one who has submitted words and intentions, bearing the Dharma tokens and seeking to present a memorial. This servant prostrates upon the earth and bows to present the memorial text, which now rests upon the plain table. I humbly beseech the attending officials above to deign to examine and consider it, to transmit it upward in due time, and to request that the memorial be reviewed.

The memorial is raised aloft upon the imperial table, the dragon-headed writing knife stationed to the left.

To the right, the vermilion brush and fish-shaped inkstone stand guard. The duplicate of the memorial is proclaimed. According to old protocol, the memorial is first dispatched, then sealed. Yet if no official is sent ahead, the sealed memorial is never again opened for invocation—this is deemed improper. Now, sealing precedes dispatch. Should one wish to follow the old rites, the Daoist assembly may carry the memorial text, the memorial case, the face seal, silk thread, and paste to the High Priest’s table. The High Priest holds the memorial case, silently reciting the *Opening the Case Spell*; the case is not opened first, but the memorial is placed outside it. Formerly, wax filled the seal’s impression, and a wax seal was used—yet wax is impure. Now, only silk thread is tied, and paste is applied to the seal’s impression, stamping it without wax on the paper.

The scribe is summoned, the minor clerk of the case. Grasping the dragon-headed writing knife, he opens the case’s mechanism. The memorial ascends to the imperial presence, opening the path of communication. May what is petitioned swiftly reach its destination, and may this servant fulfill his duty from beginning to end.

Next, the memorial is passed over incense while silently reciting the *Fumigating the Memorial Spell*:
*"Smoke of five colors, ascend with the memorial to heaven.
Qi of five hues, carry the memorial to the Emperor.
Lesser officials’ stale qi must not recklessly interfere."*

The memorial is sealed: the Dharma Master personally places the memorial and petition into the case, a Daoist hands the thread, paste is applied to the seal’s impression, and the High Priest affixes the paper seal. Then, silently invoking the *Commanding the Memorial Spell*:
*"This servant’s brush, spirit-bright, commands the Upper Clarity.
Immortal youths and jade maidens, open the dragon case.
Let this servant’s petition swiftly reach the Celestial Court.
Hasten, hasten, as decreed by law and command."*

Again, silently reciting the *Dispatching the Memorial Spell*:
*"The solemnity of dispatching the memorial ensures timely transmission.
The secret seal is heart-transmitted; the numinous memorial is discreetly entrusted.
Vermilion smoke rises by night; cloud paths traverse the day.
I gaze upward in hope of profound grace, silently bestowing blessings and aid."*

The High Priest, having sealed the memorial, places it upon the tablet, kneels in reverence, and dispatches the official. He solemnly dispatches the Five Body True Officials within his person, one minor clerk, twelve scribes, thirty-five Merit Clerks, Left and Right Official Envoys, Urgent Qi Merit Clerks, Flying Memorial Attendants, Five Thearchs’ Direct Talismans, Flying Dragon Mounted Clerks, and other officials. Adorned in formal attire, caps with hanging tassels, swords at their sides, and talismans in hand, they are to promptly carry the memorial on behalf of this servant, ascending directly to the Three Heavens, reporting to their respective bureaus, and presenting the memorial in audience.

This servant, by karmic fortune, has presumptuously assumed a sacred office, yet fails to comprehend the true and orthodox, remains ignorant of qi’s signs, is of humble rank and coarse understanding, dull in perception and foolish in judgment. The memorial now presented may violate regulations, its script untidy, its phrases erroneous, its words omitted or misaligned, its language irreverent. I beseech the memorial’s attending clerks and minor scribes to timely correct and amend it, ensuring its proper presentation, lest the officials above reject it.

This servant, holding his breath, follows the memorial as it ascends to the Supreme, Formless, Nameless, Void, and Spontaneous Perfectly True Great Dao—Most High Dao Lord of the Upper Clarity Jade Thearch—humbly praying it not be delayed. May the officials at each checkpoint and the numinous officers within the memorial sequentially distinguish and act: granting what is requested, summoning what is called, healing what is afflicted, delivering what is saved, annihilating what is condemned, and advancing what is promoted. Should any lesser official’s stale qi intercept this servant’s memorial in the void, preventing its ascent, I hereby request it be recorded and handed to the appropriate celestial prison, punished according to celestial law, to uphold the celestial statutes. All memorial documents must assuredly reach the throne above.

This servant prostrates to the right of the imperial presence, reverently awaiting celestial favor and praying for a response.

The High Priest hands the memorial to the Daoist assembly, placing it upon the memorial table. The bell-keeper initiates the ritual; the supervisor of the fast accompanies the memorial, leading it to the burning site. The memorial is burned with fierce fire. The announcing official, within the altar’s precincts, recites the *Fumigation of the Memorial Hymn*. The High Priest escorts the memorial out, then prostrates, visualizing the process, performing the rites as prescribed.

At the four corners of the altar, incense burners are placed, and talismans are burned in the four directions. The High Priest rises from prostrating over the memorial and announces the *Hymn of Memorial Burning*, concluding the proclamation of the rites.

The minister, with utmost sincerity, reverently addresses and invokes the Boundless Great Dao, the Most High Perfected Masters, the Great Dharma Masters of the Mysterious Center, the Great Dharma Masters of the Three Heavens, the Orthodox Unity Pacifying Response Perfected Lords, the Perfected Lords of the Lingbao Scriptures and Registers’ Three Masters of Salvation, the Perfected Lords and Marshals of the Four Saints of the Northern Culmen, the Left Immortal Elder of the Supreme Ultimate and Impulse-Response Perfected Lord, the Grand Historians of the Nine Provinces’ Immortal Assembly, the Lofty and Illustrious Great Envoys, the Perfected Lords of Divine Merit and Wondrous Aid, the Sacred Ones of the Three Caverns’ Altar, the Eternal Patriarchs of the Transmitted Teachings, the Perfected Immortals of the Ten Directions who have attained the Dao, the Three Perfected Lords of Tang, Ge, and Zhou, the Memorial-Offering Divine Officials under the Three Heavens’ Gate, the Guiding Perfected Officials, the Merit-Recording Jade Maidens, the Attending Direct Talismans, the Cloud-Road Escorting Immortal Colleagues of the Void, the Fivefold Perfected Officials, and the Myriad Spirits within this minister’s body.

I have heard that preserving authenticity and contemplating the Dao may aspire to commune with the loftiness of the Brahma-qi. Yet in bowing to present this memorial and transcribing its text, I have not yet penetrated the subtleties of the teachings. Merely following the ancient rites to perform this task, I deeply know that this mortal frame is no immortal.

Having presumptuously drawn upon private grace, I dispatch the Twenty-Four Spirits to soar this memorial to the Purple Ultimate. Reverently relying on the nurturing embrace of the cosmos, I gather the Thirty-Five Divisions to unify qi and ascend to the Supreme Mystery. Yet my thoughts remain impure, my offerings crude in ritual—still, I dare to grasp at the cloud-borne regalia, humbly bathed in your condescending presence. How could I bear to lag behind your cloud-borne chariot? I can only pray that you might graciously pardon my reckless presumption and, in the end, bestow upon me the gift of life and completion.

All that I request, all that I beseech, may it be heard and answered. My gratitude runs deep; bowing my head, I know where my duty lies. Stretching my neck toward the celestial thoroughfare, I prostrate myself in reverent farewell.

*Ode to the Departing Sages:*
The High Master kneels in devotion, receiving the talismans.

This minister’s memorial now concluded, the Fivefold Perfected Officials within my body, the Merit-Recording Envoys, and all attendants withdraw through the Gates of Myriad Mysteries—those on the left return to the left, those on the right to the right, pervading heaven and earth. The Direct Envoys and Merit-Recording Officials, charged with oversight, return to their proper stations, securing the golden halls and jade chambers, ensuring no misstep or disorder. When summoned again, let all proceed as before.

*The Twelve Vows:*
The incense burner is sealed.

O Fragrant Envoys, Left and Right Dragon-Tiger Lords, and all Attending Spirit-Officials of the Incense—may this place where I present my memorial spontaneously generate golden elixir, cinnabar, and azure mushrooms. May the Hundred Spirits and Myriad Perfected gather here before this incense burner. May I, in studying the Dao, attain the Dao; in seeking immortality, attain immortality; may the officiating priests receive blessings; may the world be enveloped in grace; may the departed souls be delivered; and may the trapped and benighted ascend.

O Immortal Youths and Jade Maidens of the Ten Directions, attend the fragrant smoke and swiftly convey this minister’s memorial and supplications directly to the presence of the Most Perfect, Boundless, and Great Dao—the August Jade Emperor of the Luminous Heaven.

Exiting the chamber, descending the altar, the master concludes with words of gratitude.

Withdrawing into the oratory chamber, the memorial officials take their positions at the altar of offering.

Having duly received the master’s transmission of the memorial method, which is the Dao of the Cavernous Mystery and Numinous Treasure, and as memorials also derive from ancient ordinances akin to the Orthodox Unity tradition, the practices commonly employed in the world, along with the Numinous Treasure’s ranks, share great similarity with minor differences among their officials, clerks, soldiers, and generals. However, when it comes to flying spirits to petition the Thearch and the visualization practices employed, the Numinous Treasure and Orthodox Unity diverge entirely. Without transmission through celestial oaths, such methods may not be openly revealed. As with the Jade Purity’s ranks and the Cavernous Perfection’s division, memorial formats are not prescribed—this has been universally acknowledged throughout the ages.

In recent times, the Tiantai method has claimed that "heart memorials" of the Jade Purity rank should employ the *Tongzhang* seal. This assertion arises from seeing the *Tongzhang* seal recorded in the Divine Empyrean Registers and thus inventing this theory, unaware that the seal’s inscription is in fact the *Great Charter for Ascending to Heaven* of the Numinous Treasure. It further claims that the Cavernous Mystery division should employ the *Nine Numinous Flying Steps* memorial seal. Yet the *Nine Numinous Flying Steps* merely describe the actions performed during memorial presentation—such a practice is unattested in antiquity. For the Cavernous Spirit division, it prescribes the *Yellow Spirit Transcending Memorial* seal, which is also not exclusively tied to the Orthodox Unity tradition. Such errors stem from insufficient investigation.

Jiang’s *Established Rites* states that purification rites derive from the Numinous Treasure, while memorial presentation originates from the Orthodox Unity. Given its lineage’s transmission from the Orthodox Unity’s ancestral altars, and as the Heavenly Master follows the original ordinances for memorial presentation, it does not extensively reference the Numinous Treasure. Following the argument in *Established Rites*, one may omit the Numinous Treasure’s original ordinances yet still preserve the Orthodox Unity’s memorial format. This approach, though somewhat precarious, offers a measure of stability. However, failing to recognize that the Cavernous Perfection division lacks memorial formats and instead dividing the Three Caverns’ memorial presentations based on Tiantai methods risks deviating from the canonical teachings.

Some claim that the *Three-Five Flying Steps* constitute the Orthodox Unity’s memorial method, while the *Nine Numinous Flying Steps* belong to the Cavernous Mystery division’s practices, even going so far as to conflate the Divine Empyrean’s officials, clerks, soldiers, and generals with memorial presentation. Yet the Divine Empyrean’s teachings flourished only during the Xuanhe era of the Song dynasty. Before the Divine Empyrean’s emergence, the Numinous Treasure’s ordinances had long been transmitted in the world, never intermingling with the Divine Empyrean. Thus, in recent times, those who practice the Great Cavern by incorporating the Divine Empyrean while also practicing the Numinous Treasure, calling it *Jade Purity Numinous Treasure*, may seem comprehensive, but such a format is unattested in antiquity.

The Cavernous Mystery Numinous Treasure’s method for memorial presentation should be practiced during moments of leisure in daily life, cultivating qi and refining spirit to ascend into emptiness and enter subtlety. Internally, this is called *Ten Revolutions Returning the Numinous*; in memorial presentation, it is termed *Primal Net Flying Steps*. At the altar, one avoids cumbersome actions, manual gestures, or footwork. Instead, the Dao assembly is instructed to place four incense burners at the four corners of the memorial altar, each filled with abundant fragrant flames. As soon as the High Merit kneels in prostration, four talismans are burned in the incense burners at the four corners. Once the High Merit has dispatched the officials, the memorial is reverently held and presented to the Dao assembly, who convey it for burning. The High Merit then prostrates in submission to the memorial. This is what is meant by "still and unmoving, yet responsive and thus penetrating"—the effort must be cultivated in ordinary times. This approach differs greatly from the Orthodox Unity’s visualization of flying spirits.

Only by transmitting this lineage, receiving this dharma title, inscribing this memorial format, invoking these sacred ranks, employing this seal, and practicing this method from beginning to end, from exterior to interior, as a unified whole, can one achieve thorough resonance. If one merely appropriates a few practices to augment existing studies, or if the transmitter of the method feels ashamed to follow tradition, refusing to amend the seal’s script, memorial format, titles, or positions, yet falsely adopts the name of *Primal Net Flying Steps* to deceive the world, then the Dao’s constancy and its statutes cannot be violated.

*Great Cavern Numinous Treasure Great Law*, Scroll Twenty-Five Concludes
