**The Petition and Thanksgiving Section of the Six Memorials**
*Compiled by Jin Yunzhong, Right Assistant of the Initial Office of the Divine Youth, Enforcer of the Southern Bureau of the Cavern Mystery Numinous Treasure Dharma Masters*

Presenting memorials before the sovereign is proper ritual. From the Crown Prince and various princes to the chief ministers and high officials, the use of *jian* or *qi* petitions is likewise ritual—this is the way of the world. When the Daoist teachings were first established in antiquity, only memorials in *zhang* form existed. From the middle ancient period onward, imitating worldly conventions, documents such as proclamations, memorials, and petitions emerged. Since these draw from ancient canons and are governed by ritual classics, the six petitions should uniformly employ *jian* texts. The old format of using *biao* memorials before the master violates ritual propriety. Recently, some have used *shu* memorials, and upon examination, Han and Tang dynasty court officials all used *shu* when discussing matters—akin to the "palace memoranda" of the Song. Yet the *shu* presented before the master begins with a narrative, followed by parallel prose in four-six rhythm, which is not the ancient form of *shu*. Therefore, adhering to antiquity, one should follow the example of addressing the Crown Prince and various princes by using *jian*, which does not contravene ritual and strikes a proper balance.

According to the *Wen Xuan*, there are nine *jian* petitions from the Jin and Liang dynasties. Two of these are addressed to the Supreme Emperor, where the writer refers to himself as "your subject," beginning with "Your subject so-and-so respectfully states" and concluding with "Death penalty, death penalty." The remaining petitions to the imperial court’s chief ministers and various princes do not use "your subject," and their openings and closures are uniform, without any "middle thanks." As for the *jian* format in the Song dynasty’s official regulations, it resembles today’s *biao* memorials, only replacing "kowtow" with "knock head" and omitting "your subject." Following my master’s transmission, I use memorial documents only when submitting petitions before the Celestial Emperor; all other enumerated documents employ *jian*. Upon comprehensive examination of ancient and modern formats, I adopt the example of addressing the Crown Prince, using *jian* with "your subject." If one follows the old Jin and Liang style, it should be in unadorned prose. Alternatively, if conforming to current practice, parallel prose may be used. Either approach is acceptable, provided it adheres to classical norms and avoids impropriety. To treat master and disciple as equals in status is improper; the language should be concise and direct, avoiding irreverence. If one pursues ornate rhetoric, stringing together allusions like the memorials and petitions of secular courts, this violates Daoist canons and betrays the original intent of responding to heaven with sincerity.

What I, Yunzhong, have compiled here serves provisional use and is not presumed to be a fixed format. Those of great talent, broad learning, and mastery of ritual teachings may refine it with profound, elegant, and vigorous prose—this would be most fortunate.

**Six Formats for Petitions to the Six Altar Platforms**

**Petition to the Mystic Master**
Your subject [Name] respectfully states: On the [Day] of this month, for [Person] I am conducting the [Name] Retreat for [Purpose], and now humbly establish the altar platform.

I have heard that when the Dragon Han unfolded the celestial charts, it embraced the ancestral *qi* of the ten thousand heavens. When the Vermilion Brightness inaugurated its destiny, it arrayed the luminous canons of the Three Caverns. Having expanded the means of salvation, the forms of retreat observance were established. Following the master’s teachings, I reverently knock upon the gates of heaven.

Your subject, unworthy and insignificant, presumptuously oversees the ritual canons. Unfurling the altar and unfolding the rites, I exhaustively fulfill the retreat’s covenant. Listing the articles and transcribing the words, I lay forth my earnest sentiments. Moreover, upholding devout sincerity, I respectfully adhere to the protocol of court memorials. Were it not for relying upon the master’s compassion, how could I ascend to the imperial threshold?

With reverence, I consider...

The Venerable Celestial Master of the Mysterious Center, the Great Dharma Master, the Serene Elderly Heavenly Worthy—his Dao equals that of Heaven and Earth, his transformation parallels yin and yang. He refines and molds the ten thousand images yet does not claim merit for himself; he instructs and nurtures the Three Powers, and all beings receive his beneficence. Gazing down, he perceives the utmost sincerity of those who present retreat petitions, never deviating from the original intent of establishing the teachings. He guides the foolish and deluded, compassionately pitying those pressed by karmic deeds. May the memorial’s words ascend, safeguarding the retreat’s integrity from demonic interference. May this single-minded devotion rise to reach the hearing of the Ninefold Heaven.

With reverence, I present this memorial to make known my plea.

Your subject, [Name], knocks his head in awe, trembling with fear of deathly transgression, and respectfully speaks.

In the year [Year], the cyclical year being [Stem-Branch], on the [Day] day of the [Month] month, the duly ordained ritual officer, your subject [Surname and Name], presents this memorial.

I address the Five Emperors:

Your subject [Name] states: On the [Day] day of this [Month] month, on behalf of [Person’s Name], I have established the [Name] Retreat for the purpose of [Matter]. Having now prepared the altar with the preliminary rites, I declare:

I have heard that in the primordial chaos, the origin was endowed, and the Three *qi* coalesced to form the true. In the vast expanse, forms were fashioned, and the Five Directions were established as guardians. They oversee the records of merit and transgression, wielding the authority to reward and punish. Relying upon their sheltering grace, I dare to present my earnest plea.

Reflecting upon myself, I was born of impure dust and received a dull and foolish nature. Yet, by chance, I have relied upon past karmic conditions and obtained the shade of the profound. Having received the teachings of the Orthodox and True, I dare to propagate the canons of salvation. I solemnly prepare the altar and perform the morning rites, arranging the words of the memorial to present my plea. Were I not to implore the scrutiny of the celestial records, how could I achieve spiritual resonance?

With reverence, I consider the Central Yellow Emperor Heavenly Lord, the Northern Black Emperor Heavenly Lord, the Western White Emperor Heavenly Lord, the Southern Red Emperor Heavenly Lord, and the Eastern Bluegreen Emperor Heavenly Lord. From the wondrous kalpas of the beginning, they fused the divine and transformed the primordial. Assisting Heaven and Earth, they uphold the Pole Star; grasping the workings of creation, they govern the directions. Their grace permeates the ten thousand beings, their benefits extend to all classes of existence. May they embody the sincerity of my prayers and bring to fruition the merit of this retreat. May my earnest devotion ascend to the Nine Heavens, and may their benevolent influence widely moisten the Six Directions. May the hundred spirits fulfill their duties, and may the Ten Lands radiate their light.

With reverence, I present this memorial to make known my plea.

I, your humble servant [Name], kowtow in reverent fear, dreading the gravity of my transgressions, and respectfully submit this memorial.

In the year [Year], month [Month], and day [Day], I, [Name], a duly ordained Daoist officiant, present this memorial.

To the Three Officials,

I, your humble servant [Name], declare: On the [Day] of this month, I shall conduct the [Name] Retreat on behalf of [Person] for the purpose of [Matter]. Tonight, I humbly establish the altar and commence the rites.

I have heard that the utmost benevolence unfolds the teachings, bestowing the luminous statutes of salvation and deliverance. The Great Dao proclaims compassion, arraying the scriptures of retreat and cultivation. Thus, the blessings of humans and heavens are shared alike, and the hidden and manifest realms together know repose. I have recorded these humble circumstances and now present them before your profound scrutiny.

I reflect with awe upon my own foolish and impure nature, my humble and mediocre endowments. Though I have long been touched by good causes and molded by the transformative power of the True, I am ashamed by the paucity of my talents and the dimness of my understanding. To conduct the Dao and establish the retreat is to presume upon the foremost office; to deliver the living and ferry the dead, I fear, may scarcely reach the lofty heavens. Without relying on your completion and perfection, how could this endeavor be brought to fruition?

With utmost reverence, I invoke the Lower Prime Water Official Emperor Lord, the Middle Prime Earth Official Emperor Lord, and the Upper Prime Heaven Official Emperor Lord. You govern the revolutions of the ten thousand transformations and hold sway over the Three Spirits. All living beings are subject to your oversight, and every good deed is recorded in your registers. Now, at the very inception of this retreat and covenant, I dare to petition the offices of your examination and judgment. May my plea ascend to the Nine Heavens and be made known.

May the Three Realms pardon transgressions and forgive faults, that the retreat’s uprightness remain untainted by demonic forces, and the refining of souls and cultivation of spirits deliver those sunk in darkness. May the celestial retinue pause in its procession to look upon the merit of this retreat.

With reverence, I present this memorial to make known my plea.

Your humble servant [Name], kowtowing in awe and dread of mortal offense, respectfully states:

On the [Day] of this [Month], [Year], I, [Name], a duly appointed ritual officer, submit this memorial.

To the Heavenly Master:
Your servant [Name] declares: On the [Day] of this month, I shall establish a retreat on behalf of [Person] for the purpose of [Matter], beginning tonight with the opening of the altar.

I have heard that when the turning of the Dao aligns with the true season, it spreads numinous winds to nurture all things. When heaven unfolds its divine transformations, it magnifies the supreme Way to bequeath its texts. Illuminating the canonical rites, it perfects past and present. Thus, I humbly invoke your compassionate protection to inaugurate this pure precinct.

Reflecting on my long-standing karmic affinity with goodness, I have early been steeped in your gracious blessings. Yet ashamed that my merits remain unestablished, I recall that salvation and deliverance demand diligence. Moreover, moved by the earnest entreaties of the sponsor, I dare to present this petition.

In accordance with the standards of the canonical statutes, I shall exhaust my efforts in reverent observance. Truly, I rely on your guidance to hope for a response that pierces through.

With utmost reverence, I invoke the Great Dharma Master of the Three Heavens, the Rectifier of the Dao, the Pacifier of Primordial Qi, the Illustrious and Protective Perfected Lord. Born of the purest essence of the Dao and endowed with the most potent of numinous qi, your merit has saved the world in its myriad directions, and your office attends the imperial throne of the Three Realms. You refine and shape the unlearned, guiding and drawing forth those yet to come, ever expanding the reach of your teaching. May you deign to record the sincerity of this retreat.

I pray that my words ascend to the celestial palaces, that your decrees be issued to the terrestrial bureaus, that the officers and lords of the Three Caverns’ registers be dispatched, and that the generals and functionaries of the ten directions’ scriptural and disciplinary codes be commanded to receive the talismans and carry out the orders, opening the Dao and unsealing the passes. May the retreat’s uprightness be perfected, and may both the hidden and the manifest realms attain radiant peace.

With reverence, I present this memorial to make known my plea.

Your humble servant [Name], kowtowing in awe and dread of mortal offense, respectfully states:

On the [Day] of this [Month], [Year], I, [Name], a duly appointed ritual officer, submit this memorial.

To the Three Masters:
Your servant [Name] declares: On the [Day] of this month, I shall establish a retreat on behalf of [Person] for the purpose of [Matter], beginning tonight with the opening of the altar.

I have heard that when the turning of the Dao inaugurates the profound mystery, it arrays the myriad paths to spread transformation. When auspicious signs open the Three Caverns, they gather the host of subtle wonders to radiate their splendor. Illuminating the canonical rites, they expand the compass of the model. Presumptuously trusting in my foolish sincerity, I venture to appeal to the numinous offices.

Reflecting that in delivering the hidden and protecting the manifest, no merit precedes that of retreat blessings, and that the enumeration of merits and the listing of petitions fall under the jurisdiction of the Masters’ domain, I now, in accordance with steadfast devotion, consult the ancient canons. To hope for a response, I must rely on your compassionate consideration.

With utmost reverence, I invoke the Perfected Lord of the Registers of the Numinous Treasure, the Perfected Lord of the Scriptures of the Numinous Treasure, and the Perfected Lord of the Scriptures and Disciplines of the Numinous Treasure. From the inception of the teaching, you have bequeathed the codes for eternal kalpas. The transmission of the Dao’s registers and the multitude of texts on its methods and talismans have accumulated through your scriptures and registers. May you, in your profound and far-reaching benevolence, take pity on later learners.

I pray that you may specially dispatch the true chariot to pause at the imperial altar. May the retreat’s uprightness be brought to completion, and may the memorial’s words ascend to the throne.

With reverence, I present this memorial to make known my plea.

Your humble servant [Name], kowtowing in awe and dread of mortal offense, respectfully states:

On the [Day] of this [Month], [Year], I, [Name], a duly appointed ritual officer, submit this memorial.

To the Inspector of the Retreat:
Your servant [Name] declares: On the [Day] of this month, I shall establish a retreat on behalf of [Person] for the purpose of [Matter], beginning tonight with the opening of the altar.

I have heard that when the Dao unfolds its subtle codes, it establishes the standards for retreat observances. When the teaching spreads its true blessings, it divides the offices of canonical oversight. Affairs are entrusted to the offices of the mysterious, and sincerity is grounded in the humble petitions of mortals. I earnestly implore your profound scrutiny to record this retreat’s covenant.

Reflecting that I, a mere clod of dust bound in the web of illusion, have been granted a dull and obscure nature, fundamentally lacking in discernment, I have presumptuously stained the ranks of the mysterious. Yet, having received the wholehearted devotion of the retreat’s sponsor, I reverently strive to fulfill the ritual currents and present my petition. I pray for the joint deliverance of the manifest and the hidden, that distant and near may alike partake of your blessings. Without relying on your oversight, how could this endeavor be accomplished?

With utmost reverence, I invoke the Great Dharma Master and Perfected Lord, Inspector of the Numinous Treasure Retreat. Having refined the true through countless kalpas, you have magnified transformation across the myriad directions. Your grace universally permeates the paths of the lost, and your beneficence broadly encompasses later learners. May you briefly halt your celestial retinue, that a thousand spirits may guard the mysterious altar. May you slightly rouse the canonical rites, that the Three Qi fill the Dharma realm.

With reverence, I present this memorial to make known my plea.

Prostrate, I, your humble servant [Name], bow my head in trepidation, dreading the gravity of my transgressions, and respectfully submit this memorial.

In the year [Year], the month [Month], and the day [Day], I, [Name], a dharma-officiant of the ordained rank, present this memorial.

**Six Memorials of Gratitude for the Dispersal of the Six Canopies of the Altar**
**Memorial of Gratitude to the Mysterious Master**

I, your humble servant [Name], declare: On the [Day] of this month, I presided over the establishment of the [Name] Retreat for [Name of Patron], which has now been brought to perfect completion.

I have heard that Heaven covers the ten thousand beings, and even the dust-like ignorant rely upon its nurturing transformation. The teachings emerge from the Nine Purities, and both the hidden and the manifest alike receive deliverance through their unfolding. Thus, I, a latecomer to learning, have been enabled to complete the retreat’s observances. Daring to exhaust my mortal devotion, I offer this memorial to the lofty hearing of the Perfected.

Reflecting in awe, I recognize that in erecting the altar and performing the Dao, I must rely upon the canonical rites. In invoking the spirits and contemplating the Perfected, I have surely fallen short of the standard forms. My conduct is base and my understanding shallow; my actions and restraints are coarse and careless. My nature is dull and my knowledge dim; my words and compositions are profane and irreverent. Though the rites have now been completed, I am mindful of the many transgressions I have committed. Beating my breast in self-reproach, I search my heart and find it wanting.

With utmost reverence, I contemplate the Great Dharma Master, Master of the Mysterious Teachings: your merit transcends the Ten Poles, and your rank is arrayed among the Three Heavens. You regulate the principles of yin and yang, and your grace universally permeates the Six Directions. You sustain the workings of creation, and your teachings broadly extend across the ten thousand directions. Thus, even one as insignificant as a blade of grass or a speck of dust may presumptuously shelter beneath the protection of your august authority.

I humbly beseech you to bestow your great compassion and graciously extend your merciful regard. May you forgive my profound faults and expunge my name from the registers of the Five Emperors and the Four Offices. May you perceive the sincerity of my mortal devotion and deliver the souls in the Three Paths and Nine Hells. May your beneficence extend without end, and your grace reach all sentient beings.

With reverence, I present this memorial in gratitude, to make known my plea.

The humble servant [Name] knocks his head to the ground, trembling with fear of the deathly offense, and respectfully states:

In the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day], the duly ordained servant of the Daoist rites, [Name], presents this memorial.

**Memorial of Gratitude to the Five Emperors**

The servant [Name] declares: On the [Day] of this month, on behalf of [Name], I conducted the [Name] Ritual Fast, which has now been successfully completed.

I have heard that the primordial radiance of the Mystic Vastness stirs the numinous mechanism of transformation. As the boundless deliverance of humanity is its aim, so the salvation of the world has its scriptures. By the grace of the canonical records, I have been permitted to complete the rites of the Ritual Fast. Daring to exhaust my humble sincerity, I offer this to continue the numinous majesty.

Reflecting upon myself, I am of base constitution, endowed with meager and foolish faculties. My dull self has presumptuously assumed the talismans and registers, yet my learning has not attained mastery of the canonical texts. Though I have pledged my heart in solemn vows, the urgency of my devotion could not be restrained. Through the recitation of words and the display of reverence, the ritual assembly was brought to its conclusion. I am ashamed that no merit can be recorded, and only transgressions accumulate to be feared. Without beseeching compassionate aid, I cannot hope for pardon.

With reverence, I contemplate:
The **August Sovereign of the Central Yellow Emperor**,
The **August Sovereign of the Northern Black Emperor**,
The **August Sovereign of the Western White Emperor**,
The **August Sovereign of the Southern Red Emperor**,
The **August Sovereign of the Eastern Bluegreen Emperor**.

Each shares in the true division of the Dao and follows the celestial inception of purity. They examine the promotion and demotion of the ten thousand spirits and govern the circulation of the five qi. All mortal dust is embraced within their compassionate embrace, and both the hidden and manifest depend upon their nurturing care.

I humbly pray that the meager blessings of this Ritual Fast may be inscribed, and that the profound offenses of transgression may be graciously pardoned. May the suffering souls ascend and their spirits be transformed, bringing clarity and peace to the Six Heavens. May all living beings fulfill their nature and the ten thousand kinds attain tranquility and peace.

With reverence, I present this memorial in gratitude, to make known my plea.

Your Majesty,

I, [Name], prostrate myself in awe and dread, acknowledging my mortal offenses, and respectfully submit this memorial.

On the [Day] of this [Month] in the year [Year], I, [Name], a duly appointed ritual officer, present this memorial in gratitude to the Three Officials.

I, [Name], declare that on the [Day] of this month, I conducted the [Name] Ritual Fast on behalf of [Name], which has now been successfully completed.

I have heard that the jade altar’s solemn rites have already received the grace of divine regard, and the sacred tablets have returned, bearing the fullness of our prayers. Offering the prescribed texts and presenting our pleas, I humbly beseech that your sacred attention be bestowed anew.

Reflecting upon myself, I am but a humble vessel of this degenerate age, a student of dust-laden toil. My thoughts lack coherence, leaving me ignorant of the steps toward cultivation. My countless transgressions remain unexpiated—how could I presume to master the canons of ritual fasting? Merely following the forms to perform the rites, I fear my errors may violate the proper standards. Knowing well that punishment is inescapable, I dare yet lay bare my sincerity and confess my faults.

With reverence, I invoke the **Lower Prime Water Official Emperor**, the **Middle Prime Earth Official Emperor**, and the **Upper Prime Heaven Official Emperor**, who govern the Nine Treasuries and oversee the Three Primes. All spirits and mortals are subject to their judgment, and both the hidden and manifest depend upon their molding power. Moved by this foolish ignorance, they grant forbearance, pardoning the grave offenses of ritual failure and forgiving the many faults of those who fasted together. May their mercy extend throughout the Three Realms, inscribing the merits of this Ritual Fast. May their blessings spread across the Ten Directions, universally elevating the lingering souls.

With reverence, I present this memorial in gratitude, to make known my plea.

Your Majesty,

I, [Name], prostrate myself in awe and dread, acknowledging the gravity of my transgressions, and humbly submit this memorial.

On the [Day] of this [Month] in the year [Year], I, [Name], a duly ordained Ritual Master, present this memorial in gratitude to the Heavenly Master.

I, [Name], declare: On the [Day] of this month, I conducted the [Name] Ritual Fast on behalf of [Name], which has now been successfully completed.

I have heard that the primordial net unfolds its mysteries, establishing the statutes for delivering the hidden and guiding the world. The true teachings bequeath their scriptures, enumerating the ranks of ritual fasts for the cultivation of affairs. Thus, even the unlearned may fulfill their virtuous endeavors.

Reflecting upon myself, I recognize that my being has not yet penetrated the true, nor is my talent sufficient to fathom the principles of things. In reciting scriptures and practicing the Dao, I merely adhere to the established norms. Yet in transgressing prohibitions and failing in ritual propriety, I have truly fallen short of the perfected canon.

It is only by the forbearance of the Venerable Master that the guilt of my humble and coarse nature may be pardoned.

With reverence, I invoke the **Great Law Master of the Three Heavens, Who Upholds the Dao and Assists the Primordial, Orthodox Unity, Serene Response, Manifest Protection, Perfected Lord**—born of celestial vision, refined upon the cloud terrace. Moved by the jade bureau’s repeated descents, he transmitted the thousand-scroll treasury of the jade caskets. May he take pity on this humble talent and further expand his vast vows. May he support both the hidden and manifest, bending to record merits. By bestowing grace and pardoning transgressions, may he prevent this ritual fast from becoming a source of fault.

May all sentient beings together realize the unconditioned.

With reverence, I present this memorial in gratitude, to make known my plea.

I, [Name], prostrate myself in awe and dread, acknowledging the gravity of my transgressions, and humbly submit this memorial.

On the [Day] of this [Month] in the year [Year], I, [Name], a duly ordained Ritual Master, present this memorial in gratitude to the Three Masters.

I, [Name], declare: On the [Day] of this month, I conducted the [Name] Ritual Fast on behalf of [Name], which has now been successfully completed.

I have heard that the wondrous root is wordless, yet adapts its teachings to the capacities of beings. The primordial pivot establishes its models, responding to the world with the proclamation of compassion. Through the vastness of its canonical principles, it enables the accomplishment of ritual fasts.

Unworthy as I am, I dare to offer my sincere prayers once more.

Reflecting upon myself, I, though base and insignificant, have presumptuously received the mandate of transformation and nurturance. Gazing upon my own foolish and mediocre nature, I have overstepped my place in the office of deliverance. Erecting the altar, burning incense, and reciting scriptures, I have presented memorials to deliver the hidden and manifest. Fortunately, the ritual proceedings have been completed, yet I am ashamed that from beginning to end, I have violated the statutes.

Without the grace of the Masters, how could I escape the unseen retribution?

With reverence, I invoke the **Perfected Lord of the Numinous Treasure, Master of Salvation**; the **Perfected Lord of the Numinous Treasure, Master of the Registers**; and the **Perfected Lord of the Numinous Treasure, Master of the Scriptures**. They uphold the celestial canon and propagate the Dao, transmitting the true. Their pure transformation is inexhaustible, and their divine blessings are boundless. May they bend to pity this unworthy student, expunging the records of sin and pardoning transgressions. May they deign to record the sincerity of this fast, inscribing its merits and manifesting its beneficent influence. May the Ten Directions share in the rejoicing, and may the Nine Nights receive their blessings.

With reverence, I present this memorial in gratitude, to make known my plea.

Your Majesty, I, [Name], kowtow in trepidation, dreading the gravity of my transgressions, and respectfully submit this memorial.

In the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day], I, [Name], a duly ordained ritual officer, present this memorial in gratitude for the oversight of the fast.

I, [Name], declare: On the [Day] of this month, on behalf of [Name], I conducted the [Name] Fast, which has now been successfully completed.

I have heard that establishing rites and unfolding affairs must adhere to the regulations of fasting rectitude. Following the teachings and performing the rituals truly depend on the grace of divine observation. Daring to persist in my foolish sincerity, I venture to offer this devotion to the numinous compassion. Reflecting humbly, I recognize my lifelong lack of talent, yet have been fortunate to receive the shelter of the mysterious. Unversed in the canonical protocols, I have presumptuously occupied a rank in the ministry of salvation. My mindfulness has not been true, and I have wrongly held the office of register and transmission. Though I have striven to complete the rites, I am alarmed by the depth of my transgressions and deviations. Relying entirely on your merciful forbearance, I hasten to express my repentance and gratitude.

With reverence, I invoke the **Perfected Lord, Grand Dharma Master of the Numinous Treasure, Overseer of the Fast**, who presides over the standards of ritual and the records of the teachings. Having already received the accomplishment of meritorious deeds, I still pray for the remission of severe punishments. May the memorial ascend to the Nine Poles, and the petitions be conveyed to all bureaus. May the blessings of the fast be boundless, and the true felicity universally bestowed. May all the assembled ritual participants have their records of transgressions expunged, and may all beings under heaven partake in the joy of life.

With reverence, I present this memorial in gratitude, to make known my plea.

Prostrate and trembling, I, your humble servant [Name], bow my head in fear of capital offense and respectfully submit this memorial.

In the year [Year], the [Month] day, I, [Name], a dharma-officiant of the ordained rank, present this memorial.

Having duly followed and examined Du Guangcheng’s *Ritual Regulations for the Fast*, I have arranged the sequence of the Six Canopies. After weighing ancient and modern canonical rites, I have therefore employed this memorial format.

Now, the Five Emperors of recent times are often conflated with the Five Venerable Lords of the Supreme, and their positions are thus assigned to such figures as the Azure Numinous First Elder Heavenly Lord of the East. Yet the Five Qi abide in the midst of Heaven as the Five Venerable Lords of the Supreme; in celestial patterns, they are the Five Planets; on earth, the Five Marchmounts; in affairs, the Five Constants; in things, the Five Phases; among spirits, the Five Emperors—such as the Azure Emperor of the East, the Majestic Numinous One, and the like; and in humans, the Five Viscera. Truly, the Five Qi are present in all things without exception.

However, the Five Venerable Lords of the Supreme are the root and origin of the Five Qi, the Supreme Lords in the midst of Heaven. If the scrutiny of mortals’ merits and transgressions and the recording of worldly blessings and misfortunes were to be their concern, it would be unfitting for the Heavenly Emperors to descend to such tasks. Thus, when the Master of the Mysterious Center oversees the teachings’ standards, it is the Three Officials and Five Emperors who examine merits and transgressions—these Five Emperors are in fact but functionaries of the Three Realms.

As for the Azure Emperor of the East, Majestic Numinous One; the Vermilion Emperor of the South, Blazing Fury; the White Emperor of the West, White Summoner of Measures; the Black Emperor of the North, Exhaling Radiance and Discipline; and the Yellow Emperor of the Center, Containing the Pivotal Axis—these are glossed in older scriptures as the Five Venerable Lords, though this identification is already questionable. Moreover, the attribution of the Azure Emperor to spring, the Vermilion Emperor to summer, and so forth, refers to the Five Directional Emperors, who should be ranked alongside the Three Officials as examiners.

Beyond these, the positions of the Five Emperors are not limited to these alone. Weighing the matter carefully, the altar for the fast should only employ the Azure Emperor of the East, the Vermilion Emperor of the South, the White Emperor of the West, the Black Emperor of the North, and the Yellow Emperor of the Center, for this is the most universally applicable arrangement. There is no need to fix the Five Venerable Lords of the Supreme as the definitive model.

Furthermore, earlier scholars have debated the Five Emperors without reaching a settled interpretation. Since the oversight of covenant fasts is the duty of the Three Realms’ functionaries, their positions lie below the Master of the Mysterious Center and are ranked alongside the Three Officials—this makes it all the more improper to definitively equate them with the Five Venerable Lords of the Supreme. Those well-versed in the scriptures and teachings should examine this further. This matter is also addressed in the sequence of ranks for the Offering and Thanksgiving Rites to the Sage.

Here ends the twenty-sixth scroll of the *Great Rites of the Highest Clarity Numinous Treasure*.
Beginning the twenty-seventh scroll of the *Great Rites of the Highest Clarity Numinous Treasure*.

The Master of Rituals of the Southern Bureau of the Cavernous Mystery Numinous Treasure, Compiler Jin Yunzhong of the Right Wing Office of the Initial Repository of the Authority of Youth, presents the section on *Memorials, Petitions, and Edicts*:

The gateways to immortality are manifold, yet establishing merit to succor the world stands foremost. Thus, those who practice the registers and observances of the Dao must exert themselves in the teachings and precepts. Since they have yet to attain communion with the perfected and penetration of the numinous, whenever petitions are made, they must rely upon written memorials and edicts. These must be reasoned in their wording and flawless in their adherence to canonical forms. Just as memorials to the imperial court follow fixed formats, how much more should reverence be shown to the August Heavenly Thearch, the Boundless and Most Honored? To act recklessly or profane the sacred would be unthinkable. Those who preside over fasts and offerings bear the duty of proclaiming and conveying sincerity, aiding and delivering both the hidden and the manifest. Though they must be versed in the teachings and precepts, they must also possess some mastery of literary expression. Moreover, in the Great Yellow Register Fast, revered by both humans and heavens, everything depends upon the high priest’s conception and phrasing. They must not blindly follow vulgar sentiments, carelessly preparing memorials that obstruct reason and make resonance impossible. Within the precepts and methods, matters must first be reported through memorials and petitions, hence these are provided here in accordance with ritual use and may not be omitted.

**Memorial Format**
[Official Title] Your subject [Name], with awe and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to memorialize:

Your subject, having considered the matter, respectfully records the petition and memorializes [Name of August Thearch] the Jade Sovereign of [Realm].

Your subject humbly beseeches the Heavenly Compassion to grant this petition and specially bestow its implementation.

Your subject, having presumptuously offended the Heavenly Majesty, is filled with terror and dread, awaiting punishment. Respectfully memorialized.

In the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day], [Official Title] Your subject [Name] memorializes.

This memorial format is seldom used among common people, and in the Zhe region, its form is particularly unknown. Master Yunzhong transmitted this lineage, which has been practiced for a long time, yet it is employed only for the Three Clarities Thearchs and the August Thearch of the Northern Culmen of Primordial Heaven. The Three Clarities Heavenly Worthies are the Three Qi of the Mysterious, the Primordial, and the Origin—root and source of the myriad transformations, ancestors of the Three Realms. They give birth to Heaven and Earth, initiate yin and yang, formless and nameless, unfathomable and unknowable, styled as Heavenly Worthies, a designation given by necessity. As for the August Thearch of Vast Heaven, He governs the myriad heavens, commands the ten thousand spirits, and corresponds above to the Mysterious Qi. The Great Thearch of the Northern Culmen records the myriad stars, serving as the pivot of Heaven, corresponding above to the Primordial Qi. The Heavenly Thearch appears in the celestial patterns beneath the Curved Array, ranked below the Purple Tenuity Enclosure, corresponding above to the Origin Qi. Beyond the Three Realms and within the Six Ultimates, none are more exalted. Thus, this memorial format, resembling the opening text of a memorial, is not to be treated with the casual familiarity of worldly etiquette. Therefore, the requests made therein are not to be verbose; one merely petitions for the bestowal and implementation of the matter.

When making offerings, before the Thearch, one may simply state: "It is desired that the Heavenly Grace deign to take note." This suffices.

The *tie-huang* (attached yellow slip) is placed to the right of the official title, with its lines aligned in spacing to match those of the memorial. It is affixed level with the "上言" ("memorializes") line, using an odd number of characters. At the end of the memorial, the *yi-huang* (supporting yellow slip) states: "Petitioning the relevant True Bureau to bestow and implement." It is affixed to the right of the date, extending upward to the *tie-huang*, and sealed with an impression, following the format of worldly memorials.

**Inner Envelope**
To the Jade Sovereign of [Name] Thearch,
Respectfully sealed by [Official Title] Your subject [Name].

**Outer Envelope**
Memorial Petition Respectfully Submitted to
[Official Title] Your subject [Name] respectfully seals.

To the Heavenly Pivot Bureau under the Three Heavens.

The outer envelope may also read: "Memorial Petition Respectfully Submitted to the Heavenly Pivot Bureau under the Three Heavens for presentation." Alternatively, a separate petition may be submitted to the Heavenly Pivot Bureau, called an *Introduction Petition*. If sending a single document, it is enclosed within the memorial envelope; if multiple documents are sent, the petitions are listed separately and enclosed in another envelope for submission to the Heavenly Pivot Bureau. This is analogous to worldly memorials being separately submitted to the Chancellery.

**Petition to the Heavenly Pivot Bureau**
[Official Title] Your subject [Name] respectfully states:

Regarding [Matter], the petition is hereby recorded and memorialized to the Heavenly Court. It is necessary to report as follows:

Respectfully submitted to the High Perfected who govern the Three Heavens under the Heavenly Pivot Bureau. May the True Compassion of the common hope deign to facilitate its presentation and implementation.

Your subject, having presumptuously offended the True Majesty, is filled with terror and dread. Respectfully submitted.

In the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day], [Official Title] Your subject [Name] submits.

Upon examining the canonical teachings, Master Yunzhong found that while some aspects of the High Heavenly Governance may be known, others remain unfathomable. Without thorough penetration of the Jade Clarity and direct audience before the Golden Gate, one must not presume to conjecture or fabricate names and ranks. Thus, in the celestial bureaus and ministries, one refers only to "the High Perfected who govern," avoiding transgression of prohibitions. The orthodox canons do not specify these, and the transmitted texts of incantations circulating in the world cannot be relied upon.

Among the celestial ranks, the Heavenly Worthies, Heavenly Thearchs, Dao Lords, Primordial Ladies, and Heavenly Lords—such as the Heavenly Worthy and Heavenly Thearch—are proper canonical titles. For instance, the Dao Lord of the Luminous August of the Upper Palace of Purple Tenuity is one such title. The Primordial Ladies, such as the Primordial Lady Ancestress of the Myriad Qi, are of the same rank as the Heavenly Thearchs. All these may use the memorial format, following the style of worldly memorials.

In recent times, transmitted ritual texts have arbitrarily established names and ranks for the Highest Perfected, which cannot be enumerated here and are not to be followed. For example, addressing the Celestial Master as "Heavenly Lord" or calling the Jade Maidens of Soul-Summoning "Primordial Ladies" creates even greater disorder in the canonical system. One must not be misled into error. Beware, beware.

**Memorial Format**
[Official Title] Your subject [Name] respectfully states:

Your subject, having considered the matter, respectfully records the petition and memorializes [Name of August Thearch] the Sovereign.

It is desired that the Heavenly Compassion grant this petition and specially bestow [specific action].

Your subject, having presumptuously offended the Heavenly Majesty, is filled with terror and dread, trembling in utmost reverence. Respectfully submitted.

In the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day], [Official Title] Your subject [Name] memorializes.

The previously affixed yellow slips, along with secular legal documents, shall be submitted to the respective palaces and courts as designated. If not recorded in the orthodox canon, no palace or court names may be fabricated. Some seek to distinguish themselves from others, deceiving the common folk, yet they fail to realize they profane the celestial symbols and invite divine punishment upon themselves. Fools who imitate them lead later learners further astray. Strict adherence to antiquity is thus imperative.

In secular memorials, the format typically begins with the official’s title and name, followed by the matter at hand, and concludes with the right-aligned submission. Daoist practitioners have recently adopted this, fully conforming to the secular style.

**Secular Memorial Format**
[Official Title] Your subject [Name] respectfully states:

In accordance with the prescribed form or the petition’s intent, this matter requires submission for Your August Majesty’s consideration.

Having recorded the above, it is desired that the True Compassion grant this petition and specially bestow [specific action]. Respectfully submitted for Your Majesty’s decree, awaiting the imperial edict.

In the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day], [Official Title] Your subject [Name] respectfully memorializes.

**Alternative Secular Format**
[Official Title] Your subject [Name] respectfully states:

Having recorded the petition’s intent, this matter is respectfully submitted for Your Majesty’s consideration. Respectfully submitted.

In the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day], [Official Title] Your subject [Name] respectfully submits.

The yellow slips before and after shall follow the standard format. However, in secular formats, only Daoist memorials vary in the titles of the August Thearchs, making it difficult to ascertain proper transmission. In recent times, these two formats have been widely used, with the addition of sacred titles, differing only slightly from secular conventions. The memorial style described herein is employed solely by the Yundun lineage. Those who follow secular customs often adopt this format for practical purposes.

The celestial ranks—palaces of the sun, courts of the moon, the Five Stars and Four Luminaries, the Northern Dipper and Three Officials, the Four Saints and Five Masters, the High Celestial Assistants, the Noble Ministers of the Jade Emperor, the Heavenly Bureaus’ directors, and the various offices of the upper realms—all employ petitions (*shenzhuang*).

It is said that the rituals of fasts and offerings, the protocols of proclamations, and the documents of memorials and announcements bear no trivial consequences. Yet in recent practice, memorials (*zoudu*) are used even for the Seven Primes, Five Masters, and the celestial ranks of the upper realms. Even the Supreme Mystery Capital Bureau has adopted memorials. This blind imitation of secular court titles, arbitrarily assigning exalted ranks to the perfected, is a grave profanation.

Take, for instance, the Master of the Mysterious Center (*Xuanzhong Fashi*). Though revered as the founder of ritual teachings, he remains a subject before Heaven. Some claim he is Lord Lao’s incarnate manifestation, yet no orthodox canon records this. Even if he were indeed Lord Lao’s transformed emanation, he could not be honored as an emperor. For the Primordial Qi resides in the Great Clarity, where he is the Heavenly Venerable. If he assumes a form to propagate teachings, he is called the Master of the Mysterious Center—a subject of the Three Realms.

Lord Lao, who established the Dao before Heaven and delivered beings across kalpas, cannot be fully recounted. In the Zhou dynasty, he served as the Archivist Under the Pillars, concealing his name and assuming a mortal guise to save humanity, disregarding rank. At that time, he was but a subject of the Zhou court. Yet when his purple qi crossed the pass, his blue ox returned to the celestial gates, and he consolidated his true form in the highest heavens, assuming his rightful place in the Great Clarity, he was then called the Heavenly Emperor or Supreme Thearch. Thus, when he manifested to serve the Zhou court, he did not deem it lowly; when his qi returned to the celestial heights to rule the upper realms, he did not consider it exalted. His being resides between wondrous existence and wondrous non-existence, and he may be named according to his manifestations.

As the Heavenly Venerable of the Dao and Virtue, he is the sovereign of Heaven and thus warrants memorials (*zhangzou*). As the Great Master of the Mysterious Center, he is a subject of Heaven and thus warrants petitions (*shenzhuang*). To directly equate the Master of the Mysterious Center with Lord Lao is incorrect. Some further err by calling him the Heavenly Venerable of Serene Old Age (*Jinglao Tianzun*), which is even more absurd.

The Three Treasures of Dao, scriptures, and masters: the Dao cannot be named, so teachings are established through scriptures. Once teachings are set, they are transmitted only by masters. Within the fast altars, the fundamental lineage must be revered. Thus, from the Dao come the scriptures, and from the scriptures come the masters. It is not that their rank among the Three Treasures elevates them to the status of the Supreme Thearch.

The old *Luotian* Offering Rites, later revised during the Song dynasty, were compiled by the Daoist Registry after consulting canonical standards. Even then, the Five Masters’ positions were placed below the Three Officials, Four Saints, and the assembled perfected. The Orthodox Unity Heavenly Master must not be misrepresented.

According to records, the Heavenly Master was born during the reign of Emperor Guangwu of the Eastern Han at Mount Tianmu in Wu. Later, a Temple of the Divine Immortals was established there. In the second year of *Yongshou* of the Han, he ascended to the heavens in Shu. The Supreme Lord dispatched envoys of the Five Emperors to confer upon him the title of Orthodox Unity Perfected, facing the Ninefold Clarity and serving as a subject of the Three Realms. This is clearly documented in his biographies and scriptures.

In the rituals of fasts and offerings, the master is the fundamental lineage, and establishing a separate tent for him is proper etiquette. In documents, petitions (*shendu*) should be used, deferring to the Heavenly Emperor. How can one submit memorials before both sovereign and subject alike? Can the Heavenly Master and the Jade Emperor be equated? On the day of the Heavenly Master’s ascension, his rank was merely that of a Perfected. Only during the Song dynasty was he posthumously honored as the Serene and Responsive Perfected Lord of Orthodox Unity, which already elevated his celestial rank. Some further address him as the Heavenly Lord (*Tianjun*), equating him with the Heavenly Emperor.

The Heavenly Lords of the Three Qi—Celestial Treasure of Pure Tenuity, Numinous Treasure of Jade Clarity, and Divine Treasure of Great Red—are the Three Qi Heavenly Lords. The Azure Spirit Elder of the East, along with those of the West, South, North, and Center, are the Five Directions’ Heavenly Lords. Can the Heavenly Master share this rank?

The Heavenly Master transmitted and mastered the scriptures, delving deeply into the Nine Schools and Hundred Philosophies. His merits accomplished and conduct illustrious, he was summoned to ascend to Heaven. His adherence to ritual propriety and rank was most precise. Yet now, witnessing the flattery and obsequiousness of foolish men, who address him as Heavenly Lord in their memorials—how can the celestial ranks not be enraged?

Yet I fear such memorials may never reach the celestial realms. That the ignorant dare act thus is truly alarming. The names and ranks of the highest Perfected are not for the world to presume to detail. To follow the ancient canons in their use is proper; but to indulge in excessive titles—calling a Perfected One a True Lord, a True Lord a Heavenly Lord, or a messenger a mere "envoy"—is to brazenly violate the celestial prohibitions.

In the upper realms, the most revered among male Perfected are called Dao Lords, and the most revered among female Perfected are called Yuan Ladies, akin to the various Heavenly Worthies. Yet in this age, men know only how to fabricate extravagant titles, even to the point of addressing female lords with the honorifics due a Dao Lord. Moreover, for ranks unattested in the scriptures, they claim on their own authority that so-and-so is the Perfected Overseer of such-and-such an abbey, that so-and-so presides over such-and-such a ministry, or that so-and-so governs the Celestial Bureau—whatever their whim desires, they arbitrarily promote the celestial offices and the sagely ranks, then boast of their own exceptional usage. Alas, the world may be deceived, but can Heaven be deceived?

The celestial bureaucracy’s divisions and appointments are far stricter than those of the mortal realm. Hence the saying among divine immortals: "The upper realms are replete with offices and courts." Not even the slightest transgression is permissible, yet mediocre men dare to recklessly profane and desecrate. I have personally witnessed those who engage in such practices, and they are not without karmic retribution—yet those who remain heedless are still many.

Now, when addressing the celestial ranks in memorials, one uses the term "your servant." Some argue that if one uses "your servant," one should employ the formal "memorial," and if one uses "memorial," one should not use "your servant." In my humble opinion, during the Three Dynasties, vassals addressing the lords of other states all used "your servant," and even when addressing the Son of Heaven, they used "your servant." Later ages abolished the feudal system in favor of commanderies and counties, and the realm became one family, so the rites of vassals were no longer seen. The formats for memorials and petitions in the mortal realm, prior to the Qin and Han, lack clear textual evidence. Yet when vassals submitted documents to their own lords, they surely did not dare equate their rites with those due the Son of Heaven.

Moreover, the distinction between ruler and subject is one of the great constants of Heaven and Earth. Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, King Wen, King Wu, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius established teachings to instruct all under Heaven and posterity. The distinction between ruler and subject, the bond between father and son, and the righteousness between husband and wife were all established in accordance with Heaven. As for the celestial patterns: the sun, moon, and stars, resplendent and visible, were already ordained at the dawn of creation, before the emergence of the sages. The distinction between ruler and subject was eternally fixed in Heaven.

The Northern Culmen resides at the center of the sky, opposite the Southern Culmen, serving as the pivot of Heaven. The sun, moon, and myriad stars revolve with the sky, while the two Culmens remain unmoving, enabling Heaven’s rotation. The Northern Culmen, situated within the Purple Tenuity Enclosure, is perpetually visible. The *Astronomical Treatise* of the Jin states: "The five stars of the Northern Culmen lie within the Purple Tenuity Enclosure. The Northern Culmen is the most revered of the Northern Asterism." Within the Curved Array, the star at its mouth is called the Heavenly August Emperor, residing beneath the Curved Array. According to my observation: the Heavenly August Emperor’s rank is equal to the Northern Culmen, making it the celestial sovereign. Above it are the Canopy and the Curved Array treading upon it; to its left and right are the Upper Minister and Upper Guards encircling it. The Dipper’s... (text missing) resides before it, serving as the office of the tongue and throat. It regulates the four seasons, measures the primordial qi, issues the Emperor’s decrees, and governs the Three Realms. Beyond it, the Celestial Market Enclosure, Supreme Subtlety Enclosure, and Purple Tenuity Enclosure each have their own imperial thrones, which are merely branch offices of the Purple Tenuity Enclosure.

The myriad phenomena of the celestial sphere—sun, moon, and stars—are all governed by the Northern Culmen. The Northern Asterism stands as the celestial image, and the host of stars pay it homage; this is the pattern. The sages observed the celestial patterns to examine the profound measures, and they also followed what was eternally fixed to establish their system. Was it not that before the sages emerged, Heaven already had its ruler and subjects?

Moreover, even the imperial thrones of the Celestial Market and Supreme Subtlety Enclosures cannot rival the Northern Culmen. How much less can the two dim stars within the Dipper’s bowl—the imperial throne within the Dipper—compare? In recent times, ignorant men, relying on books like the *Comprehensive Diagram*, the *Wuwei Scripture*, and the *Register of the Northern Dipper*, have altered their names entirely. They have fabricated the *Method of the Celestial Mechanism*, directly venerating the Seven Primes of the Dipper and the two stars of the Dipper’s imperial throne as equals to the Heavenly Emperor. In their documents and memorials, they follow the same protocol as for the Jade Emperor. Such impropriety is beyond words.

The ancient liturgies indeed included Dipper Offerings. The term "offering" is the Daoist general term for collective sacrifices; it does not mean that because there is an offering ritual, one may arbitrarily exalt the recipient as the Supreme Emperor. Since the ritual pertains to the Dipper Palace, it collectively venerates all the Perfected within the Dipper, focusing the offering to express prayers. How can one, merely because there is a specialized offering ritual, elevate the stellar Perfected of the Dipper to the rank of Heavenly Emperor?

Some texts refer to the Dipper stars as the "Celestial Grand Commandant" or the "Celestial Supreme Emperor," but this is in terms of their governance. For example, Mount Tai’s title "Heavenly Equal" signifies that its merits and virtues can equal Heaven, not that the god of Mount Tai is the Jade Emperor. The ancient liturgies included forty-two offerings, among which were offerings to the Generals of Ding and Jia and the Eight Scribes. If one were to extend the logic of specialized offerings, would it then be permissible to elevate the Generals of Ding and Jia to the rank of Great Emperor?

Beyond the stellar realm lie the Nine Purities and Ten Poles, realms not recorded in the Confucian classics and without measurable celestial patterns. Yet the Three Caverns’ orthodox scriptures and the Four Auxiliary Perfected Canons describe them in great detail. The Three Qi of the Mysterious, Primordial, and Origin—congealing to form shape—become the Three Realms’ supreme sovereigns. Below, they correspond to the August Heaven, Northern Culmen, and Heavenly August Emperor; above, they govern the myriad heavens as the lords of Heaven.

Now, following my teacher’s transmission and consulting the relevant precedents, I employ the first-rank memorial format, for one must not profane Heaven with the common rites of the mortal world.

The abbreviated forms of memorial formats—ancient practitioners of prayer and supplication most often presented *zhang* petitions. Now, since the *zhang* format cannot be employed as a regular practice, one must resort to the *zoudu* memorial instead, which retains only the residual intent of the *zhang* and does not constitute its proper form. Few in this world understand this distinction, and some simply follow conventional formats without adopting this one—such flexibility is permissible.

From this point downward, for all Heavenly Worthies, Heavenly Emperors, and Heavenly Lords as recorded in the ancient ritual canons and orthodox scriptures, the first-rank memorial format must be used. This practice was established after the founding of the Daoist teachings in the Middle Antiquity, adopting the secular memorial format of the mortal world. However, secular memorials do not employ sacred titles, for the world recognizes only one sovereign. Yet the Heavenly Worthies and Supreme Emperors manifest in countless forms and appearances. Following the scriptural canons, those with established names and titles must be addressed in memorials, though their designations vary. Thus, sacred titles cannot be omitted from the memorial text. Those not recorded in the orthodox canons but merely invoked in later ritual traditions—such as designating the Mysterious Center as a Heavenly Worthy, or addressing a Heavenly Worthy as Heavenly Master or Heavenly Lord—are numerous and cannot be lightly employed without authoritative basis.

For all others besides Heavenly Worthies, Heavenly Emperors, Dao Lords, and Primordial Ladies, the *shenzhuang* petition format is uniformly used. This applies even to those of the highest rank, such as the Perfected Lords of the Upper Realms; those of the greatest authority, such as the Central Ministers of the Purple Tenuity Enclosure; and the Four Sagely Upper Assistants, the Lofty Perfected of the Heavenly Ministries, the Three Officials, the Five Masters, the sun, moon, and stellar lodges—all follow the *shenzhuang* precedent.

As for those who style themselves "ministers," this reflects the fact that practitioners, fearing they may not yet transcend the Three Realms to become direct ministers of the Golden Towers, may have attained realization only to the extent of receiving scriptures in the Grotto Heavens and shedding their forms in the Void Mystery. Thus, before the host of Perfected Ones in the Upper Realms, they must still assume the role of ministers—much as ancient feudal ministers served their lords. The *zoudu* memorial is not used here, for just as feudal ministers dared not address their lords as "Son of Heaven," so too must restraint be observed. If, however, a practitioner’s Dao is profound and virtue exalted, and they judge that one day they will ascend lightly to the Nine Purities and directly serve the Three Realms as ministers, then before the Perfected Ones of the Upper Realms, they need not adopt the title of minister or follow the precedent of feudal subordinates. This depends entirely on the individual; in my humble opinion, it seems that officials of the earthly realms are not yet suited to such a rank. Yet one cannot assert that no such persons exist in the world, and thus I dare not presume to judge arbitrarily.

As for using the *biao* memorial before one’s teacher—later ages adopted the practice of presenting *biao* only before a sovereign. To employ it before a teacher is improper in terms of ritual propriety. One should emulate the ancients, who presented *jian* memorials to the crown prince. The *Wen Xuan* and other ancient texts contain such formats. Thus, before one’s teacher, the *jian* should replace the *biao*. To disregard distinctions of honor and rank, to ignore canonical formats, and to reduce the Three Clarities, the Jade Emperor, the Five Masters, the Four Sagely Ones, the Three Officials, and the Seven Primes to a single category—using the *zoudu* format uniformly—would be unreasonable both in the human world and in the heavens above. Some ritual manuals, in establishing formats, instruct practitioners to use the *zoudu* before the Five Masters and Seven Primes; this reflects a temporary oversight in aligning with the canons and should not be taken as grounds for disrupting proper principles.

I, Yunzhong, am but a latecomer, fortunate to have been nurtured by the true teachings. Yet my karmic obstructions are deep, and I have not encountered a perfected master. Unversed in the ritual canons and limited in understanding, I dare not deliberately advance heterodox views. To deceive the world and seek undeserved fame would violate the principles I hold dear, and I cannot willingly submit to falsehood. Before the Great Clod was divided and the Supreme Dao merged indistinguishably, before texts were inscribed and names distinguished, there were no memorials to submit. From the Middle Antiquity onward, as ritual canons expanded and rites were established in accordance with the times, memorials and petitions came into use. Once written forms were instituted, they had to conform to canonical regulations. Yet later generations, in their ignorance, either cling solely to their teachers’ transmissions or blindly follow old formats. Can one remain deluded by tradition and insist on teacher-centered transmission? Can one obstruct principle by adhering to vulgar formats? Some reckless and deceitful individuals claim that the Dao is realized through spiritual communion, that Heaven is reached through the heart’s resonance, and that written texts are not strictly necessary. If this were so, they would already be able to appear before the Emperor in spirit and attain the Great Stability of the Celestial Court. Then memorials and petitions could be abolished, and *biao* and *zhang* dispensed with. But so long as affairs remain bound to form and matter, and the spirit has not yet transcended the Void Mystery, such boastful and exaggerated claims—using words to conceal faults—risk consigning one to the ranks of the benighted and deluded.

The formats of memorials and petitions pertain to matters of rank and hierarchy and cannot be treated lightly. To address a minister as a sovereign in the human world is to sow chaos. To address a minister as a sovereign among the Lofty Perfected—would that not sow chaos in the heavens? To sow chaos in the world is a crime deserving of execution; to sow chaos in the heavens—can that be without consequence? The principles of Heaven and humanity are one; the unseen and the manifest are in accord. To disrupt celestial regulations in vulgar fashion is impermissible even in the heavens above. As for the law of condemning the heart’s intent—what punishment would suffice?

If one conducts oneself in this manner, as a minister one would be disloyal, as a son one would be unfilial. The ancients condemned rebellious ministers and treacherous sons who usurped power in their time. Treacherous ministers who betray their states first exalted their sovereigns to provoke the ambitions of power-hungry officials. Such individuals, heedless of falsehood and indifferent to ritual propriety, resort to deceit in their schemes and harbor flattery in their hearts. Their fate in the netherworld is thus evident, and their conduct in the human world can be imagined. Practitioners who, having received but a single register or transmitted a single method, immediately employ uncanonical texts to flatter the heavens—if this is how they conduct their affairs, their character as human beings can be surmised.

The rites of memorials and petitions are of great importance in the ritual canons. Thus, I, Yunzhong, have no choice but to set forth these distinctions in detail. My arguments here may be presented before the Supreme Emperor and declared to the host of Perfected Ones. They are not private opinions, nor are they forced interpretations; they do not exalt the self while denigrating others, nor do they seek reputation by currying favor with the multitude.

The myriad spirits stand in luminous array, the ten thousand phenomena spread in solemn order—truly they witness the sincerity of Yunzhong’s intent.

**Memorial Format for the Upper Realm**
[Official Position] [Rank] Minister [Surname], [Given Name],
respectfully submits this memorial in accordance with the petitioner’s intent, as it must be presented for consideration.

The undersigned humbly memorializes [Sacred Title].
May the Perfected Compassion grant this petition and specially authorize its implementation.
This minister, daring to offend the Perfected Might, is overwhelmed with awe and trepidation. Humbly submitted.

[Year, Cyclical Year] [Month] [Day]
Memorial submitted by [Official Position] [Rank] Minister [Surname].

**For the Middle and Lower Realms**, including the Great Emperor of Fengdu, the Great Emperor of Fusang, the High Ministers of the Five Peaks, the Sacred Emperors of the Five Peaks, the Divine King of Yang Valley, the Lords of Grotto-Heavens and Blessed Lands, the Water Emperors of the Nine Rivers, the Prefect of Mount Tai, the Six Heavens of the Earthly Prison, the Ten Feng Halls of Darkness, and all deities with official titles or those who have received ennobling sacrifices—memorials shall be used.
The recipient’s title shall be placed at the beginning, followed by the year and month. Alternatively, the title may precede the memorial text.

**Memorial Format for the Middle and Lower Realms**
Office of the Great Ritual of the Numinous Treasure.
It is noted that this office, in accordance with the petitioner’s intent, must submit this memorial for consideration.

The undersigned humbly memorializes [Sacred Title], reverently hoping that the Sacred Will may grant this petition and specially authorize its implementation.
Respectfully submitted.

[Year, Cyclical Year] [Month] [Day]
Memorial submitted by [Official Position] [Rank] Minister [Surname].

For deities of the Middle and Lower Realms of slightly lesser rank, such as those of the Feng Halls, Springs, and Crooked Waters, the Prefects of the Nine Provinces’ Earth Altars, City Gods, the Officials of the Year-Star in the Sacrificial Register, and the Divine Tiger Generals and Clerks—documents shall be in the form of *die* (official notes).
The ritual master shall write in regular script, sign with full name, and affix a careful seal, without any hint of irreverence.

For example, City Gods of prefectures and counties have, since ancient times in the Heavenly Heart and other ritual systems, been addressed with public *die*. This is because ritual masters act for the benefit of others and the world, and their affairs are conducted publicly. Moreover, in the Middle Realm, deities such as the Great Emperor of Fengdu and the Sacred Emperors of the Five Peaks hold positions of such exalted dignity that distinctions of rank must be observed.

In later times, however, those who dispatch documents have lost the mean: reckless individuals write with grandiose seals and disrespectful, irreverent language, while timid practitioners even address City Gods with memorials. Both excess and deficiency are departures from proper form. Here, two types of *die* formats are provided.

**First-Class *Die* Format**
Office of the Great Ritual of the Numinous Treasure *die* to [Deity’s Title].
This office, in accordance with the petitioner’s intent, must issue this document.

The *die* requests that the preceding matters be duly considered. [Text continues.] Respectfully submitted.

[Year, Cyclical Year] [Month] [Day]
*Die* issued by [Official Position] [Surname] [Seal].

For deities of the Middle and Lower Realms of slightly lesser rank, or those listed in the sacrificial register but not yet ennobled, or the principal spirits of mountains and rivers who have not received ennobling titles, as well as lower-ranking generals and clerks in the ritual system, or deities who serve as branch officials under the main deities of venerable temples—second-class *die* shall be used, omitting the word "to" before the deity’s title. The closing shall read "therefore *die*," as the ritual propriety is already diminished.

If the deity is listed in the sacrificial register but has not received a title from the present dynasty—yet was a sage emperor, renowned king, loyal minister, or martyr in antiquity, whose former rank was exalted and who still receives sacrifices today—memorials shall be used, not *die*. For example, the temple of Great Yu in Yue is dedicated to an ancient sage ruler; how could such a deity be treated lightly? One must carefully consider the nature of the matter and act accordingly.

**Second-Class *Die* Format**
Office of the Great Ritual of the Numinous Treasure *die* [Deity’s Title].
This office, in accordance with the petitioner’s intent, must issue this document.

The *die* requests that the matters be duly considered. [Text continues.] Therefore *die*.

[Year] [Month] [Day]
*Die* issued by [Official Position] [Surname] [Seal].

For minor deities of the Middle and Lower Realms, as well as generals and clerks of this office—such as the borrowed troops and soldiers under the Five Peaks in the Heavenly Heart system—*tie* (notes) shall be used.

The registers of the Three Caverns and Four Supplements have fixed ranks, but in modern ritual texts, schools proliferate, lineages diverge, and the names of generals and clerks are limitless, no longer confined to the Three Caverns and Four Supplements. Since their ranks and precedence are not prescribed in the canonical texts, practitioners must exercise careful judgment.

**Tie Format**
Office of the Great Ritual of the Numinous Treasure *tie* to [Deity’s Title].
This office, in accordance with the petitioner’s intent, must issue this document.

The *tie* states: [Text continues.] Therefore *tie*.

[Year, Cyclical Year] [Month] [Day]
*Tie* issued by [Official Position] [Surname] [Seal].

For the *Gongcao* (Functionaries) and the office’s clerks and soldiers, *guan* (official communications) shall be used. Do not fabricate the names of the *Gongcao*; instead, issue clear instructions. The closing of the *guan* for delivering offerings must not include phrases such as "if disobeyed." Ritual masters rely entirely on the *Gongcao* for transmission. Since ancient times, the *Gongcao* have been held in high regard in the altar rites of fasts and offerings. Since ritual masters cannot ride the void and command *qi*, on whom else can they depend? If one were to treat them with arrogance or write "if disobeyed," thus invoking the altar statutes, what punishment would the ritual master impose if the *Gongcao* were to disobey? The closing should instead read: "Transmit this promptly; do not delay," or similar language.

In recent times, deceitful and eccentric individuals, relying on their own opinions and arbitrary judgments, have fabricated ritual texts. This has led to alterations of ancient texts, embellishments of old canons, or the extraction and modification of talismans and incantations from other books, which are then compiled under false names. They invent seals, forge heavenly statutes, and fabricate altar laws, creating endless variations that confuse and mislead the world. Their ritual forms are flawed, their dispatches crude and improper, resulting in disrespect toward the sacrificial register, contempt for the Perfected Deities, ignorance of precedence, and inappropriate use of documents—errors too numerous to recount. Those of profound understanding must carefully examine right and wrong.

**Guan Format**

**Guan to a Specific Deity of the Divine Treasure Grand Ritual Bureau**

To the deity [Name] of the Divine Treasure Grand Ritual Bureau:

This Bureau, in accordance with the submitted petition, hereby issues this *guan* for transmission.

This *guan* is to be executed by the deity [Name]. Issued accordingly.

*Guan* issued in the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day].
Sealed by the ritual master [Name and Title].

---

For household deities such as the Controller of Fate and local earth gods—whose ranks are the lowest and may be directed—use the *lu* register.

**Divine Treasure Grand Ritual Bureau**

This Bureau, in accordance with the submitted petition, hereby issues this directive for command.

This *zha* is hereby entrusted to the deity [Name], who is to deliberate on the matter and comply with its execution. Issued accordingly.

*Zha* issued in the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day].
Sealed by the ritual master [Name and Title].

---

For transmitting documents along the way—such as petitions from local earth gods to city gods, or memorials from mountain spirits—where the *guan* to the Merit Officer is unnecessary, use the *yin* dispatch.

Deliver to the local earth god for onward transmission.

**Divine Treasure Grand Ritual Bureau *Yin***

This Bureau now issues this memorial to [Location], requiring command.

It is hereby directed to the local earth god of [Location], and to the earth gods of subsequent locations in sequence, to transmit it accordingly.

Issued in the year [Year], month [Month], day [Day].
Sealed by the ritual master [Name and Title].

---

The formats for *guan*, petitions, and memorials are as described above. In ancient times, talismanic methods derived from the classics and canons. When drafting official documents, they followed secular conventions. Yet the transmission of ritual authority from master to disciple has endured for ages. One should modestly adhere to the old canons, neither transgressing ritual propriety nor erring in matters of precedence. Let the language be neither excessive nor deficient, that it may properly convey reason. Thus may the unseen and seen worlds be harmonized, and sincerity reach the divine.

If ritual offices deviate from ancient forms, or transmissions employ vulgar terms, the consequence is that the names and ranks of the Perfected Deities are altered, and the bureaucracies of the Three Realms are reshuffled—all for the sake of novelty and eccentricity, to dazzle the moment. For instance, the Northern Dipper’s stellar palace is falsely elevated as the "Nine Mornings Jade Palace," or the Solar Palace is referred to by an alternate name from the scriptures, such as "Luminous Splendor Palace." Such examples abound, all of which are inappropriate.

This is why the Yellow Register Retreats—uniting the manifest and the hidden, revered in both ancient and modern times—must be upheld.

Here now is a draft of the requisite documents for memorials and petitions, prepared for use in ritual construction. As for the weight of the matters at hand and the degree of detail in their execution, these shall be left to the High Master’s discretion when the time comes—no fixed rule is prescribed.

The following presents the forms for petitions and memorials, from preliminary announcements to the dispersal of the altar. All documents pertaining to the matter are listed below.

Whenever the Yellow Register Retreat is to be conferred, a memorial must first be submitted in advance.

[This rite] shall ascend in offering to the august spirits of the altars of soil and grain, elevating their numina to the Empyrean. May the present emperor’s longevity equal heaven and earth. May the seas and lands enjoy peace, the living beings radiant prosperity. May the three paths and five destinies all ascend in deliverance; may the nine earths and six heavens all attain transcendence.

Earnestly hoping for Your True Compassion to grant this petition and deign to present it to the **Celestial Court**, that a decree be issued to all true bureaus under the Three Realms, commanding them to accord due response and act in accordance with the prescribed format. **Pre-notification to the City God of the Locality**
