Resplendent, they illuminate the true body,
the flowing essence returns to the Great Vastness.
Below, they descend to the Abyssal Spring Palace,
above, they ascend to the Realm of Non-Being.
Their bodies roam freely, their traces take flight,
suddenly, all is forgotten.
The Seven Treasures flow with pure essence,
mingling with the radiance of chaotic primordial flowers.
Swallowing the Nine Clouds’ elixir,
this joy is without end.
We dedicate this to the lonely souls,
to aid their rebirth in the immortal realms.

**Recite the *Three Lights Yang Jade Dharma-Food Incantation*:**
The Yang Jade of true *qi*,
the wondrous division of the Three Luminaries.
The Mystic Harmony chants the numinous sound,
the Eight Assemblies unfold the jade scriptures.
The Five Elders feast in the cinnabar abode,
floating upon the clouds of light.
The Great Saints and all celestial multitudes
mount dragons to drink the Jade Nectar.
The Three and Five determine the register of life,
playfully they attend the Supreme Guest.
The radiance of splendor shines boundlessly,
hand in hand, they pay homage at the Celestial Emperor’s court.
We dedicate this to the lonely souls,
to aid their rebirth in the immortal realms.

**Recite the *Jade Purity Sweet Dew Dharma-Food Incantation*:**
Turn back and gaze upon the Round Net,
converge the luminous traces to bow before the numinous radiance.
Seize the *hun*-soul and restrain the seven *po*,
contemplating with clarity to stabilize the center.
In movement and stillness, pay homage to the Void,
in rest and repose, feast in the Mystic Chamber.
Hunger is sated with yellow and azure blossoms,
thirst is quenched with the nectar of the Jade Grove.
The divine banner commands the great demons,
uniting the body to refine the true light.
Reflect again upon the Great Nothingness,
ever roaming within the emptiness.
Perfect penetration dissolves the waves of deliverance,
true transformation knows no end.
Boundless and without beginning or end,
the practitioner must clearly understand.
Silent and vast, beyond doctrine and teaching,
responding to the turning of the ages, it unfolds the grand pattern.
The descending Dao does not reveal itself,
yet it must first be enacted.
Convergence returns to the non-dual realm,
following the heart’s intent, it naturally unites and parts.

We dedicate this to the lonely souls,
to aid their rebirth in the immortal realms.

**Recite the *Jade Purity Cloud Palace Brahma-Prosperity Nurture-Soul Nourish-Po Incantation*:**
The numinous fungus has no root,
yet it is the source of all transformations.
Within, the seven *po* congeal,
above, the three *hun* coalesce.
The twenty-four Perfected,
enter and exit without gate.
In the profound obscurity,
flickers the primordial essence.
Through kalpas, it persists or perishes,
arising with the flow of *qi*.
Externally, it solidifies the undifferentiated,
internally, it nourishes the seven meridians.
The five spirits plant their blossoms,
the Three Terraces spread their glory.
The Purple Lad and the White Youth,
return the form to infancy.
Ascending upon clouds,
galloping through mists in the void.
Within resides the Jade Perfected,
named the Divine Lord.
To his left, he grasps the Peerless,
to his right, the White Prime guards.
The Dark Beast blocks behind,
the Cinnabar Phoenix escorts before.
Above floats the emerald canopy,
below surges the golden lotus.
Fragrant clouds condense in the sky,
sweet dew flows without end.
Used without exhaustion,
tracing the source, it never ceases.

Recite the middle section repeatedly,
as many times as deemed sufficient.

The incantations for Dharma-food vary across regions,
here only the commonly used ones are recorded.

**Dedication:**
Having offered this array of Dharma-food,
proclaimed the numinous chapters,
and sacrificed to the nether paths,
we broadly aid the suffering shades.
Surely, by the power of the Dao,
they shall partake of this feast.
Now, let us compose our forms and spirits,
purify our perceptions and thoughts,
direct our hearts single-mindedly toward the Dao,
and make all thoughts true.
Through this refining and tempering,
we advance upon the path of ascent.
For the supreme karmic conditions,
recite the *Celestial Worthy of Birth in Heaven and Attainment of the Dao*,
whose merits are inconceivable.

*Shangqing Lingbao Great Rites*, Scroll Thirty-Eight concludes.
*Shangqing Lingbao Great Rites*, Scroll Thirty-Nine begins.

**On the Dispersed Altar and Offering Rites**

Compiled by Jin Yunzhong, Registrar of the Southern Bureau of the *Dongxuan Lingbao* Masters and Right Adjutant of the Initial Office of the Divine Youth—*Upper Section on Dispersed Altars and Offering Rites*

The ritual methods of the Daoist fasts (*zhai*) originated in the middle antiquity. Between the Jin and Song dynasties, Master Simplicity (Jianji Xiansheng) first distinguished the Three Caverns (*sandong*) and separated the Four Supplements (*sifu*), systematically arranging their regulations and revising the fast rituals. Later, during the Tang, even after Zhang Qingdu’s revisions, they remained incomplete. It was not until Master Broad Accomplishment (Guangcheng Xiansheng) expanded and compiled them that the liturgical canons and ritual standards of the *Huanglu* fasts became resplendently detailed. Posterity has followed them without daring to transgress.

Yet their fundamental purpose declares that the *Huanglu* fasts universally encompass both life and death, uniting the fortunes of humans and heavens. From the common folk below to emperors above, all may cultivate and revere them—such is their boundless merit. However, given the vastness of their volumes, it is impractical to incorporate them entirely into ritual manuals. Those who propagate the teachings should extract and employ the relevant liturgical texts from the complete corpus.

The rites for dispersed altars and offerings (*sanjiao*) are divided into two scrolls in the original canon. To prevent errors in transcription and account for discrepancies between ancient canons and contemporary practices, this section has been compiled separately. The remaining liturgical texts retain their original categories for ease of reference.

**Items Required for the *Huanglu* Fast Rites, Compiled by Master Du Guangcheng:**
- Narrative introductions, consecrated talismans, ritual decorum, altar diagrams, and requisites.
- Petition documents, fast proclamations, altar prohibitions, procedural conduct, and lists of ritual vestments.
- Pre-fast preparations and inaugural invocations.
- On the first day at dawn: the procession of officials and morning audience rites.
- The Great Repentance and the Twenty Directions Repentance.
- The altar ascent and scripture-circling ritual.
- **First Day of the Main Fast:** At midday, the procession and audience rites.
- **Second Day of the Main Fast:** Three periods of procession and audience rites.
- **Third Day of the Main Fast:** Three periods of procession and audience rites.
- Merit proclamations, dispersed altar rites, petition documents, offering rites, and master’s dismissal.
- Lamp offerings, including the Nine Netherworlds Lamp Ritual.
- The Dragon and Jade Disc Offering Ritual.

Additionally, there are:
- The Three Periods of Procession and Audience Rites for the *Huanglu* Fast of Transference and Deliverance.
- The Three-Day *Huanglu* Fast for the Three Primes.
- The Three-Day *Huanglu* Fast for Disaster Dispelling.
- The Three-Day *Huanglu* Fast for House Pacification.
- The Ten Directions Repentance, as well as single-day rites for house pacification, illness alleviation, and the protection of masters and friends.
- The Three-Day *Huanglu* Fast for Universal Deliverance of the Departed, along with various directional repentances, the Five Segments Repentance, the *Huanglu* Fast for the Court’s Protection of Ministers, the *Huanglu* Fast for Ministers’ Disaster Dispelling on Behalf of the State, and the *Zhenwen* Ritual Forms—totaling forty scrolls.

The *Huanglu* fasts govern both the hidden and manifest realms, equally sustaining the living and the dead. Here, the complete *Guangcheng Fast Canon* is transmitted alongside the ritual methods. Those of shared commitment should study and ponder it deeply, thereby recognizing Master Guangcheng’s profound mastery of the ancient scriptures and his devoted efforts in the teaching’s transmission—no trifling achievement.

**On Offerings**
Master Guangcheng states: The *jiao* (offering rite) is another name for sacrifice. Sacrifices involving animal victims and blood offerings are called *ji* (festivals), while those with vegetarian delicacies and refined offerings are called *jiao*—both may summon the perfected and invoke the numinous.

The *Hetu Jingpin* ranks them among the Three Caverns. There are one hundred twenty-four types, akin to fast rituals, along with fifty-six categories of miscellaneous offering rites. All were devised by sages and worthies of past and present in response to karmic conditions. Each can invoke the perfected, pray for blessings, aid beings, benefit humanity, assist royal governance, and nurture all life.

Some rites take the Most High as their principal deity, with the Northern Dipper as their foundational focus. If the offerings are abundant and refined, and the heart sincere with devotion fully expressed, what blessing will not descend, what evil will not be dispelled? Yet if the rites of invitation deviate from proper form, or gestures and postures lose their proper measure, the perfected cannot be summoned to descend.

From this it follows that the Three Caverns include twenty-seven ranks of fasts, and the Three Caverns likewise comprise forty-two grades of *jiao* rites. Yet vulgar and reckless practitioners now conduct *jiao* rites and establish fasts indiscriminately. The Orthodox Unity tradition includes *jiao* rites, sometimes performed after the dispersal of the altar following a fast. But to alter the Orthodox Unity title, change the Orthodox Unity vestments, and then proceed with the *jiao* rite—this is particularly erroneous. For *jiao* rites exist within all Three Caverns. Moreover, the *jiao* rite following altar dispersal marks the conclusion of fast observances, a thanksgiving to the perfected spirits. How can one justify altering titles and vestments to perform it in a separate manner? Such carelessness and novelty-seeking corrupt the ritual canons—how can this be adequately described? This represents the correct principle of past and present, the universal consensus of the world; how can private whims be allowed to disrupt it?

Thus, in recent times, after the dispersal of the altar and the sending off of the masters—when all matters have been concluded—some again invite the perfected and conduct another *jiao* rite, calling it a "special *jiao*" (which may be acceptable), but claiming it fulfills the meaning of a post-fast *jiao* rite entirely misses the original intent. If one follows ancient methods, there is no need to issue a separate *jiao* invitation; before sending off the Six Canopies, one may proceed with the merit-reporting, conduct the *jiao* rite in full, and then send off the masters and clear the altar. The procedure is simple yet coherent, and does not violate the classical ritual forms.

For *jiao* rites, the use of carriages and horses and the like merely serves to express sincerity; it suffices to present a dedicated document for the offering. In ancient times, beyond the submission of memorials, written documents were few. From the Supreme Emperor to the ranked perfected, offerings were made as appropriate, so the positions for *jiao* rites were not numerous. In later ages, written documents, memorials, and petitions multiplied, and wherever such documents were sent, corresponding *jiao* rites of thanksgiving were required.
