Scroll Forty of the *Highest Clarity Numinous Treasure Great Dharma* begins.

The Master of the Cavernous Mystery and Numinous Treasure, the Keeper of the Southern Bureau’s Enforcing Statutes, the Provisional Youth of the Primary Prefecture, the Right Auxiliary Administrator of the Golden Center—compiled under the section *Arrangements for Dispersing Altars and Setting Up Offerings*:

The Three Hundred and Sixty Divine Ranks of the Yellow Register Grand Fast and Offering for Repaying the True Spirits were briefly outlined in the preceding scroll. Their hierarchical order is determined by reference to the *Chart of the Luo Heaven Offering* and the ritual positions promulgated during the Xuanhe reign, cross-referenced and arranged accordingly—not compiled according to secular or private preferences.

The august names and titles of the Perfected Ones are likewise adopted only in accordance with their original sources and the honorifics bestowed by successive courts. For instance, the Great Demon Kings of the Three Realms and Five Directions, and the Flying Heavenly Divine Kings of the Ten Quarters, all being offices of the utmost consequence within the Numinous Treasure tradition, are thus accorded dedicated positions.

The Five Elder Heavenly Lords appear in the Daoist canons, yet there are also the Five Emperors of the Five Directions, whose identities have varied across ancient and modern discussions. Most commentaries in the Daoist scriptures collectively refer to them as the Five Emperors without distinction, thereby deepening the confusion. In the *Scripture of Salvation*, the Five Elders initiate the path, and the host of immortals flank the imperial chariot. Li Shaowei’s commentary cites the *Scripture of Fundamental Conduct*, stating:

- The Eastern Azure Elder, Primordial Spirit of the Treasure Florescence Verdant Grove, is titled the Azure Emperor, surnamed Yan, named Kai, styled Lingwei Yang.
- The Southern Vermilion Elder, True Spirit of the Flourishing Treasure Radiant Yang, is titled the Vermilion Emperor, surnamed Dongfu, named Yan, styled Chibiao Nu.
- The Western White Elder, August Spirit of the Seven Treasures Golden Gate, is titled the White Emperor, surnamed Shangjin, named Changkai, styled Yaopobao.
- The Northern Black Elder, Mysterious Spirit of the Dark Yin Solitary Obscure Fivefold Numinosity, is titled the Black Emperor, surnamed Jie, named Linghui, styled Yinhou Ju.
- The Central Yellow Elder, Primordial Spirit of the Jade Treasure, is titled the Yellow Emperor, surnamed Tongban Yuanshi, styled Hanzhuniu.

Thereafter, the Azure Emperor guards the hun-soul, the White Emperor attends the po-soul, the Vermilion Emperor nurtures the qi, the Black Emperor circulates the blood, and the Yellow Emperor presides at the center—none of the myriad spirits transgress their governance.

Yan Dong’s commentary states: the Eastern Azure Emperor Lingwei Yang, the Southern Vermilion Emperor Chibiao Nu, the Western White Emperor Baizhaoju, the Northern Black Emperor Yuguang Ji, and the Central Yellow Emperor Hanzhuniu. Li Shaowei further annotates: these are the Five Elder Supreme Emperors, each receiving the Red Script Mandate. In heaven, they govern the immortals of the Five Directions; on earth, they oversee the Five Sacred Peaks; and within humans, they rule the Five Viscera. Though this interpretation approaches correctness, it fails to elucidate the underlying principle.

Now, according to astronomy, within the Supreme Subtlety Enclosure of the heavens, there are five stars—one at the center, four flanking it—called the Five Emperors’ Thrones, which are the Emperors of the Supreme Subtlety. The *Jin Astronomic Treatise* states: these are the Eastern Azure Emperor Lingwei Yang, the Southern Vermilion Emperor Chibiao Nu, the Western White Emperor Baizhaoju, the Northern Black Emperor Yuguang Ji, and the Central Yellow Emperor Hanzhuniu. Within the Purple Tenuity Enclosure, there are also five stars known as the Five Emperors’ Inner Thrones. The *Astronomic Treatise* states: these are the five stars where the Emperor resides. Thus, the Eastern Year Star governs spring, corresponds to wood, manifests in human appearance, and embodies benevolence. The Southern Fire Star governs summer, corresponds to fire, manifests in human vision, and embodies propriety. The Western Venus governs autumn, corresponds to metal, manifests in human speech, and embodies righteousness. The Northern Water Star governs winter, corresponds to water, manifests in human hearing, and embodies wisdom. The Central Saturn governs the four seasons, corresponds to earth, manifests in human thought, and embodies trust.

Confucian texts limit their discussion to what is observable in astronomy, whereas Daoist canons include the Five Elder Supreme Emperors and further assign them surnames and personal names. However, the Five Elder Supreme Emperors are identified in Daoist canons as the five deities Lingwei Yang and others, while in astronomical texts, the Five Emperors’ Thrones are also attributed to Lingwei Yang and the same five deities. Such proliferation of names has yet to attain coherence in principle. If Confucian and Daoist texts were harmonized in accordance with principle, then the Five Elder Supreme Emperors would be the root and origin of the Five Qi and the fundamental beginning of the Five Phases.

As manifested in astronomy, they become the Five Stars or the Five Emperors’ Thrones. Once heaven and earth separate, they condense into tangible forms, becoming the Five Sacred Peaks. Having formed as mountains, they must have spirits to govern them, hence the Emperors of the Five Sacred Peaks. As the year progresses and the four seasons are established, the spirits governing their commands are the Five Emperors. Extending downward to the elements, they become metal, wood, water, fire, and earth; in affairs, they are the Five Emperors; and in humans, they are the Five Viscera—all being this same Five Qi, though their manifestations differ. One must not rigidly adhere to names and conflate them into one.

In Lin Shichen’s *Jade Register*, the Emperors of the Five Sacred Peaks are equated with the Heavenly Emperors. When submitting memorials, one declares oneself a subject unified with heaven and earth, implying that the Five Qi share a common source. The intent is to regard the Five Sacred Peaks as the Five Heavenly Emperors, treating them as equivalent. Lin Shichen was a scholar of lofty attainment, yet his perspective was somewhat partial. The Five Elders are the root of the Five Qi, the gateway of the wondrous existence and wondrous non-existence within the heavens, sharing the same body as the Heavenly Worthy. When they become the sovereigns of mountains, they are merely called the Peak Spirits. If they were the same five deities, then in heaven they could be called the Five Elders, and on mountains the Five Sacred Peaks—this would be acceptable.

Moreover, from humankind to the myriad beings, none do not receive the primordial ancestral qi of the Originator. This single qi is divided to ascend in nature and receive numinosity. Yet it would be incorrect to equate humans directly with the Originator Heavenly Worthy. The inception of the Five Emperors shares a single source, but the manifestations of the Five Qi differ in their functions. Therefore, in the ritual protocols for approaching the altar, one visualizes the divine soldiers and multitudes of the Five Sacred Peaks and Five Emperors, as well as the divine soldiers and multitudes of the Five Directions and Five Emperors.

If the Five Elderly Lords of Heaven were indeed deities who command troops and horses, then in the ritual altars they would only be referred to as the Five Emperors’ encampments. The ancients did not call them the Five Elders’ encampments, for recording merits and demerits, examining sins and blessings, is not the duty of the Five Elders in the celestial realm. Following simplicity without hindrance, the altar may simply invoke the Azure Emperor of the East, the Vermilion Emperor of the South, the White Emperor of the West, the Black Emperor of the North, and the Yellow Emperor of the Center—what harm is there in this? If these Five Emperors are indeed the Five Elders, then calling them the Five Emperors is unobjectionable. If the Five Emperors differ from the Five Elders, then referring to them as the Five Emperors is all the more appropriate. Why cling rigidly to one interpretation? Reasonably speaking, it is best to name them according to the abode of the Five Qi. In the celestial realm, they are called the Five Elderly Lords of Heaven; in celestial patterns, the Five Emperors’ Seats or the Five Directions and Five Stars; among divine spirits, the Five Directions and Five Emperors; in mountains and peaks, the Five Sacred Peak Emperors; and within the human body, the Lords of the Five Viscera. Is this not both logically coherent and easy to practice? If one wished to trace all back to a single source, calling the Lords of the Five Viscera the Five Elderly Lords of Heaven would be as absurd as a child of three feet knowing it to be impossible. This was briefly addressed in the *Six Encampments’ Petitions and Thanksgivings*. Yet in this ritual arrangement, the Five Directions and Five Emperors are listed twice, lest later generations misunderstand the reasoning, and so it is explained in detail here. Many earlier scholars have discussed this matter, yet few have reached a definitive conclusion. Fellow practitioners should investigate further. If any arrive at a settled judgment, it would resolve the confusions of later ages—this would be most fortunate.

Moreover, in recent times, some have presumptuously altered the titles of perfected beings, such as changing "Celestial Master" to "Heavenly Lord of the One Dao" or "Xu Jiyang" to "Heavenly Pivot Envoy." Such distortions and profanations are rampant. These individuals are not worth reproaching, but scholars of broad learning should collectively reject such practices.

**Ancient Ritual for the Yellow Register Grand Fast and Scattered Altar Offerings**
In ancient times, there were no arrangements for the layout of the ritual arena; all rites were conducted upon the altar. Thus, when setting up an offering, outside the altar, azure silk and crimson seats were prepared, along with seasonal fruits and ritual libations. After presenting the memorial and casting the dragon tablets, the deities were invited to descend, and the offering was set forth. Though later generations continued to perform rites upon the altar, they also installed images, established positions, and arranged the ritual space. The altar was used for offerings, while the ritual arena itself was furnished with sacrificial provisions. If following the ancient method, after presenting the memorial upon the altar, the deities would be invited to descend, and the offering would be set upon the altar, while the threefold presentation of offerings could proceed within the ritual arena. Alternatively, after presenting the memorial and casting the dragon tablets, the incense burner would be carried out the door. The officiants would withdraw to the quiet chamber for a brief rest, then re-enter, ascend the altar, offer incense, recite the ritual texts, invite the deities to descend, set forth the offering, receive the precepts and assume their roles, chant the *Hymn of the Three Paths and Five Sufferings*, circumambulate the altar, exit the door, send off the deities, and burn the concluding offerings before concluding the rite and dispersing the assembly.

Nowadays, during the circumambulation while chanting the *Hymn of the Three Paths and Five Sufferings*, the hasty lowering of the gate placards is most improper. The ritual space is prepared to model heaven and earth, with gates and placards arranged to demonstrate proper form. Once the altar rites are complete, all should be dismantled together—why the rush to lower the placards? Such disorderly conduct disrupts the solemnity of the ritual, mingling movements and halts in a most inconvenient manner. Moreover, the words of the *Hymn of the Three Paths and Five Sufferings* merely expound upon sins and blessings to exalt the scriptural teachings, and are not part of the gate-lowering ceremony. This should be carefully considered.

The officiants form ranks before the master, and the High Priest offers incense. The *Hymn to the Dao* is chanted. They enter the Earthly Gate, ascend the Heavenly Portal, offer incense to the Ten Directions, the incense at the imperial table, and the incense at their own stations. Each bows to the master and visualizes as prescribed. The *Five Stars Mantra* is recited, the ritual drum sounded, the incense burner activated, and each announces their ritual position:

*"We, your servants [names], now humbly burn incense. May this merit be dedicated above to the ancestral spirits of the imperial lineage, the present emperor, the civil and military officials, the ministers and all underlings, and the disciples performing this fast, [names], along with their seven generations of ancestors, nine lineages of descendants, living kin, the three masters and nine generations of our own ancestors, all people under heaven, and all sentient beings—those lost in the dark paths of the underworld. We devote our bodies, spirits, and lives to the Most High Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions and the Boundless. We beseech forgiveness for the grave sins of past lives and the present, that we may escape the Three Evil Paths, the Ten Sufferings, Eight Difficulties, and Nine Calamities. May our bodies attain the true Dao, soaring through empty space, ascending to heaven in broad daylight, to serve and guard the Dao Lords, roaming freely in the supreme golden palaces and seven-jeweled natural palaces of the void, forever united with the Dao. May our supplications be received before the perfected and boundless Dao."*

**Repentance to the Ten Directions**
*"We, the ritual assembly, wholeheartedly devote our bodies, spirits, and lives to the Most High Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions and the Boundless Dao. We repent for the ancestral spirits of the imperial lineage, the present emperor, the princes and ministers, the civil and military officials, the disciples performing this fast, our three masters and nine generations of ancestors, our inner and outer kin, those living and deceased, our affinal relatives, the rulers of the underworld, the suffering souls of the earthly prisons, the wandering spirits of the air, the sunken souls and stagnant spirits, all sentient beings with consciousness, and every living creature. From the distant kalpas of the past to this very day, we may have committed transgressions in bodily deeds—our four limbs and actions violating the precepts, not adhering to the scriptures. Or in mental deeds—our thoughts scattered, emotions restless, minds racing without cease. Or in verbal deeds—mixing good and evil in speech, using ornate words to conceal wrongs, employing flowery language to deceive the multitude. The great sins of the three karmas accumulate like mountains; the transgressions of the ten evils fill vast seas. Through this repentance, we beseech their complete eradication. We humbly pray that the revered ancestral spirits may roam freely in the Purple Ultimate."*

May the sacred chart endure forever, the imperial throne remain secure and peaceful,
the Emperor’s longevity match the Five Peaks, his wisdom equal the sun and moon.
May princes, ministers, civil and military officials faithfully assist the imperial enterprise,
broadcasting the transformative power of the Dao.

For the ritual master of this household, and for our nine generations of ancestors and seven lineages,
our four companions and three teachers—those who have shed their mortal forms in the Southern Palace,
washed their souls in the cinnabar radiance—
may the three paths and six destinies all emerge from darkness,
ascending to the shore of blessedness.

May we ourselves enter the realm of perfected immortals,
unite with the Dao and merge with the True,
our spirits returning to profound stillness,
penetrating the spontaneity of nature,
our nature and life harmonizing with the Dao,
mysteriously attaining non-action.

We bow our heads in reverence and gratitude to the Most High and Perfect Three Treasures.
Following the ritual scripture, we perform the Triple Invocation and Triple Bow.
We circumambulate, then gather the True Writs.
The assembly chants in unison as the High Priest takes up the True Writs,
fumigates them with incense, strikes his teeth twelve times, and recites the incantation.

If this ritual is dedicated specifically to delivering the departed,
the middle section of the writ is placed for pacification, and this incantation is proclaimed:

Most High and Perfect, Great Sage and Lofty Venerable,
spreading transformation and circulating qi through the thirty-two heavens.
Eight gatherings and nine luminances naturally form the script.
Pacifying heaven and earth, safeguarding against kalpic years.
The Primordial Beginning’s talismanic command universally notifies the Three Origins.
Below, it summons the nine earths; above, it connects with the three heavens.
At its center, it announces to the seas and mountains, the great peaks and rivers.
Today, we make this supreme declaration, and the myriad spirits all hear.

Through this fast and the practice of the Dao, we deliver the departed souls.
May the Three Officials and Nine Bureaus eradicate the roots of sin.
May the three souls be eternally delivered from the source of the five sufferings.
May they receive blessings life after life, their names inscribed in the cinnabar register.
May their spirits be born in heaven, refined and transformed by nature.
May they transcend life and death, enduring for countless kalpas.
The command of the nine heavens is transmitted by wind and fire couriers.

The assembly bows again, following the True Writs and memorial, and burns them.

If this ritual is performed for the state and the people,
to ensure prosperity, protect the age, avert disasters, and deliver from calamities,
saving both the living and the dead,
then the Red Writs are used for pacification, and this incantation is proclaimed:

The Primordial Beginning of the highest heaven, the three luminaries shining brightly,
the four seasons illuminating, the four directions made clear and pure.
Where the revolving destiny clashes, meteors surge and scatter.
The five phases are disordered, the three constellations unsettled.
The gods of the Five Celestial Palaces, the luminous spirits of the Seven Stars,
the True Lord Great Culmen, whose tabooed name is Jade Essence,
and the Lady Imperial Consort, whose name is Nurturing Infant,
together govern the Mysterious Pass, revolving the myriad heavens.

Today, a certain calamity has arisen, darkly foretelling misfortune.
We present this True Writ, also inscribed and submitted above.
We scatter our hair to confess our faults, revealing our cinnabar sincerity.
We beseech your mysterious scrutiny, restoring the celestial canon.
May qi not flow recklessly, may disasters not arise wantonly.
We burn the True Writs, dispersing their smoke in the Jade Court.
The Upper Radiance supervises and measures, universally notifying the myriad spirits.
May the qi of the three passes be purified, the disasters of the nine darknesses eradicated.
May yin and yang harmonize, the land know great peace.

We request that golden dragons transmit this by wind and fire couriers.
The assembly bows again, and the True Writs are burned with the memorial.

Again, we declare our ritual ranks:
We, the ritual master [Name], together with the assembled officials of this altar,
solemnly and sincerely address the Most High and Boundless Dao,
the Primordial Celestial Venerable of the Origin,
the Most High Dao Lord, the Most High Lord Lao,
the Most High and Mysterious Elder, the Ten Directions’ Numinous Treasure Celestial Venerables,
the Perfected Great Sages who have attained the Dao,
the Perfect and True Lords and Masters,
the thirty-six divisions of revered scriptures,
the Great Dharma Masters of the Mysterious Center,
the Celestial Masters and True Lords,
the Supreme Ministers and Prime Ministers,
the Four Controllers and Five Emperors,
the numinous palaces of the Five Peaks,
the grottoes and abodes of the famous mountains,
the officials and attendants of the three realms,
and all true spirits.

By our past karmic affinity with the Dao, we have personally encountered this orthodox transformation.
The Celestial Venerable expounded the teachings, promulgating the Three Caverns.
The precious formulas and numinous charts bring prosperity to households and peace to the state.
Having attained participation in the true mysteries, we are permitted to receive and cultivate them.
Our duty lies in establishing merit, universally benefiting both the hidden and the manifest.
We should propagate the sagely instructions, broadly delivering celestial and human beings.
None who sincerely submit should be rejected or abandoned.

Today, in accordance with the edict, we dare not withhold this from your notice.
We present this blue-green memorial from the altar, respectfully announcing it.

Proclamation:
In accordance with the words of the memorial, we are truly sincere and earnest.
It is fitting that this be reported.
We hope to attain spiritual resonance.

Together, we circulate our cinnabar sincerity, mutually guiding one another.
Examining the immortal classics and the standards of the spirits,
we unfold the yellow register’s scriptures.
On behalf of the ritual master [Name],
at [Location] in [Prefecture and County],
we establish the pattern of the mysterious rites,
modeling the two principles.
With the treasured offerings of lamps, candles, incense, and flowers,
golden dragons and silken banners,
and the pledges of our destined lives,
we verify our cinnabar sincerity.

On [Date and Time], we commence the fast,
burning incense, practicing the Dao,
repenting before the mysterious darkness,
lighting lamps to continue the illumination,
shining upon the three realms.
Below, we reach the nine earths; above, we extend to the myriad heavens,
delivering the living and rescuing the departed,
universally benefiting household and state.

For three days and five nights, we practice the Dao and recite the scriptures.
On [Date] at the hour of the boar, the ritual is completed and the task accomplished.
The lotus lamps extinguish their flames, the jade chimes cease their sound.
The immortal chariots return to the Upper Mystery, the dharma currents disperse in the lower realms.
Golden dragons soar in shadow, submitting the merits of the fast above.

May the sagely grace proclaim mercy,
opening the path to deliver the hidden souls,
rewarding merit and bestowing honors,
universally extending to the numinous bureaus.

The inner and outer true officials we bear within our bodies,
the soldiers and clerks of the Three Caverns,
the sun, moon, and stellar constellations,
the Five Emperors and Five Peaks,
the Three Rivers and Four Seas,
the cavalry and chariots,
the incense-bearing golden lads,
the flower-scattering jade maidens,
the Five Emperors’ direct talismans,
the messengers who transmit and report,
the flying dragon couriers—
all have labored diligently.

Today, we separately bow and present yellow silk and vermilion memorials,
reporting their merits and recommending their promotion.

We, whose study of the dharma is incomplete,
have erred in our demeanor and conduct,
transgressing the regulations and failing to conform to the ritual forms.
We fear being impeached by the Four Controllers,
seized by the Five Emperors.
For our thousand transgressions and ten thousand faults,
we beseech your forgiveness and pardon,
mercifully overlooking our ignorance,
that we may not incur punishment.

At the beginning of this fast, we reverently invited the Ten Precepts of the Upper Grade of Wisdom.
Now that the dharma rites are complete, we respectfully return them to their celestial palaces.

The fast we have conducted is now accomplished.
We reaffirm its merits and present a yellow silk and vermilion memorial,
placed upon our jade table.
We request that the text of the memorial be reviewed.

The memorial is presented before the imperial throne, with the dragon-headed knife placed to the left of the sacred seat and the vermilion brush to its right. The memorial is proclaimed. The High Priest kneels at his station to seal the memorial. Once sealed, an envoy is dispatched.

We reverently dispatch the Five True Officials within our body, each accompanied by a minor clerk and twelve scribal assistants. We further command the Registrar of Merit, the Flying Dragon Couriers, and the swift messengers, all in solemn attire with caps and pendants, grinding ink and preparing brushes, girding swords and ordering records. They shall act on our behalf without delay, bearing the yellow silk and vermilion memorial to ascend to the celestial bureaus, presenting it in accordance with the memorial’s petition.

Should there be any erroneous characters, omitted words, or misplaced passages that do not follow in proper sequence, the scribal assistants and minor clerks, wielding dragon-headed writing knives and sharp brushes, shall correct and amend them on the spot. Let no supervising official have cause to reject or return it.

Sealing the qi, the memorial ascends directly to the presence of the Supreme Lord of the Boundless Dao of the Three Heavens. Let it not be delayed. The officials of the left shall pass through the gates in order, while those of the right shall present it in sequence. Let all officials and lords distinguish and arrange matters accordingly.

May what is requested descend, what is delivered reach, what is summoned arrive, what is governed be healed, what is condemned be destroyed, what is proclaimed be communicated, what is promoted advance, what is wished be fulfilled, and what is sought be obtained.

Should any subordinate official obstruct or intercept our memorial, preventing its ascent, they shall be seized and delivered to the nearest prison, their crimes adjudicated according to the celestial statutes, that the heavenly decrees be made manifest.

We prostrate ourselves, awaiting the response of profound grace.

The High Priest hands the memorial to the Daoist assembly. The collected true writs are placed upon the memorial table and burned together. The Fast Supervisor escorts the memorial text, leading the ritual to the Gate of Heaven, where it is burned. The incantation for the burning is recited.

The High Priest prostrates before the memorial, visualizing as prescribed in the ritual form. Rising, he declares, "Let it be heard." The Mountain Tablet is proclaimed.

The High Priest holds the tablet, fumigates it with incense, and strikes his teeth nine times, reciting the incantation for the Mountain Tablet:

"Mysterious and luminous, the Primordial Lord oversees the true.
The Five Elders of the Supreme Emperor, the vermilion script of the red writ.
The origin of heaven and earth, governing the Three Primes.
Gathering qi and summoning assemblies, hastening the ascent of immortals.
The exalted mandate of the Highest, proclaimed throughout the ten directions.
Sun, moon, and stars; the Five Peaks and sacred mountains.
Above in heaven, below on earth; the great spirits of the hidden realms.
Overseeing life and recording deeds, at the Southern Three Gates.
Unsealing the jade tablet, inscribing names in the cinnabar register.
Erasing the record of transgressions, elevating to the rank of imperial retainer.
The fast’s sponsor, [Name], relies upon the Perfect Dao.
Having established the fast and performed merit, redeeming the nine generations of ancestors.
All suffering souls, the rites now complete.
We reverently follow the sacred mountain, offering the jade tablet.
Beseeching the erasure of sins, that all may attain liberation.
Let there be no enmity or kinship, departing from the Three Evils.
May souls ascend to the Nine Heavens, crossing the threshold of life and death, enduring for myriad kalpas.
Today we make this supplication, may the myriad spirits hear it.
With this dragon tablet, we pledge to the true officials.
May our plea be granted, transmitted by the golden dragon couriers."

Next, the Water Tablet is proclaimed. The High Priest fumigates the tablet as before and recites the incantation for the Water Tablet:

"The Primordial Lord and Five Elders, the Supreme Emperor most exalted.
The perfected of the ten directions, the sacred immortals of Mount Taihua.
The vermilion writ proclaims the mandate, heard in even the most hidden realms.
Ascending to the Nine Heavens, we request the descent of the jade writ.
Sun, moon, and five stars; the Seven Primes of the Northern Dipper.
We announce to the Five Peaks, the sacred mountains of the four directions.
Below, we announce to the rivers and seas, the twelve springs and sources.
The water emperors of the nine bureaus, the great spirits of the hidden realms.
Today we make this supplication, unfolding myriad wishes.
The fast’s sponsor, [Name], has established the fast and performed the Dao.
For the sake of the living and the dead, redeeming the seven generations of ancestors.
The roots of past transgressions, we reverently offer the jade tablet.
Beseeching that it be heard above, recorded in the water府.
May the departed ascend to heaven, crossing the threshold of life and death.
May the myriad spirits hear this.
With this dragon tablet, we announce to the water officials.
May our plea be granted, transmitted by the golden dragon couriers."

Next, the Earth Tablet is proclaimed. The High Priest holds the black tablet and, as before, recites the incantation for the Earth Tablet:

"Heaven and earth unfold, the myriad qi divide and bestow spirit.
The grottoes of the Three Primes, the radiant purity of the ten directions.
The Five Elder Supreme Emperors, governing life and death.
The cinnabar script of the red writ, the primordial essence of the Primordial Lord.
Proclaimed throughout the world, the august spirits of the nine lands.
Today we make this supplication, may the myriad immortals affirm life.
The fast’s sponsor, [Name], has established the fast and performed the Dao.
For the sake of the living and the dead, we wish for our immortality.
We offer the jade name to the Supreme Emperor of the Earth府.
Erasing the record of crimes, presenting the tablet to the upper palace.
Inscribed in the registers of Huaqing, the body attains flight.
In harmony with heaven and earth, the nine generations of kin.
Rotten bones renewed in glory, souls ascending to the Southern Palace.
Transformed in the immortal courts, today we proclaim this mandate.
May the myriad spirits hear it.
With this white tablet, we manifest our utmost sincerity.
May our plea be granted, transmitted by the golden dragon couriers."

The Hymn of the Dragon Tablet is recited.

Praying to ascend to the Purple Palace, the High Priest enters the ritual enclosure to perform the jiao offering.

We reverently and earnestly supplicate the Supreme Lord of the Boundless Dao, the Primordial Celestial Worthy of Original Commencement, the Supreme Dao Lord, the Supreme Lord Lao, the Most Exalted Mysterious Elder, the Celestial Worthies of the Ten Directions, the Perfected and Great Sage Hosts who have attained the Dao, the perfected lords and venerable masters of all ranks, the thirty-six divisions of revered scriptures, the Great Dharma Masters of the Mysterious Center, the responsive and perceptive spirits of the Three Realms, and all true numina.

We prostrate ourselves, having heard that the yellow writs of the Registers of Destiny, the celestial ranks of the Mysterious Capital, the sacred writs and secret seals, are of solemn majesty and awe-inspiring dignity. Above, they dispel celestial disasters; below, they avert terrestrial calamities. They bring blessings to households and the state, safeguarding and securing the emperor. Their boundless merit extends to all beings, who are enveloped in fortune.

We, in reverent compliance with the fast’s provisions, have earnestly revealed our prayers, arrayed the symbols, and performed the rites. Having completed the ritual proceedings, we have received abundant protection. The nation and the realm rejoice together. The dark paths and suffering realms, by the blessings of the fast, are revived. The cold courts of the night府, bathed in compassionate grace, are opened and prosper.

Now, the fast’s sponsor, [Name], holds profound gratitude yet lacks means of repayment. Daring to take this moment at the conclusion of the altar rites, we humbly offer the reverence of the jiao offering.

Looking up in gratitude to the True Spirits for their compassionate regard, we offer slight repayment for the diligent service of the divine marshals. Gazing toward the numinous radiance, we earnestly renew our plea for descent.

We, together with the fast’s sponsor, prostrate in utmost reverence, yearning for the sagely presence. With due solemnity, we proceed to the rites of invocation, audience, tea offering, and the first oblation.

We, in all sincerity, reverently address the Most High Dao, the August Sovereign of the Myriad Heavens, the Great Saints of the Ten Directions, the Divine Immortals of Heaven and Earth, the Lords of the Sun and Moon, the Four Controllers and Five Emperors, the Northern Dipper of the Three Terraces, the deities of mountains and rivers, the host of Numinous Treasure Perfected Ones, the officials of the Three Realms, and all the assembled divinities of this jiao altar.

By ancestral blessings, we were born into this life. Having received the sacred texts, we have followed the teachings of the Mysterious Dao. Our merits are as light as dust and dew, while our transgressions weigh like mountains. Rightly, we should restrain ourselves and cultivate discipline. Yet the Dao permits deliverance and aids the state in establishing merit. Thus, when beings seek refuge, it is only proper that we not refuse.

Now, the fast’s sponsor, in utmost sincerity, has poured forth his heartfelt vows. Through this fast, he seeks to deliver the departed, revive the souls of the night’s dark courts, beseech grace and forgiveness, atone for transgressions, bring fortune to the state, and universally benefit all beings, moving and still. With the fast’s merit now accomplished and demonic obstacles dispelled, we rely entirely upon the responsive presence of the True Spirits, the sagely assembly of the altar, the inner and outer officials, and the ritual officers and soldiers of the talismanic register—all of whom have brought this great blessing to fruition, fulfilling the sponsor’s earnest prayers.

Yet in our morning observances, we may have offended the celestial patterns; in our reverent constructions, we may have failed in proper decorum. The fast’s offerings may have been deficient, the altar’s regulations incomplete. In movement and stillness, we may have transgressed the proper measures; in posture and gesture, we may have strayed from the norm. Thus, we have presumptuously offended the True Spirits and violated the statutes and prohibitions. For these faults, we now confess in this jiao offering. We beseech the relevant authorities to proclaim these matters to all under their charge, to erase our transgressions, and to absolve our faults. Daring to rely upon the grace of their trust and protection, we pray for the descent of future blessings.

With the assembled Perfected Ones in attendance, we offer the second libation to express our sincerity. Presumptuously disturbing the august spirits, we are filled with trepidation. We, together with the fast’s sponsor, prostrate in awe and reverence, bowing twice.

**Second Oblation Rites**
We, in all sincerity, reverently address the Boundless Dao, the Most High Perfected Ones, the authorities of mountains and rivers, the underworld bureaus, the yin and yang overseers, the officials of the Three Realms, and all numinous powers.

We have heard that the Three Clarities’ August Saints, the Five Emperors’ Venerable Divinities, the True Spirits of Heaven and Earth, and the Mysterious Controllers of the Supreme Offices shape creation and nurture all beings. Embracing non-action, their merit precedes even the covering of Heaven and the bearing of Earth. Their divine mechanisms are unfathomable, their virtue extends to the hidden and the manifest. They secretly protect the state, subtly assist all beings, dispel all disasters, and ward off all calamities. Whatever is beseeched, they surely oversee and protect.

We humbly pray that they witness and record the merit of this fast. May the fast’s sponsor, [Name], his seven generations of ancestors and nine degrees of descendants, his five relations and six clans, the departed and the long-gone, and all the souls thus delivered ascend to the Vermilion Palace, roam the Azure Heavens, and know no suffering, their clothing and sustenance naturally provided. May we, our four companions and three masters, our worldly and Daoist kin—those who have passed attain transcendence and deliverance, and those still living realize the fruit and achieve immortality.

Next, we pray for the fast’s sponsor, [Name], and all his living kin: may misfortunes scatter, sins dissolve, true qi flourish within, and divine officials guard without. May his years be prolonged, his fortune and longevity renewed. In all his comings and goings, may the gods protect him. May he be transformed in the Northern Palace and reborn in the Southern Dipper. May the local earth gods ever watch over him.

Above, we pray for the emperor’s eternal longevity, the state’s flourishing prosperity, universal peace under Heaven, and the cessation of warfare. May the long night of the Nine Dark Realms lead to rebirth in Heaven. May all beings within the Four Seas together ascend to the realm of longevity.

We, whose mastery of the Dao is incomplete and whose cultivation remains unfulfilled, fear transgressing the Mysterious Statutes, making our petitions difficult to convey. We humbly pray that our unexpressed supplications swiftly ascend to the Nine Heavens. May the true texts and numinous scriptures universally succor the hidden and the earthbound. May the Mysterious Wind spread widely, its beneficent influence descending to moisten the hidden and the manifest, bringing prosperity to the living and the dead.

The rites of invocation and gratitude now complete, may the responsive presence be felt in this moment, and may the jiao offering reach its conclusion. Daring to present the third oblation, we, together with the fast’s sponsor, prostrate in deepest gratitude and reverence, bowing twice.

**Final Oblation Rites and Memorial Presentation**
We, in all sincerity, reverently address the High Perfected Ones of the Three Realms, the Saints of the Ten Directions, and all the assembled divinities of this jiao altar.

With the fast’s proceedings concluded and the jiao rites completed, we now present our disordered offerings and humble tributes, hoping for the grace of lenient protection and the pardon of our foolish transgressions. May fortune flow to all beings, and blessings spread to all directions.

Our worldly merits are meager, unworthy of the divine hosts. The Perfected Ones dwell in distant realms, far beyond the Jade Palace. May the celestial beings of the Upper Realms ascend to their palaces. May the lords of mountains and rivers return to their divine offices. May the True Spirits of the talismanic registers, the soldiers and horses of the Three Realms, report to the Heavenly Court and receive their ranks and rewards. May the local earth gods and city gods, having received the fast’s blessings, all partake in the Mysterious Fortune.

Bowing at the celestial steps, we send them off with shared reverence. Overwhelmed with longing and devotion, we prostrate in deepest sincerity.

**Hymn for Sending Forth the Spirits**
Vast and formless, the empty void—

**Next: Precept Hymn, Circumambulation, and the Cantor’s Position**
The Heavenly Worthy, in great compassion,
Preaches the precepts to deliver all beings.

Next, the Cantor chants the Return of the Precepts. Three bows are performed, and the officiants submit their ranks. In order before the sacred table, they present their rank tablets, perform three bows, withdraw, and relinquish their offices.

At the commencement of this fast, and throughout the presentation of memorials, the dispatch spirits from within this servant’s body—the functionaries of merit, the Three and Five True Officials, and the hundred nodal divine clerks—all return to this servant’s body. Entering through the Gates of Myriad Mysteries, those on the left return to the left, those on the right to the right. The Directing Merit Functionary supervises and oversees, each resuming their original positions without error. When later summoned again, they shall return as before.

The incense is replenished, and three bows are performed. Circumambulation begins, and eight hymns on the Three Paths and Five Sufferings are chanted while circling the altar thrice, as in the *Step of the Void*.

*"The Three Powers and the myriad things..."*
*"Great worthies, guard these precepts..."*
*"Sin and fortune arise not from others..."*
*"Lust and jealousy are the roots of calamity..."*
*"Past lives are surely so..."*
*"Human life is already spent..."*
*"To learn the Dao and practice it is urgent..."*
*"Great worthies delight in the scriptures and precepts..."*

**Hymn for Dismissing the Altar**
Vast emptiness enfolds all forms.

Descending through the Heavenly Gate, exiting the Earthly Portal. Departing the altar, the ritual concludes. Proceeding to the master’s tent, gratitude is expressed, and the memorial is presented.

The old rites for sending off the master lacked a formal address in the ritual manuals. Fearing disorder in speech at the moment, six texts for addressing the overseers before the tents have now been composed, appended below for the use of the entire tradition. Should any text be imperfect, revisions may be made.

First, proceed to the head of the western three tents, approaching the Overseer of the Fast. Offer incense, and both the High Priest and the Fast Officer bow, kneel, and deliver their address:

*"This humble servant, [Name], in proper ritual position, respectfully bows and offers sincerest devotion, reverently addressing the Most August Master of the Numinous Treasure, Overseer of the Fast. In delivering salvation to heaven and humanity, nothing precedes the blessings of the fast. In expanding the teachings, all depends on the master’s grace. Fortunate indeed is this sincere offering, born of your boundless compassion. Private devotion is fulfilled, and divine favor knows no limit. Yet this servant, dull and ignorant, errant in learning, has but roughly completed the listed petitions and memorials, while often violating the ritual’s true intent. Thus, I present this memorial to confess my faults before your eyes, unashamed of my importunity, and humbly make this declaration. I implore your compassion and special consideration."*

**Reading the Memorial**
*"The memorial just presented has presumptuously reached your divine attention. May you pity this later student and graciously bestow your lenient favor. Though five days have passed and nine mornings completed, a thousand transgressions have amassed into ten thousand faults. I beseech their thorough cleansing and full pardon. May good deeds be recorded, and divine blessings flow forth. The ritual concludes, the mats are rolled, and the altar is dismissed. The celestial retinue does not tarry—already their rainbow banners are arrayed in the layered heavens. The divine steeds are harnessed, yet none may follow the crane-drawn chariot through the long sky. The ritual assembly extols and bows in shared reverence, sending them forth."*

The *Hymn for Completing the Fast* is raised, as before.

Next, proceed to the Heavenly Master’s tent and deliver the address:

*"This humble servant, [Name], in proper ritual position, respectfully bows and offers sincerest devotion, reverently addressing the Most August Master of the Three Heavens, Supporter of the Dao and Assistant of the Mysteries. This servant observes how the sincerity of the fast universally reaches all, completing the perfection of the altar rites. The blessings of the Dao spread afar, truly through the master’s sheltering grace. Reflecting on my own reckless presumption, I have received profound compassion. Yet this servant, dull and slow, shallow in learning, dares not falter before the altar but fears violating the ritual’s standards. Overwhelmed with shame, I can but confess my faults in this memorial. Humbly, I present it for your perusal. I earnestly hope for the master’s mercy and gracious consideration."*

**Presenting the Memorial**
*"The memorial has now been presented. May you pity this later student and forgive these deep transgressions. Command the bureaus of investigation to dissolve the records of faults. Notify the offices of assessment to record the merits of this fast. Gratitude wells within, yet no ground suffices to repay such grace. Gazing afar at your divine radiance as if still present, I now see only your retinue soaring through the sky. The altar assembly extols and bows in shared reverence, sending you forth."*

The *Hymn for Completing the Fast* is raised, as before.

Next, proceed to the Five Emperors’ tent and deliver the address:

*"This humble servant, [Name], in proper ritual position, respectfully bows and offers sincerest devotion, reverently addressing the Azure Emperor of the East, the Vermilion Emperor of the South, the White Emperor of the West, the Black Emperor of the North, and the Yellow Emperor of the Center. This servant observes how prayers to heaven and earth follow the ritual codes, and the completion of the fast depends on their scrutiny. Having fulfilled the nine mornings’ rites, all beings receive blessings. The fulfillment of good karma truly stems from your divine regard. Ashamed, I lower my head in submission. Yet this servant, of flesh and blood, with learning from mere hearsay, has trodden the altar and practiced the teachings while often violating the true canon. Though the fast’s construction is complete, I fear my transgressions are inescapable. Thus, I dare present my sincerest thoughts and respectfully offer this memorial. Presumptuously reaching your sagely attention, I implore your consideration."*

**Presenting the Memorial**
*"Having read this memorial, it has already reached your enlightened oversight. May you forgive the punishments for my errors and stay the might of investigation. Command the bureaus of records to erase my faults and the offices of merit to inscribe my good deeds, that my name may be marked. The ritual concludes, and your chariot is prepared. Unable to follow your retinue, I can but gaze longingly at your clear passage. The ritual assembly extols and bows in shared reverence, sending you forth."*

The *Hymn for Completing the Fast* is raised, as before.

Next, proceed to the eastern three tents. First, approach the Three Masters’ tent and deliver the address:

*"This humble servant, [Name], in proper ritual position, respectfully bows and offers sincerest devotion, reverently addressing the Most August Master of the Ancient Numinous Treasure Scriptures, the Master of the Numinous Treasure Registers, and the Master of the Numinous Treasure Salvation. This servant observes how the vast dissemination of the ritual teachings stems from your clear transmission, and the completion of the fast truly arises from your protection. Sincerity reaches heaven, and gratitude fills the earth. Bound in humility, I know my fortune; carved in bone, my gratitude is endless. Yet this servant, crude and rustic, slow in learning, has presumptuously held the office of proclamation and completed the rites of salvation. Though the affair is fulfilled, my faults remain grave. Thus, I rely on this memorial to confess my transgressions."*

With reverence, I now proclaim and present this memorial, humbly beseeching your gracious review.

The memorial is recited:
The foregoing memorial is respectfully submitted, laying bare my sorrowful sincerity. May the ritual teachings be upheld, and my faults and flaws be forgiven with compassion. May my transgressions be erased from the records of the Three Primes, and the merit of this fast be inscribed in the Nine Poles. May the celestial registers be fully reported, and the echoes of the Brahma-voice be gathered. Cloud chariots cannot linger in the mortal realm; feathered canopies shall ascend the heavenly path. This humble body cannot rise, yet the true conveyance is distant. The assembly of the Dharma raises its voice in praise, bowing together in reverent farewell.

The fast proceeds as before.

Next, approaching the tents of the Three Officials, the address is made:
This servant of the Dharma rank, so-and-so, humbly bows and offers sincerest devotion, reverently addressing the Most August Heavenly Official of the Upper Prime, the Earthly Official of the Middle Prime, and the Water Official of the Lower Prime. This servant observes how the recording of good deeds and the inscription of merit rightfully belong to the courts of the Three Primes. The completion of this five-day fast and offering is a fortunate fulfillment of the ritual norm. That this wholesome fruit has come to fullness is truly owing to the vast and universal grace bestowed. Were it not for the great creation, how could this humble servant’s private prayers be answered? Yet this servant, of feeble and withered capacity, with crude and neglected learning, possesses but narrow vision and thus commits many errors in conduct. Though the good cause is roughly accomplished, I fear hidden retribution. Desiring to implore pardon, I now present this memorial. Unfolding the memorial, I humbly beseech your gracious review.

The memorial is recited:
The foregoing memorial is respectfully submitted, hoping it may reach your true hearing. I beg a measure of leniency in the mysterious statutes and pray that my sins may be wholly erased from the celestial records. May the offices of the immortals be commanded to inscribe the merit of this fast. May the power of the Dao be magnified to extend its sheltering cover, and may its profound shade be boundless. Now that the jade altar’s rites are complete, the jade chariot cannot be delayed. As it is destined to ascend the empyrean, I can only gaze longingly toward the jeweled vault. The assembly of the Dharma raises its voice in praise, bowing together in reverent farewell.

Next, approaching the Mysterious Master, the address is made:
This servant of the Dharma rank, so-and-so, humbly bows and offers sincerest devotion, reverently addressing the Great Master of the Mysterious Center. This servant observes how the mysterious net has been raised, and the fast has fortunately reached completion. The numinous shade has manifested its trustworthiness, universally bestowing blessings upon both the seen and unseen worlds. In this, I rely entirely on the gift of life and accomplishment. Yet this servant, of petty and insignificant capacity, with shallow and limited learning, though supported to complete the affair, must have committed errors and violated the ritual codes. Hanging my head in shame, I bind myself and beg forgiveness. I now present this memorial, presumptuously laying it before you. I humbly hope for your true compassion, that you may graciously review it.

The memorial is recited:
The foregoing sincerity has reached the depths of your profound hearing. May the great pardon of your mercy be extended, universally remitting boundless punishments. May the merit of good deeds be inscribed throughout the Three Realms, and the blessings of this fast flow to the Ten Directions. The dusty and turbid paths are difficult to traverse; the immortal retinue abides in the mysterious celestial realm. As the numinous steeds prepare to depart, though my heart is filled with longing and attachment, I know that pursuit is beyond reach. Overwhelmed by your boundless grace, my sincerity cannot be fully expressed. The assembly of the Dharma raises its voice in praise, bowing together in reverent farewell.

Next, addressing the supervising deities, the prayer is offered:
This servant of the Dharma rank, so-and-so, reverently burns incense and addresses the supervising deity of the altar. I observe how the support and exaltation of the ritual net rely on the power of the deities who oversee the sacred rites. The solemnity and strictness of the altar’s precincts depend on the diligence of the earthly spirits in fulfilling their duties. Now that the great fast has reached completion and the rites of the immortal ceremony are concluded, the protection and defense, the summoning and proclamation, all stem from your sustaining care, and your labor in stationing and guarding has been weighty. Having already reported your merit to the heavenly courts and prayed for the advancement of your kind to the ranks of immortals, the subtle rites are now complete, and the divine conveyance cannot be delayed. Each returns to your respective abodes, resuming your numinous offices. Should there be future fasts, I shall again pray for your presence and favor.

The ritual proceeds to the burning site, where paper money, horses, and memorials are consumed.

**Burning Prayer and Hymn of Redirection**

The foregoing prayers and dedications are now redirected:
I observe how the Scarlet Writs unfold wondrous teachings, inexhaustibly aiding the world. The Yellow Registers and mysterious codes deliver countless beings. Today, the officiant so-and-so, with heart set on salvation and resolve fixed on cultivation, has established the Supreme Numinous Treasure Yellow Register Great Fast for five days and nights. He has prayed to heaven and reported to earth, presented memorials and petitions, burned incense and lit lamps, recited scriptures and performed the Dao, safeguarding the state and family, benefiting and protecting the living and the dead, conducted offerings to give thanks, and now concludes the altar and disperses the assembly. The majestic good fruit and vast wholesome cause have fortunately reached completion, all now fully accomplished.

I humbly pray that the nation and kingdom be tranquil, the realm and earth be at peace, the nine generations of ancestors ascend to the realms of goodness, and the six relations of kin be bathed in descending blessings. May the souls of the deceased, so-and-so, who are hereby commemorated, by virtue of this fast’s merit, come to know their past lives, forever escape the realm of delusion, and directly ascend to the land of purity. May those in the three paths be released from the toil of punishment, and those in the nine earths be freed from the suffering of bondage. May all who bear kinship and hold consciousness attain enlightenment and revival. May all who possess nature and form receive benefit and aid.

For the supreme karmic connection, I invoke the great sagely Primordial Heavenly Worthy of Original Commencement, the Most High Lord of the Dao, the Most High Lord Lao, the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions, and their inconceivable merit and virtue.

The High Priest concludes the rites, offers incense, and exchanges congratulations on the completion of the fast. He retires from his position, and the assembly disperses.

I reverently hear that the Dao cannot be named, and thus scriptures were established to propagate the teachings. The scriptures cannot be fully encompassed, and thus auspicious signs unfold according to the times. The primordial qi divides into three, forming the mysterious, original, and primordial three qi. The mysterious qi constitutes the Qingwei Heaven, known as the Jade Pure Realm. In the Dragon Han kalpa, the Primordial Heavenly Worthy expounded the twelve sections of the *Scriptures of the Cavern of Reality* in this heaven, from which the texts emerged—this is called the Heavenly Treasure. The original qi constitutes the Yuyu Heaven, known as the High Pure Realm. In the Yan Kang kalpa, the Primordial Heavenly Worthy expounded the twelve sections of the *Scriptures of the Cavern of Mystery*, from which the Lord of the Dao produced the texts—this is called the Numinous Treasure. The primordial qi constitutes the Great Red Heaven, known as the Supreme Pure Realm. In the Red Bright kalpa, the Primordial Heavenly Worthy expounded the twelve sections of the *Scriptures of the Cavern of Divinity*, from which Lord Lao produced the texts—this is called the Divine Treasure. Thereafter, in the aftermath of the Kaihuang era, the Three Caverns were proclaimed and disseminated, descending to transform the human realm. Since the era of the Supreme August, the multitude of scriptures and canons have flowed forth without end. The scriptures of the Three Caverns sometimes conceal and sometimes reveal themselves, now preserved, now lost. Were it not for the Uppermost Jade Capital of the Mysterious Metropolis, they could not be fully possessed.

The complete corpus of the thirty-six divisions totals 1,844,200-odd scrolls. Yet in the world, what is present is often lacking elsewhere; what descends later may conceal what came before. Since the opening of heaven and earth and the flourishing of the teachings, the human realm has never possessed the Three Caverns in full. At the end of the Qin dynasty, the Three Mao Perfected Lords cultivated and preserved the Supreme Dao, and the teachings of the Cavern of Perfection first began to sprout. By the Xingning era of Emperor Ai of the Eastern Jin, Lady Wei of Southern Marchmount transmitted the multitude of *Great Cavern Scriptures* to Yang the Director of Destinies, from whom they were gradually disseminated. In Eastern Wu, Master Ge the Immortal received the scriptures from Xu Laile, and the canons of the Cavern of Mystery spread widely. When the Orthodox Unity Heavenly Master encountered Lord Lao at Crane Cry Mountain, the teachings of the Cavern of Divinity were broadly expounded—these were their great origins. Beyond these, some appeared in other books, some were recorded in historical annals, some were bestowed upon individuals by special descent, and some were transmitted in accord with the times, emerging and vanishing unpredictably, now concealed, now revealed.

Between the Song and Qi dynasties, Lu Jianji, endowed with a spirit of numinous refinement, revived the teachings of the August Void, widely promulgating the Daoist canons and broadly opening the wellsprings of the Perfected. He distinguished the differences among the Nine Purities and Three Caverns, arranged the variations of the Five Methods and Four Auxiliaries, and discerned the true from the false, the refined from the coarse. Of the scriptures and decrees that remained, only 18,000 scrolls survived. Later generations referred to the "thirty-six divisions and eighteen thousand chapters" as the catalog compiled by Lu Jianji.

Thereafter, as the north and south fell into turmoil, the scriptures scattered and perished. During the reign of Emperor Wu of the Later Zhou, the Tongxuan Abbey was established to gather Daoist canons, still numbering ten thousand scrolls. By the end of the Sui dynasty, warfare raged across the land, the Central Plains were in chaos, and the scriptures were either burned or destroyed, their teachings nearly eradicated. During the Kaiyuan and Tianbao eras of the Tang, when the realm was at peace, Emperor Xuanzong began to collect and restore them, recovering only slightly over seven thousand scrolls. This was the time when Tang compiled the *Compendium of the Jade Scriptures*.

Before long, great bandits pressed in, the Son of Heaven fled into exile, and Daoist abbeys and jade palaces fell into ruin wherever they stood. Later, Master Guangcheng once again faced perilous times, exerting every effort to seek out and gather lost texts, supplementing what had been lost. Compared to the Kaiyuan catalog, less than half remained. After collating the scriptures of the Three Caverns, he incorporated the ritual codes compiled by Lu Jianji and Zhang Qingdu, weighing ancient and modern practices, carefully determining what was appropriate, and re-edited the *Forty Scrolls of the Yellow Register Retreat Rites*, achieving perfect accord and deviating not from the ancient norms.

He observed that while many scriptures had already been lost in his time, the situation was not as dire as it is today. After the book’s completion, he exposed the text to the heavens in a solemn declaration, and its numinous efficacy was manifestly revealed. Nearly four hundred years have passed since then, and none have dared to question or alter its precedents. Those who follow its rituals in practice have all received responses, with evident retributions too numerous to count.

After the Tang, the Five Dynasties descended into chaos, and the Daoist teachings were lost and regained seven or eight times. In the divided lands of the realm, some regions also revered and expanded the scriptures. Some built jade palaces, others compiled *Daoist Canons*, often incorporating whatever texts were available in their locales, resulting in many errors and corruptions. After the Song dynasty unified the realm and peace prevailed, Emperor Zhenzong commanded his minister Wang Qinruo to collate the Daoist canons. Yet the refined and the coarse remained indistinguishable, the true and the false intermingled, and errors could not be avoided.

During the Xuanhe era, Emperor Huizong promoted ritual codes, and the teachings flourished for a time. Yet the scriptures and orthodox canons could never be fully purified. After the Jingkang incident, when the court settled in Qiantang, the north and south were sundered, and Daoist scriptures became even more incomplete. When Master Guangcheng compiled the retreat rites, he resided in the imperial academy, holding concurrent offices of authority. The court’s archives, provincial and prefectural libraries, the Daoist officials of the two capitals, and the secret repositories of the two capitals were all at his disposal, and he could gather and examine them at will. Thus, his writings and treatises each had their textual basis, and later generations throughout the realm followed them without exception.

Today, the *Daoist Canons* across various regions can be counted in number, yet few scriptures remain free of error. Moreover, private transmissions and local copying make it difficult to rely upon them. Yet some, having obtained a few scrolls, esteem themselves highly, unable to distinguish true from false, claiming superiority over their peers and attacking the ancients. In their words and arguments, they even presume to alter Master Guangcheng’s retreat rites, though they dare not openly criticize them, instead subtly raising objections and making unauthorized changes. They believe that their privately transmitted "secret scriptures" place them above Guangcheng, unaware that when Guangcheng compiled his work, he relied on the power of the court to search and collect—how could the meager holdings of a single household compare?

Lu Jianji compiled his ritual codes during the Song and Qi dynasties, and Zhang Qingdu preceded Guangcheng, yet Guangcheng’s work never omitted their teachings or adhered solely to his own views. Thus, he often recounted where Zhang Qingdu had already discussed a matter or where he had followed Lu Jianji’s codes, demonstrating meticulous attention to both the grand and the minute, encompassing all details. For later scholars today to presume to critique him—it is doubtful their arguments could endure.

The scriptures privately held today cannot compare to those of that time. The present compilation of the *Numinous Treasure* strictly follows ancient methods. The *Yellow Register* fully adheres to Guangcheng’s codes. Though it may not conform to worldly customs, it can stand without shame before gods and spirits. As for the section on scattering the altar and setting up the offering, it differs slightly from the local customs of the Zhe region. Even the *Established Rites of the Yellow Register* by the Jiang family largely adhere to ancient codes, citing scriptural sources. Yet some parts also incorporate modern practices, such as scattering the altar and removing the mats before issuing the invitation memorial for the offering, then conducting the offering separately—this is merely a recent custom.

In the Jiang family’s rites, these practices are adopted from the customs of eastern Zhe, yet no scriptural source is cited for this format. According to the liturgical codes of the middle antiquity, the prostration, invocation of merits, submission of memorials, and the three petitions to mountains, waters, and earth spirits—along with the descent of the deities and the setting up of the offering—were all sent off together with the master at the conclusion of the altar rites. Only Master Lu of the Orthodox Unity tradition, in his observance of the *Yellow Register* rites, performs the submission of memorials and scattering of the altar *after* the offering, then sends off the master and concludes the rites together. The Orthodox Unity school follows different principles, yet Master Lu’s intent was to establish a standard based on ancient rites.

Though these practices differ from those of Jiangdong and Jiangxi, applying ancient methods in eastern Zhe conflicts with local customs. Moreover, the Jiang family’s *Established Rites* has already been published, and its conventions align with Zhe’s popular practices. Many will surely follow it. As this text serves as a public instrument for the world, I dare not alter antiquity with such changes. In time, may there arise scholars of profound antiquity and broad learning who will fairly assess these matters, lest they be easily dismissed.

The post-offering rites of sending off the master and expressing gratitude are the oral declarations of the High Priest. Though such minor details are not recorded in ancient codes, they remain indispensable at the altar. I, Yunzhong, have already composed and fixed these in advance, ensuring their proper use to prevent disorderly speech at the critical moment. This is not a case of mixing modern practices with ancient canons.

For the overnight invocation and the establishment of the altar, the nine-day purification fast, and all corresponding liturgical texts, refer to Master Guangcheng’s *Fasting Codes*—these are not repeated here.

Here ends *Scroll Forty of the Great Rites of the Highest Clarity Numinous Treasure*.
*Scroll Forty-One of the Great Rites of the Highest Clarity Numinous Treasure* begins.

The *Investiture of Dragon Tablets and Dispatch of Memorials* from the *Numinous Treasure Rituals of the Dongxuan Tradition*, compiled by Jin Yunzhong, Right Attendant of the Initial Prefecture under the Southern Bureau of Enforcement for Numinous Treasure Daoist Masters:

**Section on the Yellow Register Memorials for Liberating and Ascending the Spirits of the Lower Realm** states: Upon completing the rites of deliverance from karmic roots and the purification fast, in accordance with the *Red Writ Jade Formulary*, inscribe a jade tablet with cinnabar, attach one golden dragon and nine golden clasps, bind them with azure silk, and seal them within an inaccessible cliff. This serves as a pledge to the spirit immortals of the Five Marchmounts, a token of their ascension.

It further states: After concluding the rites invoking the Five Thearchs, inscribe a jade tablet with cinnabar, attach one golden dragon and nine golden clasps, bind them with azure silk to a stone, and cast them into the Three Rivers. This serves as a pledge to the Water Thearch, a token of ascension, strictly following the true text of the *Jade Formulary*.

It further states: Upon completing the rites for the Water Thearch, inscribe a jade tablet with cinnabar, attach one golden dragon and nine golden clasps, bind them with azure silk, and bury them at the altar site to notify and ally with the Earth Officials, all in accordance with the ritual codes.

The *Jade Casket of Luminous Perfection* states: When performing the *Yellow Register of the Numinous Treasure*, one should use three *liang* of superior gold to cast three dragons, each weighing one *liang*. The state uses superior gold, nobles and high ministers use secondary gold, while scholars and commoners gild silver. Accompanying the memorial, inscribe the purpose of the purification fast, the year, month, and day of the *Tai Sui*, and the name of the officiating master. These are to be cast into renowned grotto-heavens, numinous springs, dragon pools, or at the altar site to notify and ally with the celestial, terrestrial, and aquatic bureaus, ensuring the validation of the fast’s merit. Those who omit this will be examined by the Earth Officials.

The *Codes of the Nine Capital Bureaus* state: The dragon rides the clouds and qi, governs yin and yang, coalesces into form or disperses into patterns, its transformations unfathomable, descending into earth or ascending to heaven. Thus, in the thirty-six heavens—the realm of utmost yang—it serves as a courier to transmit messages and communicate with the mysterious and numinous. Is this not the role of the dragon? The dragon embodies the yang soul, hence its use in celestial affairs. The heavens employ dragons as steeds, traversing between the celestial and human realms. Gold, the noblest of the five metals, is unyielding and steadfast, treasured by heaven and earth, and capable of uniting with the numinous. Thus, superior gold is used to cast dragons in their likeness, which are then cast into grotto-heavens to notify and ally with the Two Primordials. The true officials and subordinate officers of the grotto-heavens transmit the dragon pledge and memorial, recording the meritorious deeds to be reported to the Most High Saints. The response to such resonance is as inevitable as a shadow following form. Those who perform purification fasts must not omit this.

The *tablet* (简) signifies notification; the *memorial* (札) signifies record. It records the good deeds of the age and notifies the Highest Perfected. Its length is one *chi* and two *cun*, symbolizing the twelve earthly branches; its width is two *cun* and four *fen*, corresponding to the twenty-four qi; its thickness is two *fen*, symbolizing the Two Modes. Its top and bottom are square and upright, representing the sun’s square shadow, straight and unobstructed, yielding to nothing. The state uses jade for these, as jade possesses the Nine Virtues and serves as a pledge to the celestial and terrestrial spirits, hence its use. Nobles, ministers, and commoners universally use hibiscus wood, its purity and fine texture comparable to jade, thereby distinguishing the hierarchy of honor.

The *bi* disk is the treasure used in rites for heaven, earth, and mountains and rivers, made of jade. For mountain memorials, a green *bi* is used, circular in shape with a diameter of two *cun* and a hollow center. The mountain memorial serves as a pledge to the Nine Heavens, hence the use of a green *bi*, symbolizing heaven and earth. For water memorials, a *bi* with six projections is used, black in color, with a diameter of three *cun* and a hollow center. The water memorial serves as a pledge to the Water Officials of the Nine Rivers, hence the use of a dark *bi*, the color of water, with six projections, the number of water. For earth memorials, a yellow *bi* is used, square in shape with a diameter of two *cun* and a hollow center. The earth memorial serves as a pledge to the Nine Earths; yellow is the color of earth, and square its shape.

The *bi* and dragon accompany the sealed memorial, bound with azure silk. The codes state: The method for casting the Three Memorials requires nine golden clasps to accompany each, totaling twenty-seven clasps for the three memorials. The golden clasps substitute for blood oaths, and the azure silk for severed hair, signifying the utmost sincerity in forging alliances. Thus, the clasps and *bi* are bound with azure silk, attached to the memorial and dragon, and then cast. The state uses gold clasps, ministers use silver clasps gilded with gold. Each clasp has a diameter of nine *fen* and is circular like a ring.

The codes further state: Upon completing the purification fast, select an auspicious day or a time of ritual purity, prepare the offerings, and let the master, officials, and the fast’s sponsor—whether by boat to a water grotto or by ascent to a mountain—arrive at the grotto-heaven. Clear the area outside the grotto of杂草, sweep and purify it, arrange the ritual mats, and set out offerings of wine, fruit, grains, venison, broth, and tea. The state provides sixty portions, while ministers and commoners provide twenty-four, all in accordance with the ritual protocols. Then, don ceremonial robes, perform ablutions, and pay homage to the ritual proceedings, strictly adhering to the codes. The local spirit officials and supervisory officers should notify the immortal bureaus within the grotto, transmitting the memorial of the fast. Thus, blessings and good fortune will swiftly manifest. However, one must not omit the notification and directly cast the memorial into the grotto, lest it fail to reach the true spirits and instead incur punishment.

If the mountain or water grotto is too distant for the master and assembly to travel together, select one or two ritual officers from the altar to accompany the disciples and memorial to the grotto. There, perform the rites of notification, casting, and offering, strictly following the prescribed protocols. For state rituals casting dragons at the Five Marchmounts and other mountains, refer to the *Golden Register Codes*, which differ in complexity from these ordinary rites.

One must not conceal or delay the memorial texts; the local earth officials will record and report such omissions, and the resulting punishment will be severe. Exercise utmost caution.

Three memorial tablets shall be made, each of paulownia wood, twelve inches in length, two inches and four fen in width, and two fen in thickness. Three golden dragons, each crafted from one tael of silver and gilded. Three jade bi-discs: the azure bi of circular form, the black bi of hexagonal form, and the yellow bi of square form, each with a hollow center measuring three inches in diameter. Twenty-seven golden knobs, made of silver and gilded, each nine fen in diameter, ring-shaped with a hollow center.
