I humbly address once more the high venerables of the Three Realms, the sages of the Ten Directions, the sovereigns of the river sources, the numinous spirits of the rivers and seas, the Fusang and Yang Valley, the immortal hosts of the Water Palaces, and all mighty numina arrayed upon the offering altar.

We reverently approach the numinous springs to perform the offering rites for the sponsor of the Register of the Yellow and the White, [Name]. The fast is now complete, the tablet cast, and the covenant sealed. May it be hoped that good deeds will be recorded and merit inscribed, transgressions dissolved and faults pardoned. For the fast’s sponsor [Name], may enmities be resolved, the register of life extended, the name struck from the ledger of death and inscribed in the book of rebirth. May transgressions be expunged, and renewal granted. May the nine ancestral lineages and seven generations of forebears be delivered from the roots of suffering, escaping the dark and cold realms of Yang Valley, bathing and refining, ascending to the celestial halls. May tombs be peaceful and auspicious, calamities averted, the whole family receive blessings, spirit and qi be purified and serene, learning and understanding be keen and bright, aspirations and wisdom be complete and luminous. May the true Dharma be propagated, treachery and malice subdued, the Three Realms attain deliverance, merit fulfilled and conduct perfected. May the emperor be secure and the state prosper.

We humbly present this supplication, praying that our petition be granted as stated.

We, the officiant and the sponsor of this rite, prostrate ourselves in utmost devotion, bowing twice in reverence.

**Final Offering**
The announcement text is declared, the document sealed with dragon, jade, and knot, bound in silk, placed in a casket, and perfumed with incense. Nine times the teeth are clicked, the incantation of the Primordial Supreme Perfected is recited, and the document is cast into the water.

**Hymn for Casting the Dragon Document**
The Heavenly Worthy imparts precepts,
The Most High expounds the true scriptures.
To uphold the Dharma requires diligent resolve,
Merit and virtue prize the spirit’s essence.
With sincere heart, we invoke the Three Treasures,
Burning incense to petition the hundred spirits.
Inscribed names cast into the watery abode,
Meritorious deeds ascend to the Supreme Clarity.

**Re-entering the Ritual**
We, the officiant of such-and-such rank, humbly reaffirm our sincerity, reverently invoking the lofty perfected and exalted sages, the immortals of rivers and seas, the administrators of the water realms, the rulers of the lower worlds, the assembled deities of the altar, and all mighty spirits.

We announce the completion of the document presentation and the casting of the dragon document, humbly receiving fulfillment and graciously bearing witness. The perfected of the upper realms have returned to the celestial palaces, the immortals of the water palaces have each returned to their divine offices, the functionaries and messengers have all resumed their posts, the local earth deities have returned to their original ranks. Merit is recorded across the Three Realms, and blessings extend to all directions.

We, the officiant and the sponsor, prostrate ourselves in utmost devotion, bowing to send them forth.

**Sending Forth the Deities**
The incense is replenished. The *Hymn of Learning Immortality* is recited, offerings burned, and merit transferred.

**Rite for Casting the Earth Document**
The earth document is buried in the ground before the altar.

If preparations are made in advance, a pit three feet deep is dug at the earth gate. After the merit-recitation and petition-presentation, once the three documents have been declared, the earth document is placed in a bag, sealed with green silk, attached to a golden dragon and golden knot, and buried—eliminating the need for a separate announcement rite. If time does not permit on the night of the altar’s dispersal, a separate covenant may be made, though the rite must not be omitted. Thus, this is recorded for use as needed. The arrangement of ritual positions and sequence follows the same form as the mountain and water document rites.

**Invocation of the Supreme Three Heavens**
Here, the local earth deities, the spirits of the village and soil, and others are summoned. Proceeding directly to the presence of the Most High, Boundless Dao of the Nine Lands, the August Spirit of the Earthly Sovereign of the Great Underworld.

**Addressing the Deities by Their Titles**
We, the officiant of such-and-such rank, together with all altar officials, humbly unite our sincerity to reverently invoke the Great Dao of the Primordial Ultimate, the Three Honored Ones of the Most High, the great sage assemblies of the ten directions who have attained the Dao, the perfected lords and venerable masters, the Five Elder Thearchs, the thirty-six divisions of exalted scriptures, the Great Dharma Masters of the Mystic Realm, the perfected of the sun, moon, and stars, the celestial administrators, the Great Emperor of Fengdu, the Nine Bureaus and Three Palaces, the lords of the Yellow Springs, the boundless world, the August Spirits of the Nine Lands, the Central August Spirit of Earth, the Five Thearchs of the Earthly Bureau, the officials of the Three Realms, the local earth deities, and all mighty spirits.

We have heard that the nine lands and nine regions are fathomless in their depths, the six heavens of the yin realms vast and boundless. Above stand the perfected of the Five Peaks, below are the myriad spirits in their offices, extending to the grotto-heavens and blessed lands, the immortal realms and sacred mountains—all establish bureaus to weigh sins and blessings, dividing governance over the registers of living beings. Moreover, in conducting this rite of purification, it is fitting to make covenant.

Reverently approaching the numinous altar, we beseech your lofty scrutiny. May celestial radiance descend to illuminate, divine chariots arrive from afar, this rite’s merit be inscribed, and our sincere prayers recorded.

We, the officiant and the sponsor, prostrate ourselves in utmost devotion, bowing twice in earnest supplication.

**Inviting the Sages**
The initial offering of tea and wine is made.

**Re-addressing the Deities by Their Titles**
We, the officiant of such-and-such rank, together with all altar officials, humbly reaffirm our sincerity to reverently invoke the Boundless Great Dao, the Most High Honored Ones, the perfected of the sun, moon, and stars, the exalted sages of the ten directions, the celestial administrators, the underworld officials, the august immortals of the Nine Lands, the assembled deities of the altar, and all mighty spirits.

We, though of humble qi and foolish nature, have by past karma encountered the true Dharma and auspicious causes. At the revelation of the *Lingbao* scriptures and the proclamation of the Red Writs, we, though unworthy and defiled, have reverently served the Orthodox Perfected, assisting the state and the times, establishing merit and propagating the teachings.

Now, on behalf of the Yellow Register sponsor so-and-so, we conduct the great Yellow Register purification rite, dedicating it to the state and universally delivering the living and the dead, seeking blessings and beseeching grace, dispelling calamities and repenting transgressions. For five days the rite is held, nine audiences completed, the altar dispersed, and the work fulfilled.

We humbly present the dragon document, reverently approaching the numinous altar, daring to reveal our sincere hearts and beseech your divine scrutiny. We dare to present the secondary offering to express our utmost sincerity.

We, the officiant and the sponsor, prostrate ourselves in utmost devotion, bowing twice in earnest supplication.

**Secondary Offering**
We, the officiant of such-and-such rank, humbly reaffirm our sincerity to reverently invoke the lofty perfected of the Three Realms, the exalted sages of the ten directions, the earthly administrators, the august spirits of the Nine Lands, the assembled deities of the altar, and all true spirits.

Reverently approaching the numinous altar, we conduct this rite of offering on behalf of the Yellow Register sponsor so-and-so. With the purification rite completed, we cast the document and make covenant.

May good deeds be recorded and transgressions pardoned. For the sponsor, may disasters be resolved and grievances absolved. We beseech the erasure of the earth document to remove the record of sins. May vows be fulfilled and lives preserved, the body safeguarded.

In the Nine Elder Immortal Capitals, may names be inscribed in the Jade Register. For the nine generations of ancestors, parents, kin of the womb and seed, the previously and recently departed, may all enjoy blessed causes, escape the nine darknesses below and the eight gates’ realms, calamities dissolved, tombs and homes purified, evil roots severed, and ascent to the halls of blessing achieved.

May our studies be perfected, our merit and conduct resplendent, sharing in the same fortune in life and death, forever preserved without peril. May the emperor receive blessings, the world know peace.

We beseech the fulfillment of these wishes, humbly making covenant.

We, the officiant and the sponsor, prostrate ourselves in utmost reverence, bowing twice.

**Final Offering**
The announcement text is declared.

The document is sealed with a dragon, jade tablet, and knot, bound with silk into the document pouch, placed in a casket, and fumigated with incense. Nine times the teeth are clicked, and the incantation of Heaven and Earth’s opening is recited. The document is cast into the earth and buried within the altar. Choose an auspicious day under the lunar mansion to open the pit and inter the document.

**Hymn of Casting the Dragon Tablet**
The ritual work is now complete,
The talismanic command announced to the sacred altar.
Jade tablets bear our sincere devotion,
Golden dragons swiftly transmit the pledge.
With reverent hearts we look to the Central Palace,
Returning our lives to the Yellow Circle.
In life and death, all find joy,
Soon to bow before the Heavenly Countenance.

**Second Rite**
The officiant, your humble servant [Name], respectfully reaffirms sincerity and petitions the exalted perfected, the supreme sages, the immortals of the nine earths, the administrators of the earthly treasury, the lords of mountains and peaks, the deities arrayed at the ritual feast, and all mighty spirits.

We announce the conclusion of the document presentation and the completion of the dragon tablet casting. Humbly we receive the fulfillment of our work, graciously granted your observation. The ten thousand perfected have ascended to the jade heavens, the host of sages have each returned to the central realms, the officers have resumed their posts, and the local deities have returned to their ranks. Blessings extend to all sentient beings, and grace covers all without exception.

We, the officiant and the sponsor, overwhelmed with gratitude and longing, now humbly bid farewell.

**Hymn of Sending Forth the Deities**
The incense is replenished.
The *Hymn of Studying Immortality* is recited, the offerings burned, and merit dedicated.

The method of casting the three documents is fundamentally for receiving the Central Covenant, for scholars seeking immortality, for erasing sins and casting documents to inform the Three Origins. If used for one’s own receipt of registers, the section concerning the sponsor’s construction of the Yellow Register retreat is omitted, and the following is appended:

Your servant [Name], in the year and month, respectfully approaches the Master of the Three Caverns [Name], to receive the *Five Elders’ True Writ of the Red Script*, the *Inner Sounds of the Three Divisions and Eight Luminaries*, the *Registers of Immortals and Two Talismans*, the *Eight Mighty Writs*, the *Five Emperor Talismans*, the *Central Covenant Scriptures*, and other texts. Upon completion of transmission, the dragon tablets are cast upon the sacred mountain, the water tablet into the clear spring, and the earth tablet into the central palace. The golden dragon swiftly transmits the plea to erase the records of sin. The remainder follows the same rite.

For cultivators of the Dao, on the Three Origins and Eight Festivals, to repent sins and invoke the perfected, the *Red Script Tablets of the Five Elders* are cast. The *True Writ Jade Instructions* are produced, and the document records the officiant’s title, the year, month, day, and hour of birth, the ruling deity of one’s fate, the mountain to which one’s name is tied, and the vows to become a spirit, an immortal, to attain eternal life, transcend the world, and ascend to the Upper Clarity.

The Perfected of the Five Peaks, most divine and numinous,
We beseech the erasure of sin records and the inscription of names in the Nine Heavens.
We petition the sacred mountain, the golden dragon swiftly transmitting.
In the year, month, and first day of the Tai Sui, the announcement is made at [Location].

For the earth and water tablets, follow the Yellow Register document format, recording only the officiant’s title and birth details. The sealing, dragon, jade tablet, knot, and silk binding proceed as before. At the ritual site, the casting is performed.

For the first casting, each document uses nine golden knots. For the second and third castings, only the dragon tablet is used, without knots.

The detailed procedures for Daoists casting documents are compiled according to the scriptures and have been presented in the *Jade Writ True Seal Chapter*; they are not repeated here. In the *Rites of Master Guangcheng*, after the earth tablet of the Yellow Register sponsor is read to declare merit, once the recitation is complete, it may be buried in the altar the next morning without further notification.

Here, following the method of Master Zhang Chengxian, the three-document petitions differ in the ranks of the perfected addressed, hence their inclusion again. If within the ritual altar, after the merit declaration and incantation, the documents may be cast immediately. This refers to burial immediately after recitation. For the mountain and water tablets, though the merit declaration is complete, if a ritual is held at the grotto, the sequence should be followed: recite the sealing incantation again before casting, ensuring thoroughness. One must not, having completed the altar announcement, proceed directly to casting at the mountain or grotto, lest the local spirits fail to receive the message. The merit may not reach them, resulting in great loss.

It is further said:
To deliver the good men and women of all heavenly realms from the Three Evils, Five Paths, and Eight Difficulties, enabling them to pass beyond the Three Evils and meet the Dao in every lifetime, on the Eight Festivals and Jiazi days, cast the three jade tablets to erase the records of past sins. Declare the merit to the heavens, and the matter will be transmitted three times through the Three Officials, Nine Treasuries, and various heavens, each relaying the message upward. All spirits will respect and protect, the Five Emperors will attend and guard, the administrators of the Three Realms will welcome, and the gates will be purified. The deities of heaven and earth, the sun and moon, will come to pay homage, while thousands of demons and myriad spirits dare not intrude. Wishes will be firmly established, and all endeavors will succeed. The seven generations of ancestors and parents will be liberated, ascending from the Three Paths and Five Sufferings to the heavenly halls. The blessings of life and death, good and evil, will be repaid in kind. The Three Officials and Nine Treasuries record human merits and transgressions, the principles clear, with karmic connections spanning lifetimes, leaving no detail unaccounted.

For the noble, the emperor, the ruler of the land, officials, all people, and the nine generations of ancestors languishing in the Three Paths, perform the great Yellow Register retreat for three days and nights. Pledge allegiance to the Nine Heavens, cast documents to the Three Origins, and the blessings and benefits will be immeasurable.

Listen carefully and practice diligently; do not be negligent, lest demons corrupt your body.

Master Daoist Zhang Chengxian says: Upon ascending the altar and receiving the Central Covenant of the *Numinous Treasure*, follow the *Scripture of Spontaneity* and cast ten golden knots, then the dragon tablet into the clear spring, as the path to immortality. Upon re-ascending the altar to receive the *Red Script of the Five Elders*, the *Two Registers and Staff of the Eight Mighty Writs*, and the *Vows of Resolute Faith*, follow the covenant’s true rite and cast three dragons with twenty-seven knots at the mountain, water, and dwelling, as tokens of the quest for immortality. Then, according to the *Jade Instructions*, separately cast nine dragons with twenty-seven knots on the Eight Festival days at the mountain, water, and dwelling, to erase the Black Registers, report names to heaven, and seek the removal of sin records.

Upon completing the Yellow Register retreat, cast the dragon tablet following the Three Origins document format.

Thus, these three memorials for the mountain, water, and dwelling each address their respective immortal bureaus, ensuring the erasure of sins, the inscription of names in the Nine Mysteries, and the elevation of one’s entire household to honor.

It is further said: The Great Dao, through the singular *qi*, transforms and gives rise to the Three Realms, shaping the myriad existences. Therefore, the Three Origins’ courts were established to govern transgressions and blessings—namely, the Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water, who truly preside over the Three Origins. Human life and death, longevity and premature demise, blessings and misfortunes, good and evil, fortune and calamity—all are bound to them. The Three Registers are likewise the canonical works of the Three Origins. The method of retreat requires casting three tablets to petition the Three Origins: the mountain tablet is offered to the celestial grottoes and palaces, presented to the Heavenly Official of the Upper Origin; the water tablet is cast into the numinous White Water Prefecture, addressed to the Water Official of the Lower Origin; and the earth tablet is placed at the altar or dwelling, directed to the Earth Official of the Middle Origin. Within the details of the tablet texts, the titles of the true spirits and the principles of the matter are made manifest and clear.

Now, the Primordial Beginning settled and stabilized, unfolding the Five Scriptures. Thus, the Five Elder Lords received the *Red Writs of True Text*, anchoring the root of Heaven and the source of Earth, descending to guard the Five Peaks and establish the Five Directions. This is indeed the root and origin of the *Lingbao* tradition, the pivot of salvation for humanity. Those who study the higher Way, aspiring to the Dao and seeking immortality, transmit the scriptures of the Middle Covenant and bear the *Lingbao* registers. They all inscribe the *Red Writs of True Text* in cinnabar upon hibiscus-wood tablets, write the memorials on their faces, and cast them into mountains, rivers, and dwellings, thereby forging covenants with the Three Realms and severing the roots of sin. Even at the Five Peaks, tablets are cast and dragons dispatched to extinguish transgressions and dissolve faults—this is their fundamental purpose. The matter is recorded in the *True Writs*, *Jade Instructions*, and various scriptures.

When conducting a retreat to establish a Yellow Register altar, upon the conclusion of the altar’s dissolution rites, one petitions with the three tablets for mountain, earth, and water, accompanied by golden dragons, golden knots, and jade disks, to record and inscribe the merits of the retreat and address the Three Origins. This method truly derives from and employs the *Red Writs*. Since Master Zhang Chengxian of the Tang compiled the *Retreat Regulations*, it has been explained in detail. When Master Guangcheng later compiled the *Yellow Register Retreat Regulations*, he exhaustively described the origins and ends of the *Red Writs* and the canonical forms of tablet-casting, rendering the matter luminously clear and beyond doubt.

In recent times, many have appended a talisman after each of the three tablets. Yet, as the transmitted ritual texts differ among individuals, so too do the talisman forms. How can one not know that the original intent of tablet-casting lies in the *Red Writs*—can it be practiced otherwise? Thus, the incantation for the mountain tablet reads:

*"Mysterious and luminous above, the Primordial Beginning oversees the true. The Five Elder Lords, the Red Writs in cinnabar. The origin of Heaven and Earth, governing the Three Origins."*

The incantation for the water tablet reads:

*"The Primordial Beginning and Five Elders, the exalted Lords of the Supreme. The perfected of the ten directions, the numinous immortals of Mount Taihua. The Red Writs proclaim the mandate, penetrating all, even the hidden."*

The incantation for the earth tablet reads:

*"Heaven and Earth unfold, the Nine *Qi* divide their numen. The grottoes of the Three Origins, the ten directions radiantly pure. The Five Elder Lords, opening the true and guiding life. The cinnabar writings of the Red Writs, the Primordial Beginning of the Highest Clarity."*

The openings of all three incantations clearly invoke the *Red Writs of the Five Elders*. Now, to replace them with other talismans in tablet-casting is to deviate from the original intent, especially when the incantations no longer align. Therefore, here we adhere strictly to the scriptural principles: the memorials follow the ancient forms, and the true texts after the tablets employ the *Red Writs of the Five Elders*. In meaning and text, they serve as the tokens of tablet-casting. This derives from the orthodox scriptures, unlike the private manuals of later masters.

Though ritual texts may vary by lineage, their fundamental forms must not be altered. Tablet-casting directly concerns the courts of the Three Officials, where the weight of transgressions and blessings is profound—particular care must be taken. All procedures for tablet-casting and memorial petitions follow the *Retreat Regulations* of Master Guangcheng. However, as these texts have circulated for ages, errors and omissions have crept in through transmission, often reducing them to mere opening and closing invocations. The core method remains akin to the *Jiao* rites. Such incomplete transcriptions force the officiant to improvise, risking errors in the moment.

To prevent this, the present text meticulously records the sequence: the proclamation of incantations, the kindling of the incense burner, the invocation of the gods, the three offerings, and the sealing of the burner—all in accordance with the *Jiao* rites, ensuring smooth execution. Written as a ritual manual, it facilitates recitation and avoids impropriety. The wording adheres entirely to the texts of Master Guangcheng.

*Highest Clarity Lingbao Great Methods*, Scroll Forty-One concludes.
*Highest Clarity Lingbao Great Methods*, Scroll Forty-Two.

The *Dongxuan Lingbao* Master of the Southern Bureau, Keeper of the Dharma Canon—Compiled by Quan Tongchu Fu, Right Wing Administrator Jin Yunzhong

*Transmission and Ordination with the Retreat Rites*

The Dao of *Lingbao* rightfully belongs to *Dongxuan*. Yet it encompasses the pivotal mechanisms of the Three Caverns and embraces the profound mysteries of all scriptures. From the time when the Perfected One Xulai transmitted it to Lord Ge Xuan, the teachings gradually became manifest. When King Xiaodao bestowed it upon Xu Jingsun, the ritual codes and methods reached full completion. It can stabilize heaven and earth, safeguard the state and secure the household, deliver the dead and rescue the living, dispel evil and uphold the upright, inwardly refine form and qi, outwardly gather the myriad spirits, effortlessly attain spontaneity, and merge indistinguishably with the Dao.

Thus, it is transmitted only to those deemed worthy; it is not passed on to the unfit. The scriptures state: *"The most devoted offer gold and treasures to express their sincerity, swearing an oath to heaven before transmission."* They also say: *"If there is one of utmost devotion who offers gold and treasures to pledge sincerity, following the old protocols to swear an oath before the Ten Heavens, only then shall it be conferred."* The presentation of tokens serves to embody sincerity, while the oath to heaven serves to solidify the vow. Between master and disciple, they drink cinnabar in place of blood pacts and divide a ring to signify their shared covenant. Though gold and treasures may be gathered, the heart must follow—proof of sincerity cannot be lacking. Those who are wealthy yet stingy are unworthy of transmission. Those who dwell in poverty yet delight in the Dao need not offer gold.

However, since the middle ages, as the Three Caverns have spread, the rules of transmission and reception have followed a graded sequence. Study proceeds in order; one must not presumptuously advance. First, one must receive the secret registers of all ranks of the *Dongshen* division and practice the various methods of *Zhengyi*. With unwavering resolve and merit in aiding others, one may then approach the ancestral altar to receive the secret registers of the *Zhongmeng* rank and advance to the highest grade of *Dongxuan*. Only then may one request sponsors and supervisors for ordination, submit a petition to the master, record it in the heavens, notify the Three Realms, and hold the altar rites for transmission, promotion, and practice.

The so-called oath before the Ten Heavens refers to invoking the *Lingbao Heavenly Worthies* of the ten directions and swearing an oath to heaven. The division of the contract and breaking of the ring pertain to the oath between master and disciple, not to the division of contracts with the Heavenly Worthies. Thus, there are the *Three Sovereigns’* wooden tablets and the *Simwei* contract for stabilizing resolve. As this pertains to the general teachings of the ancestral altar, such ritual objects should be issued along with the registers. They are not elaborated here to avoid overstepping the transmission protocols.

Following the *Lingbao* scriptural regulations, the *Five Numinous Tablets* and the *Staff of Authority* are to be used in accordance with the respective methods. The seals, swords, certificates, and promotions of this Dharma are not lightly bestowed in transmission rites, for they honor the primacy of the scriptural tradition. Thus, the Dharma concludes with transmission and ordination.

The disciple who inherits the Dharma must first secure sponsors and ordination supervisors before presenting incense and tokens before the master, submitting a petition that states:

*"The Dharma-rank holder, [Disciple’s Surname and Given Name], born on the [Day, Month, Year, and Hour] of [Disciple’s] original destiny, hailing from [State, County, Ward, and Residence]."*

Mindful that I, [Disciple’s Surname and Given Name], have long been nurtured by karmic blessings and refined through the transformative power of the True, I now bear the talismans and registers, standing in rank among the ordained. Formerly, I received transmission of [specific Dharma] from my ordination master, [Master’s Name], and have upheld it for some time, humbly sustained by his protection. Deeply ashamed of my lack of merit, I dare not falter in diligence. With reverence, I present the Dharma tokens and pour forth my sincerest devotion, bowing before the master’s sanctuary to petition for the transmission of the *Shangqing Lingbao* Great Dharma, including its talismans, charts, seals, and oral instructions. Should I receive this transmission, I vow to devote myself to its cultivation, redouble my resolve, and join in exalting the Mysterious Design, striving to propagate the Great Teaching. If, after receiving the Dharma, I were to lightly disclose or profane it, transmit it to unworthy recipients, fail to uphold its true and orthodox nature, mingle it with heterodoxy, violate my oaths, or betray my vows—thereby incurring the resentment of the Dao and the wrath of my master—then may I alone suffer the punishment of wind and blade, and may my nine generations of ancestors share the condemnation of Mount Feng.

I hereby submit this petition, with the endorsement of my sponsor, [Sponsor’s Name]; my ordination supervisor, [Supervisor’s Name]; and my ordination master, [Master’s Name]. Humbly I beseech the master’s compassion to record this transmission in the Celestial Register, file the petition with the Three Realms’ respective true bureaus, and open the altar for the transmission rite. Respectfully submitted.

[Year, Month, Day] by the Dharma-rank holder, [Disciple’s Surname and Given Name].

Upon receiving the petition, the ordination master shall invoke the August Thearchs and Perfected Ones, submit the petition for their consideration, and file it with the Three Realms.

**Petition Format for Submission**

To the *Jade Clarity Sacred Realm*, the *Most High Lord of the Dao, Primordial Heavenly Worthy of the Cavernous True*.
To the *Highest Clarity True Realm*, the *Most High Heavenly Worthy of the Cavernous Mystery and Numinous Treasure*.
To the *Great Clarity Immortal Realm*, the *Most High Heavenly Worthy of the Cavernous Spirit and the Dao and Its Virtue*.
To the *August Jade Thearch of the Supreme Heaven*.
To the *Celestial August Emperor of the Gouchen Constellation*.
To the *Great Emperor of the Purple Tenuity of the Central Heaven*.
To the *August Earthly Deity, Empress of the Earth*.
The above seven petitions follow the same format and are all submitted to the *Celestial Pivot Bureau*.

**Petition Template**

The Dharma-rank holder, your humble servant [Surname and Given Name], with awe and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice, respectfully addressing the throne:

Your servant, unworthy though I am of my rank among the numinous hosts, has long lacked virtuous conduct. I ought to reflect upon myself rather than presume to engage with others. Yet as the Teaching demands propagation, its affairs cannot be suppressed. Thus, I dare to present my humble sentiments, venturing to address the lofty heavens.

Your humble servant, holder of the Dharma-rank, respectfully submits this petition on behalf of the disciple of the register [Register Name], [Surname and Given Name], who hails from [Native Place] and holds the Dharma-office. With reverence, I report that this disciple was born in the year, month, day, and hour of his own fate, and is now in his [Age] year of life. Previously, he sought a master and received the transmission of the Orthodox Dharma. Having passed some time since then, he has fortunately been nurtured by the powers of life and growth, and has from time to time attained communion with the numinous. Now, he aspires to receive and transmit the Great Dharma of the Supreme Clarity and Numinous Treasure, dedicating himself to its cultivation and vowing to deliver both the manifest and the hidden. Should he ever reveal it to unworthy persons, thereby confounding the Orthodox with the false and the heterodox, he willingly accepts the severe punishment of Mount Feng and offers no plea in defense. Given this steadfast sincerity, it is fitting that the transmission be granted.

Your servant proposes to promote and appoint [Name] as a disciple of the Middle Alliance of the Numinous Treasure, serving as an officer in the Southern Bureau of Dharma Execution. At the risk of death, I record this petition and submit it to Your August Majesty. I humbly beseech the sagely compassion of the Heavenly Dao to grant my request, allowing me to confer the appointment and proceed with the transmission.

Your servant, having dared to offend the majesty of the Celestial Throne, trembles with awe and trepidation, awaiting punishment with utmost urgency and anxiety.

Respectfully submitted.
On the [Day] of the [Month] in the year of the Great Year Star [Year], your humble servant, holder of the Dharma-rank, [Surname and Given Name], presents this petition.

Among the seven petitions above, those that may be omitted for each august presence are to be enclosed in separate envelopes and all delivered to the Celestial Pivot Bureau, to be forwarded as follows:
- To the *Great Emperor of Longevity of the Southern Culmen*, enclosed and delivered to the Southern Culmen Imperial Palace;
- To the *Most High Savior from Suffering of the Azure Palace of the Eastern Culmen, the Heavenly Worthy of the Azure Palace of the Eastern Culmen*;
- To the *Heavenly Worthies of the Numinous Treasure of the Ten Directions* (ten petitions);
- To the *Nine Celestial Emperors* (nine petitions);
- To the *Thirty-Two Heavens* (thirty-two petitions);
- To the *Lord of the Wood* (one petition);
- To the *Queen Mother of the West* (one petition).

**Petition Template**
The Dharma-rank holder, your humble servant [Surname and Given Name], respectfully submits.
Your servant, with reference to the native place and the foregoing text, records this petition and submits it to Your August Majesty, humbly beseeching...

May the Dao’s Heavenly Wisdom and Compassion deign to grant this humble servant’s petition. Permit this servant to receive investiture and transmit the precepts for enactment.

This servant, in reckless presumption before the majesty of the Dao’s Celestial Throne, trembles with awe and awaits judgment in utmost contrition.

Respectfully submitted.
On the [Day] of the [Month] of the Year of the Great Year-Star, the Dharma-rank holder, your humble servant [Surname and Given Name], submits this petition.

All petitions to the Heavenly Worthies and Celestial Emperors shall follow this form.

The above twelve petitions are of uniform format. Whether submitted as separate or combined petitions, there is no distinction in weight or precedence. However, as each is governed by its respective celestial bureau, they must be presented to their respective offices. Thus, petitions to distinct bureaus—such as the separate palaces of the sun and moon or the divided administrations of the Three Officials—cannot be combined but must be submitted separately.

Additionally, the Flying Heavenly Divine Kings of the Ten Directions require ten separate memorials, each following the same intent as the petitions above. Their formats are not further detailed here.

Should the Preceptor not retain it, the right half may instead be submitted with a memorial to the Supreme Clarity Heavenly Pivot Bureau for verification, serving as proof of the disciple’s cultivation of immortality and study of the Dao.

To erase the record of sins and inscribe the name in the register of higher rebirth, revise the closing lines of the right half as follows:

Upon completion of the transmission rites, the certificate is drawn to seal the covenant, eradicating the roots of evil, dissolving the records of transgressions, and ensuring the disciple’s cultivation of immortality and study of the Dao shall attain perfect fulfillment. Year and month as in the preceding form.

*Form of the Rings.*

The ring serves to manifest the solemn vow, akin to the ancient practice of casting jade tablets in covenant. The ring itself is originally round and uninscribed. In contemporary altar traditions, however, the preceptor affixes their signature upon it, and the same is done during dharma transmissions. The ancients, embracing simplicity and eschewing adornment, valued plainness in all matters. Yet when the Perfected Official of the Dao compiled the *Orthodox Methods of the Celestial Heart*, inscriptions were added to the ring. Its text reads:

*"The Orthodox Methods of the Celestial Heart,
Revered by the myriad spirits,
Transmitted in covenant with Heaven,
Cyclic and unending."*

This, too, reflects the purpose of the ring, though it departs from ancient forms. As the Numinous Treasure constitutes the highest rank of the Cavernous Mystery, it should not follow common custom. The ring signifies the vow of fidelity. When Master Lu presided over the altar to divide the certificate, he did not split the ring, implying that once the certificate is divided and the covenant sealed, the ring need not be sundered. The disciple wears the ring to uphold the unbroken vow. Those of profound discernment should deliberate carefully on this practice.

*Form of the Inscribing Knife*
The inscribing knife is forged from steel as a sharp blade, its upper half sheathed in silver shaped as a dragon’s head. The same form is used for presenting memorials, its edge serving to correct errors. For dividing certificates, a blade is especially necessary. Modern practitioners fashion these from silver leaf, which is incorrect.

*Form of the Appointment Document*

**Bureau of the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure**

Upon verification of the petition submitted by the disciple of the register of transmitted methods, [Name], of such-and-such native place and lineage, the Bureau finds:

Born under the original destiny of his person on the year, month, day, and hour recorded, he has long relied upon good causes and received the refining transformation of the True. Having presumptuously practiced the Orthodox Rites and been recklessly enrolled among the ranks of the Numinous, he now steadfastly offers his sincere devotion and presents his earnest sincerity. Previously, he had already submitted a petition to the ancestral altar and been promoted to receive the secret registers of the Middle Covenant. Now, he wishes to advance further in transmission, receiving the talismans, charts, seals, and oral instructions of the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure of the Supreme Clarity, pledging himself to reverent observance. His vow is to succor the hidden and manifest, to sever poison and expel demons, and to assist the Dao and aid transformation.

Should he dare to intermingle heterodoxy or falsehood, confuse sacred texts, recklessly transmit to the unworthy, or frivolously divulge celestial treasures, he willingly offers his person in atonement to Heaven and Earth and the Three Officials of the Water Bureau.

As his oath is firm and unwavering, his sincerity unshaken, and his qualifications meet the standards for propagation, it is fitting to receive and guide him. Having already recorded and memorialized this before the Three Heavenly Thearchs and submitted documents to the true bureaus of the Three Realms, the altar shall be opened in accordance with the proper form, and the transmission shall be conferred facing Heaven. It is hereby ordered that his appointment be processed, and he be granted the secret texts of the original rites of the Numinous Treasure of the Supreme Clarity, along with the requisite seal, sword, scepter, and staff. The following items shall be itemized and issued by official document:

1. The petitioner, having already received the secret registers of the Middle Covenant, now advances to transmit the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure. In accordance with the statutes and regulations, he shall be promoted to the position of **Executive Officer of the Southern Bureau, Enforcer of the Rites of the Numinous Treasure of the Middle Covenant**.

2. One set of the **Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure of the Supreme Clarity** shall be issued.

1. Issue the following seals:
   - One seal of the **Bureau of the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure**,
   - One **General Petition Seal**,
   - One **Supreme Petition Seal**,
   - One **Yellow Spirit Seal**,
   - Three **Divine Tiger Seals**.

2. Issue the **Sword of the Eight Radiant Spirits**, measuring three feet and six inches in length.

3. Issue the **Five-Spirit Scepter-Staff**, to be carried and held in accordance with the statutes and rituals.

4. In accordance with the regulations, grant the **Disciples of the Cavern Mystery** the following:
   - A **Lotus Crown**,
   - A **Purple Robe**,
   - A **Yellow Skirt** with thirty-two strips and a **Yellow Cloak**,
   - A **Luminous Jade Scepter**,
   - **Jade Pendants**,
   - **Red Sandals**.

5. The **Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure** belong to the **Cavern Mystery** and serve as the pivot of the **Three Caverns**, constituting the supreme method of the **Middle Vehicle**. Their dignity and sanctity surpass ordinary regulations. All petitions, receipts, and administrations must be reported to the **Five Constant Demon Kings of the Three Realms**, and in accordance with the rites, official documents shall be sent to the **Flying Heavenly Divine Kings** of the respective domains. Whenever talismans or consecrated water are issued, the **Divine Kings** shall be dispatched, along with their subordinate **Envoys, Officers, and Soldiers**, to carry out the issuance and bestowal. The **Numinous Treasure** shall be served by the **General of Accordant Will**, who shall oversee the execution of duties.

6. When presenting memorials, entering the chamber for meditation, paying homage to the Emperors, and flying the spirit to initiate affairs; when burning incense, reciting scriptures, and praying for divine assistance; and when summoning and employing divine spirits, the following shall be duly invoked:
   - The **Three and Five Merit Officials**,
   - The **Left and Right Envoys**,
   - The **Golden Lads of Incense**,
   - The **Jade Maidens of Flower Scattering**,
   - The **True Talismans of the Five Emperors**,
   - The **Incense Officials of the Day**.
   They shall act in accordance with the rites and serve in accordance with the seals. Once the task is completed, they shall return to their original positions and respond to summons as required.

7. When summoning and capturing wandering souls, the following shall be dispatched in accordance with the statutes:
   - The **Divine Tigers**, the **Two Great Saints He and Qiao**,
   - The **Envoys of the Three Departments for the Pursuit of Souls**,
   - The **Jade Maidens of the Seven Offices**,
   bearing talismans and documents to carry out the task.

8. When performing purification rites and setting up altars, proclamations and talismans shall be issued, and the **Flying Heavenly Divine Kings of the Ten Directions** shall be invoked to descend. The **Talisman Envoys for Summoning the True and Divine**, the **Couriers of the Golden Dragon of the Mysterious Capital**, and the **Jade Dragon Post** shall receive the talismans and carry out the proclamations. Once the task is complete, they shall promptly return to their original ranks.

9. The **Divine Officials of the Numinous Treasure**, the **Jade Lads and Jade Maidens**, the **Heavenly Generals**, and the **Immortal Soldiers** are subordinate to the **Supreme Mystery** and are not ordinary functionaries. In accordance with the scriptures and regulations, they shall be invoked as needed to assist in the performance of rites. The **Dharma Master** must not shout, scold, or point at them, for these spirits are not bound to the mundane world or registered in the registers. One must purify the mind, regulate the breath, recite incantations, burn talismans, visualize with focused gaze, and secretly summon and employ them. Once the task is complete, each shall return to their original rank.

10. Any unauthorized claims of divine officers, arbitrary establishment of immortal bureaus, or mixing of vulgar practices with scriptural rites are strictly forbidden. Those who violate these precepts and杂用杂法 shall be forsaken by the oaths sworn to Heaven. Thus, the **True Scripture of Admonitions for the Emperor’s Brush** was compiled from the **Four Translations**, serving as the essential canon of the **Three Caverns**. It harmonizes Heaven and stabilizes Earth, bringing fortune to the state and peace to the family. Revered by a thousand sages, its benefits extend not only to the manifest and the hidden. Serving as a model for all directions, its blessings endure through past and present.

The dharma-successor disciple [Name], holding the rank of *Dongxuan* and transmitting the *Lingbao* scriptures, has privately sworn oaths and completed the transmission. The matter is not trivial, and the office is most weighty. One must forever steadfastly maintain singular resolve, secretly refine the hundred spirits, examine oneself and cultivate the body, never transgressing the statutes nor violating the precepts. In aiding others and benefiting all things, one ought to establish virtue and build merit. The Five Emperors and Great Demons observe one’s diligence or indolence; the Three Officials and Capital Prisons expose one’s faults and transgressions. Be meticulous, secretive, and devoted: when the ten thousand *qi* are whole, the Three Heavens bestow their summons. Be careless in leakage or negligent in reverence, and one’s own body shall fall while nine generations suffer abandonment. Maintain constancy in observance—let this admonition never be forgotten.

Thus, this document is issued.

**Transmission Master:** [Full Rank, Name] (seal)

For transmission rites conducted alongside fasts and offerings, if the host is of sufficient means, a prior petition shall be submitted in advance. On the evening before, an imperial edict-water purification of the altar shall be performed, with the fast’s procedures observed as in standard ritual. At dawn the following day, the altar shall be ascended to commence the rites. Over three periods, the Dao shall be practiced, the Perfected invoked in repentance, and gratitude expressed. The *Lingbao* three-day ritual texts may be employed. An evening offering for transmission is especially fitting. Yet, all too often, worldly practitioners limit transmission rites to mere offerings. Therefore, the present text sets forth the full transmission-offering liturgy, which constitutes the proper transmission of the dharma—an affair of this very tradition, not of the *Huanglu* rites. The details are as follows:

The offering mat is arranged with the Supreme Emperor at the center, flanked by attendant sages—either sixty or one hundred twenty in number. The Three Treasures’ stations are set in the middle, with the imperial brush placed as in fast-altar protocol. The Five Masters’ tent is erected to the left of the altar. The Perfected Lord of Wondrous Merit and Salvation, the *Taiji* Penetrating Responsive Immortal, is positioned to the right; alternatively, the Five Masters and these two may share a single tent. Petitions and memorials for the offering are arrayed before the masters, then dispatched.

The Daoist assembly stands in ranks before the masters. The *Zhiqing* initiates the ritual proceedings, while the *Gaogong* and the disciple each offer incense and bow. The *Gaogong* kneels to receive the memorial. The assembly bears the petitions in grand procession to the dispatching site, where a ritual officer recites incantations and performs purification. The *Zhiqing* initiates the ritual proceedings. The *Gaogong* burns the *Jiangzhen Zhaoling* talisman to transform the spirits and summon the generals. Next, the initial offering is announced. Then, the second offering is announced. Finally, the third offering concludes the rites. The transmission document is proclaimed. The *Gaogong* dispatches the missives. The disciple performs the libation. The burnt offerings are consumed. The preceding is concluded. Dedication and recitation of merits follow. The evening offering proceeds as usual.

*Concluding* **The Great Rites of Highest Clarity and Numinous Treasure, Scroll 42**

**The Great Rites of Highest Clarity and Numinous Treasure, Scroll 43**
*Compiled by Jin Yunzhong, Right Auxiliary Administrator of the Golden Bureau of the Southern Court’s Enforcement Office for Dongxuan Lingbao Dharma Masters*

**Rites for Transmission During Fasts**
**Protocol for Transmission Offerings During Fasts**

A Daoist of authority, one in number, performs the consecration of the altar and the exorcism of water. Next, within the offering hall, the Dipper Lamp is lit, and the *Huaxia* hymn leads the procession. The High Priest emerges from the oratory and stands in rank before the master. The High Priest and the disciple offer incense and bow in reverence.

Next, the fast is observed, and the master, the Mystic Master, the Heavenly Master, and the Preceptors of the Scriptures and Registers—Xu and Ge—are invited. The Cloud Chariot is raised. The High Priest kneels in reverence and makes the invocation. The *Hymn of the Dao* is chanted. Led by the *Huaxia* hymn, the High Priest approaches the offering altar, enters the Earthly Gate, ascends the Heavenly Portal, offers incense to the Ten Directions, presents incense at the Imperial Table, burns the talismans for summoning and invocation, and recites the secret incantations. Kneeling in reverence, incense is offered at his proper station. The Master of Ceremonies announces the commencement.

"I have heard that the hidden fusion of primordial *qi* first took form in the chaos of the beginning. The division of the Three Powers drew sustenance from the vast primordial kalpa. The mysterious grace is universally bestowed, the Dao’s sheltering shade encompasses all, the bellows and keys regulate *yin* and *yang*, and the potter’s wheel shapes humanity and all beings. Thus, there is no darkness it does not illuminate, and all prayers are answered. Reverently, we burn the incense of the Dao, the incense of virtue, the incense of Non-Action, Purity, and Natural Spontaneity.

We humbly present this offering to the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of Virtual Non-Being and Natural Spontaneity, the Most High Great Dao Lord and Heavenly Worthy of Numinous Treasure of the Cavernous Mystery, the Most High Lord Lao and Heavenly Worthy of the Cavernous Spirit and the Dao and Virtue, the Jade Emperor of the August Heaven, the Great Emperor of the Purple Tenuity of the North Pole, the Heavenly Emperor of the Star Palace of the Curved Array, the Heavenly Worthies of Numinous Treasure of the Ten Directions, the August Earthly Deity of the Rear Soil, the Heavenly Worthy of the Great Unity Who Saves from Suffering of the Eastern Culmen and Azure Palace, the Azure Lad and Dao Lord of the Eastern Flowery Realm and Upper Minister Wood Duke, the Great Emperor of Longevity of the Southern Culmen, the Golden Mother of the Nine Numina and Primordial Sovereign of the White Jade Tortoise Terrace, the Nine Heavenly Emperors, the Five Elderly Heavenly Lords, the Thirty-Two Heavenly Emperors, the Perfected Lords of the Five Fortunes and Ten Spirits and the Great Unity, the Eleven Luminaries of the Upper Clarity, the Filial Daoist King of the Solar Palace, the Filial Illustrious King of the Lunar Palace, the Nine August Star Lords of the Northern Dipper of the Central Heaven, the Three Primordial Lords of Heaven, Earth, and Water, the Four Sagely Perfected Lords of the North Pole, the Great Dharma Master of the Mystic Cavern, the Three Heavenly Great Dharma Masters Who Uphold and Assist the Dao, the Perfected Lord of Orthodox Unity and Quiescent Response, the Three By the power of this fragrant cloud, we universally extend our offerings. May the Jade Sounds gather *qi*, may the numinous winds assemble the mists, may the purple void flourish in splendor, may the myriad immortals be assisted, may those who hold registers and grasp scriptures together arrive before the Emperor. Grant that our petitions be conveyed, that our prayers be answered, that our exorcisms be effective, and that our salvations be accomplished. May the lictors and messengers, the flying dragon riders, distinguish and convey these petitions, delivering them in due time.

The matters having been presented, may they return to their stations within my person and resume their places in the palaces. When summoned again, let them arrive as before, in accordance with precedent."

Each announces their dharma rank.

The humble official So-and-So, along with the assembled altar officials, reverently and with one mind, present this memorial to the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of Virtual Non-Being and Natural Spontaneity, the Boundless Great Dao and Most High Dao Lord, the Most High Lord Lao, the Jade Emperor of the August Heaven, the Great Emperor of the Purple Tenuity of the North Pole, and the Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions.

Your servant has heard that the formless and nameless are the wondrous subtleties of the Mysterious Perfection, while the luminous and manifest are the numinous mechanisms of sagely transformation.

Before the cosmos took form, at the origin of heaven and earth’s foundation, there stood the primordial singular qi. It divided to nurture the Three Powers, governed the myriad spirits, and molded all living kinds. Thus were the primal principles first revealed, establishing the root and lineage of ten thousand kalpas. The Great Brahma radiated its splendor, disclosing the secret mysteries of the Nine Purities. The Three Caverns spread forth, and the Nine Grades were proclaimed. These served not only to assist the transformative mechanisms of heaven but also to manifest the essentials of the Dao. Through the opening of instruction by the venerated masters, they have been reverently upheld across ancient and modern times.

Your servant, though of humble and unworthy capacity, has presumptuously attached himself to the end of the ranks. Overwhelmed by the perfection of the supreme transformation, he has been granted a glimpse of the numinous texts. It is fitting that he exert his utmost to propagate the teachings, and dare not neglect his duties on account of others. Having received the admonition to purify himself and advance, he must now open the path of diligent cultivation of the Dao. The transmission is inexhaustible, thus fulfilling the intent of the great teaching’s accomplishment. To achieve a structured succession, one must pray for the scrutiny and grace of the exalted perfected ones. Therefore, gazing toward the azure heavens, he offers his sincerity; envisioning the White Jade Towers, he bows his head. Though his rites be coarse and unrefined, he ventures to address the loftiness of the Mysterious Ultimate.

May the five-colored clouds of the celestial ministers surround the flaming bells and flowing talismans. May the Three Flowers and the Yellow Path of Dao descend in chariots drawn by flying dragons and phoenixes singing in harmony. May the host of sages draw near, and the myriad perfected ones take their places. Your servants, a hundred spirits trembling in awe, with minds of singular purity, bow before the jade altar and dare to present this solemn offering.

**First Offering of Tea and Wine**
Your servant, with utmost sincerity, reverently addresses the Three Supreme Realms of the Void and the Natural, the Jade Sovereign of the August Heaven of Wu, the Imperial Throne of the Purple Tenuity, the Ninefold Exalted Ones, the Lords of the Three Heavens, the Thirty-Six Divisions of Venerated Scriptures, the Great Dharma Masters of the Mysterious, the Three Heavens, and the Numinous Treasure, the Perfected Lords of the Three Masters of the Registers of Salvation, the Divine Officers and Generals of the Three Caverns and Four Supplements, the Officials and Attendants of the Three Realms, and all the mighty numina.

Your servant has heard that the Dao is fundamentally wordless, yet it is established through scriptures and precepts. The teachings and transformations are transmitted through the revelation of dharma registers to deliver humankind. The Nine Grades and Three Vehicles interconnect and permeate one another. The Six Scripts and Eight Styles mutually elucidate and clarify. Transmitted within the heavens, they become the guiding path for the ten thousand kinds. Descended to the human world, they open the gate for all beings to cultivate and advance. Without the good causes accumulated over kalpas, how could one even glimpse the orthodox canon? Thus, only after the teachings are rigorously refined may one become a master. Only with a mind pure and lofty may one receive the dharma. By establishing merit and accomplishing deeds, one may above assist in the profound plans of the Mysterious. By disciplining conduct and adorning the self, one may within rectify one’s mortal nature.

The statutes and ordinances are of utmost gravity; transmission and empowerment are not to be taken lightly. Your servant, inherently lacking in good capacity and truly devoid of penetrating insight, knows not the source of refining the Five Sprouts and Three Primes. The Six Desires and Seven Emotions merely chase the waves of delusion. He ought to reflect upon himself—how could he presume to instruct others? Yet, having pledged his heart in solemn oath and ascended the altar to receive the precepts, though he dare not rashly divulge them, neither is he permitted to conceal and lose the transmission. Moreover, moved by earnest and sincere words, he wishes to be enveloped in the transformation of the orthodox and perfected. How could he, on account of his own inadequacy, ultimately suppress and reject this? Fortunately, the aspirant possesses the will, and thus he presumes to present this petition.

Though your servant is ignorant of the mechanisms of penetrating the true and attaining the wondrous, he dare not transmit treacherous and deceptive methods. In accordance with the eternal canons, he admonishes the numinous altar. Reverently receiving the reflected light of the exalted sages and gazing upon the presence of the supreme perfected ones, he ventures to lay bare his mortal sentiments and offend the august majesty. Having prepared the blue-green memorial and the jiao offering, he respectfully proceeds to proclaim it.

**Proclamation of the Memorial; Burning of the Memorial.**
In accordance with the words of the memorial, the sincerity and earnestness of the sentiment warrant reception and guidance; he dare not decline.

Thus, the divine chapters of the Numinous Treasure, the supreme grade of the Cavern of Mystery, trace their origin to the beginning of the Kalpa of Extension—unfathomable in their inception. From the dawn of the Kalpa of Dragon Han, their wondrousness gradually manifested. They coalesced the upright qi of the Flying Mystery, forming the hidden and secret numinous sounds. They issued the root and lineage of the Five Marchmounts, spreading and illuminating through the four translations. They pacify states and families, assisting the governance of emperors and kings. They harmonize yin and yang, aiding the workings of creation. The exalted sages and lofty perfected ones all attain the Dao through these. The submerged spirits and hidden souls of the departed are none who do not ascend thereby. Truly, they are the bridge for the ten thousand kinds and the model for the thousand spirits.

Though this canon is majestic and its transmission not to be taken lightly, its vast and boundless merit encompasses all without exclusion. Your servant, a foolish and ignorant novice, has presumptuously occupied the rank of master and preceptor. The successor of the dharma, so-and-so, is of mundane and ordinary capacity, yet has audaciously received the office of the immortal and numinous. His actions exceed his station; in principle, he is ashamed at heart. He can only pray for the compassion of heaven’s creation and further hope for the nurturing grace of his masters. May he be permitted to transmit and empower, enabling advancement and promotion. May the nine generations of your servants’ ancestors be absolved of their long-standing transgressions, and the myriad lives of their heavy faults. May their records of sin be erased from the black tablets, and their true ranks be early inscribed in the Mysterious Capital.

Your servants, alarmed by the increasing presumption of their offenses, yet following the prescribed forms of the jiao rites, dare to present the secondary offering to express their utmost sincerity.

Your servant and the successor disciple, trembling with awe, bow their heads again in reverence.

**Secondary Offering Rites.**
Upon completion of the offering, the *Ten Directions Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy* is invoked.

The successor disciple bows again and makes his declaration. This may be recorded by the officiant or led by the cantor.

The officiant of the Numinous Treasure Great Dharma, your servant so-and-so, with trepidation and reverence, bows his head and prostrates himself again, addressing the exalted perfected ones of the Three Realms, the August Thearchs of the Myriad Heavens, the Limitless Supreme Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthies of the East, South, West, North, Southeast, Northeast, Southwest, Northwest, Above, and Below.

May they deign to take pity and condescend to scrutinize and record. Your servant, blessed across a thousand lives, has encountered this singular opportunity to succeed to the dharma, advance in rank, and assume office. He pledges to forever uphold his pure resolve, never daring to betray his heart. Should he violate his oath and covenant, he willingly accepts punishment and censure. Today, he and his master divide the jade ring and inscribe the pledge, drinking the cinnabar elixir. He humbly beseeches their witness and permission to receive the empowerment.

Your servant, overwhelmed with gratitude and awe, prostrates himself in utmost reverence.

The Heavenly Worthies’ names are invoked. Master and disciple stand facing one another in their ranks. The High Master begins the declaration, proclaiming the precepts.

We reverently acknowledge that the Dao of the Numinous Treasure, the profound and mysterious lineage, strides alone through the Jade Capital, delivering countless beings. Those who receive it elevate the merit of nine generations of ancestors; those who cultivate it ascend bodily through the nine skies. It is the spiritual pivot of the myriad dharmas, the summation of the true teachings of the ten directions. Its majestic model of virtue is beyond all praise. Those who receive its dharma must surely cultivate it, observe the precepts that must be observed, and maintain their practice without fail—thus may they attain the rank of divine immortals. Before Heaven, we now proclaim and elucidate the Ten Precepts.

The First Precept: Never forget the Eight Poles.
Loyalty is the pole of reverence; filial piety, the pole of compliance; fasting, the pole of restraint; respect, the pole of ritual; magnanimity, the pole of breadth; generosity, the pole of joy; forbearance, the pole of harmony; endurance, the pole of wisdom. Heaven takes the Northern Asterism as its pole; Earth, the Five Peaks as its poles; a house, its ridgepole as its pole. Heaven, having its pole, can gather the host of qi; Earth, having its poles, can gather the host of forms; a house, having its pole, can gather the host of timbers. So too does a person, possessing the Eight Poles, gather the host of virtues. When virtues are established, the Dao is complete; when the Dao is complete, one’s vision naturally becomes clear and expansive, one’s responses naturally become harmonious and fitting—this is the foundation of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The Second Precept: Never forget the Mirroring Waters.
The mirror is an analogy for the heart; water, an analogy for nature. When the heart is clear, the myriad dharmas are all reflected; when nature is still, the Five Turbidities do not intrude. The Dao within a person is perfectly penetrating—it cannot be understood through obscuration, nor attained through restlessness. Through the mirroring waters, one awakens to heart and nature—this is the essence of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The Third Precept: Never forget the Daily Record.
The Daily Record is the means by which one examines one’s good and evil deeds. In navigating the world, people suffer from not knowing themselves, not hearing their faults, and not heeding advice. Without self-knowledge, there is no awakening; without hearing faults, there is no correction; without heeding advice, there is no benefit. Now, through the Daily Record, whatever one does that cannot be written down—these are one’s own transgressions. To correct them is paramount. Thus, the Daily Record becomes one’s uninstructing teacher, one’s unspeaking friend, one’s uncommanding sovereign and father, one’s unenforced code of law. It must not be forgotten—this is the aspiration of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The Fourth Precept: Never forget the Pursuit of Deliverance and the Pacification of the Realm.
Of those to whom one is close, none are closer than parents and ancestors; of those one reveres, none are more revered than lords and sovereigns. To repay the virtue of lords, sovereigns, parents, and ancestors—this is the Pursuit of Deliverance and the Pacification of the Realm. *Pursuit* refers to reciting scriptures and enacting talismans for the sake of departed parents, ancestors, and the six relations, thereby aiding their journey in the netherworld. *Deliverance* refers to reciting scriptures and enacting talismans for the sake of living parents, ancestors, and the six relations, thereby augmenting their fortune and lifespan. *Pacification* refers to reciting scriptures and enacting talismans to pray for the longevity of the king, the emperor, and the lord, to pacify the four quarters, to summon dragons and bring rain, to expel demons and eradicate toxins, to protect the people and all beings, and to avert calamities caused by the stars—all of which are encompassed herein. Whether one fulfills the aspirations of ancestors while at home or carries out the duties of office on behalf of one’s sovereign, there are manifold benefits and repayments to be made—all should be undertaken accordingly. Even the leaves of trees, when they fall, nourish their roots—this is the principle of returning to the root and reverting to the mandate. One must not fail to strive in returning to one’s roots and reverting to the beginning—this is the proper course of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The Fifth Precept: Never forget the arts of healing and salvation, with compassion as the foremost priority.
For all who are ill, enact talismans and recite scriptures with utmost sincerity to dispel their afflictions, as if they were one’s own beloved children or parents. In all matters of convenience, bestow kindness and grace to the fullest extent of one’s heart. If one holds office and administers the law, one must strive to accumulate hidden merit, enacting policies with leniency and fairness, reflecting thrice before acting and deliberating twice before moving. Whether repairing bridges and roads or planting trees along thoroughfares—anything that benefits the world—one should exert oneself to accomplish it. Just as a person’s kindness is rooted in the roots of trees, so too is a person who lacks benevolence no better than a beast. Thus, the orangutan saves the elephant, the righteous osprey wrestles the snake to rescue its prey—those who witness such acts may reflect upon them. This is the origin of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The Sixth Precept: Never forget the arts of refinement and cultivation.
Harmonize with Heaven and Earth, emulate the patterns of yin and yang, maintain thoughts of perfect authenticity without lapse, and with sudden clarity transcend all constraints, transforming without limit. Even among insects and reptiles, some abandon their terrestrial abodes to take flight, while others forsake their aquatic paths to dash away. If such transformations occur in creatures, how much more should they be expected in humans? This is the method of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The Seventh Precept: Never forget firmness and purity.
Firmness entails uprightness, refraining from improper conduct and licentiousness. Purity entails observing the precepts, not coveting improper sustenance. Refraining from improper conduct preserves the spirit and essence of the body; refraining from improper sustenance spares the lives of beings. Regard the wives and daughters of others as one’s own revered kin; regard the lives of beings as one’s own offspring. Thus, one’s spirit remains whole and grievances diminish—this is the substance of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The Eighth Precept: Never forget frugality and restraint.
In all things one seeks, one should recognize that they are transformations of the primordial ancestral qi of the Origin. To cleanse filth, water and lye suffice—no adornment is needed. To sate hunger, grains and beans suffice—no delicacies are required. This is the fortune of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The Ninth Precept: Never forget vows and covenants.
*Vows* are the good intentions one forms upon first entering the Dao. *Covenants* are the oaths one swears before Heaven and Earth after entering the Dao, which the gods and spirits oversee—one must not arbitrarily alter them. The precepts and regulations must be upheld—this is the mindfulness of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The Tenth Precept: Never forget one’s master and companions.
The master is the one who teaches; companions are those who admonish.

The teacher is like a father; the admonisher is as an elder brother. Having become father and brother, can one fail to revere and honor them, or cast them aside? This is the fundamental principle of the Numinous Treasure’s deliverance of beings.

The foregoing Ten Precepts were transmitted by the master and expounded from the ancient scriptures. The scriptures contain the mechanism of the Dao; the methods are the application of the scriptures. To follow the orthodox teaching, diligent practice comes first. Uphold and enact them without slackening midway. Countless generations of ancestors—suffering souls in the hidden realms—shall all receive deliverance and ascend to the Vermilion Palace. The more diligently one practices and the more tirelessly one studies, the sooner one’s merit will be fulfilled and one’s attainment achieved. All may become divine immortals, soaring to the Golden Portal and roaming in the Jade Capital. Strive earnestly in this.

Next: The Division of the Ring Contract
The ring contract serves to swear oaths before the Three Officials, to pledge allegiance to the Ten Heavens, and to affirm enduring fidelity. The ordaining master must not conceal truth or disseminate falsehood; the disciple must not betray the Dao or forsake the master. The divided ring ensures the covenant remains unbroken; the torn contract ensures the vow is never violated. Those who begin with diligence but end in slackness shall have their transgressions recorded by the Five Emperors. Those who respectfully uphold their practice with devotion shall share in the blessings of the Nine Heavens.

Before the sacred presences, the contract is received and treasured for life. Next, the disciple and the ordaining master together take up the vermilion brush. The memorial and ring contract are each placed in their respective pouches.

The ordaining master says: *Turn the brush toward Heaven.*
The disciple responds: *I shall not betray Heaven. If I betray Heaven, may my seven generations suffer punishment. If Heaven betrays me, may the sun and moon lose their light.*

The ordaining master says: *Turn the brush toward Earth.*
The disciple responds: *I shall not betray Earth. If I betray Earth, may my body suffer the blade. If Earth betrays me, may grass and trees cease to grow.*

The ordaining master says: *Turn the brush toward the heart.*
The disciple responds: *I shall not betray my heart. If I betray my heart, may my family line perish. If my heart betrays me, may the transformation of the Dao cease to unfold.*

Next, the ordaining master holds a water vessel and brush, declaring: *The transmission is now complete. We renew our oath with a blood covenant, substituting cinnabar for blood. Each must steadfastly uphold their resolve. Drink this cinnabar essence to commune with the divine and penetrate the hidden, to harmonize the five qi within, and unite the hundred spirits. Ten revolutions return the numinous; ten thousand qi coalesce into immortality.*

The master, disciple, and Daoist assembly each return to their ranks and original positions. The High Master again addresses the sacred, presenting the official certificate to supplement the transmission. The memorial is recited, and the certificate of office is proclaimed before the sacred.

The disciple kneels and receives the memorial, ring contract, and certificate. Holding the contract, the disciple declares:
*This humble one is dull-witted by nature, of base endowment. By error, I have received Heaven’s grace and presumptuously advanced upon the immortal ranks. Having divided the ring and torn the contract, I have pledged oaths and sworn covenants. Before Heaven, I have received office and been granted favor beyond my deserts. Dare I not redouble my resolve and forever abide in the orthodox teaching? Should I violate this pledge, I submit to the profound statutes.*

*Overwhelmed by gratitude, I am moved to the utmost. With reverence, I bow my head in gratitude.*

The High Master proclaims the statutes:
*With utmost sincerity, I humbly invoke the Three Pure Ones, the Supreme Emperor; the Nine August Perfected; the divine administrators of the Three Realms; the sacred assemblies of the Ten Directions; the deities arrayed in the ritual altar; and all majestic numina.*

*I have heard that the Dao flourishes through people, and the Dharma is transmitted by masters. Unbroken succession enables the true wind to spread; boundless dissemination allows the great teaching to shine forth. It guides later generations from darkness toward light, elevates the people onto the path of reform and distance from transgression. To achieve the work of aiding the upright, delivering beings is paramount.*

*Yet this humble one is of dull capacity and foolish nature. My learning has not reached the perfected ones, nor has my path encountered true transmission. Presumptuously undertaking ordination, I have gravely failed in ritual propriety. How could I have expected the myriad sages to extend their compassion, the host of perfected to grant their protection? Without rejecting my lowliness, they have graciously bestowed forbearance, allowing me to proceed with the rites despite my inadequacy, enabling me to complete the transmission with their support. The division of the ring, the tearing of the contract, the swearing of oaths, the presentation of memorials before the altar, the drinking of cinnabar, and the receipt of office—though the ritual forms are roughly prepared, I am deeply indebted to their grace.*

*I am ashamed that my offerings lack full sincerity and purity, and that the rites of the altar are not perfectly refined. The ritual space is not grand; my entreaties fall short of proper form. If you pity my ignorance, I may be pardoned; if my faults are recorded, I cannot escape. I beseech your boundless mercy to universally forgive the punishment for my reckless folly.*

*May this humble one and my dharma-heirs soon encounter the wondrous essence and awaken to the numinous mechanism. May our cultivation proceed without obstruction, and may our talismans and methods receive the aid of the divine. May our breath and invocation find response, and our petitions reach fulfillment. May our bodies attain the true Dao, and our names be inscribed on the cinnabar tablets. Below, may we and our karmic burdens together rely on your grace.*

*Above, may the Dao and its methods flourish, and the true statutes spread widely. May Heaven be clear and Earth tranquil, the sun radiant and the moon bright. May the altars of state and ancestral temples, along with the former sages, ascend to the halls of eternal sunlight and roam the courts of the great desert. May blessings extend to the imperial domain and felicity flow to the divine descendants. May the present emperor receive the blessings of Heaven and Earth, his years equaling Mount Song and Mount Hua. For a hundred million years, may boundless fortune endure. For a thousand myriad generations, may auspicious omens manifest. May the realm be profoundly at peace, the frontiers serene. May the five weapons remain unused, the six qi harmonized. May crops flourish abundantly, and the people enjoy well-being.*

*May those who dwell in hidden valleys and rocky peaks, who cultivate truth and advance the Dao, complete their merit and soon receive the summons of the Nine Heavens. May they ascend in spirit and refine their forms, becoming ministers of the Three Realms.*

*Next, I pray for the ancestral spirits of this humble one, the departed masters and teachers, and all who have known their past lives. May they swiftly transcend the dark realms and awaken to the true origin, ascending to the realms of carefree wandering. May the Six Heavens and Ten Lands, the Three Paths and Nine Netherworlds, all be bathed in imperial radiance and receive the healing of primordial harmony. May punishments and torments cease, and entangling grievances be resolved. May wandering souls and flying spirits without refuge, sunken souls and lost spirits yet undelivered, be awakened and universally attain peace. May they be endowed with form, receive life with emotion, and assume their destined natures.*

*May feathered, furred, scaled, and shelled creatures; grasses, trees, and insects—all avoid untimely harm and together attain the principle of life.*

We, your humble servants, deeply ashamed of our repeated trespasses, dare not detain the assembled Perfected. We now offer our final private devotion, hoping to intoxicate ourselves with gratitude for your boundless grace. We, along with our disciples, tremble in awe, prostrating ourselves again in reverence.

**Final Offering Ritual**
We, your devoted servants, humbly and earnestly invoke the High Perfected of the Great Dao, the August Saints of the Jade Heavens, and all majestic spirits overseeing this altar and salvation. We have heard that the Dao, though formless, responds with perfect benevolence, and that Heaven, though lofty, heeds the lowly. Thus, this altar of transmission and salvation is specially blessed by your presence and observation. Yet we, in our presumption, have dared to disturb the celestial hearing and lightly profaned the divine majesty. Our fear and trepidation run deep, leaving us shaken and at a loss. We humbly implore your forbearance and gracious pardon.

Now that the rites of transmission are complete and the ceremonial offerings concluded, the realms of immortals and mortals must part, and the protective guardianship cannot remain. The clear processional music fades as the jade chariot departs. The purple clouds withdraw their radiance, no longer tracing the path of the imperial carriage. The officers return to their posts, the Perfected spirits resume their stations, and we are left only with longing and attachment, yearning for your presence. Fixing our thoughts upon the celestial steps, we bow a hundred times in farewell.

**Hymn of Sending Forth the Spirits, Receiving the Mandate, and Restoring the Incense Burner**
Exiting the altar, we proceed to the master’s tent. The High Priest kneels in reverence to express gratitude for the master’s teachings.
