The purification fast concludes, the cloud chariot is invoked, and the offerings are burned. As before, we pour libations of wine. We reflect on virtue, express thanks to the master, exchange congratulations, and withdraw.

We have long heard that the Dao is rarely encountered. Since the middle ancient era, ritual codes and teachings have flourished, yet the Great Dao has grown obscure. As the world declined further, techniques and arts proliferated, branching into many paths and becoming increasingly fragmented and impure.

The Three Caverns’ scriptures trace their lineage to the Han-era Celestial Master, who propagated the Orthodox Unity tradition, from which the Heavenly Heart Orthodox Rites emerged. When the Celestial Master received the seal and sword at the Jade Bureau and purged the realm of malevolent anomalies, the efficacy of the rites in aiding the times was truly magnificent. The Heavenly Heart Spring Writs endured the upheavals of the Wei and Jin dynasties and the division of the Northern and Southern regimes, scattering and falling into obscurity until they were nearly lost to record.

After the Five Dynasties, Masters Tan and Rao successively inherited and compiled the teachings into texts. Though they claimed the Three Talismans and Two Seals as their foundation, their titles, ranks, formats, and terminology all departed from the Han system. Even their celestial statutes and ghostly ordinances introduced penalties such as three years of penal servitude and one hundred strokes of the rod. Such terms as penal servitude and caning were established only during the Later Zhou’s Xiande era, not in the original texts of the Han Celestial Master. The Han punishments—such as three hundred or two hundred strokes of the cane—differed from later practices.

We have heard that Master Rao was well-versed in the affairs of the netherworld. Perhaps he sought to use secular conventions to admonish and inspire the world, or he may have had other insights. During the transmission rites, he issued immortal decrees to appoint officials in the netherworld. The secular system thus influenced the Yuanmiao Tradition, which adopted and codified his methods.

At the beginning of the Shaoxing era, the Daoist official Lu reorganized the Heavenly Heart Rites, further incorporating secular conventions. Master Lu, a scholar of great talent and erudition, composed the ritual codes for transmission and prefaced each of the ten volumes of his system with a treatise, surpassing all predecessors in precision and insight. Yet his vision was partial: he ranked the Celestial Master alongside the August Emperor, an act of presumption in the hierarchy of reverence. He placed the Heavenly Worthy alone above the myriad Perfected, a deviation from principle that is truly regrettable.

Regarding the issuance of immortal decrees, Master Lu departed from precedent, providing only appointment certificates rather than full mandates—a far more appropriate approach. In the human world, official ranks are conferred by the sovereign, and appointment documents are issued accordingly. Even when high ministers act on their own authority to fill vacancies, they issue only provisional certificates, not formal mandates, which require the sovereign’s command.

The transmission of Daoist teachings follows ritual codes with established forms, which we adhere to in practice. Yet these rites do not involve direct audience with the August Emperor or the public receipt of celestial decrees. They merely record the petitions and proceed with transmission according to the prescribed ceremonies, issuing appointment certificates even within the ancestral altars. How, then, can the affairs of the netherworld fully adopt secular formats, with unauthorized mandates issued at will? Such practices are truly untenable. This issue is particularly evident in the Heavenly Heart tradition.

In the Lingbao Great Rites, from Master Ge’s expansive transmission of scriptures to Master Xu’s comprehensive systematization of methods, even the Primordial Unity tradition took Master Xu as its patriarch. The Pure Rites and Esoteric Rites, though branching from the Lingbao tradition, never exhibited such bizarre and irregular practices.

After the Shaoxing era, the Lingbao rites of Tiantai spread through eastern Zhejiang, becoming even more adulterated with falsehoods than the Heavenly Heart tradition. For instance, the scriptures prescribe a ritual of pledging allegiance to the Ten Heavens, wherein one presents a golden treasure to the master, invokes the Ten Directions, and takes an oath. The words spoken are binding, for Heaven does not deceive. The intent is to solemnize the matter and prevent irreverence.

The golden treasure has no fixed number. In the ritual of pledging allegiance to Heaven and transmitting the teachings, master and disciple fast together, swear their oath, and divide a contract. This ensures that the master does not conceal the truth and the disciple does not betray the master—such is the meaning of the rite.

Yet in the Tiantai Lingbao tradition’s *Registers and Contracts of Seals*, ten pieces of yellow silk are inscribed in vermilion with the disciple’s name and the invocation: “Your disciple so-and-so bows to the Jade Treasure August Heavenly Worthy of the Eastern Direction.” The Ten Directions each follow the Heavenly Worthy’s sacred titles from the *Sutra of Salvation from Suffering*. During the transmission, the sacred titles of the Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions are split down the middle, a practice called “pledging allegiance to the Ten Heavens.”

In secular documents, terms like *ganshe* (interference), *chengxing* (impetuous conduct), *gongjin* (palace prohibitions), and *bibao* (brush and carriage) are written with omitted strokes to show deference to the sovereign. How, then, can the sacred titles of the Heavenly Worthies be split down the center? Furthermore, the contract format arranges the scriptures and registers of the transmission master in proper order at the top, while the names of the disciple’s parents and three generations are written in reverse order at the bottom, a style called the *Three Heavens Textual Contract*. Ancient rites invoked the nine generations of ancestors in oaths, praying to Heaven.

Should this disciple attain enlightenment, let the nine generations of ancestors share in the punishment—such is the gravity of this covenant. Yet to inscribe the contract and invert it at the bottom—how can this be? Who devised such a grotesque distortion? They know not that the titles of the Heavenly Worthies are not texts to be split asunder, nor are one’s ancestors objects to be upended. If this can be tolerated, what cannot?

The remaining protocols may be inferred by analogy. Fearing that men of virtue might fail to trace the source and thus fall into transgression, I have expounded upon this at length.

The division of contracts arises from the mutual apprehension between master and disciple, lest either betray the other. Yet when has the Heavenly Worthy ever betrayed you? The Heavenly Worthy does not enter into contracts with mortals. The contract above merely embodies the sincerity of mutual accord, with a talisman placed at the point of division—nothing more.

In the *Lingbao* rites before the altar, the invocation is directed to the Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions. What is compiled herein adheres strictly to ancient forms: the issuance of certificates for office and the supplementation of ranks follow old precedents. As for the wording at the end of the certificates, since it pertains to the principles of the Dao, I have composed it accordingly. If embellishment is desired, it may be altered at will, but the established protocols are not of my own invention.

The marshals and scribes of the Dao all belong to the Supreme Mystery. They are not generals under Heaven’s Heart Orthodox Rites, dispatched to command troops beneath the sacred peaks. Rather, they are summoned through the examination of various methods, which may be interchanged as needed—this pertains to those invoked for specific occasions.

In the Tiantai tradition, scriptural passages are corrupted to serve as names for marshals, officials, and bureaus, all concocted from baseless conjecture. This has already been thoroughly refuted in the *Rankings of the Three Realms’ Palace Offices*; one must not perpetuate error by blindly adopting such practices.

The certificates briefly outline the method and the marshals or scribes to be summoned, serving to complete the ritual protocols. These are not examples of interchangeable summons but follow established precedents. To imitate the imperial court by privately fabricating edicts and decrees is utterly impermissible—those of discernment must take heed.

The Heaven’s Heart Orthodox Rites have long been confounded, and the sacred writ of *Lingbao* must not follow vulgar custom. As for transmission rites, many have recently added the *Ten Heavens’ Pledge of Allegiance*, introducing a profusion of miscellaneous ceremonies that vary across regions, none of which derive from the original scriptures or ancient canons. They must not be employed lightly.

In the transmission of precepts and the performance of rituals, some use the texts of the Heaven’s Heart transmission, while others intersperse invocations from unrelated rites—this diverges entirely from the proper conduct of *Lingbao* great rites. Though such phrases may appear in ancient methods, their protocols remain incomplete. Here, I have collated and revised them in accordance with the original canons, aligning them with the principles of the Dao, lest one stand before the Celestial Thearch speaking of one matter while the ritual pertains to another.

Lineages and their origins each have their proper authorities. If one does not transmit the methods of this tradition yet employs the protocols I have compiled, the mismatch will be glaring. Those outside this lineage would do well to devise their own.

Here ends *The Great Rites of Shangqing Lingbao*, Scroll Forty-Three.
*Here begins The Great Rites of Shangqing Lingbao*, Scroll Forty-Four.

The Master of Dongxuan Lingbao Rituals, Jin Yunzhong of the Southern Bureau’s Enforcement Office—Holder of the Right Assistant Governance of the Novice’s Initial Prefecture—compiles the *Refinement and Salvation* rites.

The High Priest first approaches before the Celestial Thearch to present matters in secret petition. Then, withdrawing, he proceeds to the southeast side of the ritual arena and arranges the seat according to protocol.

**Invocation of Incense**
This incense is endowed with numinous essence and refined fragrance, its substance planted in purity. It serves to convey the heart of reverence and devotion, ascending to reach the realm of the Void and the Subtle. Auspicious mists rise, moving the Nine Heavens to respond; propitious smoke spreads, its scent pervading the Three Realms.

With the first pinch of incense now offered, we make obeisance to the Boundless Dao and the Supreme Perfected of the Celestial Thearch. Through this merit, may it ascend to benefit the august spirits of our ancestral temples and the sagely forebears of the altars of soil and grain. May the divine souls ascend to the Purple Ultimate, the imperial destiny flow with blessings, the succession of sages endure without end, and the divined years stretch long. May the Emperor of this day attain a lifespan equal to heaven and earth, his fortune vast as the deep sea. May all beings revive, and the ten directions know peace and prosperity.

With the second pinch of incense now offered, we make obeisance to the sun, moon, and stars, the sovereigns of the celestial bureaus, the scriptures and registers of the Three Caverns, and the sagely assembly within the Dharma. Through this merit, may it be dedicated to the Ritual Officer so-and-so and their kin—nine generations of ancestors, seven lineages of forebears, the five clans and six relations, the recently departed spirits, the long-deceased souls, the soul of so-and-so being delivered, and all wandering spirits of the ten thousand kinds in the dark realms, the lonely souls of the Five Paths. We humbly pray that they awaken to their roots and know their origins, emerge from delusion into enlightenment, traverse the shadowy gates and hidden roads, and attain clarity and fulfillment. May they dwell in joy forever, whether in heaven or among humanity.

With the third pinch of incense now offered, we make obeisance to the true numina of earth and water, the sovereigns of the sacred peaks and rivers, the ranked sages of the ten directions, and the officials of the Three Realms. Through this merit, may it flow back to benefit the Ritual Officer so-and-so and their present kin, their families and dependents. May they be blessed with abundant fortune and renewed longevity. May all receive the grace of nurturance and be transformed by the Void and the Subtle. May the animate and inanimate alike flourish, and all beings attain their full growth.

Next, we invoke the August Heavenly Thearch. Your servant, the Dharma-ranked official So-and-so, now prostrates twice and petitions the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of Vacuity and Spontaneity, the Most High Dao Lord, the Most High Lord Lao, the Jade Emperor of the Luminous Heaven, the Great Emperor of the Purple Tenuity’s Northern Culmen, the Heavenly Thearch of the Purple Tenuity, the Earthly Thearch Houtu, the Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion Who Saves from Suffering, the Eastern Flowery Lordly Minister Lord Wood and Azure Lad Dao Lord, the Golden Mother of the Nine Numina and Jade Tortoise Terrace, the Nine Heavenly Thearchs, the Five Elderly Heavenly Lords, the Thirty-Two Heavenly Thearchs, the Lords of the Sun, Moon, and Stars, the Four Holy Lords of the Northern Culmen, the Five Masters of the Numinous Treasure, the Grand Immortal Historian of the Nine Provinces and Highly Illustrious Great Envoy True Lord, the True Lord of the Left Palace of the Great Ultimate Who Responds with Empathy and Assists with Sincerity, and the Highest Perfected and Supreme Sages of the Three Caverns, Four Supplements, and Registers of the Dharma.

We reverently beseech Your Celestial Inspection and humbly record our foolish sincerity.

We have heard that as creation divides its forms, Heaven and Earth establish their positions. In the manifest, they give birth to humans and creatures; in the hidden, there are ghosts and spirits. Neither death nor life escapes the wheel of rebirth, and karmic retribution determines ascent or descent. Thus, banishment and service are assigned to the three evil destinies, while obscurity and submersion are divided among the six paths. Some endure kalpas without pardon; others accumulate years without release. The long night stretches endlessly, and the nether regions remain boundlessly remote. Were it not for the boundless grace of the August Heavenly Thearch, how could the hidden spirits receive even the slightest relief?

Your servant, unworthy and shallow, has presumptuously joined the ranks of the numinous. Rashly assuming the duties of ritual and carelessly overseeing the canonical teachings, I now act on behalf of the Ritual Officer So-and-so and their company, who have completed the rites according to the liturgical protocols and poured forth their sincerity. We pray for the equal repose of those in the abyssal chasms and implore the deliverance of all hidden souls.

We have previously submitted our petition and, by Your mercy, have been graciously granted assent. Thus, we have prepared the altar with solemnity and now seek to universally perform the refinement and transformation. Yet the nurturing of the myriad beings and the shaping of all life are the work of Heaven alone, not the strength of mortals. Nevertheless, the establishment of liturgical teachings must prioritize salvation and deliverance. Without the compassion of the Mysterious Creation, how could the hidden souls attain liberation?

We humbly pray that the grace of the Dao may broadly encompass all, that the work of Heaven may universally show mercy, and that You deign to issue a decree to the Palace of the Eastern Flowery Lordly Minister, the Western Numinous Tortoise Terrace, the Cinnabar Heaven World of the South, the Vermilion Mound Fire Bureau, the Southern Prosperity Upper Palace, the Palaces of the Sun and Moon, and all places where refinement and deliverance are to be conducted. May You swiftly command their response and immediately grant Your enactment.

Descend the divine radiance of Metal and Wood, bestow the true darkness of Heaven and Earth. Sweep away the shadows of the netherworld, restore and rectify the hun and po souls. May the myriad kinds and four births all receive the blessings of generation and transformation. May the three evil destinies and six paths all depart from the realm of obscurity and darkness.

Your servant respectfully follows the liturgical protocols and awaits the response of Heaven’s grace. With awe and trepidation, I bow my head and knock my forehead to the ground.

We reverently submit these words.

The True Summoning Talisman for Descent is burned. Taking our seats, we summon the generals and functionaries.

The original Numinous Treasure petition for the deliverance of the departed souls:
*"The wondrous foremost of the highest rank, ten cycles of deliverance for humanity.
Within it is the spirit who delivers people from death,
Within it is the Lord of Longevity of the Southern Culmen,
Within it is the Great Spirit Sima who delivers the world,
Within it is the Benevolent Elder Han Jun,
Within it are the Registrars of Life and Destiny of the Southern Upper Realm,
The revered spirits who extend life, increase destiny, and deliver from calamity,
Who restore bones and raise the dead, delivering boundless multitudes."*

Today, for this refinement and deliverance, the various heavens draw near, inclining their light and turning their chariots to oversee the deliverance of the living. The chancellors of the various heavens, the Southern Prosperity Upper Palace, the Registrar Han, the Inspector of Life, and the great spirits who hold the registers and grasp the records all arrive before the Emperor. According to those who ought to be delivered, the heavens are strictly examined.

The August Heavenly Thearch has issued a command; all spirits heed it.

We reverently summon the Cinnabar Heaven World of the South, the Vermilion Mound Fire Bureau, the Southern Prosperity Upper Palace, the Perfected of Refinement and Deliverance, the Great Spirits of Refinement and Deliverance, the True Lord of Wood Palace who governs the generative qi of Yang and holds the numinous essence, the Flame Radiance Lad and Cinnabar Rosy Cloud Jade Maiden of the Sun Palace, the immortals of the Sun Palace, the Jade Lads and Jade Maidens of the Fire Bureau, the Fire Bell Lads, the officials, generals, and functionaries of the Fire Refinement, the True Lord of Metal Palace who governs the correct qi of Yin and holds the numinous essence, the Round Radiance Lad and Scattered Splendor Jade Maiden of the Moon Palace, the immortals of the Moon Palace, the Jade Lads and Jade Maidens of the Water Bureau, the officials, generals, and functionaries of the Water Refinement, the holy hosts who refine hun souls and deliver po souls, the officials and attendants of the Numinous Treasure, and all mighty numina. Hasten to descend to this altar site and receive the talisman to carry out the decree.

We visualize the generals and functionaries descending. Next, we recite the true names of the Five Thearchs.

*"Gongdu completes at Wu, Qiejiao guards You,
Xingsheng turns at Zi, Kehanming at Mao,
Duli moves the central finger to the center, Gongdu gathers the souls and captures them."*

The qi of the South—make the mudra, blow, and receive the refinement of the departed souls.

We recite again:
*"Burn the true writ.
Hongxing arrives at Mao, Heihei swiftly joins Ziwen,
Mozhen plans at You, Walaxiushou completes at Wu,
The Numinous Treasure writ of the myriad things at the central finger,
Xili unites and penetrates.
The Orthodox Unity accomplishes the Dharma, wisdom benefits the true.
Take the post-haste command to capture."*

Take the qi of the five directions and five colors from the right. The attending functionaries of all registers, riding the true qi of the five colors, float through the void to arrive. Each binds and refines the departed souls, summoning and gathering their spirit-souls, clarifying their nature and consciousness to undergo refinement.

From this point until the "True Writs of the Five Sprouts," all follows the same ritual procedure as the standard offering. No further repetition is made here.

Raise the banner from the pool and proceed to stand upright at the center of the altar. The High Master declares:

"Those who have arrived at the altar are to receive deliverance—the beings of the Three Wicked Paths, the Ten Classes, the Five Destinies, and the Four Modes of Birth. Long entangled in the snares of the world, they have long obscured true cultivation. Their ninefold qi has no return, their five phases are scattered and lost. Their three hun-souls suffer punishment, drifting through ten thousand kalpas. Without the aid of good causes, they cannot restore the principle of life.

As officiant, I now follow the canonical forms to invoke the true numina. Embodying the creative power of Heaven and Earth, adhering to the harmonizing numbers of yin and yang, I pair water and fire, wash and refine form and spirit. I draw down the essence of the Two Luminaries, conjoin the vital balance of the five phases. Roots are established to receive the ancestors; from the dark depths, essence is born. In the profound and obscure, the true gathers; in the vague and indistinct, forms appear.

For all things must end and then begin anew; principles become clear only through transformation. Ghosts return to become humans, bodies undergo immortal transfiguration. Having already reported this to the Nine Heavens’ Supreme Thearch, I now beseech the bestowal of auspicious blessings and the recording of their original spirit-souls. May the true qi be conferred upon the nine barriers, and the fetal perfection be completed in ten months. May they again draw upon the primordial chaos and once more behold the light.

With reverence, I invoke the primordial qi of the Imperial True Embryonic Destiny—the Primordial Unity of the Yellow Pervasion—wrapping the embryo in its original binding, enabling the embryo’s source to flow freely and bring forth life.

Burn the first talisman and intone the first chapter.

These nine chapters are performed by the High Master and recited by the Daoist assembly, following the same procedure as the standard offering. No further repetition is made here.

Proclaim the precepts."

After the refinement and deliverance, recite the incantation until the "Carefree" passage, then perform the Shangqing mudra to completion. Proceed to read the petition aloud.

We humbly observe that the Great Dao shines resplendently, present in all without exception. Even in matters great and small, there exists a proper principle that cannot be neglected. Heaven and Earth, ghosts and spirits—none can depart from the Great Dao or transgress its proper principle.

The sun and moon radiate brilliance, the stars revolve in splendor; cold and heat follow their constant cycles, the seasons shift with their appointed signs. Nourished by rain and dew, stirred by wind and thunder, the Dao nurtures the myriad things without claiming merit, harmonizes the two qi without error. Its revolutions never cease—this is the Dao of Heaven, the proper principle of Heaven, and thus it is called Heaven.

The towering majesty of mountains and hills, the vast depths of rivers and seas, the fragrant flourishing of grasses and trees, the sowing and cultivation of grains—all bear the myriad things in perfect stillness, establishing the six directions without limit. This is the Dao of Earth, the proper principle of Earth, and thus it is called Earth.

It modulates the somber and luminous forces of yin and yang, aiding the work of creation. It brings misfortune to the excessive and blessings to the virtuous, abhors evil and harms the overreaching. Upright and impartial, perceptive yet concealed, its transformations are unfathomable, its adaptability boundless—this is the Dao of spirits, the proper principle of spirits, and thus it is called spirit.

Endowed with the qi of Heaven and Earth, harmonized by yin and yang, though the body is formed from illusory and fleeting elements, the essence is bestowed with clarity and awareness. As a ruler, one acts on Heaven’s behalf, protecting the people and reigning with virtue, spreading beneficence to all living beings, extending grace through the ages—thus fulfilling the Dao of the sovereign and establishing a grand foundation. As a minister, one is loyal; as a child, filial. Among the common people, one cultivates constancy, practices trust and righteousness, establishes virtue, and embraces kindness. Whether noble or base, rich or poor, all have their destined lot; in life and death, honor and disgrace, one does not alter the original heart—this is the Dao of humanity, the proper principle of humanity, and thus it is called human.

The Dao cannot be departed from even for a moment. Heaven and Earth are formed by following the Dao, and thus they endure forever, their end unknowable. As for ghosts and spirits, they are divided into the upright and the perverse, with distinctions of ascent and descent. As for human cultivation, habits, and the retribution of fortune and misfortune, all take shape according to their kind and cannot be generalized. Yet if even Heaven and Earth cannot depart from the Great Dao or transgress its proper principle, how much less can humans—and how much less ghosts and spirits?

As for the myriad things, their endowment of qi is impure, and their forms may differ. Some become beasts, some birds and insects; some can cry out yet lack awareness, possessing nature but little wisdom—these cannot be held accountable to the Dao or corrected by principle. Humans, the most spiritually endowed of all things, are thus the noblest of Heaven and Earth’s creations.

Thus, while alive, one is human, yet life cannot be without end; upon death, one becomes a ghost. If the original nature does not perish, when yin reaches its extreme, yang is born—thus ghosts return to being human, and the doctrine of cyclic rebirth arises. The Great Dao shines resplendently, its proper principle never obscured—what separation exists between Heaven and Earth? What obscurity between beings? What constraint upon ghosts and spirits? From Heaven above to Earth below, boundless and infinite, all is encompassed within this.

Now, in performing purification rites and practicing the Dao, burning incense and lighting lamps, entreating the true spirits, repenting transgressions, summoning the wandering souls, and delivering the spirits—these are the teachings bequeathed by the Supreme Thearch, the exalted perfected, and the sagely masters of old, established to benefit both the living and the departed, to instruct future generations, and to awaken those lost in delusion.

Today, the officiant, turning toward truth and embracing the Dao, has prepared offerings and arranged the rites, wishing to aid both the living and the dead. Having received the petition and made the announcements, I dare not deceive my heart or violate the established forms. The proclamations have been made in full, and the merit is complete.

Thus, we universally summon all within the six directions, all kingdoms, the six paths and three realms, the four births and ten thousand kinds—whether ordinary or sacred, all wandering souls. Bathed and purified, they attend the true rites, hear the scriptures, and partake of the offerings. Their spirits are gathered, their transgressions repented and cleansed, and all good affinities have been fulfilled. Bonds are released, sins dissolved. The steps to deliverance and the path to ascension lie within oneself, not in others; within, not without. When the original nature is fully awakened and all distractions dispelled, the spirit will not sink—what need is there for other schemes?

Moreover, we hope that all gathered at this altar—with the wise instructing the benighted, the awakened rescuing the deluded—will exhort and transform one another, deeply reflecting and reforming. May the divine spirits above also deign to listen: do not turn from the Great Dao, do not transgress its proper principle. Do not wantonly wield power and fortune, do not oppress living beings, do not mingle with demonic forces, do not presume to manifest as omens or specters. Do not seek bloody sacrifices, do not traffic with the living, do not display forms and apparitions, do not obstruct or encroach upon the royal domain. Assist Heaven and aid transformation, bringing peace to the times and protecting the people. Thus, you will ascend step by step, attaining ever higher ranks.

Those who were once human but are now ghosts—if in life you were noble and prosperous, do not cling to glory and splendor. If in life you were wealthy, do not grasp at riches. If in life you were poor and lowly, do not resent or fear hardship. If in life you harbored grudges, do not conceal or nurse resentment. Whether you pursued the true path without success or studied the teachings of the Buddha without attainment, now is the time to plan anew—do not tread the old paths.

Artisans, laborers, scholars, farmers, merchants—all the multitudes of the five clans and ten thousand kinds, of high and low estate, wise and foolish—none escape the decay of the body and the emptiness of worldly affairs. You must relinquish all emotional attachments and cease your delusions. Only those who have lost virtue and accumulated transgressions, who have transgressed principle and amassed faults, must deeply repent and sternly reflect.

This does not mean discarding all past affairs while still clinging to them here—rather, it is to reflect on past transgressions and misguided thoughts, avoid repeating the same mistakes, take them as warnings for the future, and make plans for rebirth. How could one, having already lost virtue and transgressed principle in life, repeat such errors after returning to the shades?

Thus, one should not linger to haunt the living, nor entangle and harm kinfolk. One must not seek vengeance for old grudges, nor cling to former dwellings. One should not act on mere echoes or shadows, nor crave sacrificial offerings—all these bring no benefit to the departed soul, but only serve as burdens to transcendence.

For those who met violent ends—whether through misfortune, untimely death, death in childbirth, or dismemberment; whether decapitated, maimed, deaf, blind, or afflicted with festering wounds—all who perished with injuries or in impurity, their forms incomplete: know this—humans take shape through essence and blood, their bodies nourished by the five grains, while the single spirit-nature arises from emptiness. When life ends, blood putrefies and flesh decays; the material form returns to earth. As for the one nature, how could it be harmed? It has never been defiled. Therefore, one need not dwell on the moment of death, nor fixate on the form of one’s final moments. Whether ghost or human, to awaken to this truth is to grasp the right principle. The blades once clenched in the teeth and the ropes once bound around the neck are now gone. The filth and stench of the past are now purified. Between heaven and earth, wherever one goes, one is transcendent—this fruit lies within oneself, not in others.

All beings, whether sacred or profane, once they understand that the Great Dao is not distant and the right principle is clear and open, will find that heaven does not abandon them, nor does earth confine them. As spirits, they may transform; as ghosts, they need not sink into darkness. If reborn as humans, they will surely rise to greatness. Grudges and enmities, though unresolved, will dissolve of themselves. The hun and po, the spirit and essence, though not forcibly restored, will recover naturally. From this, we see that heaven’s halls are surely attainable, while hell will never again be seen. Should one return to the human world, the right principle will take root in the original heart, and loyalty and filial piety will arise from innate nature. Whether in darkness or in light, one will forever abide with the Dao.

Thus, take refuge in the Three Treasures, penetrate to the root and source. Let all—saints and ghosts, gods and spirits—listen carefully.

**First Refuge: The Supreme Treasure of the Dao**
The Treasure of the Dao is formless and nameless, existing before heaven and earth. It gestates in Kan and Li, initiates Qian and Kun, enduring in boundless vastness, profound and unfathomable. At times, it manifests teachings with the times; at others, it governs the ages to reveal its radiance. Though all beings use it daily, they know it not; its grace flows endlessly through ten thousand kalpas. Between heaven and earth, all take refuge in it.
*Praise to the Treasure of the Dao*

**Second Refuge: The Supreme Treasure of the Scriptures**
The Treasure of the Scriptures comprises the Nine Pure True Classics and the Three Caverns’ sacred texts, their eight corners radiating brilliance, their five sections lush with wisdom. Some are formed by the flight of wondrous qi through the void, others penned by sages into chapters. Through countless kalpas, they broadly spread transformations; the thirty-six divisions nurture all beings. From ancient times to the present, they bestow blessings upon the manifest and hidden alike. Between heaven and earth, all take refuge in them.
*Praise to the Treasure of the Scriptures*

**Third Refuge: The Supreme Treasure of the Masters**
The Treasure of the Masters is the Lord of Teachings within the Mysterious, the lineage masters of the Three Caverns. They transmit registers, bestow scriptures, propagate precepts, and expound the Dharma, dividing their forms to practice the Dao and save the world through their writings. They serve as models for ten thousand generations and exemplars for the ten directions. They guide later learners, lead the lost back to the path, sometimes reflecting light in the void, sometimes leaving their forms beyond appearances. Between heaven and earth, all take refuge in them.
*Praise to the Treasure of the Masters*

Having thus taken refuge in the Three Treasures and penetrated to the root and source, what distinction remains between sacred and profane? The principle is one. Though promotion and rebirth may follow their own timing, and one may temporarily dwell in the shades, one must always follow the right principle. The Ten Precepts for Ghosts and Spirits should first be received and upheld. When one later re-enters the human realm and takes form in the yang world, one should take loyalty and filial piety as the foundation, conduct oneself with integrity and caution, and next, strictly observe the Nine True Precepts. Let all beings, sacred and profane, heed these precepts.

Wisdom gives rise to the root of precepts; the true Dao takes precepts as its master. Through them, the Three Treasures flourish, bestowed by exalted immortals. Riding this deathless vessel, swiftly cross the great expanse. At this moment of preaching the precepts, all the heavens bow their heads.

**The Ten Precepts for Ghosts and Spirits**
**First Precept:** Do not appear at improper times, rush into the living, recklessly enter the human world, or collude to create disturbances, causing people to dream in confusion.
*All respond:* May the yin spirits wholeheartedly receive deliverance.

**Second Precept:** Do not associate with external demons or guest spirits, demand food and drink, throw sand or hurl tiles, or frighten the living.

**Third Precept:** Do not lead epidemics into realms, violently harm good people, cause illness, or implicate kinfolk.

**Fourth Precept:** Do not guard royal lands to hinder cultivation, forcibly seize forests, trees, flowers, or fruits, or conceal heavenly taxes.

**Fifth Precept:** Do not stir the fire spirits of the four directions to burn people’s homes, damage their property, or ruin their families.

**Sixth Precept:** Do not demand blood sacrifices, deepening karmic obstacles, perpetuating retribution in the cycle of rebirth without end.

**Seventh Precept:** Do not send various demons, crows, magpies, foxes, dogs, or rats to startle and frighten the living.

**Eighth Precept:** Do not harm people’s livestock; in future lives, you will forever sink into the dark yin.

**Ninth Precept:** Do not recklessly ride horses or chariots, obstructing the living’s travels, causing disasters, or seeking private gain.

**Tenth Precept:** Do not bring misfortune upon people, accept bribes to act, cause illness, pursue souls, or lead people into delusion.

**Chorus:** May the hidden spirits, with one heart, receive deliverance.

**Nine Wondrous Precepts of the True:**
**First Precept:** Reverence and deference, filial piety and care for parents—this is called the Precept of the Initial Truth.
**Chorus:** May the hidden spirits, with one heart, listen and receive.

**Second Precept:** Diligence and devotion, loyalty to one’s lord—this is called the Precept of Mindful Truth.

**Third Precept:** Do not kill; with compassion, save all beings—this is called the Precept of Upholding Truth.

**Fourth Precept:** Do not commit adultery; keep the body upright in all things—this is called the Precept of Guarding Truth.

**Fifth Precept:** Do not steal; extend righteousness and diminish the self—this is called the Precept of Preserving Truth.

**Sixth Precept:** Do not rage; let not fury harm others—this is called the Precept of Cultivating Truth.

**Seventh Precept:** Do not deceive; let not flattery and treachery harm the good—this is called the Precept of Perfecting Truth.

**Eighth Precept:** Do not be arrogant; let not pride neglect the Supreme Truth—this is called the Precept of Attaining Truth.

**Ninth Precept:** Do not waver; uphold the precepts with single-minded devotion—this is called the Precept of Ascending Truth.

**Recitation of the Precepts:**
The precepts just expounded—may they be reverently received.
In heaven and on earth, in the hidden realm and the world of the living,
let the heart remain unconfused, let every thought be without transgression.

Yet the original nature is inherently pure and luminous,
the good heart and virtuous intent arise naturally.
Why fear the rise and fall of existence?
Why rely on precepts and disciplines?

Only because, through habit, one sinks into evil destinies,
drifts into deviant paths,
and even precepts cannot then be applied.
Awaken to the root of the original self,
realize the nature of true reality—
as a ghost, one will neither sink nor be deluded;
as a human, one will know no misfortune nor fault.
Every action, every deed, is none other than the great Dao;
every thought, every consideration, does not stray from right principle.
At this stage, one may be without precepts yet naturally uphold them.

However, in the days of the hidden realm,
one must not cling to worldly things:
fame and fortune, wealth and nobility,
grand mansions and lofty towers,
silken allure and brocade finery,
gold, pearls, jade, and precious stones,
rare delicacies and exotic flavors,
stately canopies and towering carriages,
the pleasures of music and beauty,
the joys of horses and chariots,
the comforts of service and sustenance,
the resources of enjoyment,
the affections of family,
the love of wives and children—
even hunger that craves food,
cold that seeks clothing,
gains that sustain life,
losses that bring death—
these are truly indispensable,
yet none are free from the burdens of the body,
the affairs of the world, which are thus.

Since the body cannot endure forever,
none of these can long remain.
One should know that this body cannot be detained,
all things will turn to emptiness.
Life and death follow separate paths;
attachment is of no benefit—
is this not the right principle of heaven and earth,
as it ought to be?

Moreover, after death,
the form vanishes into boundless void.
The food of the yang world cannot be eaten,
the clothing of the human realm cannot be worn.
Hunger and cold—how can they burden one?

Thus the *Daodejing* says:
*"My greatest affliction is that I have a body.
If I had no body, what affliction would remain?"*
The principle is perfectly clear.

Just because attachments and affections are not forgotten,
worldly affairs linger in the mind,
and one clings to sacrifices and offerings,
longing for kin and loved ones—
having strayed from the path of delusion and fixation,
hunger and thirst arise in thought.

All the solemn offerings presented above,
the reverent arrangements of grain and feasts—
how could these defile the spirits and gods?
They serve only to fulfill the yearnings of those not yet fully awakened,
to dissolve their fixations and delusions.
From this moment onward, having thoroughly perceived this principle:
*"Since there is no body, what need is there for food and drink?"*

Yet the rites of ancestral veneration,
the sincerity of sacrificial prayers,
demonstrate that human sentiment does not forget its roots.
Once the luminous nature is realized,
what need remains for offerings?

Whether as ghost or human,
in darkness or in light,
unattached to the myriad conditions,
one attains perfect freedom—
how could there still be divisions of the six paths,
the toils of the three realms?
Even those of feather, fur, scale, and shell,
birds, beasts, insects, and fish,
all return to their original root,
abandoning their divergent destinies,
forever attaining the joy of rebirth,
all bathing in boundless bliss.

There are the *Tai Shang Chang Sheng Ling Fu* (Numinous Talismans of Supreme Longevity),
the *Sheng Tian Bao Lu* (Precious Registers of Ascension to Heaven),
the sacred scriptures and precious decrees,
the merit certificates—
these serve as credentials for ascension.
With reverence, they are proclaimed and transmitted.

Having read the talismans, announced the documents, and conveyed the registers,
the transmission of talismans and conferral of deliverance are complete.
The virtuous work accomplished,
each departs from the altar,
all ascending the path of liberation,
entering the realm of purity and emptiness.
Proceed forward without delay.

All saints and mortals, take care.
The solitary souls and yin spirits,
now refined and perfected,
scatter and ascend like soaring clouds.

Rising, they declare:
*"The burdens of the mortal body are hard to shed,
but in death, without form, affairs are no more.
Having grasped this truth at last,
the true nature shines, revealing heaven’s mystery."*

The High Priest descends from the seat,
the announcer escorts the souls across the bridge.

Thus we invoke the majestic Dao,
the vast and wondrous power,
opening the gate of expedient means,
illuminating the path of ascension.
Boundless grace descends,
enveloping the realms of darkness.
Mysterious blessings pervade,
reaching every yin abode.
The three realms cease their toil,
the six paths are reborn anew.

Today, in reverence, we initiate the sacred rites,
cultivating blessings through the fast,
dedicating all merit to the wandering souls,
offering deliverance to the netherworld.
All classes of ghosts and spirits,
the souls of the nine provinces,
having attended the audience with the True,
heard the Dao and the scriptures,
received the incantations and the sacred banquet,
transmitted the wondrous precepts,
expounded the profound texts,
and recited the numinous scriptures—
the virtuous work thus established is complete.

All are released from their karmic bonds,
their dark records erased,
all sins absolved,
their spirits unobscured.
Each receives the merit of the fast and departs in goodness,
all ascending to the pure realms, transcending rebirth.

The *Faqiao* (Dharma Bridge) of the Greatly Merciful Heavenly Worthy is crossed.
The offerings are burned.
The *San Qing* hymns are chanted,
and the merit is dedicated.

Sincerity moves heaven;
the devotion of the fast has ascended to the Three Realms.
The teachings save all beings;
the grace of the Dao descends to the Nine Springs.
Far and near receive blessings,
the manifest and the hidden rejoice together.

Today, the officiant has performed the rites with utmost reverence,
establishing the fast to bless the sovereign and kin,
universally aiding the living and the dead.
May all virtuous fruits be perfectly fulfilled.

We humbly pray that the souls of the departed,
the nine ancestral spirits,
the lingering souls of the ten directions,
the wandering souls of all lands,
the beings of the six paths and three realms,
the myriad forms of the four births—
all receive deliverance,
emerging from the shadows of yin.
Their forms purified, their bodies cleansed,
they roam freely beyond the Three Realms.
Their minds enlightened, their natures revealed,
they ascend to pay homage in the Ten Heavens.
All sentient beings share in this grace,
all creatures bathe in this numinous bliss.
Officials and kin alike receive favor,
all rejoicing in this boundless fortune.

For this supreme good cause,
we invoke the Great Sage, the Primordial Heavenly Worthy of the Origin,
the Supreme Dao Lord,
the Supreme Lord Lao,
the Heavenly Worthies of the Numinous Treasure in the Ten Directions,
and their inconceivable merit and virtue.

We reflect deeply upon the various fasts of the *Huang Lu*:
their fundamental purpose is deliverance.
In the manifest realm, they pray for the sovereign’s peace and the well-being of all beings.
In the hidden realm, they rescue ghosts and deliver souls,
universally aiding all classes.
Thus, the merit is made complete.

Whether to ascend and bless ancestral spirits,
granting the departed their reward,
or to dispel calamities and disasters,
bringing blessings to the living—
if one’s concern is solely for oneself,
lacking the heart to universally deliver,
then the fast is insufficient.

Thus, the universal feeding of the hungry ghosts
must be performed with utmost sincerity.

In the ancient rites of Qi,
the altar was established the night before,
the audience with the True was held,
repentance and thanksgiving were offered,
lamps were lit, documents were cast,
the fast was concluded, and the altar was dispersed—
these were the practices of old,
as recorded in Master Guangcheng’s *Huang Lu Zhai Ke*,
not to be altered by later generations.

As for the universal summoning of the solitary souls of the six paths and three realms,
in recent times, expanded texts have appeared,
along with rituals for purification,
incantations for feeding,
and proclamations.
Alas, their compilers failed to examine them carefully,
often resulting in contradictions with principle.

For instance, in the transmitted *Rites of the Six Paths*,
when addressing the hell realm, it speaks of:
*"Molten copper poured into mouths,
sharp saws severing bodies,
skin and flesh scorched and rotting..."*
Such vulgarity is extreme.
Whether such things exist or not cannot be certain—
why must they be described in such detail?

Elsewhere, there are texts for the twenty-five classes of solitary souls,
with two or three versions,
each riddled with contradictions.
For example, in summoning the spirits of courtesans and actors,
it speaks of:
*"Wine staining fragrant cheeks,
lotus faces ever fresh..."*
How could such words be respectfully proclaimed before spirits and gods?

As for the souls of miscellaneous classes,
their faults are forcefully exposed,
their shortcomings harshly criticized—
all for the sake of crafting a text,
approaching the realm of jest.
To address them thus,
even a practitioner would disdain it,
let alone the spirits and gods.

The universal deliverance feast is the greatest affair of the fast.
One should clearly expound the great principles,
awaken their good hearts,
inspiring the spirits to turn toward goodness and distance themselves from sin.
Would there be none who awaken?
Yet instead of summoning them to come,
one indulges in slander and abuse,
spouting insults without restraint—
this is truly unacceptable.

In recent times, Lü Yun compiled the *Huang Lu Li Cheng Yi*,
intended as a one-day-and-night ritual.

Recently at the Tianqing Abbey in Lin’an Prefecture, I observed that many of the miscellaneous ritual texts in use were drawn from vulgar sources. For instance, in the section for delivering orphaned souls, one finds such lines as: *"Upon the vast expanse of the River of Love, snow-white waves float in the void; within the fathomless Sea of Desire, silver ripples overflow the eye."* Now, the scriptures speak of being *"blown by the currents of the Sea of Desire, adrift upon the waves of the River of Love"*—for human love and desire know no bounds, as deep and endless as rivers and seas, flowing with desire, drifting with love, like waters that never cease. The principle is quite clear. Yet to speak of *"upon the River of Love"* implies that the river has a fixed location and even banks. As for phrases like *"snow-white waves"* and *"silver ripples,"* they are even more excessive. To expound scripture in such a manner—would this not mislead the spirits of the unseen realm?

In recent times, miscellaneous ritual texts have largely followed this pattern. Moreover, when universally summoning spirits and gods without distinction of rank, how can one be certain there are no lofty and enlightened souls among them? With such absurd and reckless wording, one would surely invite mockery from the spirits and gods.

Thus, I have newly composed texts for the Six Paths, twenty-five categories of summons for orphaned souls, the *Muyu* Ritual, and various *baiwen* petitions—not presuming them to be perfect, but rather to ensure that the language is plain and accessible, the verses readable, and the content consistently aligned with the great principles, roughly appropriate to the circumstances. This avoids the pitfalls of harsh criticism, abuse, and disrespect toward the unseen realm.

As for transmitting talismans and conferring precepts, few of the existing ritual texts are truly proper. During the Jianzhong Jingguo era of the Song Dynasty, a scholar named Xin Ze, acting on behalf of the Daoist Chen Cheng, edited an ancient version of the *Teachings and Admonitions for Spirits and Gods Ritual*. Its style was pure and correct, though the text was rather lengthy. After the *Three Refuges*, it included recitations of the *Sutra of Salvation from Suffering* and the *Sutra of Purity*, concluding with a final admonition and dispatch based entirely on the meaning of these two scriptures. In ancient times, when no refinement and deliverance (*liandu*) was performed, the ritual could be simplified. However, after the *liandu* rites—which often extend late into the night—it becomes difficult to recite lengthy petitions. Furthermore, the original text included admonitions for scholar-officials, Buddhist monks, and Daoist priests, phrased with blunt directness. People of old, being simple and sincere, did not take offense, but today, such words would provoke anger in many. Yet I dare not alter the structure of the ancient text, so I have composed a separate *Transmission of Precepts Ritual* to follow the *liandu*, thereby forming a complete system.

My humble efforts have resulted in a work lacking in literary elegance or ornate beauty. Yet what can be said of it is this: it does not betray the Dao or disrupt the ritual order, nor does it transgress norms or obscure principles. I make no claim to rival the ancients even in the slightest, but compared to the vulgar and coarse language in common use, it is at least more measured and coherent, avoiding bizarre or obscure phrasing to facilitate recitation at the altar.

Beyond the ancient ritual texts for fasts, I have thoroughly revised all miscellaneous ritual manuals from beginning to end, ensuring nothing is omitted. However, rituals such as the *Children’s Rite*, the *Ten Kings Ritual*, and those involving inconceivable merits have no precedent in antiquity. Moreover, their formats are flawed, their language crude and shallow, and their principles unsound—thus, they are unworthy of inclusion in the ritual canon and should not be incorporated into practice.

All revisions adhere to ancient models in phrasing and intent, carefully reworking the ritual texts without daring to contravene the teachings of the masters. If one practices this ancient method, employs these texts, and recites these manuals, the ritual will maintain coherence from beginning to end, properly revering the Supreme Emperor and moving the spirits and gods—leaving one’s heart free of shame. If, however, one abandons this method, transfers these texts elsewhere, or conceals their origins while using their words, the result will neither suit the circumstances nor preserve their original intent.

Additionally, in the old rite for sending souls across the bridge, fish were kept in water beneath a pavilion, symbolizing the transformation of fish into dragons and the transmission of talismanic commands. The pavilion’s four gates each bore a gatha, recited before sending the souls across. However, ancient Daoist ritual codes contain no precedent for reciting gathas. Moreover, the gathas in recent use are overly simplistic. Since the ritual already employs a straw dragon to fulfill the talismanic transmission, the fish are unnecessary and thus omitted from the revised manual.

May future generations of accomplished masters and noble scholars who encounter this work be moved to refine its redundancies, amend its omissions, and perfect its flaws—this is my deepest hope.

Here ends the forty-fourth scroll of the *Great Rites of the Supreme Purity and Numinous Treasure*.
